HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MIRCROSOFT: THE APPEAL;
After a Rout, Still Fighting

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
With his final order yesterday in the Microsoft antitrust case, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said yes to the government one more time. He has agreed with the government, almost without qualification, on the facts of the case, on the law and now on the harsh remedy of splitting the company in two.
In Judge Jackson's Federal District Court, the result has been not just a defeat for Microsoft but a rout, not a closely fought legal contest but a judicial ratification of the government's case. 
 Yet the two-year-old case is far from over. And with a year or two of appeals ahead, the chances of Microsoft's ever being broken up are uncertain. Microsoft will try to reverse every element in Judge Jackson's ruling that the company is a monopoly that has repeatedly violated the nation's antitrust laws, stifling software competition and innovation.
The odds against Microsoft's winning outright on appeal are extremely high, according to antitrust experts. But they say that there are legally vulnerable points in the judge's ruling that if reversed on appeal might well enable the company to avoid the drastic sanction Judge Jackson has now endorsed.
"Microsoft is going to try to whittle away at the judge's ruling on appeal," said Andrew I. Gavil, professor at the Howard University law school. "And once you get an incremental erosion of the case, you erode the power of the argument for a breakup as well."
In his order yesterday, Judge Jackson acknowledged that the federal appeals court or the Supreme Court, or both, might disagree with some of his work. Two weeks ago, he surprised both sides in the case and most legal experts when he abruptly ended the court proceedings without a further round of hearings on the government's plan to split Microsoft in two and require a series of curbs on its business conduct.
In his order, Judge Jackson explained that he had moved quickly because, if his findings or legal conclusions are overruled, a higher court might decide on its own remedies or send the case back to him.
After noting that Microsoft contends it will be vindicated on appeal, he wrote: "The court is well aware that there is a substantial body of public opinion, some of it rational, that holds to a similar view. It is time to put that assertion to the test."
So Judge Jackson chose this approach as a way to speed along a case of national economic importance. The alternative, he decided, would be to risk going through two time-consuming sets of hearings on remedies -- one based on his legal ruling and one based on a case perhaps scaled back on appeal.
Still, some antitrust experts say that simply accepting the remedies plan from the Justice Department and states suing Microsoft could prove to be a mistake.
"If he's assuming that this case is probably coming back to him anyway, I think that is a safe assumption," said William Kovacic, a professor at the George Washington University law school. "But the danger of his approach is that it increases the chances it will come back to him."
Microsoft's prime target on appeal, antitrust experts say, will be the judge's ruling that it illegally tied its Internet browser to its monopoly product, the Windows operating system, which handles the basic operations on 85 percent of all PC's.
To Microsoft, the tying charge is the heart of the case. If that ruling is upheld on appeal, Microsoft sees a threat to its corporate way of life -- its ability to add new software features to its operating system, as it has repeatedly over the years.
In several rounds of settlement talks with the government, Microsoft was willing to change some of its practices, but it stood firm on not allowing any tampering with Windows or letting personal computer makers pick and choose from an ala carte menu of Windows features.
To Microsoft, this stance is not arrogance or hubris -- or an antitrust violation, for that matter -- but a stand of principle.
"This case, in our view, is about whether we are free to improve our products and whether we can protect the integrity of our most important product, Windows," said William Neukom, senior vice president and general counsel of Microsoft.
Microsoft has argued that Web browsing software should not be considered as a separate product but as a feature in the ever-evolving Windows operating system.
The government contended, and Judge Jackson ruled, that Microsoft had illegally tied its Internet browser, a separate product, to Windows to thwart competition and illegally protect its monopoly. To accept Microsoft's argument, the government said, would amount to granting the dominant software maker an exemption from broad swaths of the nation's antitrust laws.
But antitrust experts note that product-tying charges are tricky, especially when dealing with software, in which the products are rendered in the 1's and 0's of programming code and product boundaries often blur. And a federal appeals court in June 1998 sided with Microsoft in a separate but related case. That court said Microsoft had the right to fold a browser into its operating system as long as it could make a "plausible claim" of consumer benefit.
In addition to the tying charge, Microsoft, antitrust experts say, stands a good chance of getting a reversal on the court's finding that Microsoft made an illegal offer to Netscape Communications to divide the browser market between them. The collusion offer, Judge Jackson ruled, was made during a meeting between executives of Microsoft and Netscape, the commercial pioneer in Internet browsers, in June 1995.
The legal hurdle in attempted collusion cases, antitrust experts say, is fairly high. The crucial case, they say, occurred in 1984 and involved airline executives talking about jointly raising fares in a conversation that was tape-recorded. Whether the meeting notes, e-mail messages and conflicting witness testimony about the Microsoft-Netscape meeting are evidence that reaches the standard of "clearly unequivocal," established in the 1984 case, is open to question, experts say.
Microsoft is also expected to argue that much of the rest of the case -- mainly contracts and practices that the court found to be a "pattern of anticompetitive behavior" -- is merely evidence of a company competing aggressively in a dynamic industry, not of an economic outlaw.
"We think this ruling is very vulnerable on appeal," Mr. Neukom said. "We're in the middle innings of a contest that won't be over for another year or two. And the most critical innings are yet to come."
Yet antitrust experts say that the steepest uphill climb for Microsoft on appeal will be to overturn Judge Jackson's determination that the company engaged in an array of illegal acts to protect its monopoly, wielding its market power like a club to bully industry partners and rivals.
"It's the whole gestalt that is a real problem for Microsoft -- the court's finding that these are bad guys, who repeatedly acted to stifle competition and not for any efficiency reasons," said Richard Steuer, an antitrust specialist and a partner at Kaye Scholer Fierman Hays & Handler. "That is a lot harder for an appeals court to overturn."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Where the Case Goes Next"
In his ruling against Microsoft yesterday, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson stayed his order to break up the company, but not his restrictions on its business practices. Microsoft will seek a stay of the entire ruling while it appeals the overall case.
 
U.S. DISTRICT COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA
 
The Justice Department, with Judge Jackson's encourage-ment, intends to take the case directly to the Supreme Court for review.
 
Microsoft wants the matter to go to the Court of Appeals, which ruled in its favor in a related case two years ago.
 
U.S. SUPREME COURT
If the court takes the case, it is likely to rule by June of next year, the end of its next term.
 
The Supreme Court may decide not to take the case, sending it to a three-judge panel of the Court of Appeals.
 
U.S. COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA
The first question is whether the court will stay Judge Jackson's ruling. If it does, it would be likely to do so quickly.
 
The full appeal could last as long as two years. The court could uphold the verdict, or overturn it in full or in part. Whatever the court decides is likely to be appealed to the Supreme Court.
 
In any event, the case will return to Judge Jackson, either to oversee implementation of the remedy or to amend it according to the higher court's findings.
 
IF THE JUDGE'S RULING IS NOT STAYED -- A long and detailed list of restrictions on the company's conduct will take effect on Sept. 7. Microsoft will also have to file a detailed plan for breaking up the company by Oct. 7.
 
IF APPEAL FAILS -- Microsoft must complete the breakup and begin life as two separate and competing companies within one year of the date of the appeals ruling.
(pg. C10)

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
CAMPAIGN BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by B. Drummond Ayres Jr. (NYT)

 BODY:

THE DEMOCRATS
 
GORE PLANS 'PROSPERITY TOUR'
Vice President Al Gore plans a "progress and prosperity tour" next week in which he will propose protecting Medicare by taking it off-budget, meaning he would remove it from annual budget fights. "It's the next logical step to ensuring our long-term security," said Chris Lehane, Mr. Gore's spokesman. "What Al Gore is going to be doing next week is talking about the choices that we face in terms of continuing economic strength." In contrast to President Clinton's "poverty tour" last year, the vice president's tour is intended to highlight the economic successes of the last eight years -- and by extension associate Mr. Gore with that success. The vice president said tonight at a fund-raiser in Los Angeles, "progress and prosperity ought to be expected in this country." Mr. Gore's fly-around will include several of the crucial battleground states across the Rust Belt, including Ohio and Pennsylvania. Advisers said the tour was part of a long-planned strategy to emphasize the positive and optimistic aspects of Mr. Gore's candidacy. It is to coincide with the release of a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign this week to continue to redefine Mr. Gore's image. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT) 

THE STATES
 
CHALLENGE IN MASSACHUSETTS
Jack E. Robinson, the Republican challenger to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, says reports of his campaign's demise have been greatly exaggerated. It looked unlikely for a while that Mr. Robinson would succeed in gathering the 10,000 signatures of voters he needed by Tuesday to qualify for the race. The Massachusetts secretary of state's office credited him with 10,139 signatures before the deadline passed, so Mr. Robinson, an entrepreneur, is still in the running. But he still faces another major obstacle: overcoming the disclosures about his personal life, including bad relations with women and traffic problems. Carey Goldberg (NYT)
 
THE REPUBLICANS
 
FORD OFFERS BUSH ADVICE
Former President Gerald R. Ford says Gov. George W. Bush should consider picking an abortion-rights advocate as his running mate. Such a choice, he contends, could be the difference between winning and losing a close race. "We need a team that reflects the broadest possible spectrum of the Republican philosophy, which means somebody who is pro-choice, for example, or at least is more so than some Republicans would like," Mr. Ford said Monday in a speech at the National Press Club in Washington. "To me, freedom means nothing if not the freedom to choose," he said. "As Republicans, as conservatives, we regard life as very, very sacred. That's why we believe the individual conscience and the right to choose is a major, major factor in how we should live and how our country should survive." (AP)

HEADLINE: LIVING IN A NUTSHELL;
Living Large In Little Apple

BYLINE: By STEPHEN MIHM 

 BODY:
A LOT of New Yorkers live in small spaces, some smaller than others. My own, for example, measures 250 square feet as the crow walks. Over time, I've become obsessed with making the most of it, getting up at odd hours to stack file cabinets and weed my belongings, even removing doors from hinges. Today, within easy reach, I also have a sofa, a desk, two chairs, three bureaus and an 18-pound cat named Gus, who takes up more than his fair share of the bed.
Suburbanites with toolsheds bigger than my apartment may have good reason to wonder whether New Yorkers like me are a bit crazy. But I'm not alone, as I found out when I went in search of other small-apartment lovers in Manhattan. 
 While financial concerns force many New Yorkers to cling to small quarters, some actually savor living in the human equivalent of a beehive. Those I met could have moved long ago into much more spacious housing outside the city; the average single-family American home, after all, provides 835 square feet of living space a person, up from 477 square feet 30 years ago, according to the United States Census.
The city's housing code certainly doesn't coddle the claustrophobic. Section D26-33.03, adopted in 1967, holds that every apartment dweller is entitled to 80 square feet of so-called livable space -- not much bigger than a king-size bed. Though bathrooms aren't figured in, that's still less than the 94 square feet allotted to well-behaved inmates at Attica. Yet, Manhattan seems destined for compact living, and downsizing here has become almost a trend. Costas Kondylis, a well-known architect of residential buildings, said that in New York in the 1980's "typically, one-bedrooms used to be 750 square feet." He added, "Now on average they are 640, even 625 square feet."
The first stop in my search was the 400-square-foot Greenwich Village apartment of Zabel Meshejian. The sign in the elevator put me in the right mood. "Maximum occupancy 6 people," it read, surely a joke given that it measures less than 2 feet by 2 feet.
Ms. Meshejian works by day as a food stylist, staging photographs for companies like Godiva, Red Lobster and Nabisco. At night, in a galley kitchen, she cooks for herself, drawing from a floor-to-ceiling collection of pots, pans and condiments. "I have spices for any kind of cuisine," Ms. Meshejian said, pointing to wooden cabinets and boxes overflowing with herbs and bottles of oils. "Chinese, Indian, Mexican, Mediterranean. They're all here."
But never mind the challenge of preparing dinner in a closet. It turns out that Ms. Meshejian is also a frustrated gardener, and her apartment seemingly houses more flowerpots than a professional greenhouse. "I started with one plant, and all of a sudden I had hundreds," she said. Tiers of glass shelves in three southern-facing windows catch the afternoon sun, all filled with her favorite miniature plants: euphorbias, haworthias and lithops, kept small and root bound.
Yet, the apartment, shared with a 19-year-old cat named Munchkin, doesn't seem crowded, just cozy. Antique bureaus, wooden boxes and cookbooks line the perimeter of the living room, while odds and ends -- a parasol, some baskets, family photographs -- take up the rest of the wall space. Everything has a place, even Munchkin, who spends his days dozing in a basket.
"I have this recurring dream that I go through my closet and discover another room," Ms. Meshejian said. Not that she would ever abandon her apartment of 22 years, which is perfectly positioned across the street from a community garden, where she tends her outdoor plants. Indeed, if there's anything besides economics that keeps people chained to small apartments, it's location.
For Doris Tobias, it all comes down to breezy views of the East River and the United Nations. She lives in a one-bedroom with a little less than 700 square feet and a kitchen the size of a bathtub, not all that unusual -- except that Ms. Tobias happens to be a cookbook author. ("The Golden Lemon," published in 1979, is being reissued by iUniverse, and Ms. Tobias is the co-author, with Jean-Paul Picot, of "La Bonne Soupe Cookbook" from Macmillan.) She is preparing her next book, on "salads that start the meal and salads that are the meal," in the same small space.
"People love to have grandiose, grand-scale kitchens," she said, wrinkling her nose. "It's an act of one-upmanship. They're not for use; they're showy."
The alcove that passes for her kitchen houses a standard refrigerator; a diminutive four-burner stove; a Frigidaire minidishwasher; a convection oven barely big enough for an eight-pound turkey; and some wooden cabinets that spill into the living room. A few choice pots and utensils hang at arm's length; basil and rosemary sit in the windowsill, swaying in the breeze.
"You have to clean up as you go," Ms. Tobias added. She not only washes as she cooks, but also prepares parts of the meal ahead of time, running her kitchen like a miniature military barracks. "Tidiness is space," she said. "You have to work and clean, work and clean."
Will she ever move, get a bigger kitchen? Not likely: she's too attached to the neighborhood, where she has lived since 1979. "Things have changed," she said wistfully. "But the river is still there, rolling along."
Living small isn't for everyone, of course, and it hasn't worked so well for Richard Mason, a short cherubic man who moved into his 15-by-15-foot studio apartment in 1957, when he was 30. At first, he said, the size of the place didn't matter. He and his friends "had great parties," he continued, adding, "We had 25 people over at one time."
Later, he acquired a house on Long Island near Hofstra University, where he taught theater, and he used the apartment only on weekends. But when he retired, he moved back. Now, "It's really a challenge to live here," he said, pointing to shelves that cling like barnacles to every wall. "There's not a square inch that your eye will rest on that I actually haven't done something to."
Despite such efforts, as he sees it, he needs professional design help. "For years now I've been trying to neaten this place," he said, but it is always "on the threshold of continuing chaos."
Some savor the chaos. Surprisingly, I found that includes families. My final stop was at the home of Ursula and Nilo Mitra, who live on Pomander Walk, a 1920's gated community of miniature Tudor row houses lining a blocklong pedestrians-only alley that runs from 94th Street to 95th Street between Broadway and West End Avenue. Their 600-square-foot apartment on a single floor has two tiny bedrooms, with a home office in the parents' room and a library lining their son's bedroom walls. There is a modest dining/living room area and a kitchenette wedged into a walk-in closet.
The Mitras, who arrived from separate dwellings a few years ago, are the first to raise a child on Pomander Walk in more than 20 years. Ms. Mitra works as bookbinder; her husband, who has a doctorate in particle physics, works for Ericsson, which makes cell phones. Their son, Amitav, is 2 and will be joined by a baby sister in October. Two cats (Samantha and Nimbus), plus a sometime nanny, round out the household.
"Dinner is crazy around here," Mrs. Mitra said. And privacy is practically nonexistent. "There are no real borders in this place, except maybe our bedroom," she said. And that doubles as an office, with a hardwood partition the couple designed themselves. The floor-to-ceiling unit contains a clothes closet, a file cabinet, several bookshelves and drawers for linens. Another storage unit, also of their own design, wraps around one of the windows, providing space for china and a collection of vases.
The Mitras store bulk purchases of diapers, toilet paper and canned goods off-site in Ms. Mitra's studio in Hoboken. When they get restless, there is always Central Park. "We spend half of every day out there,' Mrs. Mitra said. "Amitav loves the sandbox."
The Mitras can afford to move out, but they are attached to their community And they are inured. Both grew up in small spaces: Mr. Mitra in India, where extended families make privacy a luxury; Mrs. Mitra, in an apartment in Germany with three siblings. "My father was the only one who had a private room," she said, recalling his study.
As she sees it, small is good for children -- and parents. In big suburban homes, she said, "the child is often in the farthest corner of the house."
"Far too much responsibility is shifted away from the parents and put elsewhere," she added. "Part of being responsible is being there and seeing what's going on with your kid."
She laughed. "That is not a problem in a place like this."

HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MICROSOFT;
Gates's Statement: The First Day of the Rest of the Case

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of the opening statement by William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, at a news conference yesterday in Redmond, Wash., as recorded by The New York Times:
I'm reminded of the old saying that today is the first day of the rest of your life. I believe very strongly that today is the first day of the rest of this case. 
 The central issue here is a disagreement between ourselves and the Department of Justice over whether we should have been allowed to support the Internet inside Microsoft Windows. Our inclusion of that support in an integrated way did nothing to exclude Netscape or any other competitor from distributing and improving their technology. In fact, as the court found, Netscape distributed over 160 million copies of its browser in 1998 alone.
The government's position here on the specific of the browser and on the general question of improving products really flies in the face of the kind of improvements that have benefited consumers from innovation coming out of the technology industry. So today's ruling really represents an unwarranted and unjustified intrusion into the software marketplace, a marketplace that has been an engine of economic growth for America. This ruling would provide that the Internet support in Windows could never be enhanced, it could never be updated to new standards whether they relate to privacy or XML or any other consumer needs. This ruling says to creators of intellectual property that the government can take away what you created if it turns out to be too popular.
We will be exercising our right to appeal this decision, and we're confident the judicial system will overturn today's ruling. We will also seek a stay of this order so the appeal can move forward without any unnecessary harm to Microsoft and to consumers through the delay or interference with our work on new products.
I want to make it clear that the Microsoft team worked very hard to try and settle the issues in this case without the need for additional litigation. I also want to make sure that people understand that during the appeal we'll continue to do what we do best, which is building new software. We have many reasons to be confident in our appeal. For example, the ruling is directly inconsistent, as the district court acknowledges, with the appeals court ruling on exactly this topic that was made earlier.
Also, it's an unreasonable thing to call to break up Microsoft and create these regulatory provisions about how software should be defined. I also think if you just step back from this and look at the paradigm shifts taking place today and the very intense competition in our business, what's being said today flies in the face of the innovation and low prices that consumers are seeing every day, low prices that really arise out of the PC industry and the values that we brought as one of the companies that really fostered the entire PC phenomenon.
So we have strong legal, factual and procedural arguments. The court adopted the government's plan to break up and regulate Microsoft without a single day of testimony. Microsoft asked for a reasonable opportunity to respond to the government's unprecedented plan, but we were denied that right.
Here at Microsoft we've assembled a world-class team. For 25 years, that team has brought widespread benefits to the economy and to consumers. We have very exciting plans for that team including things like a breakthrough user interface that involves handwriting and speech recognition. These are efforts that can only be done by a large company with a total focus on taking its R&D and moving those into products. Keeping our team together as one Microsoft is critical to our efforts.
The values that have guided our efforts throughout our entire history include competing hard, but competing fairly; listening to customers and innovating to meet their needs; and partnering with literally thousands of companies in the hardware, software and services businesses to make our vision of low-cost computing a reality and a reality that has moved forward faster than any sector of the economy. We've got a lot of great new ideas and great new products we're working on for the months and years ahead. In particular we're very excited about the vision of a next generation of services delivered through the Internet. The Internet, as powerful as it is today, can be made easier and far more effective for both consumers and businesses.
We recognize that as an industry leader we have grave responsibilities in working inside our business. And we accept that. While we disagree with the government on this specific issue, I want to make clear that we respect the role of government and our legal and economic system. And we will, of course, abide by any final judgments reached in this case. We continue to work on a very positive basis with federal and state officials. In fact, just yesterday I was in Washington, D.C., discussing with a great number of legislators issues like improving technology in education, bridging the digital divide and important legislation like that upcoming digital signature bill.
So in conclusion, today is the start of a new phase of this case, a phase where we'll get review by a higher court. We're confident that the courts will overturn what's happened at the district level. And as the legal team works to resolve this, we're going to focus our energy on building great software for all our customers.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Untrained but Inspired, Hands Dreamed in Stone

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
In 1941 Edward Weston photographed the grassy yard in Nashville where the sculptor William Edmondson (1874-1951) carved and displayed his work. Judging from the pictures, it was an enchanted ground.
The limestone sculptures, cut from castoff blocks, look almost translucent under the sun. Dozens of figures -- celestial, human, animal -- seem to be enacting a kind of epic folk opera: score by Scott Joplin, libretto by Aesop, choreography by the great master dancers of Yorubaland. 
 Some hint of this effect can be found in "The Art of William Edmondson," an exhibition organized by the Cheekwood Museum of Art in Nashville and now at the Museum of American Folk Art. Nearly 45 of Edmonson's sculptures are shown against a blowup of one of Weston's pictures, along with photographs of the sculptor by Consuelo Kanaga and Louise Dahl-Wolfe.
As one sees at a glance, all creatures, lowly and exalted -- hoot owls and angels, preachers and politicians, athlete-heroes and back-porch neighbors -- found their way into Edmondson's work from the time he carved his first stone piece in 1931. He was 59 and recently retired from 24 years as a janitor at Nashville Woman's Hospital. His real career was just beginning.
During the next 17 years, using scrap stone and a railroad spike and a hammer as tools, he produced hundreds of sculptures, most of them figurative, others near-abstract, as tombstones and garden ornaments for the city African-Americans.
Many of the images were religious, and specifically biblical. The sisters Martha and Mary appear as plump twins tucked under a vigorously chiseled coverlet, and Eve as a strapping lass in a fig-leaf miniskirt. The crucified Jesus is an infantile figure in a diaper, something like the early Christian Christ, floating against the cross, hands held high in a gesture of praise and release.
There's also a church-shaped Noah's ark that Edmondson originally placed on a high base made of stone columns. The base, visible in photographs but now lost, probably represented Mount Ararat, where the ark perched safe and dry after the floods had receded, and for which Nashville's first black cemetery was named.
Edmondson said the ideas for his sculptures were heaven sent, delivered in visions or dreams. Traditional artists in Africa and India say the same thing. It's another way of talking about what some of us refer to as inspiration.
Wherever they came from, angels abound in his work. One in the show has big hair, a solemn face, wings like cupboard doors, and a pocketbook clutched to her side. The subtle distinctions in texture made among her hair, flesh and wings are an Edmondson hallmark and a source of intense optical pleasure in his art.
Despite his otherworldly subjects, this artist was no recluse saint. He was up on the news and paid tribute to celebrities of the day, from Jack Johnson, the first black world heavyweight champion, to Eleanor Roosevelt, who visited Nashville in 1934. And his own friends and neighbors are well represented in his work.
Here one encounters classic types: a preacher with a Sharptonesque coif, a buttoned-up schoolmarm, a pretty ingenue in a squared-off cape. But Edmondson seems to have been close to some of his subjects, like the affectionate couple in "Bess and Joe," and he warmed their figures with closely observed details: Joe is shown in a rakish snap-brim cap; Bess's legs peek, slim and shapely, from beneath her lifted skirt.
Particularly expressive are carvings of animals. Some are naturalistic: an alert squirrel munches his lunch; three small birds nod on a log. Others have a near-human presence. An extraordinary eagle with outstretched wings projects a grandeur that Edmondson's crucifixes play down. And then there are fantastic beings, like the ardent, buxom "Mermaid" and the all-but-abstract "Critter," an asymmetrical wedge of stone with a single shrewdly positioned notch to indicate a mouth.
"Mermaid," at nearly three feet long, is one of his largest works. It is one among his many sculptures with cultural roots running straight, and still green, to Africa. And "Critter" exemplifies Edmondson the modernist (stylistic cousin to Brancusi) who knocked the New York art world off its feet.
This happened in 1937. Dahl-Wolfe, a fashion photographer for Harper's Bazaar, had heard about Edmondson through friends in Tennessee and began taking pictures of him and his work in 1934. At the time the magazine refused to run work by black artists in its pages, so she passed the photos on to Alfred Barr, director of the Museum of Modern Art. Edmondson became the first African-American to have a solo show at the museum.
It is when Edmondson is considered in the light of a mainstream institution like the Modern, in fact, that the insider-outsider dichotomies that have gathered around him and other so-called self-taught artists turn instructively paradoxical.
Edmondson was intimately tied to and produced art within an economically marginal culture. But that culture has shaped virtually every aspect of American life. His art naturally looks at home in the modernist tradition, which draws so deeply on non-Western sources. It also inflects, challenges, even resists that tradition, with a whole range of specific local interests and beliefs. In the presence of his work, in short, insider and outsider are revealed to be entirely relative terms, and any attempt, however well-intentioned, to shoehorn him into either category is to shortchange him. He's too rich and complicated for that.
The Edmondson exhibition, organized by Rusty Freeman of the Cheekwood Museum and in New York by Brooke Anderson, the new director of the Contemporary Center of the Museum of American Folk Art, comes with an intelligent catalog in which these issues are explored. But in the end it is the sculptures that count, and they need neither arguments not advocates.
Formally spare, conceptually both lighthearted and profound, they represent a personal vision, but they also offer a credible version of Visionary Art -- one with both feet on the ground -- for a spiritually uptight age. And as to Edmondson's history-book status, there is something symbolically right in the fact that while his sculptures hold a place among modernism's monuments, his grave in Mount Ararat cemetery has no stone.
 "The Art of William Edmondson" is at the Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, through Aug. 27. It travels to the Memorial Art Gallery of the University of Rochester (Sept. 23 to Jan. 7); the High Museum of Art in Atlanta (Feb. 24 to May 20); and the Mennello Museum of American Folk Art in Orlando, Fla. (June 2 to Aug. 26, 2001). A dozen of his works are in "William Edmondson and 20th-Century Self-Taught Artists" at the Newark Museum through Aug. 13.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Ties (and Bungee Cords) That Bind

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
More male eyes tear up in "Pop and Me," a likable documentary about fathers and sons, than turn misty in "Frequency," the macho tear-jerker about filial devotion that word of mouth has turned into a surprise hit. Could it be that the tough-but-tender ethos of Robert Bly's "Iron John" has trickled down into the cultural mainstream despite the buckets of glib derision heaped on the men's movement? The coincidence of these two male weepies suggests perhaps yes.
"Pop and Me," directed by Chris Roe, a generically clean-cut young Californian who seems largely untouched by life, follows the boyish filmmaker on a nine-month trip around the world with his recently divorced and unemployed 55-year-old father, Richard. While on the road, between bickering and making up, the Roes interview pairs of fathers and sons in various cultures about their relationships. Although the majority of these interviews turn out to be question-and-answer sessions that reveal almost nothing, two or three are quite touching. 
 We visit the home of a bossy Egyptian general who, in the custom of many Muslim families, unconditionally rules the roost in a household where he is surrounded by several generations of his family. According to Islamic teaching, he tells us, children must unquestioningly obey their parents. And judging from the film's joint interview with the general and a grown-up son who lives at home and clearly idolizes his father, such strictures can help ensure a familial social stability. But even in this tight-lipped environment, as the general is questioned about whether he loves his son and awkward hugs are exchanged, the mists begin to roll into their eyes.
It is in Australia, of all places, while visiting an old friend of Richard's, that the Roes' kissy-huggy ethos is stonewalled by the son of a rancher who smugly dismisses this freshly thawed style of filial camaraderie as wimpy "American stuff."
The interviews and some pretty travel scenery are really only the glue holding together the story of Chris and Richard's thorny relationship while traveling. Their agreement before setting out is that Chris will be in charge of the film and Richard, who is footing the bill, in charge of travel, meals and accommodations. But Chris, the second of three sons, resents being bossed around by his father, and their relationship becomes increasingly strained until the end of the trip, when Chris coaxes his acrophobic dad into a dual bungee jump while holding a camera and sound equipment.
For a film devoted to celebrating intimacy and the breaking down of emotional barriers, "Pop and Me" is oddly withholding of information about the travelers. By the end of the movie Chris, who has done a smooth job of directing, seems almost as blank as he did at the beginning. When addressing the camera he is affable enough, but we get no sense of any inner life beyond his continual peevishness about not being in command. We learn a great more about Richard, who comes fairly close to being an ideal father with his mixture of confidence, humor, optimism and general openness. Born in the Bronx, he recalls being the son of a hopeless alcoholic who spent the last decades of his life in a mental institution. In the film's most touching story, he recalls paying a rare visit to the hospital shortly before his father's death and apologizing for being such a neglectful son. For a moment his father emerged from his fog, Richard recalls, just long enough to forgive his son.
What we don't find out is anything about the career or the marriage Richard is leaving behind or why he is stranded without even (we learn at the end of the film) a home base to go back to. Talk about midlife crises! Although Richard appears affluent enough not to have to worry about making a living once he returns to the United States, his future at the end of the movie is a complete mystery. "Pop and Me" leaves you wishing more cards had been put on the table.
 
POP AND ME
 
Directed by Chris Roe; directors of photography, Erik Arnesen and Mr. Roe; edited by Jesse Negron and Mr. Roe; music by Steve Edwards and Mazatl Galindo; produced by Richard Roe and Mr. Roe; released by Seventh Art Releasing. At the Village East, Second Avenue at 12th Street, East Village. Running time: 90 minutes. This film is not rated.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: CURRENCIES;
Europe's Central Bank Acts To Raise Inflation Barrier

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, June 8

 BODY:
In an unexpectedly aggressive attempt to help insulate Europe against inflation, the European Central Bank tightened its grip on monetary policy today by raising its core interest rate half a percentage point.
The move, pushing the baseline rate from 3.75 to 4.25 percent, surprised most economists and sent currency traders into a confused frenzy over the euro, Europe's common currency. 
 The euro, which has enjoyed a remarkable turnaround in the last two weeks, initially climbed against the dollar, going from 96 cents to more than 97 cents. But then it slipped back to 95.7 cents.
Higher interest rates tend to strengthen a currency. The euro's rise and subsequent fall today, foreign-exchange traders said, may have been caused by Wim Duisenberg, the central bank's president, who implied that there would not be any more rate increases soon.
Before today, most currency experts and economists had predicted that the European Central Bank would increase rates by only a quarter of a point.
Today's move came against the backdrop of the euro's travails in world currency markets. Since its introduction in January 1999, the euro has steadily plunged in value relative to the American dollar, from a high of $1.17 to a low of 88.5 cents last month.
Two weeks ago, the euro suddenly began its first sustained recovery. Fueled largely by speculation that the central bank would intervene directly in currency markets -- speculation encouraged by veiled threats from central bankers -- the euro has climbed 10 percent to about 96 cents.
In explaining the bank's decision today, Mr. Duisenberg insisted that the bank was not trying to meddle with exchange rates. Rather, he based the decision on Europe's accelerating growth and a heightened threat of inflation.
"The outlook for growth in the euro area has improved markedly over the past few months," Mr. Duisenberg said at a news conference here today. But, he said, the risks of inflation had increased as a result of rising import prices -- for oil in particular.
But Mr. Duisenberg said he remained unsatisfied with what he called the low value of the euro and acknowledged that this played an important if indirect role in today's decision.
That is because the euro's decline has inevitably led to an increase in the prices of imports. The euro has slumped against the yen and the British pound as well as against the dollar, so Europe's imports from most of the world have been affected.
"The reversal which started about two weeks ago still leaves, I believe, some potential for further appreciation," Mr. Duisenberg said. "I know that the exchange rate of the euro -- even after the recent appreciation -- does not yet reflect fundamentals, whatever they may be."
But Mr. Duisenberg also dampened expectations about additional rate increases later in the year. "One of the motives to raise the rate by a half-point is that such a move will clear the horizon for some time to come," he told reporters. "We think this move has cleared the horizon."
Tony Norfield, global currency analyst at the Dutch bank ABN Amro, said those remarks might explain why the euro declined after having initially risen.
Indeed, Mr. Norfield predicted that the euro had already "peaked" and is likely to slip again.
"It did look fairly aggressive at first," Mr. Norfield said. "The thing that probably took the steam out of the euro was when Duisenberg suggested that was it and there wouldn't be any more."
Mr. Duisenberg was deliberately ambiguous and left himself ample maneuvering room for a shift in emphasis. But his implied message contrasted sharply with that of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who issued a clear warning about additional rate increases after the Fed raised rates on May 16.
Though surprised by today's move, most economists said it was justified and came merely faster than they had expected.
"It won't do much to damage growth," said Holger Fahrinkrug, an economist at Warburg Dillon Read in Frankfurt. "I'd say the E.C.B. was a bit slow before and that this step compensates for that."
Stefan Schneider, head of euro-zone economic research at Deutsche Bank Research, said that Mr. Duisenberg was probably not reacting to the euro's weakness but that today's action could nonetheless keep the currency moving upward.
"The E.C.B. won't dislike the windfall effect of the euro," Mr. Schneider said. "In that respect, the timing is better than as if the hike had come a few weeks ago. The chances are always better if you support a market trend that has already crystallized."

HEADLINE: Calgary Journal;
In the Catbird Seat (or the Hot Seat, Like Seattle?)

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: CALGARY, Alberta

 BODY:
Playing on Americans' fear of the unknown, a Best Western Hotel television ad last winter showed business executives bucking an unpopular travel request down the corporate ladder. Finally, the request stopped at a hapless underling, standing wide-eyed by a photocopier as a colleague asked, "Have you ever been to -- Calgary?"
Calgarians complained and the hotel chain pulled the commercial. But many others here in the most prosperous city in Canada's most prosperous province just shrugged it off, attributing it to the provincialism of an American ad copy writer. 
 With the highest household Internet connection rate in Canada, the country's largest concentration of corporate headquarters outside of Toronto, and a brand new venture capital stock exchange incubating hundreds of new companies, people in this steel and glass city on the edge of the Canadian Rockies are too busy making money to lose sleep over outdated stereotypes. In fact, a little negative publicity might cool off a city whose population has grown by two-thirds since 1975, to 860,000 today, pushing up housing prices by one third since 1995, the fastest rate of any city in Canada.
"The traffic," groaned Alnisha Haji, a hairdresser who moved here from Winnipeg a few years ago. "Places that used to take half an hour to get to, now take an hour."
But with the lowest unemployment rate of a major Canadian city, 4.7 percent, migrants still flock here at the rate of 50 a day.
"One of the first things I noticed here were the help wanted ads," said Michelle Simick, 27, a newspaper reporter who moved here this spring from her native Vancouver. "They have signs everywhere -- in front of the 7-Elevens, in front of the restaurants, even a board up in the mall. I have never seen that in Vancouver."
"People my age here seem to be a lot further along than people in Vancouver," she said. "People in Vancouver seem to be slogging away at service jobs, waiting for jobs that never open up."
With Canada's tallest building west of Toronto, this modern city of high-rises enjoys its image of a sunny, squeaky clean city, even serving as "Metropolis" for the filming of all three modern Superman movies. But on June 11, this showcase metropolis will be thrust into the world spotlight when 3,000 delegates from 80 countries converge here for the World Petroleum Congress, a five-day event that takes place every three years.
The biggest event to hit Calgary since the 1988 Winter Olympics, the congress may not capture wide attention despite high gasoline prices.
But protesters, noting the expected attendance of 200 journalists, are gearing up for a series of photogenic protests, promising a miniature version of the antitrade protests that shook Seattle six months ago. In a genteel city where parking meter attendants wear cowboy hats to charm the tourists, it is unclear how Calgary will cope if violence breaks out.
Targets will be easy to find. Penthouse floors of downtown skyscrapers proudly bear the names of oil companies: Gulf, Husky, Mobil, Shell and Petro-Canada. But while energy sector companies occupy half of downtown's office space, appearances are deceiving in a city long labeled Canada's "energy capital."
Whipsawed by a series of oil price shocks, Alberta has diversified. The energy industry's part of the provincial economy has dropped to 20 percent today from 35 percent 15 years ago. In the near suburbs, before housing developments sprawl across shortgrass prairie to the Rockies, about 1,200 new high technology companies have sprung up in recent years, now employing 50,000 people.
Professors at a University of Calgary high technology center have licensed 300 technologies in the last decade. To lessen economic dependence on oil, Alberta's government has set up two $700 million funds, one for engineering research, the other for medical research. Last year, of Alberta's 10 fastest-growing companies, 6 were high-tech companies based in Calgary.
"People have learned," said Ralph Klein, Alberta's premier, who was Calgary's mayor during the energy downturn of the 1980's.
This year, Alberta expects to record the highest growth rate, 5 percent, of Canada's 10 provinces. The premier placed much of the credit on low taxes. Alberta has no sales tax, Canada's lowest gasoline tax and, starting Jan. 1, will have Canada's first flat provincial tax.
"When people come out here, they are amazed," said William L. Hess, a Montreal native who runs Calgary's new Canadian Venture Exchange. "The entrepreneurial drive, the quality of work available to professionals are unparalleled."
Since opening six months ago as a fusion of two old exchanges in Calgary and Vancouver, this national exchange has quadrupled its daily trades, to an average of about 28,000 today. With 2,800 small capital companies listed, it is now moving east, opening branches this summer in Winnipeg and Toronto. The new exchange replaces the Vancouver Stock Exchange, which lost credibility over stock manipulations of mining companies.
The downside of Calgary's boom has been an affordable housing squeeze. In the last year, the minimum income needed to buy the average house here jumped by one-quarter, knocking 45,000 families out of the market, according to mortgage analysts. "Homelessness has grown incredibly here," said David W. Lewry, who runs the Inn From the Cold Society, a network of homeless shelters.
But in general Calgary's success has provoked mostly envy, starting in neighboring British Columbia. Alberta, with only three-quarters of British Columbia's population of four million, expects its gross provincial product to surpass its western neighbor's this year, hitting $75 billion.
"No wonder the new Canadian Venture Exchange will headquarter in Calgary and not Vancouver," Mark Milke, British Columbia director of the Canadian Taxpayers Federation, complained in an essay in The Calgary Herald. "The stockbrokers are simply following the moving vans of other enterprising British Columbians."
In Edmonton, Alberta's capital, Don Ghermezian, manager of the West Edmonton Mall, the world's largest shopping mall, sniffed in an interview: "Calgary has nothing. O.K., it has a tower with a revolving restaurant. Big deal."
In Toronto, newspapers like to paint Calgary and Alberta as weird bastions of reactionary politics and lifestyles. In reality, Calgary is middle of the road by American standards. Last fall, a Calgary judge established the right for local lesbian couples to adopt children legally.
A yuppie haven in reality, Calgary has a household Internet connection rate of 60 percent, and a population that, surveys indicate, prefers skiing over hockey and bicycling over fishing. With the local National Hockey League team, the Calgary Flames, losing money, The Calgary Herald is campaigning to expand the sales of season passes with scare headlines like "No Bucks, No Pucks."
In this city of migrants, social mobility is often greater than in blue-blooded Eastern Canada. In May, Mayor Al Duerr bestowed Calgary's Citizen of the Year Award on Mitzie Wasyliw for her work preserving an old ranching homestead. A newspaper report noted that Mrs. Wasyliw got her start here in the 1970's when she blew into town and became one of the city's first "exotic dancers."
"I am sure there is a bit of Toronto looking down their noses at the West," Mr. Hess, the stock exchange president, said of intercity rivalries. "But, frankly, there is a bit of the West looking down its nose at Toronto."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Abig new Internet services company is determined to make its entry with a splash.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THERE is a riddle that used to appear in magazines like Highlights for Children and Boys' Life, asking readers to name the only day of the year that can also be a sentence. The answer: March Fourth.
Back up the calendar three days and you have the name of a recently formed company, offering a variety of Internet professional services, that seeks to solve another riddle: how to stand out amid competitors ranging from management consultants to advertising agencies to Web site builders. The company, called MarchFirst Inc., is hoping the right answer will be an extensive -- and expensive -- offline and online media campaign centered on a celebration of being, well, first. 
 MarchFirst began operations on, yes, March 1, with the completion of the merger of the USWeb/CKS Group, a Web services company, and Whittman-Hart, an Internet consulting firm. A brief "teaser" campaign ran in newspapers to introduce the name, which was created by staff members at McKinney & Silver, the ad agency unit of USWeb/CKS perhaps best known for its work for the Audi automobiles sold by Volkswagen of America.
The second, much larger, phase of the MarchFirst campaign, also produced by McKinney & Silver, is to begin on Monday with ads in daily and weekly newspapers. Ads in business, trade and lifestyle magazines will follow later in the month along with TV commercials on sports and other programming. The online portion includes a Web site to go up on Monday (www.marchfirst.com).
The budget for the entire campaign, carrying the theme "A new company for the new economy," is $50 million.
"It's tough to cut through all the clutter," said Robert Bernard, chairman and chief executive at MarchFirst in Chicago, particularly, he said, when dozens of dot-coms are striving to establish themselves in the business-to-business and business-to-consumer realms.
"It's very important for us to get the name out there, to create a strong brand awareness," Mr. Bernard said, adding that basing the campaign on "the human desire to be first" would accomplish that "because people will be attracted to the emotion, the heart."
"It's not just about crossing a finish line first," he added, "but also about tackling problems, taking risks, taking on challenges."
The device the campaign uses to gain attention is to demonstrate the effects of famous firsts rather than portray the causes. For instance, a print ad captioned "The first rock star" shows not Chuck Berry or Elvis Presley or Bill Haley but screaming, sobbing fans pressed against a chain-link fence.
"Here's to being first," the text reads. "Here's to leading."
A second print ad, captioned "The first cubist exhibition," displays not "Nude Descending a Staircase" but a gallery of men and women staring, glaring and even tilting their heads.
"It's good to be first," the text reads, promoting MarchFirst as providing businesses with "a new way of thinking."
The TV commercials are to present the effects of events like the wearing of the first miniskirt, as passers-by are seen registering shock and surprise; the first man on the moon, as a family watching television is glimpsed crying and cheering; and the first expedition to the South Pole, as penguins are shown turning their heads in unison from left to right as if they were humans at a tennis match.
"The power is in the effects these firsts had in moving society," said David Baldwin, senior vice president and executive creative director at McKinney & Silver.
"We could have said: 'MarchFirst. Integrated solutions for your many needs,' " he added, laughing. "But it's better to say we're making sure MarchFirst is always trying to win for clients and employees."
Indeed, said Sara Cavin, executive vice president for marketing, the campaign is aimed at MarchFirst's employees -- current and prospective -- as much as existing and potential customers.
"We're constantly 're-recruiting' our employees to make sure they've an understanding of what we do," Ms. Cavin said. That is crucial because MarchFirst, with 9,000 employees at 70 offices in 14 countries, does so much: creating traditional advertising; building and putting up Web sites; offering brand and corporate identity consulting and strategic positioning; and installing so-called front-end and back-end technology services.
Whether or not you like the company's unusual name, it offers one major advantage, according to Mr. Bernard: "Every year, we can celebrate our anniversary."

HEADLINE: Putin to Visit North Korea; U.S. ABM Plan May Be Target

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 8

 BODY:
President Vladimir V. Putin plans to visit North Korea next month, a move that underscores his active foreign policy and seems calculated to counter the Clinton administration's plan for a national missile defense.
Russian officials said today that it would be the first trip by a Russian leader to the North Korean capital, Pyongyang. 
 "This is an unprecedented event, a bold step, as no head of state from our country has ever been in North Korea, neither in Soviet nor in Russian times," Georgi Toloraya, an official in the Foreign Ministry, told the newspaper Vremya Novostei.
The announcement comes on the heels of Mr. Putin's meeting with President Clinton in Moscow, in which the two leaders found themselves at odds over the administration's plans for a limited antimissile system.
The Korea visit meeting will provide Mr. Putin with an opportunity to make his case that diplomacy, not missile defense, is the way to cope with an emerging missile threat from North Korea.
Mr. Putin can also use the visit to challenge the idea that North Korea is an irrational "rogue state," a description the United States has used to justify its antimissile plans.
Those Russian themes are likely to resonate in Western Europe, where the Western allies remain very anxious that the administration's plan will start an arms race and leave them unprotected.
In recent days, Mr. Putin took his campaign to Italy, where he urged Europeans to support a Russian alternative to the American plan.
American officials were caught by surprise by the Russian announcement. They said they welcomed the visit as way to end North Korea's isolation.
"We continue to believe that dialogue among all countries in the region contributes to peace and security on the Korean peninsula and beyond," a State Department spokesman said.
According to the Japanese media, Mr. Putin's visit is scheduled to take place in mid-July, just before the summit meeting of the leading industrial democracies in Okinawa, Japan, from July 21 to 23.
Russian officials said Moscow had become more interested in the situation on the Korean peninsula as a result of the summit meeting between North and South Korea scheduled for early next week.
Mr. Toloraya, who is deputy director of the Foreign Ministry's Asia department, said that the Kremlin had proposed the visit and that the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, had issued a formal invitation.
Mr. Toloraya said Moscow wanted to assure the North Koreans that Moscow did not favor a unified Korea dominated by Seoul. Such fears have grown in Pyongyang, he said, as Russia has developed economic and political ties with South Korea.
"That is not the case," Mr. Toloraya said in his newspaper interview. "We consider it necessary for the two Korean states to coexist for a long time."
The American antiballistic missile plan is very much on the agenda, according to the Russians. Mr. Toloraya said the Russians and North Koreans would have a general discussion on "how we can act together in the world situation, including in connection with U.S. plans for ABM."
In an indirect swipe at Washington, he said Russia's new assertive role in foreign policy had the potential to upset "somebody else's cards."
Russia fears that the limited defense the United States is planning is just the first phase in a larger system that will eventually counter Russia's strategic forces. Washington's goal has been to overcome Russian suspicions and persuade the Kremlin to amend the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.
That would enable the United States to develop a limited defensive system, which could include the deployment of 100 interceptors and the construction of radar in Alaska.
At the summit meeting between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Putin, Russia acknowledged that there was an emerging missile threat from nations like North Korea. Still, the Russians insist that the threat is not as worrisome as the United States says. And while the Americans have insisted that an antimissile system is needed, the Russians have urged diplomacy.
The United States has persuaded North Korea to accept a moratorium on the test-firing of long-range missiles. That has precluded Pyongyang from testing its Taepo Dong-2, a two-stage missile that Washington fears might eventually be developed as an intercontinental missile.
There have been several indications of growing ties between Russia and North Korea. The Russian foreign minister, Igor S. Ivanov, paid a recent visit to North Korea. And a North Korean delegation arrived at Sakhalin Island in Russia's Far East to discuss joint construction projects, the Russian news agency Itar-Tass said today.

Pyongyang Reports New Drought
 SEOUL, South Korea, June 8 (Reuters) -- North Korea, now dependent on food aid for survival, today reported that another drought had hit all parts of the country, devastating spring crops.
The official Korean Central News Agency said "drought and heat persist in all parts" of the country. "Because of a long spell of drought and heat, paddy fields are parched and rice-transplantation is suspended in some areas," it said.

HEADLINE: Through the Looking Glass: Europe Raises Interest Rates

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
WHAT would the Federal Reserve do if American inflation was running about 2 percent a year and the unemployment rate was 9.6 percent? Would Alan Greenspan have the nerve to raise rates by half a percentage point?
If that idea sounds crazy to you, then you're not in touch with reality, European style. For that is exactly what happened yesterday to Germans, for whom the above statistics apply. The European Central Bank, eager to prove its credibility as an inflation fighter, decided to confound forecasters and impose a half-point interest rate increase. 
 In this country, an unemployment rate that high would have long since become the major national economic issue -- the actual United States rate is now 4.1 percent -- and politicians would be screaming for easier monetary policy. It would take an inflation rate far higher than 2 percent to persuade anyone that tightening credit was a good idea.
But in Europe, things are different. Wim Duisenberg, the central bank's president, explained that they were worried about inflation that can be traced in part to high oil prices and a weak euro, and that the European economy was growing at 3 percent anyway.
The sad thing about Europe now is that it seems to have accepted high unemployment as a virtually permanent thing. It is coming down, but the latest reported rate for the countries in the euro currency zone is 9.2 percent. The conventional wisdom is that unemployment is high because of structural problems like high wages and laws making it difficult for employers to hire and fire at will, and that a stimulative monetary policy would only revive inflation without doing much for growth. Anyway, the European Central Bank is supposed to keep inflation from going above 2 percent.
Robert M. Solow, the Nobel Prize-winning economist, has suggested that idea is simply wrong. "European central banks kept the squeeze on for a long time" when fighting the inflation of the 1970's, he wrote a few years ago. "Suppose," he added, "there is a tendency for prolonged 'cyclical' unemployment to turn into something that looks like 'structural' unemployment. It is not hard to imagine how that might plausibly happen as the unemployed adapt to the unavailability of jobs." Eventually, he said, central banks wrongly convinced themselves that high unemployment was there to stay and the banks could not "afford to expand aggregate demand" by loosening monetary policy.
It is perfectly true that Europe needs structural reform, but as Mr. Solow noted, "it would be bad news indeed if this apparently structural unemployment really would not yield to the revival of demand for goods and labor." He suggested that history indicated it would. The European Central Bank should find out if he is right.
In the United States, there has been good reason to think the economy was overheating, and the Fed has been right to tighten. But the Fed's action makes it all the more regrettable that the Europeans seem scared of growth. "From the world's perspective, a surprising strength coming out of Europe gives us the best chance to survive a necessary sharp slowing in the United States," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company.
The euro has been weak because investors have viewed the rapidly growing United States as a much more attractive place to put money. The euro is cheap, and will recover eventually. But efforts to slow European growth are not going to help the beleaguered currency.

HEADLINE: Work Begins on Westin Hotel To the West of Times Square

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Construction workers began building a soaring 45-story Westin hotel yesterday in a once forbidding area west of Times Square, at the southeast corner of Eighth Avenue and 43rd Street.
The $300 million, 858-room hotel, which would be part of the E Walk entertainment complex on 42nd Street, is the latest example of a boom in which analysts expect a record-breaking year for both hotel occupancy rates and room rates, which are the highest in the country. With many of the hotels in Manhattan effectively full, analysts expect that an additional 7,000 hotel rooms will be built in the next four years. 
 Westin, a chain owned by Starwood Hotels and Resorts, will operate the hotel on Eighth Avenue. And five blocks away, Starwood signed a deal on Wednesday to take over the 52-story hotel nearing completion at Broadway and 47th Street as part of its W Hotels chain.
The occupancy rate at Manhattan hotels rose to 89.1 percent in April, the highest point in the last 20 years, according to a survey by PricewaterhouseCoopers, an accounting firm. During the same month, average room rates reached $245.27, 11.7 percent higher than April 1999. And reservations for the summer and fall are running unusually strong.
"It suggests that 2000 may be the best year on record for the New York City hotel business," said Sean Hennessey, director of the hotel consulting business at PricewaterhouseCoopers.
Only five years ago, many hotel owners and developers said they would never venture as far west as Eighth Avenue, because 42nd Street was too seedy to support a luxury hotel. Since then, 42nd Street and Times Square have blossomed with restaurants, television studios, game rooms, theaters and office buildings. The hotels have followed.
Designed by Arquitectonica, the Westin Hotel will be split from top to bottom by a striking curved beam of light. The project is owned and developed by Tishman Realty and Construction Company, which is building the E Walk complex.
Across the street, the Hilton Times Square, with 444 rooms, had its grand opening on Tuesday on the south side of 42nd Street, next door to the entertainment complex that includes Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum, a 25-screen AMC multiplex movie house and HMV Records.
The hotel industry in New York City has made a remarkable recovery since 1991, when nearly half the hotel rooms in the city were left empty by a recession and the war in the Persian Gulf. Five years later, the hotel industry cried poverty and persuaded city officials to reduce the hotel tax by six percentage points, to 15.25 percent. Since then, hotel owners have raised the average room rate in Manhattan by 54.3 percent, to more than $245 a night.
And in the process, Times Square became contested territory. Gary Barnett, an owner of Intell Investment and Management, and Madison Equities, began construction two years ago at Broadway and 47th Street with a plan to create a Planet Hollywood Hotel.
The theme restaurant chain planned to move its flagship restaurant there from 57th Street. But Intell put the hotel up for sale after Planet Hollywood tumbled into bankruptcy court last year and sold its stake in the project back to Intell for about $32 million.
Sheraton, Hard Rock and a number of other companies competed for the project, and on Sunday it appeared that the Radisson hotel chain had won out with a bid to run the hotel as a joint venture. But at the last minute, real estate executives said, Starwood jumped in and grabbed the deal with an offer worth an estimated $175 million to lease the hotel and retail space for 25 years.
Intell will retain the 300-foot-tall steel columns on the hotel that serve as a superstructure for the illuminated billboards, which are worth millions of dollars a year in rental fees.
Mr. Hennessey, the hotel analyst, said that Starwood, which owns the Sheraton, Westin, St. Regis and W chains, has been eager to open a hotel on the West Side of Manhattan, where it may be able to reap bigger profits as patrons pay higher prices.
"The room rates at West Side hotels in Manhattan have been $25 to $35 below the rates of comparable hotels on the East Side," Mr. Hennessey said. "With the development of first-class office space and the evolution of Times Square, that spread is going to narrow and represent stronger than average gains for West Side hotels."
Dan Gibson, a spokesman for Starwood, confirmed yesterday that the company had signed a deal to run the hotel under the W brand. But he declined to give any details.

HEADLINE: Government Reports Decline in Import Prices

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
The prices businesses pay for imported goods, excluding petroleum, fell in May for the first time in almost a year, government figures showed today, suggesting that inexpensive imports are helping to keep inflation contained.
"It's been one of the major reasons why there's no pricing power in the U.S.," said Chris Rupkey, senior financial economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi in New York. "The goods are coming in from overseas; they're cheap; and it keeps businesses from being able to raise prices." 
 The index of imported prices for goods outside of petroleum products fell 0.2 percent last month after rising 0.1 percent in April, the Labor Department said. May's decrease -- which was attributed to falling prices of food, some capital equipment and consumer goods -- was the first since a 0.1 percent decrease in July.
Prices of imports, including oil, rose 0.6 percent in May after falling 1.5 percent in April. Imported oil prices, which have risen 72.1 percent since May 1999, have pushed up the overall import price index 6.4 percent over the last year. Nonpetroleum imports rose 0.9 percent in the 12 months ended in May.
The report is further evidence that inflation is not about to derail the record nine-year economic expansion. Federal Reserve policy makers have increased interest rates six times over the last year, pushing the overnight bank lending rate to a nine-year high of 6.5 percent, in an effort to slow growth and keep prices in check.
The Labor Department reported that the number of workers filing for state unemployment benefits rose last week to the highest level in five months. First-time jobless claims rose 20,000, to 309,000 for the week, the most since Jan. 8. Still, for the year to date, initial claims have averaged 280,000 a week, down from last year's average of 298,000.
The report on import prices is the first of three measures of inflation for May. The Labor Department reports its Producer Price Index on Friday and the Consumer Price Index on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Plans Tour on Prosperity Issues

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE with RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 8

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore plans to kick off a new stage of his campaign next week, making a "progress and prosperity" tour devoted to the relatively new questions of how best to guide the nation in an era of budget surpluses.
Mr. Gore said he would open the discussion on Tuesday in New York City with a speech about protecting Medicare from what he called "political poaching" and reserving it for the use of the 40 million Americans for whom it was collected. 
 "We're at a turning point in our country's history," Mr. Gore, the putative Democratic presidential nominee, said in an interview here today. "We've never had a debate about how to make decisions concerning a large, continuing surplus, and there are a number of big choices that we have to make."
He added, "The decisions related to the surplus are no less difficult or important than the decisions we have made concerning the deficit."
Besides Medicare, he said he would delve into other questions, including: "How to use entitlements correctly; how to pay off the debt more quickly in order to reduce interest rates and promote more economic growth; and how to make the investments that are needed in top priorities like education, to get people access to the skills they need."
The vice president's new focus is less about Medicare than about the ongoing debate over how best to take advantage of the nation's newly found fiscal health. It is part of Mr. Gore's effort to sell voters on debt reduction as a smarter alternative to the big tax cuts advocated by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, his expected Republican rival this fall.
It is also part of the Gore campaign's effort to put a positive sheen on Mr. Gore's candidacy and to make explicit use of what his advisers say is perhaps his best argument for being elected: the unprecedented prosperity of the last several years.
Mr. Gore has not received much direct credit for that prosperity, but the tour, to highlight the economic progress in states like Pennsylvania and Ohio that will be major electoral battlegrounds, should increase his association with it.
"The American people deserve the credit for the strength of the economy," Mr. Gore said. "I think the policies of this administration, which I've helped shape, have indeed unlocked some of that potential and made it much more likely to occur."
The vice president frequently points to his association with Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary and one of the nation's most respected financial analysts, as testimony to his fiscal discipline, but he said that he came up with the idea of putting Medicare into a "lock box" on his own.
"I consult with Bob Rubin all the time," Mr. Gore said today. "But this particular proposal on the Medicare lock box I put forward and I hoped that he would react positively to it, and he did."
The Medicare surplus this year is projected by its trustees at $22.3 billion, and to total $250 billion over 10 years. The surplus comes from payroll taxes levied on employees and employers to pay for hospitalization, nursing home care and other health benefits under Medicare.
Under the government's accounting rules, the Medicare surplus has been considered part of the general government surplus, unlike the surplus generated by Social Security, which both legally and politically has been segregated from excess general government revenue.
Both the Democratic and the Republican parties have agreed to use the Social Security surplus, which amounts to more than $2 trillion over the next decade, only to reduce the national debt held by the public. The public debt stands at $3.5 trillion.
Estimates of the non-Social Security surplus over the next decade range from $800 billion to nearly $2 trillion, depending on what assumptions are made about how fast government spending will increase.
Mr. Bush is relying on the non-Social Security surplus to pay for his tax cut plan, which is valued at $1.3 trillion over the rest of the decade.
Mr. Gore's Medicare "lock box" proposal would reduce the amount of money available for tax cuts by $250 billion, making it easier for him to portray Mr. Bush's tax plan as fiscally irresponsible, especially when added to Republican proposals for additional spending on programs like national missile defense.
The vice president has been determined to avoid negative references to Mr. Bush over the last few weeks. He said today that the intention of his Medicare proposal was not to make Mr. Bush's plan seem riskier, but he would not be unhappy if a voter drew that conclusion.
"If that makes it harder for someone to use the Medicare trust fund for purposes other than Medicare, then that should be one of the effects," he said.
Mr. Gore's plan would also restrict Democrats from using all of the non-Social Security surplus for additional spending.
Jim Horney, an analyst at the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal-leaning research group, said of the Gore plan: "This is obviously an attempt to reduce the likelihood of there being big tax increases or spending that would eat up the surplus. If it helps to avoid big tax cuts or spending increases before dealing with the long-term issues of Medicare and Social Security, that would be good."
Referring to the Medicare surplus, Mr. Horney said, "It's not nearly as much as the Social Security surplus, but it's still a significant amount of money."
Mr. Gore's lock box plan would not do anything to shore up Medicare, which, without any changes, is expected to become insolvent around 2025. By earmarking the Medicare surplus for debt reduction, the main economic effect of Mr. Gore's plan would be to underscore his commitment to paying off the national debt by 2013 or sooner, a path that he says would help keep interest rates down and stimulate economic growth.
But by setting up even an indirect tradeoff between Medicare and tax cuts, Mr. Gore is returning to a political strategy that Democrats have used successfully against Republicans for years: implying that Republican tax cuts for the rich would endanger health insurance for some of the nation's most vulnerable citizens.

HEADLINE: Commencement;
Hold On to Individuality, Levy Advises

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy told graduates at the College of Staten Island yesterday to take advantage of the growing globalization of the economy and the increasing interconnectedness of the world's people. But he warned them not to relinquish their privacy and individualism.
"The world has become smaller, the Internet has pulled us all together and our economies have all become one," Mr. Levy told the roughly 1,800 graduates gathered on a broad lawn at the college, which is part of the City University of New York. "How do we protect our spiritualism from the relentless march of the logical force of the future? How do we stand up and be ourselves?" 
 One way, Mr. Levy said, is to continue pursuing a "moral education" after leaving school.
"It means intellectual honesty," he said. "It means having a sense of vision. It means having a sense of creativity."
Mr. Levy, whose goals as chancellor include recruiting hundreds of qualified teachers to help turn around the city's failing schools, also stressed the importance of teaching in urban schools and compared it to volunteering in the civil rights movement or the Peace Corps. "Education, in my judgment, is the key social issue of the day," Mr. Levy said. "Education and teachers generally are the vessels by which we convey civilization."
Mr. Levy thanked the dozens of graduates who had majored in education, and in particular, Maria Gusenfitter, the valedictorian of the college's class of 2000. In a speech to her classmates, Ms. Gusenfitter told of her struggles raising her son Jack, who was born deaf, on her own as she worked toward her bachelor's degree.
"Despair can whisper lies about what will become of you," Ms. Gusenfitter said, describing her depression when her husband abandoned her after their son's birth. But Ms. Gusenfitter's family rallied around her, she said, baby-sitting for her son while she attended class and making sure she had transportation to get there.
"Somehow this love, if you let it in, can pierce the darkness and the coldness," she said, her voice breaking.
Ms. Gusenfitter, who plans to pursue a master's degree in elementary or special education, said she wanted to teach partly to help troubled students through tumultuous times.
"I will remind them that darkness is but for a while," she said, "and light will come again."
