HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MIRCROSOFT: THE LAW;
Experts Praise Judge's Rulings On Microsoft

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
Legal experts gave the judge in the Microsoft case high marks yesterday for his handling of the case, saying he took some risks but grounded his ruling in fundamental principles governing fair competition.
They said the actions of the judge, Thomas Penfield Jackson, had made it more difficult for Microsoft to suggest that the computer industry ought to be given more leeway than traditional businesses under antitrust law. 
 "It reminds people that there are antitrust laws out there," said George A. Hay, a professor of antitrust law at Cornell Law School. "It is a useful reminder that there are rules and just because you are big you can't do whatever you want."
The risks for Judge Jackson in the ruling, the legal experts said, included his decision to deny Microsoft new hearings on whether to break up the company or impose some lesser remedy after he had decided it abused its monopoly power. Some experts said appeals courts might overturn that decision and could order new hearings.
But several antitrust experts said the judge made efforts throughout the case to tie his decisions to traditional views of antitrust law, which is based on the principle that aggressive competition is encouraged, but not when it crosses the line into efforts to hamper competitors' abilities to make new products or market existing ones.
The judge said in an earlier ruling that Microsoft had maintained its dominance by keeping "an oppressive thumb on the scale of competitive fortune."
Some of the experts said the judge's emphasis on traditional antitrust principles, like rules against intimidation by monopolies, could blunt Microsoft's public efforts to suggest that the Justice Department was overstepping the appropriate bounds of antitrust enforcement.
The company has suggested that the suit was an anti-capitalist attack that would be harmful not just to Microsoft. The company's chairman, William H. Gates, said it was an "unwarranted intrusion" into "a marketplace that has been an engine of economic growth for America."
Microsoft used the rapid change of the new software industry as an argument to suggest that Judge Jackson should view the case differently than he might have viewed a case against a smokestack company, said Charles J. Goetz, an expert on antitrust law at the University of Virginia School of Law.
Professor Goetz praised Judge Jackson for refusing to be drawn into that approach and focusing on Microsoft's competitive style. "There has been an attempt by Microsoft, to a large extent successful with the public," Professor Goetz said, "to distinguish this case from traditional antitrust cases because it is in the high-tech field."
"But mere fast change is not the issue," Professor Goetz continued. "What this case was about was that other companies appeared to be coming up with a 'better mousetrap' and Microsoft was charged with engaging in very costly attempts to try to prevent competition from those products."
Einer Elhauge, a professor of antitrust law at Harvard Law School, said Judge Jackson's decision on Wednesday had to be viewed in the context of his earlier findings, like holding that Microsoft intimidated competitors and made efforts at collusion.
"It is very hard to second-guess him," Professor Elhauge said, "and it is going to be very hard for an appeals court to second-guess him" on his factual findings. If those findings are accepted, Professor Elhauge said, the conclusion to order a breakup appears "entirely sensible" under legal precedents. Lesser remedies like orders to monopoly companies to cease abusive tactics have proved difficult to police, he said.
Several experts said one of Judge Jackson's legally risky decisions was his treatment of Microsoft's Windows operating system and its Web browser as two separate products that it had illegally tied together.
Under antitrust rules, a company that has a dominant product, like a salt-packing machine in an early case, cannot take advantage of its dominance by requiring customers to buy another product, like raw salt, to get the popular product.
But if, as Microsoft urged, its Web browser should more correctly have been viewed as an innovation that enhanced Windows, portions of Judge Jackson's ruling might be vulnerable on appeal. It was on that issue that the federal appeals court in Washington overruled Judge Jackson in an earlier phase of the company's battle with the government.
Eben Moglen, a professor at Columbia Law School, said the decision that Windows and the browser were two products illegally tied together could be vulnerable in an appeal. But even on that subject, Professor Moglen said, Judge Jackson made extensive efforts to portray his approach as consistent with the law.
"He was as orthodox on antitrust issues as he could possibly be," Professor Moglen said, adding that he thought Judge Jackson had worked to try to protect the decisions from being overturned.
Several of the legal experts said yesterday that they saw little support for Microsoft's suggestion that the judge was relying on antitrust concepts that are out of step with the fast-moving computer business.
They said that the computer age might require adjustments to some antitrust concepts, like the question of whether an operating system and a Web browser are really separate products. But, some of them said, evidence of intimidation or efforts at collusion are the heart of the legal system's effort to keep commercial markets competitive.
Professor Elhauge of Harvard said the company's sense that it was the victim of an injustice was a familiar defense. "Every industry, as it is growing," he said, "seems surprised that the antitrust law applies to it."

HEADLINE: Panama Still Failing to Stem Narcotics Traffic, U.S. Report Asserts

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: MIAMI, June 8

 BODY:
The Panamanian government has made little progress this year in its fight against drug trafficking and money laundering, according to a United States Customs intelligence report.
The report, which is expected to be discussed at a Congressional hearing on Friday, said Panama continued to be a major transshipment point for cocaine and increasingly for heroin, which are smuggled through weakly patrolled borders and ports. The reported noted that in 1999 drug seizures declined 80 percent from 1998 and no major drug arrests were made. 
 A preliminary version of the report, which was provided to a House subcommittee on criminal justice and drug policy, originally had harsh words for Panama's law enforcement agencies, saying they were "corrupt and ill trained" and "overwhelmed" by drug traffickers. The final version softened that criticism, saying they faced "difficulties dealing with sophisticated trafficking organizations."
The report said that Panama's sprawling Colon Free Trade Zone was used by traffickers not only to hide drugs in cargo containers but also to launder profits. It cited serious security problems at Tocumen International Airport, where there have been allegations that cargo and ramp workers are helping to move drug shipments.
Customs officials would not comment on the report, which they said was classified.
Nevertheless, the report's observations are sure to be used by Congressional critics and others who have expressed grave concerns about Panama's inability to secure its border with Colombia less than six months after the United States withdrew all its troops.
"The situation in Panama has taken a dramatic turn for the worse," said Representative John L. Mica, a Florida Republican who is the subcommittee chairman. "The information we have is pretty damaging, especially since the United States exited six months ago."
With increased unrest and violence in Colombia, more traffickers have been seeking a safe haven in Panama. At the same time, the country's lax banking laws and dollar economy have proved as much of a lure to them as the high-rise buildings they have settled into.
"It's not all about drugs," a diplomat said. "The country is built on dodging taxes, dodging bizarre exchange rates and evading court settlements." He added, "The narcos have grafted right on." As a result, the diplomat said, efforts to crack down on money laundering have been unsuccessful.
"Basically, about the entire economic elite of this country is involved in some form of money laundering, and the government is not going to crack down on that," he said. "Money is a morally neutral item in this country. It does not matter where it comes from."
Part of the problem has been that the government of President Mireya Moscoso assumed power only last September and is still feeling its way. Some critics have faulted her for not having enough of a vision for the country's future and say that she has been more preoccupied with petty politics and deciding which supporters get which government posts.
At the same time, her government has been ambivalent about what kind of relationship it wants with the United States after nearly a century of American influence on Panamanian affairs. It is also about to sign a long-awaited national security plan that will, for the first time, outline its strategy for securing its borders and the canal.

HEADLINE: Behind a Solemn Rite for Obuchi, a Burst of Politicking

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 8

 BODY:
Japan's late prime minister, Keizo Obuchi, was remembered today in a solemn state service marked by emotional eulogies, cannonades, a parading honor guard in crisp white uniforms, and thousands of dark-suited mourners, including President Clinton.
The service for Mr. Obuchi, who died on May 14, six weeks after having suffered a stroke, began under a hot and brilliant sky with a long slow procession into the large hall. The ceremony was held by Mr. Obuchi's wife, Chizuko, and their 28-year-old son, Takeshi, who bore a white box containing his father's ashes. 
 With members of the imperial family and dignitaries from 170 countries in the hall, where a huge portrait of Mr. Obuchi hung against an illuminated powder blue background, his successor, Yoshiro Mori, remembered his friend and ally.
"I am anguished to think how deeply disappointed Mr. Obuchi must have been to have had to retire from the arena of action, felled by an unforeseen illness," Mr. Mori said. "In this moment of bereavement, I can do no more than express my heartfelt gratitude to former Prime Minister Obuchi for dedicating his all to this nation."
For all of the sobriety of the occasion, what was occurring offstage both before and after the ceremony was a burst of political activity and diplomacy of great significance for Japan's immediate future, and for the future of this region.
Mr. Mori, for one, finally had a setting in which he could enjoy the statesman's attributes of his office. And with elections scheduled for June 25, Mr. Mori's huddles with Mr. Clinton, President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea and senior Chinese and Russian officials provided welcome relief from the cycle of provocative blunders and tortured semiretractions that have cut deeply into the prime minister's popularity ratings.
Eager for a lift, Mr. Mori's aides made much of the meetings with Mr. Clinton; Mr. Kim; the leaders of Australia, Indonesia and Thailand; and high-ranking officials from other countries. In all, Mr. Mori and Foreign Minister Yohei Kono had talks with 33 countries in two days.
After Mr. Clinton had met Mr. Mori and Mr. Kim, his aides praised Seoul for taking the initiative in engaging its northern neighbor and hinted strongly at a relaxation of American economic sanctions against Pyongyang, many of which have been in place since the end of the Korean War. "I would expect we would have an announcement on that very soon," a spokesman for the White House, P. J. Crowley, said.
The administration had often expressed frustration with Mr. Obuchi and his government over the slow pace of reform to lift Japan out of its decadelong slump. But on this occasion, Mr. Clinton offered praise, saying history would regard Mr. Obuchi as someone who "rose to the challenge with courage and confidence."
Mr. Clinton did hint at new frustrations with Japan. Foreign Ministry officials said the president had raised, among other issues, the question of high international telephone-connection fees imposed by the national carrier, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, which Washington sees as an unfair barrier to competition.
Western diplomats said Mr. Clinton's decision to attend the service -- flying a roundtrip total of 26 hours for an eight-hour stay -- and his strong praise for Mr. Obuchi should be seen in the context of the "unusually strong alliance" that links the two countries and the steady support that Japan has provided for American foreign policy.
The timing of the service, three weeks after Mr. Obuchi's cremation, was itself mired in politics. It was widely reported that the service was held as close as decently possibly to the elections to guarantee a large "sympathy vote" and help the long-ruling Liberal Democratic Party.
Since the date was announced, a string of unusually blunt nationalist statements by Mr. Mori, whose description of Japan as a "divine country with an emperor at its center" evoked imperialist prewar propaganda, undermined support for the government in the polls. Now the election promises to be a referendum on Mr. Mori rather than a commemoration of Mr. Obuchi.
Mr. Mori's time in office has been unusually troubled. Opposition leaders and editorialists have poked holes into the sometimes contradictory official explanations of how power was secretively passed from the stricken Mr. Obuchi to a brief caretaker prime minister and, finally, to Mr. Mori.

HEADLINE: Procter & Gamble Shake-Up Follows Poor Profit Outlook

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The chief executive of Procter & Gamble, the consumer products giant, resigned yesterday as the company announced it would suffer another disappointing quarter and its stock price fell to less than half of what it was worth just four months ago.
With the move, Procter acknowledged that it had tried to remake itself into a more aggressive company too rapidly and that its core brands, which include Crest, Pringles and Tide, had suffered as it focused on developing new products. 
 Procter's board immediately named Alan G. Lafley, a 23-year employee of the company, to succeed Durk I. Jager, the hard-charging executive who had vowed to shake up the company's staid culture and force managers to act in a more entrepreneurial style. It also called John E. Pepper, Mr. Jager's predecessor and longtime rival, out of retirement to serve as chairman.
"In hindsight, it's clear we changed too much too fast," said Mr. Lafley, 52, who was a president overseeing the company's beauty-care products and its North American operations. The cost has been steep: Procter has lost $75 billion in market value since January.
At a time when many executives are saying they want their corporations to act like small, entrepreneurial companies, largely in response to the growth of Internet commerce, Procter's struggles indicate just how difficult a successful transformation is.
Under Mr. Jager, 57, the company tried to bolster a mediocre growth rate by developing products more quickly, eschewing the many-layered approval processes and market tests for which the conservative company was famous. Mr. Jager also moved many managers to new jobs to shake up a corporate culture in which employees are called Proctoids because of their efficiency and obedience.
The initiatives have led to some success -- like Swiffer, a floor-cleaning cloth -- but the price has been too high, the company said yesterday. Costs have risen almost as fast as sales, and the money Procter spent on its initiatives left less to spend on the marketing of its largest businesses.
Earnings per share for the company's fourth quarter, which ends June 30, will be about the same as a year earlier, rather than 15 to 17 percent higher, as the company had estimated. For the fiscal year, Procter is now likely to earn $4.23 billion before one-time charges, up only slightly from $4.15 billion last year, according to Prudential Securities.
Shares of Procter fell $6.125, to $56.75.
In a conference call with analysts, investors and reporters, Mr. Lafley said he would spend the next six weeks studying Procter's spending to decide which efforts should continue to receive their current levels of investment. "We will make tougher choices," said Mr. Lafley.
Although neither he nor Mr. Pepper criticized Mr. Jager by name, they bluntly repudiated the pace with which he had tried to change the $38 billion company. The company moved executives between divisions too rapidly, they said, and it adopted new financial measures that turned out to be too optimistic. Speed, Mr. Lafley said, "is not a substitute for good business sense."
"What we thought would take about a year to complete is clearly going to take at least a year longer," he said.
As a result, many of Procter's most important brands have underperformed products made by rivals like Kimberly-Clark and PepsiCo's Frito-Lay. Crest, for example, has lost market share to Colgate and Aquafresh as Procter managers have been slow to respond to consumers' growing appetite for toothpastes that promise to do more than simply clean teeth. In the 52 weeks that ended April 23, Crest's sales grew 1.3 percent while overall toothpaste sales increased more than 3 percent, according to Information Resources, a Chicago company that tracks supermarkets, drugstores and larger retailers like Wal-Mart.
Tide is underperforming its rivals in the liquid-detergent aisle. The growth rate of Charmin toilet paper is trailing those of Quilted Northern and Kleenex Cottonelle. Zest, Ivory and Oil of Olay soaps have all lost market share over the last year. And Pringles has fallen further behind Frito Lay's best-selling potato chips, according to Information Resources.
"The focus all went to speeding new products to market," said Timothy M. Ghriskey, a senior portfolio manager at the Dreyfus Corporation, which owns shares in the company.
It was the earnings shortfall -- a result of slower-than-expected sales -- that led to the resignation of Mr. Jager, a native of the Netherlands who took over the chief executive's post 17 months ago. Mr. Pepper, 61, who is more popular among employees but also considered less aggressive, originally beat out Mr. Jager for the chairman's job in 1995 only to cede it to him last year after a disappointing and abbreviated term.
In January, newspapers reported that Mr. Jager was considering buying the drugmakers American Home Products and Warner-Lambert in an effort to vastly enlarge Procter's small pharmaceutical division. Investors thought the idea too ambitious and Procter's stock fell more than 10 percent, causing Mr. Jager to abandon his plan reluctantly. Mr. Jager also made overtures to buy Gillette.
In March, Procter warned that its third-quarter profit would be smaller than expected, and shares fell another 30 percent.
Yesterday's news brought the shares down to their 1997 level in what is by far the largest drop over the last two decades for the widely held stock. The decline is likely to aggravate morale problems at the company's Cincinnati headquarters because of the large portion of employee retirement savings that the company puts into its own stock.
The announcement also offers the latest evidence of the struggles that consumer-product companies are experiencing despite the longest economic expansion in United States history. Companies like Coca-Cola and Gillette have been able to push through only moderate price increases, if any. Consumers have refused to pay more for staple goods, and retailers led by Wal-Mart have gained more power through their growing size. At the same time, economic troubles in Asia and Latin America hurt sales in recent years, and the current weakness of the euro has dampened profits in Europe. The rise in oil and paper costs have not helped, either.
Although Mr. Jager said in a statement that the decision to resign was his, analysts said it was yet another example of the small margin of error that chief executives have at a time when the volatile stock market punishes companies that surprise it with bad news.
This year, the top executives at Coca-Cola, Mattel and Xerox have left after producing disappointing results. "The capital market is taking its vengeance on those who do not get great numbers," said Michael Useem, a professor of management at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. "And directors are much more inclined just to pull the switch."
Mr. Lafley graduated from Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., and Harvard Business School, and his only full-time job outside of Procter was in the Navy. He is personable and energetic, said Sally J. Dessloch, a vice president at J. P. Morgan Securities, and has a reputation for doing a good job of motivating employees. Other analysts said his style was closer to Mr. Pepper's than to Mr. Jager's.

HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MIRCROSOFT: THE VIEW ABROAD;
A Muted Reaction of Admiration and Disbelief

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, June 8

 BODY:
Windows and Word may be ubiquitous across Europe and Asia, but news of the court order to break up Microsoft generated a muted reaction outside of the United States today.
There was a sense of admiration -- mixed with disbelief -- among many commentators that a government would take such a step. Neither Europe nor Japan have ever seen a comparable effort to break up a large company, though European regulators have become much more aggressive about imposing big fines on companies for anticompetitive activities. 
 "The breakup of a company is impossible under German law," said Stefan Siebert, a spokesman for Germany's cartel office in Bonn. "All we can do is prohibit abuses and impose fines."
In Rome, La Republica captured the sense that the breakup was something that could happen only in the United States.
"A Washington judge with the deceptively good-natured image of a western actor has with almost hate-filled words ordered the breakup of Microsoft into two separate parts," the newspaper said in an editorial today. "The century of the New Economy begins exactly where that of the old economy began: with an America that breaks up the monopoly of the 'new oil.' "
Mario Monti, head of the European Commission's competition ministry, said through a spokeswoman today that he "congratulates" the United States government for its work but said it was too early to know whether the court order would affect European investigations into Microsoft.
Mr. Monti has raised questions about the Windows 2000 operating system, suggesting that it may hinder the abilities of computers linked over networks and over the Internet.
His office is also scrutinizing Microsoft's plan to acquire 29.7 percent of Telewest Communications P.L.C., the British cable television operator. Microsoft has teamed up with the Liberty Media Group to buy a controlling stake in Telewest from the Media One Corporation.
"We understand that there will be an appeal," said Amelia Torres, a spokeswoman for the competition ministry. "We will have to see what the final ruling is."
Though most European software companies said they would not be affected by the Microsoft case, several welcomed the order.
"We welcome the recognition that monopolies have never been successful or sensible," said Reiner Jung, a spokesman for Brokat Infosystems A.G. of Stuttgart, a fast-growing developer of encryption programs and other software used in online banking systems. "That doesn't mean we want a weaker Microsoft," he added. "Quite the contrary, we want a strong Microsoft. But what we don't want is a monopoly."
Suse A.G., in Nurenberg, which produces software that runs on the Linux operating system, a competitor to Windows, argued that a court-ordered breakup of Microsoft might do little to break the Windows monopoly unless the company makes its code available to rivals.
"Microsoft will have the ability after the breakup of making available applications for other platforms," said Carsten Fischer, a spokesman for Suse. "But Microsoft has to adhere to the rules of open-source software, which includes opening up its documentation."
The biggest effect of the Microsoft case in Europe could prove to be on its many alliances and partnerships. Microsoft has struck technology deals with scores of European media and telecommunications companies, and it sought to invest in both cable television and wireless networks.
Microsoft officials say their goal is a foothold in new media, from interactive digital television to advanced wireless data communications.
For the moment, companies involved with Microsoft are waiting to see what happens. "We have consistently made it clear that we welcome Microsoft as a potential corporate shareholder, and that remains our position," said Rachel Turner, a spokeswoman for Telewest.

HEADLINE: Teenage Mother Accused of Throwing Baby in River Was Depressed, Lawyer Says

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: PATERSON, N.J., June 8

 BODY:
A lawyer for a 17-year-old mother charged with throwing her baby into the Passaic River Saturday night said today that she had been forced to leave home two years ago and was recently depressed and suffering from memory lapses.
"I think this is a very troubled young lady," the lawyer, Anthony Fusco, said after a brief court hearing on the charge that his client murdered her 16-month-old son. "What's going on in her mind right now, God only knows. I'm not so sure even she knows why she did this." 
 During the hearing, in the family division of State Superior Court, Mr. Fusco conceded that the woman, whose name was not released because of her age, told Paterson detectives early Monday that she had dropped the baby into the river from a footbridge. In a move that blocked prosecutors from discussing the statement that she gave the police in open court, Mr. Fusco waived his client's legal right to learn about evidence supporting the murder charge during the hearing. He also received permission from the presiding judge, Nestor Guzman, for a psychiatric examination of the mother.
Later, outside of court, Mr. Fusco said he would consider an insanity defense if the Passaic County prosecutor attempted to try the teenager as an adult. An assistant Passaic County prosecutor, Lisa Verlardi, told the judge that her office was considering trying the mother as an adult.
Mr. Fusco's portrayal of the young woman's life today was less positive than the account her cousin gave on Wednesday.
Mr. Fusco said that the woman's life had been stormy. Her parents are divorced and her mother is being treated for severe schizophrenia, he said. In the spring of 1998, about the time she became pregnant with the baby she is accused of killing, she was told to leave home, Mr. Fusco said. He declined to explain why, but said the pregnancy was not the reason. Later, the teenager's sister became her legal guardian, and she moved in with an aunt and her cousin Wanda Cruz, he said.
The woman dropped out of high school in November 1998, two months before her son was born. She and the father of the child, who never married, dated for several months after the baby's birth, Ms. Cruz said Wednesday. In recent months, she had begun evening classes in hopes of receiving a high school equivalency diploma and becoming a nurse's aide, she added.
Former co-workers at a department store in Wayne said the woman left a sales clerk job about two months ago to take a higher-paying office job, but Mr. Fusco said she was unemployed in recent months and had been depressed, with mood swings that had become more severe. "She can remember certain things, but she doesn't remember a lot of things," he said.
He scoffed at prosecutors' accusation that she threw the baby into the river because she wanted to visit a new boyfriend and was unable to find a baby sitter.
"There certainly were people who were available for that," he said.
An autopsy determined today that the baby, named Anthony, died of asphyxiation by drowning, said Boris Moczula, first assistant Passaic County prosecutor.
Mr. Fusco said he told the woman this morning that the baby's body had been found on Wednesday, about three miles downstream from the footbridge.
"Her color in her face just left it," he said. "It was instant tears."

HEADLINE: Bank Puts Its Money, and Its Name, on Staten Island Ballpark

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
A Staten Island bank is giving its name -- and $400,000 a year for at least nine years -- to the new stadium that will house the Staten Island Yankees.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, at the stadium's groundbreaking yesterday, said money from the bank, Richmond County Bank, would be shared by the city, which will own the stadium, and the Yankees. In exchange, Mr. Giuliani said, the stadium will be known as the Richmond County Bank Ballpark at St. George. 
 The city has agreed to spend $71 million for parking, roads, shoreline reinforcement and the stadium itself, which is expected to be ready for opening day in 2001.
Yesterday's ceremony on Staten Island, coming at a time when the city has also begun construction of a minor league stadium for the Mets along the Coney Island Boardwalk, provoked fresh criticism from financial analysts. Even though critics could be expected to welcome any private money for the project, the bank agreement hardly muted arguments that the city's investment is excessive, particularly in support of minor league teams.
"There is no reason to believe a city's investment in a stadium will pay for itself in terms of economic development or tax revenues," said Ronnie Lowenstein, chief economist for the Independent Budget Office, a nonpartisan fiscal watchdog group. She said the best that could be hoped was that stadium projects "shift economic activity across neighborhoods," perhaps benefiting the long-neglected neighborhoods of Coney Island and St. George.
The city has projected that the Coney Island stadium, like the one on Staten Island, will be ready to open next year.
Mr. Giuliani said that the Staten Island project had already increased real estate values in the St. George neighborhood, as investors and retail businesses moved in.
"I am singing with joy," said Guy V. Molinari, the borough president. Mr. Molinari criticized City Hall through much of the 1980's for neglecting Staten Island in economic development projects, but he now finds his borough, and particularly St. George, among the city's biggest recipients of public projects.
The city has budgeted $81 million to renovate the St. George Ferry Terminal and $20 million for a new National Lighthouse Museum, on land just east of the terminal.
The team's general manager, Jeff Dumas, said yesterday that the sale of naming rights for the stadium was included in an agreement in which the city and the Yankees would split the $400,000 a year pledged by the bank, but he added that the bank's payments could rise in the future on the basis of factors like attendance and advertising.
For use of the stadium, the Yankees have agreed to a 20-year lease, with yearly payments of up to $510,000, based on attendance.

HEADLINE: Lights, Camera, Streaming Video;
Traditional Hollywood Exploring Dot-Com Entertainment

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 8

 BODY:
Mika Salmi says that he is always a little cautious when venturing into the wilds of Hollywood from his Atomfilms home base in Seattle.
"It's very fast in Hollywood," said Mr. Salmi, whose company produces short films on the Internet and sells them to outlets like airlines and shopping malls. "People are always coming to us, trying to buy us. We're not anti-Hollywood. The key is just not to get caught by them." 
 Over the last year or so, the once separate and distinct worlds of old-line Hollywood and the dot-coms of the new economy have been intermingling with increasing urgency, taking their first faltering steps toward the coming age of digital entertainment, whatever that might turn out to be. While the major studios, conservative as always, are largely maintaining a discreet distance from the roiling waters of the Web, many entertainment executives, filmmakers, celebrities and talent agencies have been plunging head-first into the digital deep end.
Hardly a week passes without the announcement of a new actor or director signing a deal with a dot-com to create exclusive digital films, or of a Hollywood insider proclaiming the acquisition or creation of a new venture.
"You have so many people in Hollywood who know so much about their business that they convince themselves that they know about every business," said David Wertheimer, chairman of WireBreak.com, which emphasizes interactive entertainment on its Web site. "They look at what's on the Web and they say, 'Hey, I can make better videos. I'll start my own dot-com.' They see so much attention and so much money going to these Internet guys and they think, 'Who's that pimply faced guy on the cover of Time Magazine? That's supposed to be me.' "
Hollywood has had to dodge or absorb a steady stream of challenges over the decades, from sound to color to television to videocassettes to independent films. Each one was predicted, at the time, to be the movie establishment's undoing. Yet each time, Hollywood not only persevered, but, eventually, overcame the threat. Now, while that may well happen again, many are wondering whether the hidebound studios have finally found an adversary they will be unable to dominate.
To Joe Roth -- a longtime movie executive who left the top job at Walt Disney Studios last year to start the just-introduced Revolution Studios, an independent production company, and who is also involved in two Internet ventures -- the issue is just that stark. "When all of this resolves itself," he asks, "who will be occupying the top tier?"
In other words, will the entertainment conglomerates own the dot-coms or -- as in the case of the America Online acquisition of Time Warner -- will the dot-coms own the entertainment conglomerates?
"I think this is definitely a time of confusion and opportunity," said Larry Kasanoff, a longtime feature-film producer whose Threshold Entertainment includes a dot-com operation aimed at attracting young males with a combination of sophomoric sitcoms, video-game sagas and models in bikinis. "Is this period going to be long enough that a bunch of dot-com start-ups will have time to get established? I don't know. I think, five years from now, we'll look back and a lot of these dot-coms will have been absorbed by the big studios. Others will have been able to use this confusion time to take their place in the landscape. We intend to be one of those."
The new entertainment dot-coms fall into a number of categories. Some offer so-called streaming video, usually live-action and animated shorts on the Internet, with a smattering of games and chat rooms and varying degrees of interactivity. Others are more business-to-business sites, connecting filmmakers with agents, with projects or with each other. Some are digital laboratories, aiming for a niche audience and, through the success or failure of their programming, providing an incubator for future movie and television projects. And many are just flat-out marketing tools, dedicated to the glories of a particular film or image-conscious celebrity.
As might be expected in a business where celebrity is the hottest commodity, many of the Hollywood dot-coms have been trying to outdo one another by signing up major actors and filmmakers. Shockwave.com, which creates Web-based animation software as well as maintaining its own destination site, has signed deals with filmmakers like James Brooks and David Lynch. Z.com, among whose backers is the manager turned mogul Brad Grey of Basic Entertainment, has signed deals with the producer Jerry Bruckheimer and the director Oliver Stone. And there are dozens of others.
The invasion of the dot-coms has been, as far as Hollywood is concerned, a relatively recent phenomenon. "If you look back to early 1999, there were maybe six or seven Internet sites offering streaming video in one form or another," said Rick Hess, president of Propaganda Films, which makes theatrical features as well as digital entertainment for the Web. "Today, there are maybe 75, and that number is going up. But everyone figures that, down the road, when the dust settles, there will only be maybe a dozen of them left."
Those in the Hollywood mainstream who have been counseling caution feel somewhat vindicated by the failure of recent Internet initial public offerings, and the precipitous drop in high-tech stock prices. And few can contain their delight at the collapse, last month, of one of the highest-profile of the entertainment dot-coms, the Digital Entertainment Network, even though its financial troubles were largely attributed to its profligate spending rather than to a flaw in the overall strategy of streaming video over the Internet.
No one in Hollywood expects that the venture will be the last entertainment dot-com to fail, and much of the discussion in recent weeks has been about which will go next.
"I've detected a real change," Mr. Wertheimer said, as people have reacted to the one-two punch of the Nasdaq plummet in April and the collapse of the DEN. Many of the players who were poised to jump into the dot-com waters have decided to pull back, or wait a little longer, he said, and some of those who are already in up to their eyeballs are getting a lot more cautious.
"I think that this may turn out to be Hollywood's Vietnam, with a lot of people rushing into this without a clear idea of why they're getting in," Mr. Wertheimer said. "We're going to see a lot of people retreating and declaring victory."
Handicapping the field has been particularly difficult, in part because there is no clear picture of where this is all headed and because so many of these new entertainment dot-coms have shifted their strategies in recent months in the face of rapidly changing technologies, increased competition and growing investor nervousness.
Ifilm, initially based in San Francisco and one of the early leaders, began as a site where filmmakers could post their digital shorts and try to find an audience. Now, it is based in Los Angeles and offers not only its own stable of shorts but also serves as a portal with easy-click access to digital entertainment all over the Web.
Pop.com, an Internet partnership between Steven Spielberg and Jeffrey Katzenberg of DreamWorks and Ron Howard and Brian Grazer of Imagine Entertainment, was announced with a lot of fanfare last October as a site that would be up and running this spring, offering original short "pops" of entertainment featuring some of Hollywood's top performers and filmmakers. But Pop.com is still not online and there are reports that its principals are retooling their Internet strategy.
When this wave of dot-coms took off, much of the initial momentum was toward building so-called destination sites, aimed at grabbing and holding an audience, preferably the 12-to-24-year-old males who drive so much of popular entertainment. Now, however, with a lot of destinations but with a scarcity of things to watch there, many of the new start-ups and some of the older ones have turned their attention elsewhere. Several companies have announced, or intend to announce soon, that they will spend more time and energy on creating content for others' sites than for themselves.
No one has a real clue where all this will end. "We are in the middle, right now, of speeding toward some future unknown environment," said Morgan Rector, president of the Imperial Bank Entertainment Group, one of the financial institutions most active in underwriting feature films.
The Hollywood establishment is worried that with the Internet offering the promise of new ways to distribute movies while also competing for eyeballs and entertainment dollars, the new order might well upset longstanding financial arrangements. And, just as significantly, there are worries that what has happened to the pop music business -- with songs being swapped and pirated on the Internet beyond the reach of record company accountants -- will happen with movies, too, if firm protections are not put in place fast.
The dot-coms, meanwhile, worry about being transformed into just another division of a profit-hungry global media conglomerate that will prevent them from expanding and exploding outdated entertainment concepts. "They always said that Hollywood runs on fear and greed, and it's definitely true," Mr. Salmi said. "The greed kicks in when they look at all the dot-com millions. The fear is, 'Oh my gosh, we'd better act quickly or we'll miss something big.' "
To some, there is a bit of a lemming-like quality to the way so many independent producers and former studio bosses have announced the formation of their own start-ups, as though having a dot-com in your roster of in-house activities is now as essential as getting the best table at Spago or the Grill.
"In a way, it's like, if you don't have that as part of your dialogue over lunch at the Grill, then you're not with it," Mr. Hess said.
Hollywood is meeting the dot-coms in a variety of ways. Each of the major studios has its own in-house Web operation. Some, like Warner Brothers Entertaindom.com or Sony's Station.com offer original entertainment and games. Others, however, are simply marketing devices for coming releases.
But the heavy action has been in Internet start-up companies.
Mr. Roth, for instance, has hired John Hegeman, one of the people responsible for the successful "Blair Witch Project" Internet marketing campaign, to create Distantcorners.com, a site specializing in horror and science fiction. And he bought a substantial interest in Mediatrip.com, which his Revolution Studios intends to use as a marketing tool for his feature films and as an incubator for new characters and offbeat stories.
Robert Cooper, former head of production at DreamWorks, recently announced the creation of a new Internet start-up, which will be aimed at creating digital content for a variety of Web sites.
Indeed, in interviews with more than a dozen top entertainment executives, every one had either started his own dot-com, bought an interest in somebody else's, or claimed he was just waiting for the perfect moment to announce a new dot-com strategy.
There is more here, they all insisted, than smoke and mirrors. "I believe it," Mr. Cooper said. "I'm betting my money on it."

HEADLINE: A Pattern of Unsolved Greek Terrorism Cases

BYLINE: By JAMES RISEN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
The killing of a British diplomat in Athens today came in the midst of a growing debate in Washington over Greece's record in curbing anti-Western terrorism within its borders.
Only on Monday, a bipartisan American commission on terrorism recommended that the Clinton administration consider imposing sanctions on Greece for failing to fully cooperate with the United States in combatting terrorism. 
 Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright quickly dismissed the call for sanctions, yet officials throughout Washington expressed frustration with Greece's continued failure to solve terrorism cases, particularly actions directed at Americans.
The failure of Greek authorities to solve anti-American terrorism cases over a 25-year period has turned the group called November 17 into one of the most mysterious and most successful terrorist groups in the world.
American and Greek officials do not even know the names of the group's leaders.
Since 1975, four American officials have been killed in Greece, but no arrests have been made in any of the killings.
Greece is "one of the weakest links in Europe," the State Department's latest annual report on terrorism observed. With 20 acts of violence last year against United States government and other American targets, both people and property, Greece was second in the world, after Colombia, in the number of anti-American terrorist attacks.
"The absence of strong public government leadership contributed to the lack of breakthroughs against terrorists" in Greece, the State Department said in its annual terrorist report. "Popular opinion makers generally downplayed terrorism as a threat to public order."
November 17, the group believed to be responsible for today's killing, is the same Marxist cell that officials believe is behind a string of unsolved murders of American diplomats in the country. The group announced its existence with the 1975 killing of Richard Welch, the Central Intelligence Agency's Athens station chief. The group's name refers to Nov. 17, 1973, when dozens of demonstrators were killed as the Greek Army suppressed a student protest in Athens.
The United States was a supporter of Greece's ruling junta, and American diplomats have been prime targets of the group ever since. Among the worst incidents were the 1983 killings of George Tsantes, an American naval officer and his chauffeur, and the 1988 murder of an American military attache, William E. Nordeen.
The lack of progress by investigators has led to a perception among American officials, and even within Greece, that Greek officials have turned a blind eye to November 17's activities.
"I believe that there are people throughout the U.S. counterterrorism community who are convinced that there are some Greek officials who over the last quarter century have had important information on 17 November and have not acted on it or shared it with us," said one former senior United States government official.
But a former American intelligence official who served in Greece and investigated November 17 said the idea of a link between the group and the Greek government is a myth.
"The real story is just that the Greek police are inept," he said. "They are just incredibly sloppy."
The police failures have led the terrorists to taunt the authorities.
The November 17 attackers have used the same .45-caliber pistol in most of its killings dating all the way back to Mr. Welch, switching only briefly to a 9-millimeter in a few incidents.

HEADLINE: Death Toll in Congo's 2-Year War Is at Least 1.7 Million, Study Says

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 8

 BODY:
Two years of war have caused the deaths of more than 1.7 million people in eastern Congo, where people who manage to flee the fighting often die of hunger and malaria while hiding in impenetrable forests, a leading refugee agency said today.
This means that about four times as many people have died in the area since August 1998 as would be expected under normal conditions, according to a study released by the agency, the International Rescue Committee in New York. 
 Although the expected death toll in the five-province area of 18 million people would be 600,000, the actual number was 2.3 million. Of the 1.7 million additional deaths reported in the survey, 200,000 were caused by acts of violence, whereas the rest were attributed to the war-related collapse of health services and food supplies.
"Men with guns come and wreak havoc on a very regular basis," said Les Roberts, an epidemiologist at the Johns Hopkins University, who supervised the study for the agency. "Those men cause more death by making people flee their homes than actually by shooting or slitting throats.
"People flee into the forest when a village is attacked, often at night. If they get a little sick and they are not eating, they often die. One girl told us how she fled her village at night with her family of eight. Five of the eight died as they hid in the forest."
The survey was conducted in April and May, with random samplings of houses in and around Moba, in Katanga Province; Kabare, Katana and Kolonge in South Kivu; and Kisangani in Orientale Province. Researchers asked residents questions like how many people were in the family, whether anyone had died since last Christmas, a major holiday among the many Roman Catholics in the region, and how many died last year.
The Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, where Mr. Roberts formerly worked, provided baseline statistics for sub-Sahara Africa. The results from the region, with a population of 1.2 million, were extrapolated to the interior regions and neighboring provinces.
"We have done what scientists hate to do, extrapolate from 1.2 million people to 18 million people," Mr. Roberts said. "But have very consistently made conservative assumptions. I think we have protected ourselves from the criticisms that we are being extremists or hyperbolic."
When he finished his survey, Mr. Roberts asked the United Nations relief assistance coordinator for the area and a representative of the United States Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance in the region to look over his findings. They thought that he might have been conservative, Mr. Roberts recounted.
Everywhere he and his team found abandoned health clinics, local economies in shatters and families struggling without the subsistence agriculture or barter systems that had sustained them, he said. Children younger than 5, the study said, account for more than one-third of the excess deaths in eastern Congo, an area disrupted since 1994 by waves of ethnic and civil wars, sometimes indistinguishable from armed scrambles for gold and diamonds.
Rwanda and Uganda sent troops into Congo, the former Zaire, in August 1998 in support of rebels opposed to the government of President Laurent Kabila. Last summer, Rwandan and Ugandan troops turned on each other, and they have been fighting each other this week around a diamond center, Kisangani, adding at least 50 additional civilian deaths to the toll.
Today, Secretary General Kofi Annan spoke with Presidents Paul Kagame of Rwanda and Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, and he was assured that a cease-fire, not the first in recent weeks, went into effect this afternoon. But hours later, Ugandan and Rwandan troops were fighting in Kisangani, Reuters reported.
Jean-David Levitte, the French ambassador to the United Nations and the president of the Security Council this month, said the council members "deplore the loss of life and the damage inflicted by the forces of Uganda and Rwanda on the Congolese population."
In the International Rescue Committee report, Kisangani had been found to be one of the brighter spots in an extremely bleak picture of life in one of Africa's potentially richest countries. The United Nations had hoped to make the city a neutral site where a large contingent of peacekeeping troops could be based and political negotiations begun to end the Congo war.
The study found that eastern Congo has become "an unchecked incubation zone for disease."
Mr. Roberts said malaria and diarrheal diseases, including cholera, appeared to be the leading causes of death, although meningitis and suspected cases of polio were also found.
Because blood transfusions are often needed for malaria victims, he said, "my strong gut feeling is that the prevalence of H.I.V. has increased."
H.I.V., which causes AIDS, and other deadly viruses are known to have flourished in Congo. "Congo has something like the 14th highest death rate on the planet," Mr. Roberts said. Most of the other 13 countries are in sub-Sahara Africa.
"There has been no blood tested in this region since 1998," he added.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN C.E.O. -- A special report.;
Gore Dots the i's That Bush Leaves to Others

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
The vice president just was not satisfied. A team of graphic artists had labored to come up with a logo to emblazon on Al Gore's campaign buttons, bumper stickers and placards, but he felt they had failed to capture the right spirit. So he sketched an alternative, a swoosh and a star -- a simple, futuristic look with the words, "Gore 2000."
"I took several of the suggested designs and kind of recombined them and added a different approach," Mr. Gore said. "I sat down and drew that on the table with the people who had made suggestions." 
 It never occurred to Gov. George W. Bush to do that. When his staff presented him with a proposal for a blocky, traditional logo featuring an American flag and the words, "George W. Bush For President," his response was to the point.
"I just looked at it and said, 'It looks good,' " Mr. Bush recalled.
It may seem like a small thing, but Mr. Gore's keen interest in the signature of his campaign and Mr. Bush's admitted lack of interest perfectly capture the stark differences in how they are running for president.
Mr. Gore's fingerprints are on every major move or pronouncement. He prides himself on making decisions based on his judgment, built on nearly 8 years in the White House and 16 years in Congress, and not on the views of his advisers.
The vice president immerses himself in policy, and often even in logistical matters. Recently, when he was in a rush to travel from New York to Washington, Mr. Gore announced that he was scuttling Air Force Two because he would make better time on the US Airways shuttle. His stunned military and Secret Service aides knew not to try to talk him out of it.
Mr. Bush, by contrast, is far more removed from specifics. He prefers to surround himself with people he trusts. Once he feels comfortable that they understand his philosophy, he leaves them to come up with proposals for him to sign off on. Notably, it was Mr. Bush's aides, not the candidate, who plotted a course of action when the campaign was in crisis after Mr. Bush lost the New Hampshire primary.
The unmistakable contrasts in how Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore make decisions, handle pressure and relate to their advisers offer revealing insights into how they would run their presidencies. In extensive interviews, officials from both campaigns sought to play up anecdotes that showed that their candidate would operate most effectively in the Oval Office.
Mr. Gore's supporters say his impressive knowledge base allows him to comfortably make informed decisions. Mr. Bush's backers argue that his lower level of engagement is a virtue because the governor is not burdened by needless detail.
Still, it is possible to move beyond the campaigns' spin to see striking differences in the candidates' approaches.
Mr. Gore bases his decisions on devouring information and reaching a reasoned conclusion; Mr. Bush operates more on gut instinct. Mr. Gore often lectures his advisers; Mr. Bush expects his to tell him what he needs to know.
Mr. Gore happily debates policy minutiae; Mr. Bush prefers to speed through meetings to get to the heart of the matter. Mr. Gore is not bashful about sitting at a laptop and rewriting speeches; Mr. Bush prefers using a black Sharpie marker to delete sections or change a word here or there.
The vice president's aides say he sometimes sees himself as the smartest person in the room, and often he is right. Mr. Bush's aides say he likes to joke to assembled advisers about holes in his knowledge, which is a healthy sign, they say, of confidence.
Mr. Gore scours the newspapers and, often several times a day, will cut out an obscure detail or paragraph and hand it to an aide with instructions. He tries to read every word written about him. Mr. Bush's aides said the governor read about himself from time to time, but preferred to have his wife, Laura, or others sum up what was written about him.
Neither Mr. Gore nor Mr. Bush is the stereotypical empty suit manipulated by handlers. If anything, both candidates tend to be stubborn, often not yielding to their advisers' suggestions. Not surprisingly, both are sensitive to caricatures: Mr. Gore as a control freak drowning in specifics who discounts others' opinions or Mr. Bush as a naive puppet.
Insisting in an interview that his artistry on the logo was "the exception rather than the rule," Mr. Gore said he tried "to avoid getting bogged down in details." He made clear that his style was not like that of President Jimmy Carter, who obsessed over the schedule at the White House tennis courts, or President Calvin Coolidge, who scrutinized guest lists at White House parties.
Even so, Mr. Gore asserted that his grasp of policy would be invaluable in the White House. "I like the broad brush strokes," he said. "But sometimes a significant detail is actually a broad brush stroke in disguise. Sometimes, a significant detail can be a fulcrum around which the rest of the issue turns."
Mr. Bush made no excuses for his gaps in knowledge. "I don't think anybody knows everything about every subject, and anyone who pretends they do is someone I don't want to be the president, because this is a complicated world," he said in an interview. "The key to the presidency is to set divisions, to lay out the parameters by which decisions will be made and to encourage really good, competent people to serve the country for the right reasons and to build a team."
 
A Force Behind Decisions
"I'm not a figurehead here!" the vice president snapped, after a cluster of aides had failed to adequately brief him about an event in New Hampshire in the primaries. "I've got to know what's going on in this campaign."
If anything, that was an understatement. The reality is that Mr. Gore is the driving force behind virtually every big decision of his campaign, and many small ones. His propensity to run things himself has not scared off talented aides. But Mr. Gore often turns to them more as resources to press forward with his own decisions rather than as principal decision makers.
At a meeting in late May of his closest advisers at his residence at the Naval Observatory here, Mr. Gore offhandedly told them he had settled on a new campaign strategy. He would halt the relentless attacks on Mr. Bush that some Democrats feared were doing Mr. Gore more harm than good.
"He said, 'That's what I'm going to do,' " recalled Carter Eskew, one of Mr. Gore's top advisers. "Then he laid out a series of things, like family issues, that became the basis of the next two weeks."
Some advisers had felt it was important that Mr. Gore stay on the offensive. But no one dared to challenge him. "When you work with somebody, you know when there's an opening -- and when there isn't," Mr. Eskew said. "He was emphatic."
Mr. Gore's aides also winced when he told them he would propose a sweeping reform of the campaign finance system. Many thought he would be ridiculed because of the questions surrounding his own fund-raising practices in 1996. Others worried that the issue was not a big vote-getter.
Repeatedly, they tried to distract Mr. Gore by saying other matters needed attention first.
"We'd divert him into some other areas and he'd say, 'What about that speech?' " said Tony Coelho, the Gore campaign chairman.
Such delay tactics, Mr. Eskew conceded, were "a way to try to kill it."
Yet Mr. Gore persisted. "It did not give me pause," the vice president said of the objections.
Mr. Gore is similarly never hesitant about upending speeches or events. Early last month, when he was traveling on Air Force Two from Washington to Chicago, he abruptly discarded a health care speech after reading a clipping from a morning newspaper saying that the National Rifle Association was thrilled at the prospect of a Bush presidency.
Mr. Gore, who was traveling to a conference of health care reporters, summoned aides to his cabin and announced that he would talk about gun violence. The hook: that easy access to handguns is a health care issue.
His aides said they argued against it, but Mr. Gore did not budge. After Air Force Two landed, Mr. Gore kept the motorcade waiting while he worked the phones. He called one aide in Washington about statistics he remembered that had been put out by the American Medical Association.
"I asked her to quickly find out whether or not I was right in remembering that the A.M.A. had done a big statement or publication on the handgun and the health care issue," Mr. Gore said, "and find relevant statistics on it. She found the statistics that I said I needed."
He then instructed his staff to rewrite the speech.
That was hardly an exception. After Mr. Gore's advisers drafted a statement for him last December that castigated his own administration's policy on gays in the military, the vice president thought it was too weak. So he wrote a harder-edged statement himself, over the objections of several advisers. "We thought it would kill him in the South," one said.
Then, when Mr. Bush announced his plan to cut taxes by $483 billion over five years, Mr. Gore told his aides, "We need to respond quickly." Riding in a sport utility vehicle headed to Ida Grove, Iowa, from Sioux City, he began calling experts like Lawrence H. Summers, the treasury secretary, and Gene Sperling, President Clinton's national economic adviser.
Often, Mr. Sperling said, the vice president is "searching for his own formulation, and he's looking for you to deliver the facts he needs to make the argument the way he wants."
Mr. Sperling said Mr. Gore had quizzed him with questions like "How does it compare with the House tax cut?" and "Will this consume all of the budget surplus?"
Mr. Gore attacked the tax plan at an open meeting and then again at a news conference, saying it would squander the surplus.
Sometimes, Mr. Gore plays scheduler. On the morning after the Iowa caucuses, he and his aides were operating on virtually no sleep. Finally, his entourage made it to a hotel in Nashua, N.H., for a few hours' nap before the one scheduled event of the day.
But just as two aides, Michael Feldman and Chris Lehane, were falling asleep in their shared hotel room, Mr. Gore came banging on the door. "Go away," Mr. Lehane shouted, not realizing it was the vice president.
Finally, the two aides, wearing boxer shorts, opened the door. Mr. Gore, clad in a bathrobe with his schedule in hand, demanded, "This is all we're doing today?"
"Sir," Mr. Feldman reminded him, "there's six inches of snow on the ground."
It was no use. The aides, reluctantly, added an MTV event to the schedule and a photo opportunity: they delivered coffee to the local snow crews.
Because of his deep involvement in decisions, Mr. Gore cannot blame his advisers for ones that go awry, like how he distanced himself from President Clinton on Elian Gonzalez.
"It wasn't like we dragged him kicking and screaming," a top adviser said.
 
A Corporate Executive's Touch
Mr. Bush is not inclined to alter a speech sharply or a schedule on the fly. He behaves more like a corporate executive. His aides welcome the comparison to President Ronald Reagan, who did not dither with details and set out broad goals, despite being ridiculed as out of touch.
Even at the most turbulent moment of Mr. Bush's campaign, after his humiliating loss to Senator John McCain in the New Hampshire primary, the governor stuck to his policy.
First, Mr. Bush made clear to his aides that he was distressed with the state of the campaign, telling them that it had to be more aggressive and not watch idly as Mr. McCain persuaded voters that he was the only reformer in the race. Then, rather than dictate remedies, Mr. Bush dispatched his aides to come up with suggestions.
"He laid out the principles of what he thought went right and wrong in New Hampshire," said Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's chief strategist. "Then we came up with options that were presented to him formally and informally over a couple days. He accepted them and rejected a few."
It was a far cry from what Mr. Gore did last September, when former Senator Bill Bradley began surging in polls. Without consulting his aides, Mr. Gore uprooted his listless operation in Washington and moved it to Nashville. "I announced we were going to do it," he recalled, "and that was it."
Mr. Bush's aides could not cite a time when the governor, responding to Mr. Gore or a news development, had ripped up a speech and turned a day's schedule on its head.
"We try to control our own agenda," said Karen P. Hughes, Mr. Bush's communications director and one of his closest aides. "That doesn't mean that he's inflexible. When Cardinal O'Connor passed away, the governor wanted to attend the funeral. That's an example of something that changed."
But even the decision to attend the funeral of Cardinal John O'Connor came at the suggestion of an aide, not Mr. Bush. "I don't think it initially came from him," Ms. Hughes said.
It would be unfair, though, to portray Mr. Bush as passive. He does not hesitate to overrule his advisers, and when he does he is often guided more by instinct than policy.
After reviewing a speech he was due to deliver on Social Security before a group of newspaper publishers in May, Ms. Hughes said, Mr. Bush was puzzled by the content because he was scheduled to deliver a Social Security address the next week. She recalled: "He turned around and looked at me: 'Why are we talking about just Social Security? Why aren't we talking about the importance of reforming education and rebuilding the military?' " The speech was retooled.
Before the South Carolina primary, Mr. Bush's advertising team had produced a commercial that opened with black-and-white shots of lobbyists in cigars in a smoke-filled room. The intent was to portray Senator McCain as in the pocket of lobbyists.
But Mr. Bush rejected the commercial as too harsh. Mark McKinnon, Mr. Bush's media consultant, said: "He was very affirmative about it: 'This isn't going out under my name.' It was not a debatable point."
Mr. McKinnon said he argued that because of time pressure it was not advisable to change the spot. "Listen, this was in the pressure cooker of South Carolina and minutes mattered," he said. The governor prevailed and the shots of the lobbyists were pulled.
And the night Mr. Bush defeated Mr. McCain in the Virginia primary, his aides had prepared a blistering victory speech. But in his heavy black marker, Mr. Bush deleted several pages of the most negative sections about Mr. McCain. For example, he kept the sentence, "On the next step of welfare reform, he has no plan." But he crossed out the next sentence: "His policy agenda is narrow and shallow, and it makes no place for the poor and the forgotten and the frail."
"The feeling was we needed to keep the pressure on Senator McCain," Ms. Hughes said. "I told him there was a lot of frustration at headquarters." She said Mr. Bush telephoned several aides to explain that he did not want to undermine them, but felt that the speech was too strident.
 
Candidates of Divergent Styles
Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore fume when staff members arrive late for meetings. They have little tolerance for aides who are not prepared. Yet their styles are quite different. Mr. Gore is more like a sometimes overbearing teacher, while Mr. Bush often plays the impatient student.
The governor prefers oral presentations to leafing through briefing books. "I've seen the governor say, 'Why don't you close the book and tell me what you think is most important?' " Ms. Hughes said. "He gets to the heart of the matter."
Donald L. Evans, the campaign chairman and Mr. Bush's best friend, put it this way, "His classic question is, 'Have you told me everything I need to know?' "
While Mr. Bush's biggest peeve at meetings is when aides leave their cell phones or pagers on, he is also known for not abiding long-winded presentations.
"He doesn't sit there and let a briefing go on that isn't a good use of his time," said Josh Bolten, his domestic policy adviser. "You get maybe 60 seconds in. If there's a really good briefer who's doing a good job, you might get three or four minutes before he's interrupted."
Mr. Bush is not bashful about pleading ignorance, and will even joke about how he failed a reporter's pop quiz on foreign policy.
"If he doesn't know, he'll say, 'Hold it,' " Mr. Bolten said. "If somebody uses an acronym he doesn't know, he'll stop them and say, 'What does that mean?' Sometimes he says, 'Use plain English.' He's not afraid to say when he doesn't know."
Explaining Mr. Bush's aversion to too much detail about the campaign's finances, Mr. Evans said: "We talk about the budget a fair amount. All he wants to know is, 'Are we under or over?' "
While Mr. Bush has no use for flip charts, aides said, Mr. Gore often draws charts on an easel. "Some days I think he is a professor," said Donna Brazile, the campaign manager.
Even Mr. Gore acknowledged that his grasp of issues, and his certainty about how to proceed, could be intimidating. "I think sometimes a young staffer or a new staffer who hasn't gone through the process before may feel sometimes a little hesitant to speak up in disagreement," he said. "But it doesn't last long because I try to encourage it."
Still, some who know Mr. Gore worry that his vast knowledge can sometimes lead him to foreclose other points of view.
"Gore comes off to me as a guy who has absolute confidence in what should be done and really isn't all that interested in what you think substantively," said Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Delaware Democrat who supported Mr. Gore in the primaries. "Al is interested in getting briefed, forming an opinion and then it's settled. That reflects a political certitude: a guy who will make decisions a la Harry Truman and go home and go to sleep. Except Truman operated on a gut assessment based on a historical context. Al operates on an intellectual assessment that doesn't accommodate much input."
Mr. Gore also compared his style to Harry Truman's. But he said that was a positive attribute.
"I'm a big fan of Harry Truman's philosophy," he said. "The essence of it was: 'Go ahead and make good decisions and then move on to the next decision.' Right. You live with the consequences and you get better as you go along."
 
Two Views of Logos
The operating approaches of Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush not only reflect their experiences but also their personalities and interests. Mr. Gore had a deep interest in his campaign's logo -- as well as in helping dream up a logo for the Democratic National Convention -- because he has dabbled himself in painting and thinks political branding is important.
"I've always felt that logos and other visual symbols that are seen over and over and over again actually are pretty important," Mr. Gore said. "And if you get one that really hangs together well, it's much better than having one that's kind of mediocre."
But Mr. Bush does not share that passion. In fact, asked about his logo, he replied, "You mean what's on the bumper sticker and stuff?" Saying that such artistic endeavors would waste his time, he added, "There are people smarter than me on designing logos."

NATIONAL CITY SAYS ITSOLD $2 BILLION IN STUDENT LOANS

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The National City Corporation, Ohio's largest bank, said yesterday that it had sold $2 billion in student loans as part of a move to protect earnings from rising interest rates. The sale will result in a second-quarter pretax gain of $75 million. National City, which declined to identify the buyers, will use the proceeds to make new loans at higher rates. The company, based in Cleveland, also warned that some steps being considered to lower its financing costs might mean selling some of its investments, mostly bonds, at a loss.

HEADLINE: Albany Agrees On Plan to Aid Nassau County

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 8

 BODY:
After weeks of brinkmanship, Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature have agreed to spend $105 million to bail out Nassau County and impose state oversight of county spending, in an effort to avert financial collapse in one of the nation's wealthiest regions.
The lawmakers also agreed to let New York City increase its borrowing by $4 billion, skirting a legal restriction that could have put a halt to the city's construction projects by the end of the year. 
 Both the New York City and Nassau County measures were part of a broad package to aid local governments, including the troubled school systems in Buffalo and Yonkers, that had been linked to each other in the annual frenzy of horse-trading as the Legislature nears the end of its session.
Having racked up huge deficits in a booming economy, and threatened with having its bonds downgraded to junk status, Nassau County will have to make deep budget cuts in return for the state aid. It also faces the continued threat that the state will take absolute control of the county's finances. The conditions of the deal will force Nassau to pare back one of the most generous arrays of public services -- in schools, parks, police protection, among others -- anywhere in the country.
"They should be able to do it," said State Senator Dean G. Skelos, a Republican from Nassau. "They have no choice. Albany has forced the local officials to end the political gridlock that existed in Nassau County, and to start meaningful, structural reform."
The county's financial troubles, and attempts last year to deal with them by imposing a tax on real estate sales, prompted a backlash against County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta and the Republican machine that has governed Nassau almost uninterrupted since the county was created in 1898. Last November, Democrats took control of the County Legislature for the first time, and Republican state legislators from the county fear that the rebellion could spread to their races.
The bailout is essentially the one proposed last month by Mr. Pataki, with minor revisions. Winning approval for it is a victory for him, but it comes with potential perils. As the author of the plan and the person who appoints most of the oversight board, he stands to collect much of the credit if the county gets back on its feet, and much of the blame if it does not.
Under the deal, the state will give the county $105 million outright over the next five years, including $30 million this year. It is an extraordinary step -- New York City received only loans, not gifts, from the state during its fiscal crisis, and when Orange County, Calif., went bankrupt in 1994, it pulled itself out of its troubles with no state aid of any kind.
The state will create a Nassau Interim Finance Authority both to oversee the county's finances and to sell bonds on better terms than the county would be able to get on the market. In recent weeks, the Democrats who control the Assembly had called for two agencies, one for oversight and one to sell bonds, but in the end, they dropped that demand.
In return for the state aid, Nassau must make $50 million in budget cuts this year, and $70 million in each of the next three years. If it does not, the state will impose a financial control board, essentially stripping Mr. Gulotta and the County Legislature of much of their power.
"That's the very serious threat in this package," said Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli, a Nassau Democrat. "It enforces a level of discipline that the local people have not been able to enforce."
Mr. Gulotta said that he welcomed the bailout package and that as soon as he had the bill in hand, would ask the County Legislature for a "home rule message," which is needed for the State Legislature to act.
In talks over the last few weeks, the State Senate's Republican majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, had said his house would raise New York City's debt ceiling by $2.5 billion, and the Senate passed a bill to that effect. But that figure would get the city through barely two more years, meaning that the next mayor, most likely a Democrat, would hit the limit in his first year in office.
The Democratic Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, threatened to block the Nassau bailout unless Albany increased the city's borrowing authority by $4 billion and delivered aid to Buffalo schools.
Several Assembly members said that Mr. Silver's stance, weeks after he beat back a coup attempt by fellow Democrats, would help shore up his support among members from New York City and Erie County.
While all sides wanted a deal, lawmakers had begun to worry that the Legislature could adjourn for the year next Wednesday without a compromise.
In the end, both sides backed down, with Mr. Bruno agreeing to the $4 billion figure. Mr. Silver dropped the insistence on two Nassau agencies and compromised on his demand for more Democratic representation on the oversight board.
Mr. Pataki had proposed that the board have three members appointed by him, one by Mr. Bruno and one by Mr. Silver. Today, they agreed to add two more members, one named by the governor and one by Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a Democrat. All seven must live in the county.
New York City's borrowing problem lies with a Depression-era state law that put a ceiling on borrowing, through a formula based on property assessments.
The law is a relic of an era when the primary source of local revenue was property taxes; today, for New York City, it is the personal income tax, making the worth of real estate far less relevant to city finances. Also, the assessments tend to lag behind real-world prices, so that in good times, the debt limit rises more slowly than city revenues and the demand for borrowing.
State lawmakers raised the city's borrowing limit in 1996, but the city is rapidly approaching the new cap. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and other officials have warned that without another increase, within months the city would be unable to embark on new capital projects.
"It would have been impractical for them to undertake any kind of long-term projects," Mr. Silver said. "This gives them the ability pay for roads, bridges, schools and the like."
The city had asked for a change in the way its debt ceiling is calculated, which would require a change in the State Constitution, but that proposal went nowhere. Still, it won a reprieve of about four years until it has to ask the state to raise the cap once again.
The overall agreement reached today includes $45 million in aid to Buffalo's schools, and $10 million to Yonkers's. In each case, it is a mix of outright aid and zero-interest loans.
