HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Nasdaq Rises,but Blue Chips Decline in a Quiet Session

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed in a quiet session yesterday after a tame inflation report failed to calm investors' fears that the Federal Reserve will again raise interest rates to force a slowdown in the economy.
Technology stocks rose modestly, helping the Nasdaq composite index close higher for a second consecutive week. But investors in the broader market could not shake worries that higher interest rates would cut corporate profits, analysts said. 
 "Even though corporate earnings are good, if the Fed is raising rates, there's no guarantee that they'll continue to be good," said Phil Foreman, senior portfolio manager at Evergreen Investment Management in Boston.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 54.66 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,614.06. The blue-chip index had been higher for most of the morning. For the week, the Dow fell 180.70 points.
Broader stock indicators were mixed. The Nasdaq composite index rose 49.28 points, or 1.3 percent, to 3,874.84, bringing its gain for the week to 61.46 points. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 4.72 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,456.95.
Stocks initially rose yesterday after the Labor Department reported that the Producer Price Index, which measures inflation pressures before they reach the consumer, was unchanged in May. Analysts had been expecting an increase of 0.3 percent.
The flat reading was a result of a drop in energy and food prices, which more than offset increased prices for cars, paper products and books.
Excluding the drop in energy and food prices, the core rate of inflation at the wholesale level last month was 0.2 percent, slightly above analysts' forecasts. That troubled some investors and derailed the market's early attempt to advance.
"The P.P.I. was definitely a step in the right direction," said Bryan Piskorowski, a market analyst at Prudential Securities. "While it was a somewhat mixed report, it was not very inflationary looking at the bigger picture."
The producer price report followed a series of indicators over the last few weeks that have shown a moderating United States economic pace.
Stock investors have been hoping for a gradual economic slowdown, which could persuade the Federal Reserve to stop raising interest rates. The Fed has increased rates six times in the last year in an attempt to slow the economy and keep inflation under control.
Investors will be looking closely at economic reports that will be issued next week, including figures on retail sales and consumer prices, for further signs on the economy. "Next week we will really find out how hot the economy is, and the effect of those six rate hikes," Mr. Piskorowski said.
Technology stocks were mostly higher. Qualcomm and Sun Microsystems gained, both on the Nasdaq. Qualcomm rose 1 5/8, to 79 1/16, and Sun jumped 2 7/16, to 89 15/16. On the New York Stock Exchange, the Dow component Hewlett-Packard and its spinoff, Agilent Technologies, were both up. Hewlett increased 2 1/8, to 128, while Agilent climbed 33 /16, to 71 1/8.
But some "old economy" stalwarts pulled the Dow lower. McDonald's fell 2 1/16, to 33 3/8, after the company reported sales growth slowed in May. Analysts said the company faced a difficult comparison with May 1999 figures, because McDonald's was running a popular Beanie Babies giveaway last year.
Lucent Technologies fell 3 3/16, to 59 11/16, hurting the S.& P. 500. Lehman Brothers lowered its estimate for the company's fiscal 2000 revenue and profit, saying the company was suffering from a decline in a leading product line of switches.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged at 105 2/32 and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, remained at 5.89 percent. The price of the 10-year note rose 1/32, to 102 24/32, while the yield was unchanged at 6.12 percent.

HEADLINE: One-Day National Strike Freezes Much of Argentina

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, June 9

 BODY:
Several million workers joined or were forced to acquiesce to a one-day national strike today to protest President Fernando de la Rua's economic austerity policies and Argentina's 14 percent unemployment rate.
The strike, the largest in four years, represented a rare show of unity by the fractious labor movement and the most serious challenge to Mr. de la Rua's deficit-cutting policies since he took office in December. 
 The walkout occurred at an inopportune time for the Argentine president, who is planning a trip to the United States early next week to see President Clinton and promote Argentine investments to Wall Street executives who have cooled to the country's prospects in recent years.
Major cities and much of the countryside were paralyzed as thousands of railroad, subway, bus, truck and airline workers joined the walkout. Bonfires were set, bridges blocked, and buses and taxicabs dented or otherwise damaged by workers.
More than 50 people were arrested. Thousands of stores closed, as many people decided to take a long weekend. Courts closed, and hospital emergency rooms had skeletal staffs. Uncollected garbage lined streets and shopping areas.
In small demonstrations, workers beat drums, set off firecrackers and, in a few incidents, threw rocks at the police.
"What the people want is work," said Rodolfo Daer, head of the General Labor Confederation, the largest workers' group. "What the government needs to understand is that the people are demanding a change in direction."
The government tried to limit the damage by offering to open talks with the unions, businessmen, opposition governors and the Roman Catholic Church to reach some kind of consensus on economic policy.
"In place of violence we need dialogue," Mr. de la Rua told reporters. "But in order to have dialogue, we need not have violence."
The strike was planned to protest a $938 million cut in public spending, or 2 percent of the government budget. The spending plan, announced two weeks ago, is intended to meet International Monetary Fund guidelines and retain access to a $7.2 billion emergency credit line from the fund.
The austerity package includes salary cuts for national government workers of 12 to 15 percent, reducing public retirement payments and bans on public workers' earning salaries while receiving state pensions from previous positions.
The latest round of cuts was imposed on top of $1.4 billion in cuts initiated by the de la Rua administration in its first weeks in office. All told, the spending cuts and a $2 billion tax increase are intended to bring down interest rates and keep the federal deficit under $4.5 billion this year, or one-third below the 1999 total.
The economy has responded slowly to the medicine, as the national mood grows increasingly sour over a recession that has already run for two years. Last week, Mr. de la Rua lowered projections of a 4 percent growth rate this year to 3.5 percent, an anemic comeback after losing 3 percent in 1999.
Independent economists expect this year to register an even lower growth rate, 2.5 percent, far below that of Chile and Brazil, the other major economies in the region. With its currency tied to the strong dollar, Argentina lags behind its neighbors in exports. And with unemployment reaching 20 percent or more in poorer provinces with financially weak local governments, labor and social unrest is building in the countryside. Farmers who are seeking easier credit are threatening an extensive work action this month.
Mr. de la Rua is urging patience, arguing that his policies need time to increase competitiveness on trade and investor and consumer confidence. His supporters point to recent developments that suggest that the economy might finally be ready to recover. Tax receipts, exports and imports showed signs of a pickup last month. A recent strengthening of the euro should help exports to Europe.
In a move that promises to cut government finance costs $200 million, Argentina this week completed a successful debt swap of old Brady bonds for debt with lower interest.
The general strike today was the second since Mr. de la Rua took office. But it was much bigger than the splintered work action in February, which aimed to prevent changes in the labor law that were intended to lower labor costs for businesses. Congress eventually passed changes, anyway.
The unions are also upset over a decree that promises to deregulate the health industry gradually, expanding private health insurance to the detriment of a union-based health-insurance system. The current system is a cash cow for union leaders.

HEADLINE: East Harlem Shopping Center Snagged Over Financing of Garage

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
It was supposed to bring Manhattan its first Costco and Home Depot superstores and add more than a thousand jobs in East Harlem. But now, plans to build a shopping center along Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive have run into a serious snag because no financing has been found for the $30 million garage that is needed to make the project work, officials said this week.
But they say they remain hopeful that the $160 million complex, known as East River Plaza, will eventually get off the ground. "I don't think it's in anybody's interest for this project to be abandoned," said Councilman Philip Reed, who represents East Harlem. "We worked very hard to sell this project, and the community was ultimately receptive to it." 
 Approved last fall by the City Council, the shopping center, one of the largest projects planned for Manhattan in recent years, is intended to replace the long-dormant Washburn Wire Factory along the highway between 116th and 119th Streets. In addition to the superstores, leases have been signed with Old Navy, Gap and Best Buy. Other tenants are expected to include Staples, T. J. Maxx and Modell's Sporting Goods, said David Blumenfeld, a vice president of the Blumenfeld Development Corporation, which is developing the shopping center with Canyon Capital Management.
Blumenfeld is also building a smaller retail center on 125th Street, near Lexington Avenue and opposite a Pathmark supermarket that opened last year. The complex was originally expected to house a 10-screen United Artists movie theater, but United Artists has backed out of the deal and no replacement was found, said Jesse Masyr, the lawyer representing the developers.
As for East River Plaza, Mr. Blumenfeld said his tenants were unwilling to foot the construction cost of a seven-level garage containing 1,248 spaces and had insisted on free parking for the first two hours. But state officials, who would discuss the project only privately, say that the developer should not expect the public to absorb the entire cost of a private parking garage.
The garage is needed because the developers estimate that the complex will draw 5,000 cars a day -- a figure that the project's critics say is much too low. Many people in the neighborhood are concerned about the added noise and pollution from the influx of cars to East Harlem, which has one of the highest asthma rates in the country.
But opponents, including William Minic, a cabinetmaker who would have to give up the shop he has owned for more than two decades, were never able to muster a serious challenge to the project. And on Tuesday, a Supreme Court Appellate Division dismissed a lawsuit seeking to block the state from condemning property for the shopping center, saying it had not been filed in time.
Mr. Masyr said he expected the decision to stand, but Jack R. Lester, the lawyer for the project's opponents, said the ruling did not bar further legal challenges.
Pointing out that the cost of the project had nearly doubled since it was unveiled three years ago, state officials said they were working with the city's Economic Development Corporation to try to get additional financing from the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, a federal, state and city program.
One stumbling block, state officials say, is that developers would not guarantee how many jobs the project would generate, although they expect the number to be 1,200 to 1,500. Mr. Masyr said that it was impossible to get tenants to promise to hire a specific number of employees. But he said the developers were willing to pay a penalty if certain goals were not met.
Mr. Blumenfeld said he was disappointed that the state was not pushing harder to get the project going. "It's disheartening for the people of Harlem and for myself," he said. "It's rare that you have a project that has tenants, financing and approvals and still hasn't started."
C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president, said she would urge Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to find a way to rescue the project. And she said she was still optimistic. "This is just a fork in the road," she said. "So much has already been invested that ultimately the resources will be found."

HEADLINE: Security Council Extends Oil-for-Food Program Allowing Iraq to Import Necessities

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 9

 BODY:
With Iraqi profits from oil sales now at record-high levels, the Security Council has extended the "oil-for-food" program for another six months to allow the imports of food, medicine and other civilian necessities.
During this period, a new arms inspection system will be readied to go into action in Iraq, the chief inspector said on Thursday, challenging Iraq to take advantage of a more lenient set of requirements for suspending economic sanctions imposed after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990. 
 The oil-for-food plan was instituted by the United Nations in 1996 to help alleviate the sufferings of ordinary Iraqis under the sanctions, and must be renewed every six months. Late last year, the United Nations lifted the ceiling on how much oil Iraq could sell.
In debate before a vote near midnight on Thursday, the deadline for the oil-sales extension, the council defeated a Russian and Chinese attempt to write into the resolution language that would have identified the sanctions as the sole cause of continuing hardships in Iraq.
That argument did not convince all council members, as the Iraqis are thought to have generated $8.4 billion in oil sales in the latest six-month phase. Since 1996, $25.3 billion in oil has been sold. Some experts say that President Saddam Hussein is also pulling in hundreds of millions of dollars in illegally smuggled oil.
Not all the legal profits go to the government for purchases to improve the lives of Iraqi citizens. A third of the income is set aside for a compensation fund for victims of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and other sums are earmarked for autonomous Kurdish areas of Iraq and for the arms inspection budget. Even so, Secretary General Kofi Annan said in his latest report to the Security Council this week, there is now enough money to significantly mitigate civilians' hardships if the government managed it better.
"Now that increased revenues are available for the implementation of the program, the government of Iraq is in a position to reduce current malnutrition levels and to improve the health status of the Iraqi people," Mr. Annan said. He urged Iraq to increase the oil revenue allocated to health and nutrition, to order and distribute supplies more efficiently.
Mr. Annan also said in his report that the most recent surveys by Unicef, the United Nations children's fund, found that malnutrition rates had leveled, with a slight reduction in the number of underweight children, although rates for severe conditions known as stunting and wasting were still too high. As for other aspects of children's welfare, Mr. Annan's report noted some advances in education, including the rehabilitation of schools.
But Mr. Annan again warned that the practice of certain Security Council members -- primarily the United States, though it was not named -- of blocking contracts with Iraq for water and sanitation equipment will continue to harm health.
The Security Council also decided in the resolution approved Thursday night to send an independent assessment team to Iraq to study the condition of the Iraqi people.
The sanctions were to have remained in place until Iraq was certified as free of prohibited weapons -- chemical, biological and nuclear arms as well as long-range missiles. But last December, the Security Council proposed suspending sanctions if Iraq cooperated with a new team of arms inspectors.
In an interview Thursday, Hans Blix, the executive chairman of the United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission, or Unmovic, said that the new organization has now filled most senior-level jobs and will be training inspectors over the next few months. By August, they will be ready to reopen the Baghdad monitoring center, closed by Iraq since December 1998, and prepare for resumed inspections. The International Atomic Energy Agency, which Dr. Blix once directed and which is responsible for monitoring nuclear programs, is ready to resume its inspections at any time.
Although most of Iraq's complaints about the earlier inspection commission, Unscom, have been addressed in the new system, Mr. Hussein has shown no inclination to let inspectors return.
Dr. Blix said that after an absence of 18 months, inspectors will have to re-establish baselines for surveys, reviewing all suspect Iraqi sites to be monitored. Confounding his critics, Dr. Blix, a former Swedish foreign minister, has kept some essential experts from Unscom on his team, ignoring Iraqi and Russian demands for a clean slate.
"Then comes the question, when are we going in?" he said. "We see no sign whatever of that at the present time. However, in politics things can change, and my personal view is that the Iraqis would gain by cooperating and accepting."
"They demand that the so-called sanctions should be lifted," he said. But he added that few stringent sanctions remained, beyond a ban on air travel in and out of the country. "It was an embargo on the sale of oil first; now there are no limits on how much oil they can sell," he said. "They can use any amount they want to buy food and medicine -- but they cannot buy weapons.
"This is the Iraqi position: that they want to have all these restrictions lifted.
He said the Security Council resolution creating the new inspection commission offered some innovations that Iraq should consider if it wants to speed the end of sanctions.
"It enables the Security Council to suspend the sanctions provided two criteria: that there be cooperation with Unmovic in 120 days, and included in the cooperation will also be the resolution of some key disarmament issues," he said. "The criteria are, I would say, more lenient."

HEADLINE: Economy May Have a Soft Spot;
Swelling Trade Gap Worries Some Experts and Policy Makers

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
If this bionic economy has a soft underbelly, it may be trade.
As Americans gorge on imported cars, electronics, clothing and a long list of other goods from abroad, the nation's trade deficit has swollen to record proportions, leaving economists and policy makers increasingly troubled. 
 The trade deficit for March, the most recent month for which data is available, was $30.2 billion, 56 percent higher than in March 1999. Imports for March totaled $117.4 billion, up 21.9 percent from the corresponding month a year earlier.
Broader measures of the nation's international transactions have also deteriorated. The current account deficit -- which includes foreigners' profits on investments in the United States and Americans' investments in other countries as well as trade in goods and services -- reached $338.9 billion in 1999, up 53.6 percent from 1998.
The current account deficit, which amounted to 3.7 percent of total economic output for all of last year and 4.2 percent in the fourth quarter, is projected by most economists to rise again this year. It is already by far the largest among the big industrialized countries. The last time trade was a big issue for the American economy, during the mid-and late-1980's, the current account deficit peaked at 3.4 percent of gross domestic product.
The main reason for the surge is clear. For the last few years, the American economy has been booming, while those of its major trading partners have been weak. As a result, the thirst for imported goods has grown even as the market for American exports has stagnated.
What is less clear is whether the trade imbalance will prove to be a substantial problem.
It could recede quickly if Japan bounces back and Europe's recovery continues, especially if the Federal Reserve also succeeds in slowing the growth of economic demand in the United States. And in any case, foreign companies and investors have been happy so far to finance the deficit by recycling the dollars they earn through trade back into the United States, where the technology-fueled boom has offered high rates of return. Indeed, some economists see the current account deficit more as an indicator of a healthy surge of foreign investment into the United States than as a sign of a sickening trade imbalance.
But there is a worst-case set of possibilities out there that haunts many economists: foreign investors lose faith in the American economy's relative advantages, investment from abroad dries up, the dollar plunges, inflation jumps and the Fed is forced to respond by driving interest rates sharply higher, endangering the long expansion.
With the American economy strong and unemployment low, the growing trade deficit so far has not produced the same protectionist pressures that previous surges in the trade gap have provoked. Yes, anxiety about competition from low- wage workers abroad was at the heart of labor's failed campaign against normalizing trade relations with China. But the trade gap itself has merited hardly a mention so far in the presidential campaign.
And in contrast to the 1980's, when the United States was plagued by a simultaneous rise in its trade and budget deficits, the federal government is currently running a large budget surplus, providing a substantial cushion for the economy.
Still, the situation has policy makers in Washington concerned. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has repeatedly warned that the rapid growth in imports compared with a much more modest increase in exports cannot go on forever. And it has been on the mind of Lawrence H. Summers, the Treasury secretary.
"When a large external imbalance reflects a period of strong growth relative to the rest of the world, and relatively high investment in our productive potential, as it does in the United States today," Mr. Summers said in a speech last month, "that imbalance is unlikely to pose an immediate threat to our economic well-being."
But, Mr. Summers added, "a large and growing current account deficit is not something that can be sustained indefinitely."
"It can also give rise to protectionist pressures," he said, "and it distorts the pattern of domestic economic activity."
The Clinton administration has shown no inclination to push down the dollar to promote exports by making American goods cheaper when purchased in foreign currencies. Indeed, calls for a weaker dollar from exporters and industries that compete with imports have been relatively muted compared with the 1980's, when auto companies, steel makers, farmers and other howled about their inability to compete with their foreign counterparts.
Instead, the administration has stressed the importance of increasing national savings by paying down the federal debt -- a step that could help reduce reliance on foreign capital -- and has pressed Japan and Europe to overhaul their economies to create more demand for goods from the United States.
"We'd see a more balanced situation if Europe and Japan were growing faster," said Ralph C. Bryant, an economist at the Brookings Institution, the research organization. "But you wouldn't want to put the brakes hard on the U.S. economy just to get the trade and current account deficits smaller, and you don't want to put up new fences at the border. That would be far more costly than would make sense."
But as the current account deficit has grown, there has been an increasing debate inside and outside of government about the degree of the threat posed by the trade gap.
One camp views the deficit as essentially benign.
In this view, the trade gap will narrow as the American economy slows. In any case, imports so far in this economic cycle have served as a safety valve for the supercharged American economy, helping to keep inflation under control at a time when domestic producers cannot keep up with demand.
Moreover, by purchasing so much from abroad, the United States has helped many other countries rebound from the financial crisis that swept around the world in 1998. And by investing the dollars they earn back into the United States, foreign companies, governments and investors are adding to the pool of capital that American companies have used to become more productive and competitive.
"With the current account deficit at a record high, it's silly to say it can't possibly be of any importance," said John Lipsky, chief economist at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "But the current account deficit is only a sign of other developments of more direct importance, in this case the significant and sustained growth differential between the U.S. and its trading partners."
At the same time, Mr. Lipsky added, "The emergence of what is sometimes called the new economy has attracted foreign investors."
In the sense that the current account deficit is just the reverse side of a flood of foreign direct investment in the United States, "it represents something good about the U.S., not something bad," Mr. Lipsky said.
But there is a more dire view of the trade imbalance.
In this view, further expansion in the current account deficit cannot be sustained. The deficit is at a level that leaves the economy vulnerable to a sharp fall in the value of the dollar, a jump in inflation and interest rates, and a slowdown in growth or even a recession.
"You cannot continually run a growing current account deficit without ultimately facing a very sharp fall in your exchange rate, which in the current circumstances of the U.S. economy could be a killer," said C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
The chain of events that Mr. Bergsten worries about would involve a steep drop in the dollar, a resulting surge in inflation and a determined response by the Federal Reserve to restore stability by pushing interest rates up sharply.
The current account gap, Mr. Bergsten said, is "the single biggest threat to the current expansion of the economy."
Among policy makers in Washington, there is less a sense of crisis than a gnawing concern about the long-term trends in trade. Officials at the Fed cite a theory first developed in the 1960's by Hendrik S. Houthakker, an economist at Harvard University. He found that growth in imports to the United States relative to income growth runs at roughly twice the rate it does in the rest of the world. That finding has been confirmed repeatedly over the years.
In other words, if the American economy is expanding at anything close to the rest of the world's growth rate, the American trade deficit will increase.
That was not a big problem during a lot of the post-World War II period, when much of the rest of the world experienced higher growth rates than the United States. But should growth in the United States remain as strong as it has been the last few years, and should the rest of the world not rebound, it could push the trade deficit to previously unimagined levels.
In political terms, there is also the possibility of the trade deficit with a particular country or set of countries creating protectionist pressures in Washington. Organized labor is likely to keep a close eye on trade with China, which is about to join the World Trade Organization. And any renewed effort by Japan to export its way out of its doldrums could bring a return of the trade tensions that characterized its relationship with the United States for years.
But among consumers, who have enjoyed lower prices and improved quality in many products as a result of global competition, there are few signs of worry.
"If Americans are going to want me to buy their car, then they need to offer me a good product," said Diane Spivey of Clermont, Ga., who recently bought a Volkswagen Passat. "I don't look on it as your economy and my economy. The world is a pretty small place these days."

LENGTH: 259 words

HEADLINE: Budget Follies in New York

 BODY:
One of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's proudest boasts is that he has restored fiscal discipline at City Hall. Lately, however, a different story has unfolded. New York City's spending growth is running at more than twice the rate of inflation, and borrowing is spiraling so fast that the city needs state legislative approval to exceed its debt ceiling.
Now Mr. Giuliani has made the picture worse with a pension ploy announced a few weeks ago. Since the pension funds are flush because of the stock market, he has proposed tapping $800 million from contributions due this year and next. The money is to be used to close city budget deficits in the current year and the one beginning July 1. To win union permission for that scheme, he agreed to let 200,000 municipal workers cut back on their own contributions to the system, raising their take-home pay by 3 percent. That step will cost the city $300 million a year in the future. 
 State workers have won a separate agreement from Gov. George Pataki and State Comptroller Carl McCall for a cost-of-living increase for retirees. The state pension funds can afford it, but the governor and the Legislature are also planning to apply it to the city, where the Giuliani administration says it could cost $700 million a year.
Mr. Giuliani warns that without additional state aid to help pay for the state-mandated cost-of-living hike for retirees, tax cuts proposed for next year may have to be rescinded. But the mayor would be more persuasive if he had not already showed poor judgment on pensions.

HEADLINE: Pakistan Outlines Plans To Curb Militant Networks

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 9

 BODY:
After months of criticism from Washington of its handling of terrorism, Pakistan today outlined an ambitious campaign aimed at slowly curbing networks of militants that have taken root here and in Afghanistan.
Senior officials said the military government has decided to act not because of the American pressure, but because the networks threaten Pakistan by "fanning sectarian violence and poisoning people's minds," said Moinuddin Haider, the interior minister. 
 There has been a growing criticism of Pakistan by Washington and independent groups. A Congressionally appointed advisory panel has recommended that Pakistan be designated as a government that is "not cooperating fully" against terrorism.
In an interview, Mr. Haider said his government had made a "clear-cut policy decision" to begin controlling the thousands of religious schools, some of which preach hatred of the West and provide young recruits to the "jihads," or holy wars, in Kashmir, Afghanistan, Bosnia and Chechnya, and to other conflicts involving Muslims.
Some also channel militants to terrorist groups such as those linked to the Saudi financier Osama bin Laden, who is being sheltered by Afghanistan and whose network has been accused of repeatedly killing Americans.
At Pakistan's urging, Mr. Haider said, the Taliban in Afghanistan have expelled several Pakistanis and several Arabs wanted by their home governments for alleged terrorist attacks. He said the Taliban have also occupied Rishkavour, which Western diplomats say is a leading training camp for militants near Kabul.
In addition to providing mujahedeen, or holy warriors, for conflicts throughout the world, such camps have also produced the terrorists who bombed the World Trade Center and two American Embassies in Africa, intelligence officials have concluded. Most recently, veterans of such camps plotted to attack tourist sites in Jordan and America around the time of the new year's celebrations, they say.
The United States has become alarmed about those networks, particularly those affiliated with or supported by Mr. bin Laden.
Mr. Haider, a retired general who was governor of Sindh Province until his current appointment, insisted that Pakistan made the decision based on its own security interests. "I feel this is good for Pakistan," he said. "I'm not following anyone else's agenda.
"Pakistan ought to become a progressive, modern and tolerant secular state."
He said the campaign would mark a radical departure from some of Pakistan's political and religious traditions. "It will not happen overnight, and it will upset many people," Mr. Haider said. But he added that his government was determined to enforce a "gradual rollback" of the networks.
Asked for comment on the steps outlined this week, Karl F. Inderfurth, assistant secretary of state for South Asia, said the United States welcomed them. Though Washington had not been officially informed about some of the measures, he said: "These are precisely the kinds of things we've been hoping to hear from the government of Pakistan. We hope they'll be successful in carrying them out."
Whether they will be, he added, is "the $64,000 question."
Another American official who monitors terrorism expressed skepticism about whether the Taliban were being truly responsive and whether Pakistan, which is facing strikes and growing criticism of its economic measures, would maintain pressure on the Taliban.
He noted, for example, that Washington had not confirmed that the Taliban have taken over Rishkavour. But he said Islamabad's actions reflect a "higher level of effort than we've recently seen."
Among other things, the steps Pakistan is talking about include demanding that Afghanistan shut down 18 training camps identified by Pakistan; arresting and extraditing 20 to 25 Pakistanis and an unspecified number of Arabs wanted for terrorism by their respective governments; and improving border controls.
A second part of the effort involves the potentially explosive topic of identifying thousands of religious schools, which typically have not been regulated, and imposing standards on them.
To date, Mr. Haider said, about 4,000 religious schools, or madrassas, have been registered. He has been meeting with madrassa leaders, he said, to encourage them to modernize their curriculum to include mathematics and computer skills. Such schools, he said, which often take the place of public schools, should not produce zealots, but "balanced persons."
Jessica Stern, a terrorism expert at Harvard University and a former official in the Clinton administration, said the Pakistani program could greatly reduce terrorism in the region. But she said only 4,345 schools have been registered so far, of an estimated 40,000. And, she said, most of the rural, most extremist madrassas strongly oppose government intervention in their activities. Pakistan has come a long way, she said, but it has a long way to go in preventing sectarian violence.
Zahid Hussain, a senior editor of Newsline, an independent monthly, said the military government is caught between competing pressures. On one hand, he said, it needs the West economically and does not want to be isolated politically. But on the other, he said he doubted that it could afford to antagonize the religious groups that are a core political constituency.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

House Approves Measure To Repeal Inheritance Tax
The House voted to repeal the federal inheritance tax, drawing a veto threat from President Clinton even as Democrats joined Republicans in recognizing the issue's political potency. The vote was 279-136, with 65 Democrats voting in favor.
Republican leaders, who have made repeal of what they call the "death tax" one of their main priorities, said they were driven in part by a desire to help owners of small businesses and family farms, who have long complained that the estate tax made it costly if not impossible to pass their holdings along to another generation. But Republicans also said they viewed the tax as inherently unfair and even immoral, no matter who pays it. Page A1. 

Nasdaq Jumps 49 Points, to 3,874
Technology stocks advanced modestly, helping the Nasdaq composite index close higher. The Nasdaq rose 49.28 points, or 1.3 percent, to 3,874.84. For the week, it climbed 61.46 points, or 1.6 percent, but is still down 4.8 percent so far this year. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 54.66 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,614.06. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 4.72 points, to 1,456.95. C3.
 
Microsoft's Might Is Challenged
Whether Microsoft wins or loses its appeal of an antitrust ruling that could break the company in two, its world has changed, perhaps forever. Some of the changes are linked to a growing belief that close government scrutiny has made it more difficult for Microsoft to flex its industry might. Others are linked to the rapid emergence of new consumer markets, ranging from hand-held computing to digital delivery of audio and video, where the industry standards established by Microsoft software and Intel hardware may offer no advantage. A1.
 
Prices Paid to Producers Flat in May
Prices paid to manufacturers, farmers and other producers showed no change in May as lower costs for energy and food more than offset higher prices for cars and a record jump in the cost of books, according to government figures. The flat reading in the Producer Price Index surprised analysts who had predicted that a rebound in energy costs would push up producer prices by 0.2 percent. C3.
 
For Japan, Growth but Not Recovery
The Japanese economy rebounded in the first quarter of this year, reversing the course set in the previous six months. But economists said the numbers did not necessarily signal a sustainable recovery and merely extended the pattern of alternating growth and contraction that has prevailed for many years in Japan, Asia's biggest economy. C2.
 
Shares of E.D.S. Tumble on Warning
Shares of Electronic Data Systems tumbled 26 percent after it said second-quarter sales would be less than analysts had expected. Shares of E.D.S. fell $14.8125, to $43. The stock has slipped 34 percent this year. Changes in the organization of its sales force are hurting revenue growth, and the warning is a setback for Richard H. Brown, who took over as chief executive last year. C2.
 
Amgen Loses Round in Patent Case
Transkaryotic Therapies won a round in its patent fight with the biotechnology giant Amgen when a judge ruled that Transkaryotic did not infringe on one of Amgen's patents covering its best-selling drug. A trial continues on other Amgen patents. C2.
 
Unemployment Rate in Canada Falls
Canada's unemployment rate dipped to a 24-year low of 6.6 percent in May, down two-tenths of a percentage point from April. The strong economy added more than 42,000 jobs last month and almost all were full-time jobs in the private sector. Given the strong job market and other signs of a brisk economy, economists expect the Bank of Canada to continue to match any interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve in the United States. C2.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1082 words

HEADLINE: Two Record Labels Settle Copyright SuitWith MP3.com

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 9

 BODY:
Signaling a new era of cooperation in the volatile world of online music distribution, two major record labels said today that they had settled a copyright lawsuit with MP3.com, in a deal that permits the music start-up to store consumers' record libraries and provide access to them over the Internet.
Under the settlement, MP3.com will pay roughly $20 million each to BMG Entertainment, a unit of Bertelsmann A.G., and Warner Music Group, a subsidiary of Time Warner, along with licensing fees for use of the labels' music on the service, parties close to the negotiations said. 
 The deal hardly dispels the recording industry's pressing concerns about music piracy online, nor does it make the bulk of the music from the major record labels available for purchase and listening over the Internet. But it appears to signal a recognition by the labels and by MP3.com that the traditional and the online businesses need each other and can profit by working together.
Michael Robertson, chairman and chief executive of MP3.com, declined to discuss the amount of the settlement but said that even if the reports were accurate, the fees would not jeopardize the company's long-term viability.
He said the company, which is based in San Diego, had $380 million in cash reserves. "The reality is, cash is not an issue," he said, adding that he believed the settlement paved the way for growth of the company.
Eric Sheirer, an entertainment analyst with Forrester Research, a market research firm in Cambridge, Mass., said that by settling, the music labels at once scored a victory but also signaled a willingness to embrace the online marketplace.
He said it was of symbolic importance that the record labels settled with MP3.com, which is just one of the companies that use the MP3 format to distribute music on the Internet.
"It's a huge day for the recording industry," he said. "They are embracing a business model that revolves around the MP3 format."
That does not mean, however, that the labels are embracing a mechanism for piracy, record industry officials said. The use of the MP3 format under the settlements announced today, they said, is confined to allowing consumers to listen only to music that they have already purchased, and not to download or trade music that they do not own.
In a case that could have broader implications, the Recording Industry Association of America is pursuing a suit against Napster, an online service that provides software that Internet users employ to share and trade music files, including copyrighted material. The service says it is not responsible if some people use its software to pirate music. But the recording industry disagrees, asserting that piracy costs the industry and the artists it represents tens of millions of dollars in lost sales. That case is being heard in a federal court in Northern California.
Under the deal announced today, MP3.com agreed to license, for undisclosed fees, the use of songs from BMG and Warner Music for use in its My.MP3.com service. The service allows consumers to store their own record collections on MP3.com's computers in "virtual lockers" and have access to them by way of the Internet.
MP3.com started the My.MP3.com service in January. In hopes of making the service easy to use, the company itself bought tens of thousands of commercial compact discs. Consumers who proved they owned a copy of a given disc, by inserting it into their PC while visiting the site, would thereafter gain access to that music from the MP3.com computers.
But the recording industry argued in court that MP3.com was violating copyrights by copying the music, compiling a vast database without permission or license. Although Mr. Robertson argued that his service simply extended to cyberspace consumers' legal rights to make a copy of their own music, a federal judge in New York agreed with the labels in April, finding that the practice violated copyright law because MP3.com had not received permission from the recording industry.
Three other major record labels, Sony Music, EMI and Universal Music Group, said they were continuing independent settlement negotiations and declined to comment further. A spokesman for Time Warner declined to comment on the settlement. Kevin Conroy, chief marketing officer at BMG, said that "the best enforcement is the creation of legitimate alternatives for consumers."
The lawsuit was brought by the Recording Industry Association of America, which represents the five major record labels. But because of antitrust regulations, the labels must settle the licensing agreements separately, industry officials said.
If the other labels also settle for around $20 million each, as industry analysts expect, the cost to MP3.com could be $100 million or more, people close to the negotiations said.
The My.MP3.com service has about 500,000 accounts, but the virtual lockers do not now include music from the major labels. Mr. Robertson said the service would continue to be free, even though MP3.com will have to pay licensing fees to the labels. He said the company would continue to rely on advertising for its revenue. The site, which also sells some items online, also offers music from independent artists.
In addition to any deal struck with the major labels, MP3.com is seeking licensing deals with music publishing groups, and Mr. Robertson said that the service would not be fully functional until both sets of deals were made final.
"This is building a foundation for creating a massive online business," Mr. Robertson said, calling the settlement a "win-win" for the two parties. "Shareholders of major record labels are getting a bite of the online apple," he said.
The deal apparently played well with investors. Shares of MP3.com rose $1.9375, to $19.1875, in Nasdaq trading today.
Industry analysts said the settlement might indeed represent a partial victory for MP3.com and for Mr. Robertson, who has ruffled many feathers in the recording industry by asserting that traditional music business models have been outdated in the Internet era.
Michael B. Nathanson, a music industry analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York, said he was surprised that the settlement came so quickly.
"I would have thought they would punish Mr. Robertson," he said, "But what it shows me is they realize there's a lot of traffic on his site and that at the end of the day, it makes sense to work with these sites rather than oppose them."

HEADLINE: A War Over Rent, on Two Coasts

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While Paul Krugman and most of his fellow economists may believe that it is "obvious" that rent control reduces the quality and quantity of housing (column, June 7), their analysis ignores an important factor: price-controlled housing is often the only affordable alternative for low- and moderate-income city dwellers. 
 The federal government has largely abandoned its construction of subsidized housing over the last 20 years, and the private sector has consistently shown its preference for building new housing priced for the wealthiest 5 percent of our population. While the economists are probably right that eliminating price controls would stimulate construction, it's doubtful that much of this would be decent, affordable housing for the working class.
Perhaps the answer lies in a combination of new governmental initiatives and tax incentives for private builders to increase the available housing supply for all income levels.
 
STEVE KNIGHT
New York, June 7, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 146 words

HEADLINE: A War Over Rent, on Two Coasts

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Paul Krugman diagnoses San Francisco's rent control problem, (column, June 7) but stops before recommending treatment. 
 The city granted rent-controlled tenants a share of the landlord's property rights without financially compensating the landlord, although the tenants enjoy the economic benefit of lower rents.
However, the obvious solution -- repealing rent control -- would be the same bad thinking turned backward. Tenants should be allowed to sell their rent-control rights for a market-driven lump sum, either to the landlord or to incoming tenants. Rents could be raised for the new tenant, but the extra cost to them of purchasing rent-control rights would force landlords to keep rent somewhat below market levels. Over time, most rent control would be bought out of existence by landlords.
 
SCOTT COON
San Francisco, June 7, 2000

SECTION: Section 7; Page 14; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 2175 words

HEADLINE: Wars and Rumors of War

BYLINE: By Fouad Ajami; Fouad Ajami, a professor of Middle Eastern studies at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, is the author of "The Dream Palace of the Arabs."

 BODY:

 The Balkans
 Nationalism, War and
 the Great Powers, 1804-1999.
 By Misha Glenny.
 726 pp. New York:
 Viking. $34.95.
 
 Kosovo
 War and Revenge.
 By Tim Judah.
 Illustrated. 348 pp. New Haven:
 Yale University Press.
 Cloth, $37.50. Paper, $17.95.
 
 Virtual War
 Kosovo and Beyond.
 By Michael Ignatieff.
 Illustrated. 246 pp. New York:
 Metropolitan Books. $23. 
 "Talking of war, there'll be trouble in the Balkans in the spring," a character mutters in Rudyard Kipling's 1899 novel, "The Light That Failed." He is a war correspondent idling his time away in London, hoping for deliverance in the Balkans, where he and all the other correspondents "will have as much as ever we can do" and "the chance to see things" that make reputations. It has been this way for a long time: We know the Balkans as metaphor, as a world where Europe (its meaning and boundaries uncertain at best) trails off and another reality begins, as a nemesis overtaking times and places of order.
Nowadays the Balkans again belong to journalists; the histories of these lands are written by war reporters or those who can sense the approaching thunder of war. By the time that rumble is heard, the fire will have eaten up the social and economic history and the truths and arrangements that held a place together will have been torched. This ruin gives a certain liberty to authors. The older history and reality hadn't held. If conquest rounds out the borders, why bother with the history of land ownership in the Balkans? If civility cracks, why bother with the literature of the place?
Eight years after the prison camps of Bosnia, five years after Srebrenica marked our age and mocked our pretensions that we have been delivered into a world beyond history's furies, we are wiser about the Balkans and Balkan legends. Few people are around now whose first acquaintance with them came from Rebecca West, the purveyor of Balkan legends, whose huge book of travel, "Black Lamb and Grey Falcon," grew out of a six-week venture into Yugoslavia in 1937. We have had enough stories about the Serbian Czar Lazar being offered, on the Field of Blackbirds in June 1389, a choice between an earthly kingdom for a time and a heavenly kingdom that would last for "eternity and its centuries." He opted for the heavenly one and we know what terrible crimes have been committed in his name. If the romance is gone, so is the moral fury with which the first round of Balkan terrors was treated by gifted authors who spoke for us. Readers now are wrung out of sorrow, out of the surprise and wonder we bring to reading.
Misha Glenny, a British journalist, made his name with "The Fall of Yugoslavia," published in 1993. He chronicled what he had witnessed on the scene. The present has clearly emboldened him, and he has come back with a big book, "The Balkans: Nationalism, War and the Great Powers, 1804-1999." It claims to be nothing less than the history of the Balkans since the rebellion against the Ottoman Empire in the early 19th century.
A few years ago Glenny's voice -- with its knowingness, its sly skepticism about all the competing nationalisms of the Balkans, the hints that outraged outsiders who fell for Bosnia's Muslims didn't really know the area -- could sustain a book of reportage, and his journalism. There were readers (myself included) who did not find in his writing enough of their wrath against the Serbian revanchists. But the war gave him material and confidence. He was in his early 30's. Those were the truths he brought out of the burning grounds of Vukovar and Sarajevo.
Writing a big book of history is a different endeavor. Glenny tackles Balkan history in the manner of a CNN reporter working behind history's lines -- all the way from the revolts of Serbia and Greece in the 1800's to the present. The great historian Fernand Braudel wrote of history as the interplay of "stillness and movement." He warned that chronicling events will not suffice: "Events are the ephemera of history; they pass from the scene across its stage like fireflies, hardly glimpsed before they settle back into darkness and as often as not into oblivion." Glenny doesn't have the eye for "stillness," for secrets of a people's history that aren't easily yielded up to us.
He has assimilated and rewritten a huge amount of history, but his book is weighed down by its very bulk. He relies on anecdotes, so the book hangs by a slender thread. His theme -- that interventions by the great powers through the generations have added to the ruin of the Balkans -- is hardly novel. The observation that those interventions -- the Congress of Berlin in 1878, the wars and diplomacy that ushered in and settled World War I, World War II and its resolution -- guaranteed the relative economic backwardness of the Balkans, compared to the rest of Europe" will not do as economic history. The tangled tale of new nationalisms filling the void left by the collapse of the Ottoman and Hapsburg Empires has been told by talented historians.
The explanation offered for this book is that Glenny discovered that he had carried into his Balkan reporting "prejudicial baggage" and he had been "obliged to make judgments about Yugoslav and Balkan history" when he had only "the vaguest acquaintance" with historical matters. But that can hardly justify an inquiry of this length and ambition. With Glenny's new book, we are face to face with the fate awaiting places that succumb to political ruin: the outsider's presumption that a whole, big history is there for the plucking.
In "Kosovo: War and Revenge" Tim Judah, a journalist who has covered with depth and intimacy the region for The Economist and other publications, gives himself a narrower mandate and delivers a superb political narrative of the fight for Kosovo. It is now Kosova (its Albanian name); the city of Pec goes by the name of Peja; the town of Podujevo is now Podujeva. The world has been turned upside down; two-thirds of the Serbs have left their homes behind and the old fight between Serbian claim and Albanian demography has been settled in favor of the Albanians. The place is an international protectorate; a force of 40,000 troops sent by the United Nations and NATO plays the role of reluctant imperialist. In an odd sort of way, Kosovo has been folded into a Pax Americana, a destiny prefigured by Bosnia. The rescue offered Kosovo was late and hedged; it was triggered by revulsion against the Serbs, but the troops came in subdued and wary of the Albanians. Judah covers this whole story authoritatively, so his is not a pretty book. But his instincts are good; he has no ax to grind. He recounts the Serbian horrors, but also the later massive flight of the Serbs that created a new order in Kosovo. He records the lawlessness of the new masters there, the hard boys of the Kosovo Liberation Army who emerged as the inheritors of the place.
It was perhaps destined to end this way. Edith Durham, an English chronicler who was there in 1908 and is much quoted by Judah, glimpsed the great impasse between Serbs and Kosovars: "The white castle of Czar Lazar was but a dream in the night of the past. Around us in the daylight was the Albanian population, waiting, under arms, to defend the land that had been theirs since the beginning of time." In the new American-led imperium lies the promise of a multiethnic Kosovo and the lingering juridical claim that Kosovo is still part of Serbia. But physically and morally, the Serbs have lost their hold. The NATO air campaign launched in March 1999 -- 78 days, 34,000 sorties -- delivered an astonishing reversal of fortunes. A young priest in a Kosovo monastery, the Rev. Sava Janic, one of the few clergymen of the Serbian Orthodox Church to withstand the temptations of radical nationalism, tells Judah: "Kosovo has the same destiny as Asia Minor, once full of wonderful Christian sites and now all ruins and ash."
The Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic, not known for a flair with words, did allow himself one rhetorical flourish as he began a campaign to drive out the Kosovars under cover of the NATO bombing: the Kosovars, he said, like the birds, were fleeing NATO bombs. This was one of the great moral riddles at the heart of the war in Kosovo. And it is a central moral issue raised by the intervention, which Michael Ignatieff takes up in "Virtual War: Kosovo and Beyond." A talented and versatile Canadian writer based in London, Ignatieff comes to the Balkans with the gift of a family inheritance. In the Balkans he can tease out the presence of an ancestor who speaks to the present. His great-grandfather, Count Nicholas Ignatieff, a confidant of Czar Alexander II of Russia and in the 1860's and 70's a powerful emissary to the Turkish sultan in Constantinople, was one of the instigators of the pan-Slavic spirit then at play in the Russian Orthodox Church and among Slavophiles at court and in the press.
Furthermore, as a boy Michael Ignatieff lived in Belgrade in 1958 and 1959, when his father, a Canadian diplomat, served there. Such are the meandering ways of modern exile. "The bombing of Belgrade was never an abstraction to me," he writes. He recalls life there during "Tito's heyday," and his family's big house in "the leafy hills of Dedinje, near Tito's official residence"; he remembers rooting for a local soccer club and speaking Serbo-Croatian, a language that "no longer officially exists."
Those shadows across Ignatieff's path give his book -- a series of previously published essays -- poignancy and engagement. He works a seam running across our world between landscapes of violence -- Rwanda, Burundi, Angola, Afghanistan, Kosovo, places given to blood feuds and boys with Kalashnikovs -- and nations celebrating the triumph of the market and the spread of the Internet. He straddles a moral fence of sorts as well. He can't give himself over to the morality of the new interventionists; he can't sanction the indifference of the realists. Back and forth he goes between these two sensibilities, and the tension can be felt in the book.
In doctrines of just war, you can't kill unless you are willing to die. The "virtual war" in Kosovo, a "set of split-second decisions made through the lens of a gun camera," runs up against those time-honored notions, Ignatieff writes. It was fought by air crews and technicians; NATO fought "in the hope and expectation that there would be no casualties at all." Those were the terms under which the American president stepped into Kosovo. Technological mastery did the trick; the NATO leaders waged a war without mobilizing their societies. "What was new about the Kosovo war, therefore, was the impunity with which it was waged. But if impunity is required before values are defended, what exactly are values worth?"
I take Ignatieff's point about the "virtuality" of the war and the discrepancy between NATO firepower and Serbian capabilities. But Ignatieff exaggerates the novelty of this. After reading him, I picked up "The Light That Failed." In that haunting semiautobiographical work of Kipling, colonial wars have their own "virtuality"; the discrepancy between the colonial armies with the Maxim guns and native armies with primitive weapons foreshadows that between NATO and Serbia. The 1890's was a time of imperial sunset and Kipling must have intuited that: Charles George Gordon (Chinese Gordon) had lost his life in the Sudan. An army bent on revenge went up the Nile under the command of Horatio Herbert Kitchener. At Omdurman in the fall of 1898, Kitchener engaged the Sudanese. It was long ago, but a turkey shoot all the same: 28 Britons died, and 10,000 Sudanese. Over the horizon could be felt the tremors of the Boer War, which was for the world then what these wars of conscience are to ours today. Kipling lamented the distance of it all, its remoteness from England: "With the soldiers sweated and toiled the correspondents of the newspapers, and they were almost as ignorant as their companions. But it was above all necessary that England at breakfast should be amused and thrilled and interested, whether Gordon lived or died, or half the British Army went to pieces in the sands."
When Milosevic called off his bid for Kosovo a year ago, he gave his countrymen an accounting of losses by Serbia's armed forces. If he is to be believed, the Yugoslav Army lost 462 men, the police force 114. Lovers strolled on the bridges of Belgrade, so precise was the NATO bombing and so restrained. In the annals of Serbian history chroniclers lament the misfortunes of Serbia in dark times. They ought to make an allowance for another history. They ought to tell of the small price paid by Serbia when outsiders came in, against the advice of the pollsters and realists and believers in the primacy of "geoeconomics," to prosecute a just war, pulled into Kosovo as they had earlier been into Bosnia by the shame of what they witnessed, by the image of themselves they had seen in that Balkan mirror.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: What's Still Wrong With Kids Today?

BYLINE: By Ethan Bronner; Ethan Bronner, the education editor of The Times, covered the Middle East for The Boston Globe for eight years.

 BODY:

 ORDINARY RESURRECTIONS
 Children in the Years of Hope.
 By Jonathan Kozol.
 388 pp. New York:
 Crown Publishers. $25. 
 IN the mid-1960's, when Jonathan Kozol, an idealistic Harvard graduate, taught fourth grade in Boston's inner city, and emerged with a devastating tale of social neglect, he helped define an era. Like its title, the book, "Death at an Early Age," had the unadorned brilliance of a well-conceived slogan ("Give peace a chance"). Kozol was rightly seen as a young man of courage, a symbol of his generation.
Since that time and that book, much -- and not much -- has changed. School busing has come and largely gone, civil rights has turned into affirmative action, which has come under widespread attack. Roxbury and similar neighborhoods and the schools that serve them remain beacons of despair. Concern over continuing school segregation has waned. Now the talk is of uniforms, standards and high-stakes tests.
And while other activists of his day have shifted focus or sought different challenges, Kozol has spent the past few decades producing books, articles and lectures with the same lament, the same outrage. Most recently, in 1995, he wrote "Amazing Grace: The Lives of Children and the Conscience of a Nation," a depiction of Mott Haven in the South Bronx. Such works have seemed to some critics like yet more renditions of "The Times They Are a-Changin', "without the freshness and immediacy of the first version. In other words, Kozol, while a hero to some, was viewed by others as something of a pious, repetitive scold.
The title of his new book, "Ordinary Resurrections: Children in the Years of Hope," has the same evocation of faith as "Amazing Grace" and the same narrative focus, Mott Haven, an area whose concentrations of pediatric and maternal AIDS are among the nation's highest. And the book has some familiarly irritating qualities. It can be pious ("The life of a child, after all, is made up not of social 'constructs' or developmental 'trends,' but of much smaller things like stomachaches or hurtful words or red Crayola crayons") and mundane ("Even with caution, I think it is accurate to say that many of the older people in Mott Haven who have talked with me at length feel contradictory emotions -- and, at times, a roller coaster of emotions -- in regard to the conditions of their lives and prospects for their neighborhood").
Yet over all the book is affecting, in places deeply moving. This is the most personal of Kozol's efforts and the humblest. It preaches only rarely. Mostly, it observes the lives and explores the feelings of a group of black and Hispanic youngsters -- and a few adults -- he has gotten to know at a local after-school program in an Episcopal church and two nearby elementary schools.
Kozol has been visiting and watching these children since the early 1990's but, as he says, he had not before taken the time to get to know them as individuals. They were objects of inquiry, tools in a policy argument. As he started to age -- he is now 63 -- and watch his own parents approach death, he says he began to look at his life and work in a new light. The result is a book of small insights into the lives of inner-city schoolchildren.
This is a meaningful accomplishment. For all the scores of books on children and education published each year, most everything about learning is still remarkably mysterious. We are confused not only about how students translate squiggles on paper into systems of language and quantitative analysis but also why certain approaches work for some and not others and how to understand the nature of the link between education and economic success.
These questions are not answered in "Ordinary Resurrections," whose title is taken from the label an Episcopal priest once offered Kozol for "the commonplace and frequently unnoticed ways that people rise above their loneliness and fear." But in an unpretentious manner, the difficulties these youngsters face are made real: the fathers who are "upstate" (in prison), the drugs on the streets, the unconscionably overcrowded classrooms, the lack of art and music in the curriculum, the endless churn of uncertified teachers and new pupils whose families move from shelter to tenement. Sometimes Kozol tells a story with a simple number or two: of the 1,900 students enrolled each year at Morris High School, 1,200 are in ninth grade; about 65 make it through 12th grade.
Kozol takes us into the classrooms and homes of the South Bronx. He notes the syntax of the grandmothers ("I'm tryin' to sustain") and the language of the children ("I have the beauty of my mother and the braveness of my father"). A girl explains how she makes pancakes for her mother's boyfriend ("You pour it on the pan and then it's cooking on the pan and then you look at it until it gets a little brown and then you start to see the little bubbles"). Kozol says that in the past he would skip such digressions, but "now it seems to be the moments of digression I remember with most interest later on."
Living alone with his dog in Massachusetts, having no children of his own and with his parents ailing, Kozol began to look upon the Mott Haven community as a surprising source of human contact and comfort. He looks at the underserved youngsters and thinks of his own father, a Jew who grew up poor in South Boston and Roxbury but got into Harvard College and medical school and became a renowned expert on seizures.
What plagues Kozol, and what, in effect, plagues American education, is why the wonderful kids he comes to love in Mott Haven, kids named Elio and Pineapple and Katrice, can't walk in his father's footsteps. His father, he said, was "educated to inherit treasures" and then adds, "Why shouldn't Ariel and Pineapple inherit treasures too? My father's mother was ambitious for her sons. Their mothers are ambitious for their children. . . . What will actually happen to these children that we know?" Unlike Kozol's earlier books, "Ordinary Resurrections" does not imply that his eloquent outrage is itself an answer. Rather, with humility and grace, it helps us more thoughtfully ponder the question.

HEADLINE: Get Me Rewrite

BYLINE: By Louis Bayard; Louis Bayard, the author of "Fool's Errand," is currently finishing his second novel.

 BODY:

 THE OBITUARY WRITER
 By Porter Shreve.
 216 pp. Boston:
 Mariner/Houghton Mifflin Company. Paper, $12. 
 Unhappy Gordie Hatch! Twenty-two, just out of journalism school and exiled to the obituary desk of The St. Louis Independent. Entry level doesn't get much more entry. He sits under a lead-removal fan, pulls copy off the A.P. wires and takes calls from funeral directors and bereaved relatives who can't (or won't) get the deceased's age right. And when he tries to make the job a little more interesting by writing his own "advancers" -- premature obituaries of famous people -- his editor publicly humiliates him, in a way that only older men can do. "If I had wanted the obituary desk to have an advancer file," the editor barks, "I'd have asked for it a long time ago."
Meanwhile, reporters just a few years Gordie's senior have trampolined from local police beats to overseas bureaus and are now giddily tracking the fall of the Berlin Wall and the collapse of the Soviet juggernaut. (It's 1989, the annus mirabilis of foreign-news coverage.) And if that weren't competition enough, there's the ghost of Gordie's father, who, as Gordie's mother so tediously reminds him, was among the premier newshounds of his age, one of the "lodestones of history" who witnessed the Kennedy assassination and rode it into the journalistic firmament.
Porter Shreve's disarming first novel, "The Obituary Writer," is about what happens when a potentially career-making story lands in Gordie's bony lap -- in the person of Alicia Whiting, an attractive young widow who doesn't seem to be grieving quite the way she should. "You know what happens to widows who keep their husbands' clothing in the closet?" she asks. "They keep going back in there looking for memories. Movie stubs in blazer pockets. Little notes and lost dollar bills. I'm not going to be one of those widows."
It's all the same to Gordie, whose social life has been largely confined to eavesdropping on police radio dispatches. He can't get Alicia out of his brain; he can't forget her navy crepe dress, her black cloche. "She had an unexpected quality," he realizes, "an odd combination of formality and freedom, cardigans and chiming bangles, white flowers and ticky-tack, grand observations followed by self-mockery."
And she's got something else, too: a story. It's just a little hard to pin down. There's that little unpleasantness with her late husband's relatives. And there's an unpleasant love affair in Tucson with a painter of landscapes and nudes. And possibly some very unpleasant business with a suicidal science student in Fort Worth. Alicia, it seems, has changed herself to accommodate every man she's ever met . . . and then made each one disappear. She's the poster child for self-reinvention, and just as Gordie is struggling to get a handle on the current identity, she's busy forging a new one. She wants to be a reporter. Just like Gordie.
"The Obituary Writer" has the lean, propulsive structure of film noir, and on the surface it has all the archetypes, too: the intrepid young reporter, almost too dumb to live; the mysteriously deceased husband and his embittered spinster sister; and, of course, the black widow, draining men of their essence and swallowing them whole. What Shreve does so well, though, is to break down these archetypes, to reveal them as nothing more than the characters' self-aggrandizing constructs.
Resume padding is, in fact, the central activity of "The Obituary Writer." And no one does it more determinedly than Gordie, who, to impress Alicia, pretends to be a crack investigative reporter. And whenever Gordie's powers of invention fail, other characters rush to fill the void. His mother, for instance, finds out he missed a reunion date with his high school girlfriend and instantly embroiders an excuse for him: Gordie was hiding out in a warehouse, spying on a money-laundering city official. "I hated to lie, Gordie," his mother says. "But I had to tell her something."
Tell them something. That's the Scheherazade compulsion that drives the obituary writer -- and the fiction writer -- and pretty much everyone in this book (with the exception of Gordie's levelheaded old girlfriend, who is also the least interesting character). Shreve is not a colorful stylist -- though he is nicely economical -- and he has demanded perhaps a little too much credulity from his protagonist. But he has written an involving and sneakily touching story whose twists feel less like the conventions of a genre than the convolutions of a heart -- any heart. "The Obituary Writer" reminds us that we're all writing our own advancers, minute by minute.
 
http://www.nytimes.com
