HEADLINE: In Chicago, From Printing Plant to Technology Hub

BYLINE: By JILL SCHACHNER CHANEN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
A LANDMARK building that once housed the country's largest commercial printing facility is now being converted into a mammoth "carrier hotel" housing multiple telecommunications and Internet companies.
When renovation of the onetime R. R. Donnelly & Sons Calumet Plant into the Lakeside Technology Center is completed this fall, it will hold what the developers say is the country's largest planned carrier hotel. It will offer more than 1.1 million square feet of space devoted to the technical needs of telecommunications providers and Internet companies. 
 The eight-story, English Gothic-style Calumet Plant has been a fixture on Chicago's lakefront since it was built in the early 20th century as part of the historic Lakeside Press printing complex that was once owned by R. R. Donnelly. Publications including Life magazine, Sears, Roebuck & Company's Big Book catalog and the Yellow Pages were printed in the complex before operations there ceased in 1993.
Donnelly relocated its corporate headquarters from the complex to downtown Chicago in 1992 following the city's condemnation of part of the complex to expand the McCormick Place convention center. The company also moved most of its remaining printing work to other of its printing facilities throughout Illinois.
Developers of the Lakeside Technology Center say that the market for these kinds of facilities is strong.
"We felt that this was a relatively underserved market in general and in Chicago specifically," said Robert Stuckey, managing director of the Carlyle Group in Washington, which is developing the property in a joint venture with Core Location of Bethesda, Md. "We felt that Chicago is a tier-one telecommunications hub, along with New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles, and that there was pent-up demand here that was not being served."
The onetime Lakeside Press complex, he said, "had certain physical and technological features that set it apart from others."
Carrier hotels have unusual operational requirements, including multiple power sources, numerous ventilation outlets and floors capable of bearing heavy loads. Tenants of these facilities need to have self-contained heating, cooling and ventilation systems as well as extraordinary amounts of electric power and individualized security systems, said David B. Larson, a senior project architect for McClier Construction in Chicago, which reconstructing the building.
Because the Calumet Plant was built as an industrial facility, the building was ripe for transformation. It offered 14-foot ceiling heights, floors capable of bearing 250 pounds per square foot and approximately 30 existing shafts to allow McClier to adapt them as vertical risers for chilled water, electric wiring and exhaust, Mr. Larson said.
More important, the plant is just blocks away from the North American fiber-optic long-haul route, a major transcontinental fiber-optic cable route. The proximity will allow the building's tenants easy access to the fiber optic infrastructure that they need to run their businesses, said Michael Jacoby, president of Core Location, a developer of carrier hotels, data centers and other high-tech buildings.
The developers say that the renovation of this fabled building into the largest carrier hotel in the country is somewhat ironic, given that it was built as the largest producer of a different kind of communications. Built in four stages between 1912 and 1929, the Calumet Plant -- named for its location at the intersection of Calumet Avenue and 22nd Street on the South Side of Chicago along the Illinois Central Railroad tracks that follow the Lake Michigan shoreline -- doubled Donnelly's printing capacity. It also contained Donnelly's executive offices, an art gallery and a library.
The developers plan to restore the building's Gothic-style executive offices and library and will allow tenants to use them for meetings. Some 600 printers' marks, decorative stone shields depicting printers' tools that once decorated the facade of the building over the main entrance, will also be restored, Mr. Jacoby said.
THE Calumet Plant remained an active printing press plant for Donnelly until 1993, when Sears discontinued production of its Big Book catalog and company executives decided that operating the plant, which was spread over eight floors, was no longer economically feasible.
In 1997, Donnelly sold the rest of the Lakeside Press complex, which included the Calumet Plant, to Landmark America, a Portland, Me., development company. The company originally planned to develop the property into a mixed-use development, though construction has not begun on any of the buildings.
Landmark America sold the Calumet Plant to Core Location and the Carlyle Group last year for an undisclosed sum.
Chicago officials, who once worried about the vacant Lakeside Press buildings, are applauding the transformation of the Calumet Plant because it has helped propel an ambitious plan by Mayor Richard M. Daley to position the city as a leader in technology. To spur that growth, the city provided the building's developers with a $3 million energy grant to help subsidize the costs of construction. An additional $1 million in tax abatements was given to the building's anchor tenant, Global Center of San Jose, Calif., a Web-hosting Internet services company. as an incentive to cement the deal, said Jimm Dispensa, assistant commissioner of the technology development unit of the city's Department of Planning and Development.
Stephen Johnson, vice president of design and construction for Global Center, a unit of Global Crossing, a fiber optic network, said that the tax-increment funds had little to do with the company's decision to lease space in the carrier hotel, however. The company, which leased the center's 135,000-square-foot third floor, had been looking for a carrier hotel to house its operations in Chicago for some time. "We have studies that tell us what particular arenas in the world we should be in," Mr. Johnson said. "Chicago rated high in terms of what we could get for a customer base and for its proximity to fiber."
Mr. Johnson said Global Center would like to double the amount of space it leased in the carrier hotel but would be unable to because the 1.1 million-square-foot building was already 75 percent leased. Rentals in the building range from $26 to $40 a square foot.
Other tenants include 360networks, a fiber-optic network, and Qwest Communications and Level 3 Communications, both telecommunications companies, according to Mr. Jacoby.
David Love, senior vice president of network operations for the Vancouver-based 360networks, said that his company decided to lease space in the building because of its proximity to its own cable network. The company said that it would use its space to drop off its voice and data traffic and pick up other traffic.
"The fact that a number of other carriers like us are in the building" was a plus, Mr. Love said. "It makes it so easy to share traffic with them," he added.
Even though the developers' research had shown a need for this kind of space in Chicago, they say they were being taken by surprise by the demand for the space. "We thought it would take three years to lease this much space," Mr. Stuckey said. "It looks like it will lease up in one year."

PUB-DATE: June 11, 2000

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2337 words

HEADLINE: The Haves and the Have-Nots

BYLINE: By AL BAKER

 BODY:
TWO old men chatting on a street outside the Larchmont Post Office could occupy the same turf in Garden City. The sweet aroma of cafe con leche drifting out of a Mexican restaurant in Port Chester could be coming through the entrance of a Salvadoran eatery in Hempstead. A diner in Hastings-on-Hudson could be a diner in Oyster Bay, the same hungry eaters with their sport utility vehicles nosed to the curbs outside.
The weekend tag sales that proliferate each spring could be in Levittown or Tarrytown, Roslyn or Rye, any of the scores of bedroom communities that make up Nassau and Westchester Counties. 
 To casual observers, the two counties are nearly indistinguishable. Westchester is larger in land area, Nassau larger in population. Westchester was recently ranked the 7th wealthiest county in America; Nassau placed 17th. They share Long Island Sound and a state government. Both have fabulous mansions and pockets of poverty, Lyme ticks and West Nile mosquitoes and a border with New York City.
Yet one glaring difference sets them apart. While Westchester's government is the picture of economic health, awash in a surplus, with a credit rating that is among the best in the country, Nassau is in a budget crisis that will probably require help from every New York State taxpayer, with a deficit that has pushed its bond rating nearly to junk status.
How such similar counties evolved financially -- "like night and day" in the words of an aide to the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall -- is a tale of philosophically opposite methods of budgeting and taxing set against very different political landscapes.
In Nassau, one-party politics let Republican leaders make some disastrous financial decisions. For years, county officials forged a steady record of underestimating costs and overestimating revenues. They held the line on property taxes but paid employees handsomely, while selling county property or borrowing mountains of cash to keep government chugging along.
But their luck ran out last year as the deficit reached $300 million. An apathetic electorate was energized, humbling a legendary G.O.P. machine and creating a Democratic legislative majority for the first time. At the heart of the election was the budget mess.
In Westchester, more conservative budgeting grew out of years of competition between Democratic and Republican elected officials who held one another in check. Westchester's legislative branch was overhauled 26 years before Nassau's, a move that gave lawmakers more responsibility and provided needed checks and balances in government, officials on both sides agree.
Westchester leaders never got into Nassau's habit of using one-time revenues, like money from the sale of a hospital, for example, to pay continuing costs. They did little borrowing. And, unpopular as it was, they increased property taxes a bit each year to cover spending increases.
"The problems in Nassau have been a reflection of politics and history," said Bruce Nyman, a former Democratic member of the Nassau County Legislature, which replaced the Board of Supervisors in 1996. "One-party government controlled a part-time legislature that was able to rubber-stamp the executive branch of government. When you put the politics and history together, it was a recipe for disaster."
A comparison of the counties found the following:
*In Nassau, each resident's share of the county's debt is $2,065, more than twice as much as in any other county in New York and more than six times the state average. By contrast, Westchester's debt is $627 per resident.
*Nassau spends $520 million a year -- nearly a quarter of its $2.2 billion budget -- on a police department whose rank-and-file officers are paid $90,000 a year. Westchester has a much smaller police force, representing a mere 1.8 percent of the county's $1.17 billion budget, and the average officer is paid only $63,500 a year.
*When Nassau sold its hospital last year for $82 million, it used the windfall to help plug the deficit. When Westchester transferred its hospital to a public benefit corporation in 1997, it did it for $1, not seeking to make money off the deal. Similarly, Nassau used $170 million in tobacco-settlement money to pay for ongoing costs and to help balance its books. Westchester used $63.4 million of its tobacco money to erase hospital debts through 2005.
*The biggest share of Nassau's debt -- $100 million a year -- goes to repay homeowners and merchants who successfully challenge their property tax assessments. Westchester paid $9 million in such refunds last year. And unlike Nassau, which borrows to pay, Westchester pays with money budgeted for that purpose.
*In Nassau, property taxes are collected by towns and cities that first take their share and then forward the remainder to the county. If there is a shortfall, it is the county's responsibility to collect. In Westchester, the towns and cities collect the money but pay the county first.
Taken together, the effects of such procedural differences are staggering, experts say. Today, Westchester has the highest credit rating given by Standard & Poor's, while Nassau's rating is hovering just above junk status, with a downgrade threatened this month.
"I would say that if Nassau had used Westchester as an example of how to run a county over the past 10 years, Nassau's taxpayers would be in much better shape today," Comptroller McCall said.
But the tale of the two counties is also a story of residents whose lives are playing out differently.
While Westchester's 900,000 residents are gliding along on one of the nation's longest economic expansions, there's a recession mentality among Nassau's 1.3 million people, who are nagged by a daily sense of fiscal chaos, by the prospect of tax increases and layoffs of police officers and by cutbacks in services that are punctuated by protest marches.
Still, both counties boast of hordes of retail stores filled with shoppers with ready cash. Both have high per-capita income and low unemployment.
"The fact that Westchester didn't have Nassau's problems doesn't mean it's more affluent than Nassau," said Anthony A. Cupaiuolo, a professor of public administration at Pace University in White Plains. "It was just managed better than Nassau and didn't get involved in all the political games."
In Nassau, the problem comes down to one simple truth: there is not enough money flowing in to cover the amount streaming out, as County Comptroller Frederick E. Parola, a Republican, has been warning Republicans and Democrats since June 1996.
In Westchester, because the math adds up, deficits are unheard of and the cost of governing is balanced, said Kathleen M. Carrano, Westchester's budget director, who grew up in Nassau and was once controller for Glen Cove.
Nassau's fiscal tailspin started long before its deficit hit $300 million last summer. The county executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, a Republican, took office in 1987. While he oversaw spending increases for things like keeping parks pristine and ensuring that salaries for county employees outpaced inflation, he held the line on property taxes for most of his tenure. Feeling no pain, the voters for years rewarded him at the polls.
In Westchester, tax increases came in frequent small steps, keeping county income high enough that County Executive Andrew J. Spano, a Democrat, was able to cut taxes 3 percent this year.
"I think the reluctance to raise property taxes incrementally is a major cause to where Nassau stands fiscally today," said Dr. Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, Long Island's largest business group.
One beneficiary of Nassau's lavish spending has been the police department, where costs have shot up 64 percent in the past decade, and where lucrative provisions in police contracts -- one negotiated, in 1992, and the most recent one decided by an arbitrator -- have seen payouts for retiring officers reach the six-figure mark, with the average supervisor retiring last year taking home $207,000.
Westchester's spending on its police force is much lower, just $19.6 million out of this year's $1.17 billion budget, Ms. Carrano said.
The Westchester force, the Department of Public Safety, was established by voter referendum in the early 1980's, merging the sheriff's department with what used to be the parkway police. Today there are 273 budgeted positions, including 222 uniformed officers. That compares with 4,100 positions, including 3,100 officers, in Nassau.
To Todd A. Whitestone, managing director of public finance ratings at Standard & Poor's, it is not the cost of such things as police services that is alarming, as much as it is Nassau's inability to pay.
Peter J. Schmitt, the Republican minority leader of the Legislature, said Nassau must rethink what it can afford. "Nassau has always had the Cadillac of programs and everyone else has had Chevys and Fords, and we have to get to that," he said. Politicians in Nassau need the "political will" to cut costs, he added.
Of course, cutting jobs or salaries of any sort in Nassau has always been politically unpalatable because appointed commissioners, deputy commissioners, secretaries and others have been the lifeblood of a strong Republican machine, one that has held a grip on the county government for almost the entire century of its existence.
And Democrats in Nassau, hampered by their own internal squabbling for more than a decade, were often left on the sidelines by an electorate that "tolerated wasteful spending and governmental mismanagement," said Neal Lewis, executive director of the Long Island Neighborhood Network, an advocacy group.
Dr. Cupaiuolo, of Pace, said: "In Westchester, for quite a few years, both parties held active roles. Both parties have been healthier, and that is healthier, when you have two parties that are competitive. The impression I get is that Nassau is just riddled with patronage, and outrageously so, and the political culture was, 'Let's keep bringing people on, giving them good salaries, and this way we can stay in office as long as we want.' It certainly exists in Westchester, but I don't believe to that extent."
Nassau's problems are aggravated by its debt.
In addition to loans for roads and buildings, Nassau borrows just to keep government going. To cover operating costs, Nassau's projected cash-flow borrowing this year is $485 million, compared with just $75 million for the same purpose last year in Westchester, municipal analysts said. Westchester has no short-term borrowing scheduled in 2000.
"That is a big difference with Westchester's AAA and Nassau's BBB," said Diane P. Brosen, director at Standard & Poor's, discussing the bond ratings. "One big warning sign of fiscal problems is an escalation of debt and cash-flow borrowing."
Overall, Westchester has been closer to the mark in estimating its cash flow for items like sales-tax receipts, and its expenses for things like employee overtime. Only once in recent history, in 1998, has Westchester overestimated the money it would get in sales taxes, Ms. Carrano said.
Nassau, on the other hand, has consistently underestimated overtime costs and, at least since 1995, it has overestimated sales-tax receipts. Last year, receipts were $9 million short of estimates and the year before they were $33 million short, according to Standard & Poor's.
When gaps occur, Nassau has been slow to make budget adjustments, Ms. Brosen said. "They just wait and say, 'Whoop, you know, there is a big gap here,' " she said. But in Westchester, there is "ongoing budget monitoring, both expenditures and revenues," said Robin Prunty, the Standard & Poors analyst who monitors Westchester.
Michael P. Jacobson, a former budget official in New York City who helped the former Republican-controlled Nassau Legislature prepare a fiscal plan last fall, said he was left feeling that Nassau's financial management was "completely nonexistent." A key problem, he said, was that Nassau's budget office was understaffed, though adding people was a "heavy lift politically, if you are in financial straits."
"There was not a centralized, powerful budget office that was able to know immediately, on a real-time basis early on, what problems were coming down the pike, what to do about them, how to avert problems," Mr Jacobson said. "There was absolutely no multiyear budgeting. My sense is Westchester probably has a better management system. They keep closer track."
Most of those interviewed said political will had been missing in Nassau for years, especially because budgets must be passed just before Election Day, making tax increases that much more difficult politically.
Arthur J. Kremer, a former Democratic state assemblyman who is now a lawyer at Rivkin, Radler & Kremer, one of the Island's largest firms, said that in Nassau, "the government was sound asleep and failed to follow any of the warning signs" of a fiscal wreck down the road.
But unlike New York City in 1975, or Troy, N.Y., which nearly went bankrupt in 1994, or Orange County, Calif., which lost $2 billion in a risky investment scheme, Nassau threatens to crumble in the midst of a soaring national economy.
To Edward Glaeser, professor of economics at Harvard University, the case for a state government bailout of Nassau is hard to make, even though the first steps are in place with a plan by Gov. George E. Pataki to combine $100 million in grants to Nassau with a fiscal control board that would monitor the county's efforts to get its act together, and impose its own plan if it cannot.
"This is not a city like Detroit that is mired in poverty," Mr. Glaeser said. "It is a healthy place that if it were run with any sense of fiscal responsibility, should be very healthy."
But, he said, the comparison to Westchester is even more startling, given the two counties' many similarities: "In one area, fiscal responsibility reigns, and in the other place they are playing games."

HEADLINE: A New Effort to Protect the Sound

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
WITH millions and possibly billions of dollars in financing in the balance, a plan to create a reserve for Long Island Sound is being advanced in Connecticut and New York, which are bound together by the 110-mile-long estuary.
The reserve would protect shoreline and underwater lands, restore habitats and increase public access to the Sound, which is severely limited for the 25 million people who live or work nearby. Though the Sound lies in the most densely populated region of the country, it has attracted less federal support than other estuaries, like Chesapeake Bay. 
 Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, and others said the designation would improve the chances of federal financing by providing a conduit through which money could flow to the states, municipalities and groups involved in carrying out reserve programs.
"The Congressional climate seems positive for an increase in conservation funding," Senator Lieberman said. "Creating a reserve system might help the Long Island Sound region receive some of that money."
Potential federal funds include a share of $900 million in fees from offshore oil drilling. In addition, a bill passed in the House in May would provide $80 million annually for four years to clean up the Sound; the Senate version would provide $10 million a year for five years.
The reserve would begin a second phase in efforts begun by the two states and the federal government in 1985 to reverse a decline of water quality in the Sound.
A 1994 agreement between the states and the federal Environmental Protection Agency cited low levels of dissolved oxygen, a condition known as hypoxia, as the leading threat. It set goals for a reduction in nitrogen, which is generated by sewage-treatment plants and causes the overgrowth of algae that consume oxygen, causing hypoxia and killing marine life.
The nitrogen-reduction programs, paid for principally by state and local governments, have had some success in limiting the spread of hypoxia. But an assessment by the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection last August estimated that an area more than five times the size of Manhattan was still hypoxic, mostly in the western Sound.
New York City, whose four sewage plants account for nearly 40 percent of the treated sewage discharged into the Sound, is being sued by the state and by a private group, the Soundkeeper, for exceeding agreed nitrogen levels.
Most of the $200 million earmarked for the Sound under New York State's Clean Air and Clean Water Bond Act, and the more than $200 million budgeted by Connecticut for the Sound, is intended to lower nitrogen levels by upgrading treatment plants.
To date, federal involvement has been limited to annual allocations to the Long Island Sound Office, which administers the 1994 plan. Mark Tedesco, the director, said the program had received about $18.5 million in federal money since 1985. He estimated that fulfilling the 1994 agreement would cost $2 billion over 15 years.
Mr. Tedesco said that while hypoxia had been contained, there was no decisive evidence that it had declined as a result of sewage-plant upgrades, even though they had reduced nitrogen discharges by 25 percent since 1994. "I'm hesitant to say we have significantly reduced the problem," he said.
But he added that there could be a lag before a cut in nitrogen resulted in higher levels of dissolved oxygen.
Proponents of the reserve said it would move beyond upgrades of treatment plants to address acquisition of shoreline properties, measures to restore wetlands and related programs.
To involve greater numbers of people, increasing access would also be a high priority.
"We're spending billions of dollars cleaning up the Sound, and most of the people living around it can't get there," said Robert D. Yaro, the executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a private planning group. "It's probably the least accessible piece of coastline in the United States."
Mr. Yaro said shoreline acquisitions could also limit development, a kind of "insurance policy for water quality."
Save the Sound, which represents environmental and civic groups in the Long Island Sound Watershed Alliance, has identified 450 sites, private and public, that could be preserved or restored. William P. Shadel, a habitat ecologist for the group, said the group's goal was to preserve 2,000 acres of shoreline and strengthen protection along 1,000 miles of riverfront in Connecticut by 2007.
John Atkin, president of Save the Sound, agreed that land acquisition would "potentially have a very high price tag," but he and others said the cost of degradation from overdevelopment would be more costly.
The Long Island Sound Office has estimated the annual contribution that the Sound makes to the regional economy at more than $5 billion, with boating and recreation in the lead, despite limits on access.
David Sutherland, director of government relations for the Connecticut chapter of the Nature Conservancy, said development pressures would make land acquisitions challenging. But though "the prices may seem high," he added, "in the end it will be a bargain."
Mr. Atkin, of Save the Sound, said a reserve could also set aside surface and underwater areas for research into restoring marine habitats and understanding how contaminants affect marine life.
Proponents of the reserve cited the extensive lobster die-off last fall as a dramatic example of the need to learn more. Researchers said the lobsters might have been attacked by a parasite, but uncertainty remained.
Some lobster and fishing groups fear that pesticides used in mosquito spraying were washed into the Sound and killed the lobsters.
William N. Smith, the executive director of Fish Unlimited of Shelter Island, said dumping in the Sound of material dredged from Mamaroneck Harbor could also have played a part. Mr. Smith said the dredged material contained pesticide residues and other contaminants.
There are four dumping sites in the Sound. The E.P.A. and the Army Corps of Engineers are conducting an environmental study to assess the suitability of the sites.
David J. Miller, the executive director of the National Audubon Society of New York, said hearings in 1990 helped define issues addressed in the 1994 management plan. "We want to turn the corner and get the people behind this new initiative," he said. "Now let's look at the natural coast and how to connect people to that natural coast."

HEADLINE: Woolens to Backpacks, Textiles Stay Alive

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA CHAMBERLAIN 

 BODY:
SURVIVORS and newcomers to Connecticut's once-prominent textile industry have specialized, diversified and pumped large investments into high-tech, computer-driven operations.
"The textile industry in Connecticut peaked in the middle of the 20th century and, to survive, the companies remaining have had to make significant changes in their operations," said Peter Gioia, an economist with the Connecticut Business and Industry Association in Hartford. 
 "None of the companies could have survived without a lot of innovation," Mr. Gioia said. "Companies that are still viable have had to make significant changes and run streamlined and equipment-intensive operations."
According to the association's membership, the state's textile industry consists of manufacturers in 13 categories. Most of the companies, Mr. Gioia said, produce specialty products ranging from sailcloth to armored vests.
The textile specialty of one manufacturer, Warren of Stafford, originates with the Kel goat in China. The goat's silky cashmere fleece makes the long journey in bales to Stafford Springs, where it is woven into high-priced fabrics worn by the well to do. More than a dozen framed, commissioned photographs of the pampered goat, which is native to Kashmir, give an artsy, sleek decor to Warren of Stafford's headquarters in the center of town.
It's a dramatically different atmosphere from the one engendered by the century-old mill's former life in the rural, eastern Connecticut town, where Italian, German, Polish and other immigrants first ran the looms, and where the company's original specialty was camel's hair cloth.
Warren of Stafford, whose origins parallel the birth of the textile industry in New England, has been reborn as the only United States affiliate of the Loro Piana company. Loro Piana, a family-owned textile empire, is headquartered in northeastern Italy, near Biella, which is considered the high-end textile center of Italy. After buying Warren of Stafford in 1988, Loro Piana retained the mill's name in appreciation of local history. The site works well because of its closeness to New York City, the heart of the fashion industry and the site of one of Loro Piana's marketing offices. By the time Loro Piana arrived, however, Warren of Stafford's operations, like those of many textile mills in the Northeast, had shrunk.
According to the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, in Washington, D.C., the industry remains dominant in the southeastern United States, where eight states produce some 75 percent of the United States gross domestic product in textiles.
Like the Connecticut mills, the entire United States textile industry went through peaks and valleys during the 20th century as a result of wars, economic booms and downturns, trade agreements and foreign competition. "The last gasp in Connecticut was really the 1980's, when the last of the big mills gave up the ghost," said Bruce Clouette, a lecturer in history at the University of Connecticut in Mansfield who compiled the list of historic textile sites published in the National Register of Historic Places.
The United States textile industry today is a $69-billion-a-year operation, representing 8 percent of all manufacturing jobs, and employs 600,000 people in 26,000 companies in virtually every state. In Connecticut, which is still considered a manufacturing-intensive state with some 270,000 manufacturing workers, the textile industry has a tiny percentage, with 2,400 employees. Warren of Stafford represents 10 percent of that textile work force.
The company's fine quality woolen and worsted fabric is turned into expensive apparel -- suits, jackets and coats -- for clothiers like Hickey-Freeman, Joseph Banks and Brooks Brothers. Ninety percent of Warren of Stafford's business is directed to United States markets, and a high percentage of that is in men's wear.
"Our custom division sells to the tailor industry in the United States, and their customers include many wealthy businessmen and sports figures," said Roberto Modica, the company's 37-year-old vice president of operations. "Often sports figures have a difficult time finding suits in a retail store, and some of the tailors we sell to make suits for basketball players."
Loro Piana has invested $40 million in modernization of its Warren of Stafford affiliate, most in computerized machinery.
"The investment was necessary, so we can better compete with the textile mills in Europe and Asia," Mr. Modica said. "Our annual sales are $30 million, but we have the capacity and potential today to double that figure." For Bill Horowitz, 47, president and chief executive officer of Amerbelle Corporation, a specialty textile manufacturer and local landmark in Vernon, serving the customer, especially the international customer, is a high priority.
"We're seeking to grow partnerships in Europe, South America and Asia," Mr. Horowitz said. "It's important to these different cultures to know and feel comfortable with their business partners.
"Many U.S. business people are growing up with e-mail as the culture of communications," he continued. "It's important to understand that other cultures, such as the European, seek to break bread to develop personal relationships and gain trust. This requires the personal contact and rapport that so many Americans have lost the skills to develop."
Mr. Horowitz, whose grandfather was the senior founding partner of Amerbelle in 1936, has seen a dramatic change in the company's product line over the last six decades. Historically, the company dyed fabrics used primarily as linings for apparel like women's dresses and skirts, hats and men's outerwear. In the 1960's and 1970's, as those products became more sensitive to import competition, the company shifted to industrial fabrics for products like backpacks, bulletproof vests and parachutes.
"The company has once again reinvented its product line," Mr. Horowitz said. "Today, we service companies that need specialized colors, finishes and coatings for high-end fashion uses."
Those uses range from high-performance outdoor apparel for sports like skiing, mountain climbing and kayaking, to sailing gear and soft luggage.
Throughout the 1990's, Mr. Horowitz said, the company made significant capital investments in computerized dyeing equipment. "When many New England textile companies closed or chose to relocate in the South, we remained committed to the people in our local community," Mr. Horowitz said."The textile heritage of New England is still alive here."

HEADLINE: Loggers Look at a Tree and See a Boat

BYLINE: By DAVID MONAGAN 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT'S 570 licensed loggers are an independent lot, mostly hewing an unseen living in one- or two-man bands from the forests that dot the two northern corners of the state. But the 70 million board feet of timber they harvest each year is thought by the state to contribute about $414 million to the economy, in large part because the state still holds many stands of prime hardwoods that are valued throughout the world.
One of the most storied is the white oak, quercus alba, because it grows straight, hard, and clear grained, with superb rot and water resistance -- qualities all long esteemed by shipwrights. A Cornwall logger named Charles (Duke) Besozzi has found his way into the same market, supplying select timbers for the grand schooner restorations and one-of-a-kind wooden yachts that are being brought to life in boat yards up and down the New England coast. 
 "Connecticut white oak was once known as the best white oak of all," said Mr. Besozzi, 50, of Collinsville, who looks more like a prep school English teacher than a logger with his tousled chestnut hair, clear blue eyes, and sleight but taut frame.
"It is really good and slow-growing and especially free of dead knots in the Northwest Corner and just across the line in the Southern Berkshires and New York."
He was standing beside a 30-foot length of white oak from a tree whose first milling revealed hints of rose in its milky grain. The seven-inch thick timber, which Besozzi estimated was 175 years old, will soon be refined into the tapering contours of a yacht's keel by a seventh-generation Massachusetts shipwright.
"Naval architects will fax me the dimensions of a keel or sternpost or whatever they need, and I'll go out to find the right tree. I can tell straight away if there's a keel in a tree from the trueness and height and upper edge defects, or a natural sweep waiting for deck planking. Other loggers will also set aside what they think I might like," Mr. Besozzi said, pointing towards some behemoths with the name Duke painted at the end, "and I go around collecting the best stuff like truffles."
Jon Wilson, the founder and editor-in-chief of the Maine-based Woodenboat magazine, said there is strong demand among ship builders for the white oak of Connecticut.
 "If boat builders had to depend on commercial lumber yards, they'd go out of business," he said. "There is no question that Connecticut white oak is among the most highly prized stock.
"Wooden boat builders are extraordinarily dependent on the eye of a timber harvester like this," he said. "It's as if you were a gourmet cook and the ultimate meal depended on absolutely perfect ingredients; you'd soon realize that if you don't have those you cannot express your art."
Mr. Besozzi, who studied history at the University of Connecticut and spent his boyhood summers in Maine, first spotted the possibility of combining his love of water and wood after a mast hunting excursion to Cornwall by Mystic Seaport representatives in the early 1980's. At the time, he was harvesting upward of a half-million board feet per year -- typically, the more predominant red oak, cherry, ash, and sugar maple that are central to Connecticut's forest industry.
"I was just going like a demon, cutting a huge volume and not really that satisfied. I could visualize this continuing forever, producing millions of board feet without a real point. I wanted to do something for myself," he said.
Gradually, he began to sell raw logs and then saw out fine lengths for keels and planking for schooners and cutters, yawls, dories and Chris Craft motor launches. For the last four years, he has concentrated solely on his business, New England Naval Timbers. Mr. Besozzi and his assistant, Alex Ware, a wood technology graduate of the University of Massachusetts, have since supplied major portions of the sterns, stems, gunwhales, planking and decking for numerous grand projects such as the United States Park Service's 104-foot reproduction of the Friendship, an 18th-century trading vessel out of Salem, Mass.; a 60-foot Maine schooner that will soon be transporting cargo to and from the Caribbean; and now the elaborate restoration of the 1885 schooner Coronet just beginning at the International Yacht Restoration School in Newport, R.I.
"He may be the only guy I've ever seen restrict his business to naval white oak timbers," said Clark Poston, program director at the Newport school, who noted that some good oak can be found in Rhode Island and Pennsylvania. "He's finding really large old trees that a lot of common sawyers are not necessarily going to locate."
Mr. Besozzi spoke with love of the redolent timbers by his side. One piece was worth about $800, roughly three times more than its value at a mass production mill. Stacks of white oak trunks awaited his 50-foot band saw in a glen below Cornwall Village where he works.
"When you steam white oak, you can bend it like a noodle. Then when it dries, it just retempers itself and is as strong as ever. It has stringy, interlocking fibers that make it flex beautifully, which is just perfect for wooden boats, because they are flexing and living things."
But trees do not always reward the logger's affection. Mr. Besozzi himself had the middle three fingers on his left hand severed into stubs eight years ago by a log ripping chain. Chronic shoulder and arm tendinitis have also come with the job. In April, the highly experienced Winchester logger, Richard Hayes, was killed by a falling tree. Recently, another logger with a spinal injury had to be evacuated by helicopter from a nearby forest on Cornwall's Cream Hill.
"Logging is very dangerous," explained Douglas Emmerthal, who handles the state's certification and safety programs for the State Department of Environmental Protection. "The only occupation more so is commercial fishing."
Increased safety is another reason Duke Besozzi is delighted to be cutting only a fraction of the trees he once did. "Production logging wears you out. I am so much happier," he said, eyeing a massive trunk and seeing the shape of some ship to be.

HEADLINE: White Faces at the Blackboard

BYLINE: By REGINALD JOHNSON 

 BODY:
THREE years after the state announced a program to increase racial diversity in Connecticut schools, there has been little progress in achieving one of the key goals -- hiring more minority teachers.
The objective of hiring more black, Latino and Asian teachers came about as part of the state's response to the landmark Sheff v. O'Neill desegregation case of 1996 in which the State Supreme Court ruled that students in Hartford and suburban schools were racially isolated and were therefore being denied equal educational opportunity. 
 But four years after the court decision in the Sheff case, figures show there has been little change in a fact of life about Connecticut schools: white teachers do almost all the teaching. In the 1998-1999 school year, the latest year for which figures were available, 6.9 percent of all teachers in the state are minority, including blacks, Latinos, Asians and American Indians, up from 6.3 percent in the 1992-93 school year, according to the State Department of Education. Meanwhile, the number of minority students statewide has risen to 28.5 percent, up from 26.1 percent in 1992-93.
"I think it's a very serious problem," said State Representative Cameron Staples, a Democrat from New Haven and co-chairman of the Legislature's Education Committee. "Our supply of minority teachers has still not increased, and a number of us feel it is important to do that."
In cities like New Haven and Hartford, the percentage of minority teachers is much higher, 31 and 33 percent, respectively; in Bridgeport, it is 25 percent, based on data from the 1998-99 school year. In suburban school districts, the lack of minority instructors is striking -- in many towns, less than 2 percent of the total certified staff, which includes teachers, administrators and instructors, are minority. In Fairfield, for instance, the certified staff is 1.6 percent minority; in Suffield, outside of Hartford, the certified staff is 2.2 percent minority.
After the Sheff decision, Legislative leaders and Gov. John G. Rowland agreed on measures to improve the numbers. There would be increased magnet schools, charter schools, more interdistrict services and giving students in urban school districts the choice of going to a school in a suburban district, and vice versa.
The mandate also said that each district had to make an effort. School systems had to come up with a plan for hiring a more racially diverse work force, and the state said it would pay for regional recruitment services to help.
Today, school officials on the state and and local level said they are still trying hard to attract more minority teachers, but they insist that the process is difficult in a booming economy when many potential applicants are opting for better-paying jobs in other fields.
The progress in diversifying the teacher work force is alarming legislators and others, and the Legislature in the past session passed a bill setting up a special commission to study the issue of minority teacher hiring.
Civil rights leaders are also demanding that the state has to take a more aggressive role in dealing with the problem of minority teacher hiring.
Officials such as Roger Vann, president of the Connecticut N.A.A.C.P., said the state may have to consider some kind of financial rewards, such as signing bonuses, to recruit more minority applicants.
While Mr. Vann said he feels that most school officials around the state are making a genuine effort, some are not.
"There are some districts that have no interest in recruiting minority teachers, and local officials think it is offensive to suggest that there should be more diversity among teachers in the classroom," he said.
Mr. Vann said there have been complaints in Bridgeport and Waterbury about discrimination in hiring and a lack of support by white administrators for minorities. A parent in Westport -- where there's a handful of minority teachers -- filed a complaint with the State Labor Department this year charging that school officials weren't doing enough to create a more diverse teacher staff.
Many school districts said they want to hire minority teachers, but have difficulty finding candidates. Ralph Burke, superintendent for personnel at Fairfield Schools, said he's always looking for minority teachers. Fairfield advertises job openings in minority publications, lists jobs on a Web site and takes part in job fairs. But the results have been disappointing, he said. A recent job fair, put on by a number of school districts in the region, few minorities candidates attended.
"We had about 1,000 applicants show up, and you could count the number of minorities on two hands," Mr. Burke said.
The same goes for the number of minority students graduating with teaching degrees. Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven said of the 135 students who graduated with a bachelor's degree from the School of Education last year, 7 were minorities. Of the 195 students who received a master's degree, 5 were minorities.
Mr. Burke and other education officials said that minority college students, who might think about going into teaching, are sometimes drawn to corporations, which can offer a lot more money.
"An IBM or a Microsoft may knock at the door of a college student who's strong in math or science and say, 'We know you can start in teaching at $33,000 and have your summer off, but if you come with us, we'll start you at $55,000, you'll get four weeks off, and you'll be in six figures in four years.' I hear that's happening," said Tom Murphy, a spokesman for the State Department of Education.
Rodney A. Lane, dean of the School of Education at Southern Connecticut State, said there is a deeper problem.
"A lot have gone through urban school systems, so they have in their mind what their schools were like, where a whole lot of people didn't want to come," Dr. Lane said. "We've got to overcome a cultural and socioeconomic gap that is large and growing."
Maria Lyons, who until recently was the school personnel director for Bridgeport, said that the stronger economy, combined with a greater willingness of employers to hire people without regard to gender or race, means less women and minorities are going into teaching.
"When I was in school, women had certain roles," said Ms. Lyons, who is Puerto Rican. "You went into nursing, secretarial work or teaching. But now there's so many more options for young people and other careers that pay more than teaching."
Also hurting poorer school districts like Bridgeport sometimes is that they can't pay as well as some of the better-off communities. Bridgeport's starting teacher salary for someone with a bachelor's degree is $32,500, below nearby communities like Fairfield, or Norwalk, which pay $34,000 to start. "We have lost some people to other towns like Norwalk," said Marilyn Ondrasik, director of the Bridgeport Child Advocacy Coalition, which has worked on a teacher recruitment advisory committee in Bridgeport.
The percentage of minority teachers in Bridgeport, whose student population is 88 percent black, Latino and Asian, has actually dropped a bit from the early 1990's, from 26 percent to 25 percent.
Laura Williams, a teacher who is Puerto Rican, said she jumped from Bridgeport to Fairfield for better pay and benefits. Although she wouldn't say how much she is earning, she said she is making several thousand dollars more. She teaches Spanish and Latin American culture to fourth, fifth and sixth graders in Fairfield. She said she likes the job security that teaching offers.
"It's not very often that a public school is going to fold, but companies fold all the time," she said.
 There are some who say that money is not the only issue in Bridgeport's efforts to recruit minority teachers.
Gregory Bracey, who is black, is suing the Bridgeport Board of Education for discrimination, after he was turned down for a teaching job. Mr. Bracey, who has a master's degree in education from the University of Bridgeport and has taught in New Haven and Stamford schools, got a strong recommendation from a principal in the Bridgeport school where he gave a classroom demonstration as part of the hiring process. But he was not given a job and never given a reason. He said he found out later that it may have been because of his hair, which is in dreadlocks. "I had all the credentials for the job," he said. "I believe this was racism."
Ms. Lyons would not comment on the case since the matter is in litigation, but she denied that hairstyle would ever be a criterion for hiring.
Erik Brown, who is also black, said he got fed up and left Bridgeport for the New Haven school system in 1998 after he said he was harassed by supervisors. Even though he had previously been given high ratings for his teaching work in his first year at Bridgeport, everything changed his second year when he questioned a mixed evaluation given by his supervisor. After that, he said, supervisors came to his classroom every day to observe his work. Eventually, he complained to the local N.A.A.C.P. chapter. Mr. Brown claimed there was an "old boy network" of white administrators in Bridgeport who were creating a hostile work environment for black teachers.
Nancy Geter, the chairwoman of the Bridgeport Board of Education, who is black, said she had seen "no direct evidence" of bias in city schools.
"I knew there were problems there, but I can't say that it was definitely discrimination," she said about the Brown case. "It was a matter probably of professional disagreements."
The issue of discrimination has also been brought up in Westport, where Joel Freedman, a parent, complained to the state about Westport's progress in hiring minority teachers. Mr. Freedman said he had urged the hiring of more minority teachers at a town forum last year on racial tolerance. The event was held after racist graffiti was found on school lockers.
Elliott Landon, the Westport Superintendent of Schools, said there was no basis to Mr. Freedman's charge. While he admitted that the school system had only about a half dozen minority teachers, his office was making an effort at hiring black, Latino and Asian teachers. Mr. Landon agreed with officials in other districts that the pool of minority candidates is limited. He added that even though Westport pays the relatively high amount of $38,000 to start, the steep cost of housing in lower Fairfield County deters many people from moving to the area to teach.
"I don't think we have anything to be ashamed of here," he said. "If anyone wants to come in and check to see what we've done, they can do so."
Ms. Geter said it is critical that schools, especially those with high populations of black and Latino students, have enough minority teachers. For the minority youngster, she said, "They serve as role models. They motivate you to succeed. It's very important to have a role model to aspire to."
Carolyn Nah, president of the Greater Bridgeport Chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., said said more minority teachers are needed because they bring a cultural sensitivity to the job that white teachers may not have, that allows them to handle students better in the sometimes difficult environment of inner-city schools. She said that while Bridgeport's 25 percent minority teacher profile may look good compared with the figures in the suburbs, it's still less than it should be.
"More minority teachers are needed to better reflect the racial composition of the students in the schools in Bridgeport," Ms. Nah said.
Mr. Staples of the Legislature's Education Committee said minority teachers were important for the majority, too.
"'It is vitally important to introduce students to people of different backgrounds," he said. "There is educational value to integrate people of different ethnic and cultural groups as part of a well-rounded educational experience."
Mr. Vann of the N.A.A.C.P. and others believe the state is going to have to lead the way if Connecticut is to increase teacher diversity. The problem comes at a time when there is a shortage of teachers in general, particularly on the secondary level.
Mr. Vann would like the new task force set up by the Legislature to look a number of possible solutions. First is to develop a coordinated, statewide plan to deal with the issue.
"The burden of dealing with this problem is too much for one district," he said.
Mr. Vann also said he thinks the state may have to consider offering financial incentives for people who want to teach in Connecticut, such as signing bonuses. (California is considering tax breaks for new teachers.) Another would be relaxing some of the stringent certification requirements for veteran teachers from out of state, who want to teach in Connecticut.
Mr. Staples said he agreed that the state has to get more involved financially to recruit teachers. He saidtwo ideas that the task force will look at are providing funding to forgive some student loans and mortgage assistance for minority teachers willing to locate in areas where the shortage of minority teachers is most acute.
Alma Maya of Bridgeport, who is the executive director of a community organization that offers programs to help Latino youth, added that new bilingual certification requirements and other rules also have to be reconsidered, because they are making it harder to recruit Latino teachers.
"I'm not against strong standards," Mr. Vann said. "But we have to look at all the additional hoops we have put into the process, and how they may mitigate against getting quality teachers here. We've lost people."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
In Plainfield, Houses Will Rise on Foreclosed Lots

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE 400 vacant lots and abandoned buildings that pockmark the streets of Plainfield are a sign of the difficulties experienced by this Union County city. Hurt by the exodus of residents and businesses in the 1960's, it has been struggling back ever since.
Now the city is proceeding with a plan to rescue some of the 197 properties it has taken back or is taking back through foreclosure by designating a private developer to recycle 69 of them into 117 residences in 21 one-family and 48 two-family houses. New Century Homes of Westfield will develop the homes, which will be built in a factory in Scranton, Pa., and assembled on site. 
 Last month, development started on the first home, a two-family house at 675-77 West Front Street. It will be used as a model to market the rest of the homes, which will be built as they are sold, said Arthur Fefferman, a partner in New Century Homes with Peter Weissbrod, Stuart Fuchsman and Richard Goldberger.
Most of the lots, averaging 40 by 100 feet, are in the western part of the city, which suffered over the years from abandonment. The new two-story homes will blend with their neighbors in scale and price. The one-family houses will range from 1,366 to 1,489 square feet and sell for $129,900 to $139,900; the two-family homes will have 2,090 to 3,190 square feet and cost $169,900 to $179,900.
"This is a public-private effort to produce housing for and bring the middle class back to Plainfield," Mr. Fefferman said, noting that he and his partners hoped to build similar projects in other cities.
To keep the cost of the homes down, the city is selling the lots at a reasonable cost, he said. Also, market-rate mortgages with low down payments will be available to qualified buyers through several banks, including Fleet and Summit, Mr. Fefferman added. He said that Summit was providing construction financing for the $11 million project. The company also got a $500,000 grant from Union County.
The project, said Albert T. McWilliams, Plainfield's mayor, will return the lots to the tax rolls, as well as remove "eyesores from and improve the quality of life" in the neighborhood. The added hope, he said, is that it will encourage property owners to improve their buildings and other developers to invest in the city.
"Our dilemma is the rising cost of providing services in a city with a declining tax base," he said, adding that the way to close that gap was to raise taxes or bring in tax revenue. The sale of the lots is expected to generate $500,000 and their redevelopment to bring in $450,000 a year in tax revenue, said Patricia Ballard Fox, the deputy city administrator for economic development.
OF the remaining 128 lots, the developers are in talks with the city for 10 more lots for 10 more homes, as well as for a four-acre parcel to develop a building with up to 60 apartments. Ms. Ballard Fox said the city planned to sell some of the rest of the lots to nonprofit developers for housing and keep some for open space. Still others are zoned for commercial use and will be redeveloped for that. There are 234 more lots in various stages of foreclosure that if taken back by the city will be brought into the redevelopment plan, Ms. Ballard Fox said.
Mr. Fefferman said he was hopeful that his company would develop 300 residences in Plainfield. Ms. Ballard Fox added that "if the city works well with New Century Homes on the initial lots," it is likely that other sales would follow.
The current 69-lot phase is the first sizable housing development in Plainfield in almost 15 years. And as part of the larger plan to recycle city-owned lots, the project is the first of nine redevelopment efforts planned to infuse new economic life into the city.
Through the 1950's, Plainfield was the commercial hub of central New Jersey. In the 1960's, it, like other cities in the state, was hurt by racial riots, residential and business flight and crime. The city's redevelopment history, which focused mostly on reviving its downtown, also has been checkered, leaving it seeking new residential and commercial uses.
It is hoped that the nine redevelopment projects, which will produce 500,000 square feet of commercial space and at least 700 new and renovated homes by 2005, will change that.
"We want to set the stage for redevelopment before these economic boom times end," Ms. Ballard Fox said. Along with the New Century Homes development, the next two projects will be in the city's downtown and are expected to start by this fall, she said.
One is the redevelopment of a four-acre tract bounded by Park and Madison Avenues and Front and Second Streets. The site has been used as park for the last decade after several earlier attempts at its redevelopment never materialized.
The current plan is to fill the tract with a 130,000-square-foot, three-building office and retail complex, plus a garage for up to 320 cars. The state and county have agreed to lease much of the 80,000 square feet of office space in one of the buildings.
The other project will be the reuse of the 90,000-square-foot, five-story former Tepper's department store on West Front Street at the corner of Somerset Street, which has stood vacant since 1976. The proposal calls for transforming the building's upper floors into 80 apartments for the elderly, and its lower floors to 20,000 square feet of stores as well as 17,000 square feet of community space to be dedicated to the city.
Mayor McWilliams said he was confident this time around that the redevelopment projects would be realized. The difference, he said, is that "we have the support of the City Council and have dedicated an appropriate amount of staff resources to get the job done."
Discussions between the city and New Century Homes began in 1998. Mr. Goldberger, a partner in New Century, said while the city focused on redeveloping its retail base "this plan focuses on bringing in middle-class families who will become shoppers."
Mr. Fefferman added that the partners were drawn to Plainfield because "there was support from local officials and property values in the city were increasing."
Carl A. Reed, the owner of ERA Reed Real Estate Inc., a residential brokerage company in Plainfield, said the average sales price of comparable homes in the city ranged from $105,000 to $115,000. That represents a 10 to 15 percent rise over the last two years, said Mr. Reed, who is the project's leasing agent.
To make the numbers work, the city and New Century Homes hammered out a redevelopment agreement over the last two years. Under the agreement, which was signed in January, the city declared each of the 69 lots an area in need of redevelopment, allowing Plainfield to sell the lots to a private developer rather than selling them at auction. The parties then agreed to a sales price for the lots, which equals 5 percent of the sales price of the homes, to be paid to the city in two installments.
Home loans will be 30-year fixed market-rate mortgages with down payments as low as 3 percent, Mr. Goldberger said. There will also be loans with no down payment requirements, he added.
Mr. Reed, the broker, said the monthly cost of owning one of the two-family homes would be close to what people would pay in rent. For example, buyers of a $170,000 two-family home, using a 30-year mortgage at 8.5 percent with 3 percent down, will have a monthly cost of $1,950, including mortgage payment and taxes.
That is expected to be offset by the rent from the three-bedroom second-floor rental apartment, he said, adding that three-bedroom rentals in the city cost $1,000 to $1,100 a month. The monthly cost of owning one of the single-family homes comes to $1,350, he said.
There will be three models for each of the one- and two-family houses, which are being built by Simplex Industries of Scranton. All of the homes, which are expected to be built and sold over the next year, will have a personal computer, Mr. Goldberger said.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Next Step at Former State Hospital: Law Offices

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: CENTRAL ISLIP

 BODY:
AN eight-story brick building here on Carleton Avenue that once served as the medical and surgical building for the old Central Islip State Hospital is being converted into 175,000 square feet of office space by the Arlen Contracting Corporation of Garden City, which bought the property earlier this year from New York State.
The $12 million project, called the Courthouse Corporate Center, will add the office component to a master plan adopted in 1989 by the Town of Islip for the 788 acres along Carleton Avenue that were once occupied by the state hospital, a vast psychiatric center that at its peak in the mid-50's had as many as 10,000 patients. 
 The New York Institute of Technology has recycled 24 of the smaller hospital buildings for its Central Islip campus. State courts and offices, 800,000 square feet of industrial buildings, 487 town-house condominiums and 125 subsidized apartments for the elderly and a recently opened 6,000-seat baseball stadium, owned by Suffolk County and leased to the Long Island Ducks, have been built on the grounds of the old hospital.
A federal court and office building, designed by Richard Meier & Partners, working with the Spector Group of North Hills, is scheduled to open in August, and a 268,000-square-foot shopping center called Town Center is under construction by J. D. Carlisle Development of Manhattan and will be ready for occupancy early next year. Touro College in Manhattan is planning to start construction of a 167,000-square-foot building before the end of the year, to be completed in the fall of 2002. This will replace the college's law school, now in Huntington.
The Courthouse Corporate Center is within a few minutes' walk from the 495,000-square-foot John P. Cohalan Jr. Center, the state court complex, which opened in 1992, and from the almost-completed 822,000-square-foot federal building. It is expected to attract law firms and related businesses as well as high-technology companies.
Arlen Contracting bought the medical and surgical building on Feb. 9 for $2.2 million as part of a package that included 52 acres and 845,000 square feet of space in six buildings. In addition to the medical and surgical building, the other five buildings are the former hospital's power plant, laundry, a food distribution center and two administration buildings. All six buildings on the property were vacated about five years ago.
The property went to Arlen after it submitted the high bid to the state's Economic Development Corporation, which is selling off surplus state-owned psychiatric hospitals. This was the last piece of the Central Islip hospital property that was still state-owned. The hospital began discharging or transferring patients starting in the 1960's. Its only remaining presence in Central Islip is a small group home on nine acres fronting on Carleton Avenue. This is now part of the Arlen property, and Arlen is now leasing it back to the state. Its 25 residents will be transferred to the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in Brentwood in about two years when a new group home is completed there.
BEFORE Arlen can convert any of its buildings, rezoning for each must first be approved by the Islip Town Board, and state environmental reviews must also be satisfied. Rezoning for the medical and surgical building, from education use to offices, was approved last week. The project still needs approvals for landscaping and parking plans. Arlen intends to submit separate rezoning applications for each of its other buildings, said Alvin Benjamin, the company's president.
Arlen has tentative plans for its other five buildings, Mr. Benjamin said: converting one of the 200,000-square-foot administration buildings into a nursing home or housing for the elderly; converting the 60,000-square-foot former power plant into a gymnasium and day-care center; using the 80,000-square-foot former laundry as an industrial and research-and-development site, and leasing the 130,000-square-foot former food distribution center for classrooms. The second 200,000-square-foot administration building directly behind the Courthouse Corporte Center will be demolished to provide parking for 700 cars. The nine acres surrounding the group home are being viewed by Arlen as a potential site for a 140-room hotel. Mr. Benjamin said Arlen would take four to five years to complete the redevelopment of the 52 acres.
Arlen has placed CB Richard Ellis, an international brokerage company with offices in Garden City, in charge of leasing the office space. Annual asking rents at the Courthouse Corporate Center are $20 a square foot. Utilities and taxes are expected to add about $4 a square foot to the rents.
Two leases, one for 2,500 square feet and one for 4,000 square feet, are already being negotiated with two law firms, said Raymond A. Ruiz, the vice president of CB Richard Ellis who is in charge of leasing at the courthouse center. Tenants can lease space as small as 1,500 square feet.
Asbestos removal and demolition of interior partitions have begun as a first step in creating three furnished model offices of 1,500 square feet to 4,000 square feet. The models are expected to be ready for showing within 45 days, said Russell A. Mohr, Arlen's director of sales and leasing, and the renovated building will be ready for occupancy "by the fourth quarter."
Strong interest in leasing has already come from law firms, abstract companies, court reporters and mortgage groups, Mr. Benjamin said. "Originally, the question was, 'Would there be enough demand?' " he said. "Now the question is, 'When will the building be ready for occupancy?' "
From a designer's point of view, the major challenge in converting the building from institutional to office use was changing "the image of the building," said Louis P. Giacalone, the partner in charge of the project at Ehasz Giacalone Architects in Farmingdale.
The brick facade is being left intact, but two metal-roofed penthouses, each 4,000 square feet in size, will be added to the eighth floor. New windows will be installed, and a porte-cochere will be added to the entrance facing Carleton Avenue. A rear lobby will lead to the parking lot. Both lobbies will have granite floors, and the front lobby will have skylights. The building will be equipped with high-speed data and telecommunications connections.
THE building, which is 68 feet wide and 273 feet long, lends itself easily to an office conversion, Mr. Giacalone said. The elevator core -- two banks of two elevators each, facing each other -- creates spacious lobbies on each floor, he said, and floors can be easily divided into individual offices suites that range in size from 1,500 square feet to 8,000 square feet.
A series of formal gardens will be created on one and a half acres of sloping land leading down to Carleton Avenue. They will be planted with flowering shrubs, seasonal flowers and trees indigenous to the area. Outdoor seating will be added. The landscape architect is William W. Johnson of Southold.
Tenants leasing space in the building will be able to benefit from its location within the Town of Islip's 1.7-square-mile Economic Development Zone, which covers portions of the former hospital property. Companies relocating to the zone get credits on their New York State taxes if they provide new jobs, and they receive a 40 percent discount on their energy costs, among other benefits, said William G. Mannix, Islip's director of economic development.
The turnaround at the former hospital site from largely vacant buildings to thriving commercial and residential hub began in 1982 when the New York Institute of Technology, whose main campus is in Old Westbury, responded to a proposal by Michael A. LoGrande, then the Town of Islip planning director and later town supervisor and Suffolk County executive, that the hospital property would make an ideal college campus. The college purchased 31 buildings and 564 of the 788 acres from New York State for $5.5 million. The Central Islip campus, now reduced to 175 acres because the college has sold off or donated part of its property, now has 1,000 students.
Most of the college-owned buildings are smaller two- and three-story structures. Arlen Contracting bought the larger hospital buildings, and its plan to turn the former medical and surgical building into offices has been welcomed by community leaders.
"We are very supportive of the office building because there was concern that some of these big buildings might be difficult to recycle," said Nancy Manfredonia, the executive director of the Central Islip Civic Council, a coalition of civic associations that has played an active role in the planning process at the hospital site. "This will be a very attractive facility in a very visible spot."
The fortunes of Central Islip, whose economy was heavily dependent on the hospital where many residents worked, declined as the psychiatric hospital began shutting down in the 1960's. Now with the opening of the baseball stadium, the presence of the county court complex, a 50,000-square-foot King Kullen and a 20-screen Loews movie theater as the anchor tenants at Town Center, and the soon-to-open federal building, "the community itself has awakened and become excited about what is going on here," Ms. Manfredonia said.
"We believe we are on the leading edge of what suburbia can be," she added. "People have the idea that suburbia is boring. Central Islip is definitely not boring. We're a very exciting town right now."
