LENGTH: 1713 words

HEADLINE: The Republicans Are Coming, The Republicans Are Coming,;
For the State's Rank-and-File, It's Spit and Polish

BYLINE: By JILL P. CAPUZZO 

DATELINE: CAMDEN

 BODY:
KATHY ROACH practices her best handshake and smile in a simple exercise she and 25 other eager participants act out during an orientation session for the "Philadelphia Friends," a select corps of volunteers who have agreed to be on call 24 hours a day when Republicans converge on Philadelphia next month for its quadrennial national convention.
Ms. Roach, a longtime Ocean City resident who now lives in Philadelphia and a self-described "staunch Republican," sees the convention and her assignment as destiny. 
 "Everything I do, everything in my background has led me to this point," said the 41-year-old corporate legal assistant during a break at the Philadelphia Convention Center. "It gives me goose bumps just to think about it."
Clearly, she is not in need of a five-hour intensive Dale Carnegie training course on smiling and being a cheerful ambassador for the region, as many volunteers are.
In the meantime, across the Benjamin Franklin Bridge -- one of four spans over the Delaware River connecting the convention city with the Garden State -- a fresh layer of macadam has been laid across a large stretch of land between the New Jersey State Aquarium and the base of the bridge.
Over the next several weeks trees and flowers will be planted, grandstands and garden tables will be set up, and this expanse of waterfront -- until recently strewn with rubble from demolished RCA manufacturing plants -- will serve as the first official gathering site for the Republican delegates after they have arrived in the Delaware Valley. The welcoming event, a lighted boat parade followed by fireworks and a laser light show, will feature Governor Whitman as host.
Not every place revels at being a welcome mat. But when the governor started bulldozing liquor stores, strip clubs and hot pillow joints along the Admiral Wilson Boulevard here, that was precisely what she had in mind.
For months, New Jersey Republicans have been gearing up for their party's biggest event, being held in close proximity for the first time since 1948, when the Republicans -- as well as the Democrats -- came to Philadelphia. Then there was the Democratic Convention in 1964 in a badly deteriorated Atlantic City, which that city is still trying to live down.
From the governor to vice presidential hopefuls (which in this case, may be one and the same person) to future gubernatorial or Senate candidates, to Republican party leaders to local Republican clubs to South Jersey Girl Scouts, having the convention across the river is rich in potential.
Landing the convention's opening event was a major coup for the state, even if it was partly by default -- construction work along the Philadelphia waterfront is planned for this summer -- and largely designed to shine the spotlight back onto the City of Brotherly Love, since the waterfront here offers one of the best views of the city's skyline.
Still, New Jersey officials see it as a great chance to give the delegates an early glimpse at their state as well as provide an excellent platform for Governor Whitman, who remains among the handful of names being discussed for the vice presidential slot.
"The governor wants to be very active at the convention," said Rick Mroz, who recently stepped down as the governor's chief counsel and is her designee to the convention host committee. "If she's asked to give a speech, she'd be happy to. She has always believed very strongly in supporting the party, so no matter what the candidate asks of her, she'll be there."
Mr. Mroz added that while his boss had not engaged in the speculation about herself as Gov. George W. Bush's running mate, "she has said if she is asked, she would love to do it." It would not be the first time Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Bush shared the stage at a Republican National Convention; at the 1996 gathering in San Diego, they were co-chairman and chairwoman.
In addition to the July 30 boat parade, Mrs. Whitman plans to conduct tours showcasing such economic development sites as state-financed housing projects in Atlantic City or the faith-based housing projects in Camden where New Jersey has gotten them grant money as well as play host of one other large event during convention week, Mr. Mroz said. She has had her eye on the Philadelphia Zoo, but this being one of the most popular venues, she might have to get in line.
Just behind Governor Whitman are other party leaders, many of whom have had their presence at the convention assured by virtue of their "at-large" delegate status. While each of New Jersey's 13 congressional districts elect 3 delegates and 3 alternates, another 15 at-large delegates (and their alternates) are chosen, the ranks of which are filled with names like State Senate President Don DiFrancesco, Assembly Speaker Jack Collins and former Gov. Tom Kean.
Of course Mr. DiFrancesco and Mr. Collins, both of whom are expected to seek the office Mrs. Whitman will be vacating next year, will be looking at the convention as a place to raise their political profile.
Then there is the state Republican Party chairman, Chuck Haytaian of Hackettstown, who has his work cut out for him, not only trying to organize events where New Jersey party leaders can shine, but also making arrangements for the state's delegation.
Although the official delegation consists of 54 delegates and 54 alternates, Mr. Haytaian has requested 385 hotel rooms -- an increase of 100 rooms since the last convention in San Diego, when New Jersey showed up with the second-largest delegation. He said they needed that many rooms because of the large number of "honorary delegates" -- those who want to attend the convention but were not elected -- and requests from the media.
But while Mr. Haytaian may be able to arrange accommodations, getting everyone into the convention itself is another story. The 20,000-square-foot floor of Comcast-Spectacor's First Union Center will be largely dedicated to the convention's 2,066 delegates. Much of the remaining space in the sports arena, which holds 21,000 people for sporting events, will be taken up by the 2,066 alternates and 15,000 members of the media who have requested credentials. Each delegate and alternate gets one guest pass each day, which, by the time of the convention, will be the most sought-after tickets in town.
"People just want to go down there and get on the floor," said the harried state chairman. "That's great you want to do that, but it's not possible. We'll try to get as many people as possible in. It's very limited, and not easy, but since I'm on the badges and credentials committee, maybe we'll have a little easier time doing that this year."
Then there are the volunteers, who have almost no chance of getting on the convention floor but are signing up in droves nonetheless. Allison Grove, director of community outreach for Philadelphia 2000, has already lined up close to 12,000 volunteers, whose jobs will range from checking credentials to greeting people at the airport to manning booths at PoliticalFest, a public fair with politically themed exhibitions that will run during the convention.
Ms. Grove estimates 20 percent of those volunteers are from New Jersey, making it the second-largest feeder state after Pennsylvania. She cited two South Jersey Republicans clubs as among the earliest and most enthusiastic about getting involved.
After having Ms. Grove as a luncheon guest with club members last December, the Burlington County Republican Women's Club has processed 500 volunteer applications, said the club's president, Rosemary Nichols.
And the Cinnaminson Republican Club had so many people eager sign up that the Republican municipal chairman, Richard Stroebel, decided to register the club as a corporate team, giving club members shuttle transportation to various volunteer posts, plus on-site training. Dale Carnegie is providing training for all volunteers, focusing on customer service skills and team building, as well as providing a crash course on Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware.
"We want to make sure people are confident in their ability to act as ambassadors of the region, said Angela Brown of Erial, a spokeswoman for Philadelphia 2000. "They'll be told things like, never say 'I don't know' when asked a question and always smile -- things like that."
In addition to organizing his own club's participation, Mr. Stroebel has signed on to be one of the estimated 100 "Philadelphia Friends." He is taking two weeks off from his law practice to serve as tour guide, advisor and Philadelphia ambassador to the members of whichever state delegation he is assigned.
"It's so close, it's a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity," said the 36-year-old lawyer, who got his start in politics as the head of the college Republicans at St. Joseph's University in Philadelphia. "I was born and raised here. I know a lot about the area and I can help make us look real good. I can help the party this year too."
Although he has worked as an assistant counsel to Governor Kean and chief counsel for the Burlington County Board of Social Services, Mr. Stroebel is realistic enough to know he and he fellow club members may not be connected enough to get on the convention floor.
"From the beginning I was told that the reason for getting involved is to have a lot of fun," he said. "I tell everyone who asks about volunteering that no matter what they're assigned, they'll get a good taste of what a convention is all about."
About 60 cadette and senior Girl Scouts from Camden County will join Philadelphia girls later this month to begin cleaning up parks and helping make Philadelphia shine. During the week of the convention, they will also be on hand to greet visitors coming to Philadelphia. For their efforts, they will receive an "election connection" patch to add to their sashes, and a sense of being part of history.
"As Girl Scouts, we wouldn't ever endorse one political party over another," said Rona Whitehead, membership director for the Girl Scouts of Camden County. "This way we can get involved, and support Philadelphia and the election process without getting too political about it. How often are we ever going to have a convention in a neighboring city? It's a great learning experience."

LENGTH: 793 words

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS: FOR JOSEPH E. BACHELDER III;
Engineer of the Executive Pay Express

BYLINE: By STEWART KAMPEL

 BODY:
AS shareholders gather for annual meetings, many are finding in their proxy statements further evidence that executive pay continues to soar. Even severance packages for top executives can mount into the millions, or tens of millions. As a leading executive compensation negotiator, Joseph E. Bachelder III, head of a Manhattan law firm that bears his name, may deserve a share of the credit, or the blame.
Mr. Bachelder has negotiated employment contracts for Louis V. Gerstner Jr. at RJR Nabisco and I.B.M.; Lawrence A. Bossidy, the former chairman at AlliedSignal; and George M. C. Fisher, chairman of Eastman Kodak. He has also negotiated the severance package for David A. Coulter, who left as president of BankAmerica in 1998. For James Dimon, he negotiated both his severance from Citigroup and his pay as chief executive of Bank One. 
 Mr. Bachelder agreed recently to discuss whether he was doing too good a job. Following are excerpts from the conversation. STEWART KAMPEL
 
Q. What justifies these enormous pay packages?
 
A. Actually, they haven't gone up so dramatically. Over the last 50 years, the salary packages of C.E.O.'s have grown at a rate of about 2 percent over the Consumer Price Index, and in the 1950's and 60's the growth was actually lower than workers' pay rises.
Bonuses, however, are up dramatically. And so are stock options, as part of pay packages. Over all, major U.S. corporations are doing very well. Equity has gone up over 10 times since the 80's and 90's, largely because of the dramatic growth in the markets. And shareholders have benefited greatly. That's wonderful.
The U.S. economy has been growing, and the C.E.O.'s are the chief custodians for extraordinarily growing basic assets. This has been an extraordinary period, but it was just like at the turn of the last century. Just look at all those big houses in Newport.
What has also fueled the rise is momentum. There is a very competitive market for top executives. Executive search firms hardly existed years ago. Now they're so big that some have even gone public. That created a dynamic that didn't exist. So the corporation reflects the general prosperity of many companies.
 
Q. If the value of a company's stock drops, should executives with large contracts give something back?
 
A. What is compensation? It's pay for services over the long term and the short term. If I worked for 10 years and the company had 2 bad years, how should we look at it? The C.E.O. was responsible for the enormous wealth and growth of the company as well as the opportunity everyone had to ride with its good fortune. Except for a Michael Jordan, who never had one, C.E.O.'s can have a bad year. They do get fired. Some may "retire" at a young age, but a significant number are really being fired.
 
Q. Many chief executives are getting lavish perquisites like the personal use of company planes, country club memberships, a car and driver and services like secretarial help even after they leave or retire. Are you doing your job too well?
 
A. I would attribute these unusual perks to unusual circumstances. First, extraordinary C.E.O.'s win special arrangements. Second, precedent is very important. Then those precedents become the standard. Say Charlie Snoggs wants the same perks as Jack Welch. So he becomes a competitor. He's competing for profits. And he wants a competitive salary, pension and bonus.

 Q. Your experience is mostly with old-economy companies. What should an executive of one of these businesses focus on: wages, perks or stock options? And what should an executive look for in a new-economy firm?
 
A. For an old-economy firm, pensions are very important. C.E.O.'s move so frequently today that they don't build up pensions. So it's important to have the company ensure your pension. And it's vital to have it funded.
At new-economy companies, one strategy is to purchase stock with a promissory note, which qualifies for long-term capital gains, and then have the note forgiven. Stock options will allow you to buy when the company is private and to cash in when it goes public.
 
Q. More generally, how can an executive get the best deal?
 
A. Don't exaggerate or misrepresent your salary. You'll be found out. If you're going to work for a new company, look at their proxy statements, see what they are paying their top people. Examine the form and nature of payment. Try to get credit for your service at your present company.
What happens if there is a change in control of the company? Be protected.
Check the proxy statement to see the range of bonuses that senior executives can expect. And don't quit Company A till you get what you what you want at Company B -- in writing.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 8; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1177 words

HEADLINE: THE GREAT OUTDOORS;
Claims on Property Reclaimed by Nature

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: SOUTH ORANGE

 BODY:
Set atop a hill in the exclusive Newstead section, overlooking this township's quaint downtown and much of Essex County and New York City beyond, is a 30-acre quarry that resembles a vast, overgrown crater stretching a quarter-mile across. Jagged man-made cliffs rise about 60 feet above a small stream that feeds a shallow pond.
Deer, chipmunks and other wildlife dart in and out of the bushes and trees that seem to sprout from the rock itself, and hawks soar on the updrafts of the quarry's miniature palisades, level with the back windows of the houses perched on the quarry's perimeter. 
 "I hear owls at night, I've seen foxes," said Joel Levin, who lives across Underhill Road from the quarry.
But now 198 housing units are proposed for this area occupied by the abandoned rock quarry, which has been largely reclaimed by nature to form an extraordinary landscape set in the middle of this densely populated suburb.
As surreal as this setting may be, opposition to the development -- in the form of the 150-member Coalition to Preserve South Orange is relatively prosaic: traffic would be a nightmare; runoff would be ruinous; the schools would get even more crowded. Nor would Canadian geese stop off here on their seasonal migrations.
The coalition and its allies want to preserve the quarry as one of the few vestiges of open space in South Orange, a racially and economically diverse township of 16,000 residents whose income levels seem to rise with the topography, from the cracked sidewalks near the Newark border to the manicured lawns surrounding the spacious homes in Newstead.
In making their case, however, members of the coalition decline to mention the neighboring South Mountain Reservation recreation area, which stretches across five towns in Essex County and includes 2,040 acres of parkland.
Moreover, the quarry is private property, and is zoned for housing. It was also involved in a 1993 court settlement to satisfy the township's affordable housing requirement. In a proposed deal stemming from the court settlement, John Gross, the township administrator, said the quarry developer would provide $100,000 to rehabilitate housing in South Orange, and another $480,000 to finance what is known as a regional contribution agreement in which the City of Orange would create 40 units of affordable housing.
The owner of the disputed property is Gerald Turco, a developer based in Lyndhurst whose family bought the quarry in 1979 with the intent to develop the site. But plans to develop the property were put off after the death of Mr. Turco's mother and then the collapse of the housing market. Consequently, the family continued to operate the quarry until 1989, Mr. Turko said, noting that the gravel used for most of the Continental Airlines Arena parking lot came from there.
Mr. Turco is now under contract to sell the site, for an undisclosed sum, to Trammel Crow Residential, a large developer based in Rockville, Md., contingent on Trammel Crow's receiving site plan approval from the South Orange Planning Board. But Mr. Turco, 43, who grew up in Nutley, said he was still open to other offers, including a deal to preserve the site as open space.
"Nobody approached me with any figures," he said. "If I get something in my hand I'll respond to it."
Mr. Turco laughed as he recounted that some of the same people opposing the housing development had fought to shut down the quarry operation. "I can't win," he said.
For his part, Mr. Levin of the prservation group said that as open space -- perhaps with the addition of walkways -- the quarry property would be accessible to everyone, whereas housing would merely demand additional police, fire and other township services. In addition, said the 54-year-old neighborhood activist, more housing would mean more children and place a greater demand on the school system, resulting in higher taxes.
In November, residents voted to tax themselves a total of about $100,000 a year for the purpose of acquiring and preserving open space, joining 116 other municipalities and 17 counties in New Jersey that have adopted similar local levies. Proponents say the open space revenue, combined with matching funds from Essex County and the state's new Garden State Preservation Trust created by Governor Whitman and the Legislature, are obvious sources of money to buy the property, estimated to be worth about $5 million.
But the quarry, which is peppered with no-tresspassing signs, also presents some problems as publicly owned open space. Its cliffs and rocky terrain are hazardous, and some clean-up work is needed. Two aging yellow earth movers are parked outside a big metal maintenance shed near the quarry's locked gate. The rusted hulks of a felled crane and a dump truck containing corroded 40-gallon drums litter the middle of the quarry, where the ground is blackened and smells of fuel oil.
"A big hole like that is certainly going to be a nuisance, because some day somebody is going to get hurt in there," said William Calabrese, president of the South Orange Board of Trustees, the township's ruling body. Mr. Calabrese's house on Hoskier Road looks out over the quarry, and he has abstained from voting on any board decisions concerning the site.
Mr. Calabrese said he liked the open space behind his house, but his comments did seem to reflect what coalition members said was a lack of official enthusiasm for preserving the quarry site.
"If somebody invests $5 million in a property, they have the right to develop it, or at least get their money out of it," Mr. Calabrese said. Preservation of the quarry also faces potentially competing efforts, including plans for a $10 million arts center downtown.
Nonetheless, in March the township applied for $6.6 million in state open space money but did not specify what it might be used for.
Jeff Tittel, director of the Sierra Club's New Jersey chapter, who has visited the quarry, said it would provide not only badly needed open space, but a fascinating example of the resilience of nature.
"People forget, if you leave nature alone it will start healing itself," Mr. Tittel said. "Trees are growing, wetlands are forming. It shows all the values of a good piece of open space. The other part is, this is what the community would like to see. They voted to tax themselves to buy this property. That was part of the whole campaign."
So far, Trammel Crow has not submitted a site plan application, said the township's lawyer, Edwin R. Matthews, adding that in two informal meetings with local officials in March and April, company representatives outlined a concept involving 198 housing units around a loop road. They would include 58 single-family houses of varying size, 80 town houses and 60 apartments. Six large houses would be for sale, and the rest of the units would be rental properties ranging from $1,800 to $3,000 a month, Mr. Matthews said.
Jonathan Epstein, a lawyer for Trammel Crow, declined to discuss details of the project.
"The plan is evolving," Mr. Epstein said.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
For Some, Prep School Follows High School

BYLINE: By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

 BODY:
Brian Lyons finds himself in an enviable position. On Friday, Brian will graduate from Hamilton High School West, outside of Trenton, second in his class.
The 17-year-old straight-A student scored 1570 out of a possible 1600 on his College Boards and he has been accepted at some of the country's top universities. But he won't be going to any of them in September. 
 In what is a longstanding but little-known phenomenon, a relatively small number of students -- usually boys -- choose to undertake a year of additional study at an exclusive prep school, including those in New Jersey, before heading off to college.
In Brian's case, he will attend the Lawrenceville School in the fall, where he will be one of a group of students who want to polish their academic or athletic resumes. Each year, schools like the Peddie School and the Hun School of Princeton as well as Lawrenceville take on from 6 to 25 postgraduate students. As good as the students may be, many come to improve their chances of getting into a better school. In addition, students headed to military academies, foreign students wanting to improve their English and others who simply need another year to mature make up some of this group.
"People take the postgraduate year for a number of reasons," said Ian Gracey, associate dean of admissions at the Lawrenceville School. "Often, they feel that they aren't ready for the rigors of college life, and they want a year to mature. It does a world of good for most people. My younger brother did a postgraduate year and he just blossomed."
The programs are not usually advertised or pushed by guidance offices, so many students hear about them through word of mouth. Most will live on the campus and, while about 30 percent receive financial aid, the year will be as costly as college with tuition and board -- about $25,000.
Mr. Gracey said that the Lawrenceville School usually got 90 applications each year from students seeking to do postgraduate work, of which it accepts about 25.
"We look for someone with a great sense of initiative, and we like to see them adding something to the community in arts, athletics or having students from around the world," Mr. Gracey said.
The median combined College Board scores are over 1220, he said.
Marty Mooney, associate director of college counseling at the Peddie School in Hightstown, which takes from 15 to 20 such students each year, said these programs were not for students "who bombed out in high school."
"You look for a spark in these kids," Mr. Mooney said. "This is a nice steppingstone for them."
But it's not an easy step. Mr. Mooney said that most students were shocked by the rigorous academic demands and campus regulations. At Peddie, students have a required study time from 8 to 10 p.m. every weeknight. If they are going out on weekends, they must sign out and go where they said they were going. Smoking is taboo, and students are expected to participate in community service projects.
Drew Biemer, 19, of Haddonfield just completed his postgraduate year at the Peddie School and plans to attend the University of Richmond, where he will play football.
Drew said that when his parents first suggested the year at Peddie, he balked. Now he's glad he put in the time.
"It did a lot of good for me," he said. "At times it drove me crazy, but the end definitely justified the means."
Mr. Biemer said he also felt that the school's diverse student body broadened him socially. "I feel more attached to some of these people than the people I knew in high school," he said. "It's a lot more of a melting pot."
For students from middle- and upper-middle-class suburban districts, the postgraduate year often proves to be a time to live in close quarters with students from totally different cultural and economic backgrounds. Last year, Mr. Mooney said, an athlete from Cranbury was rooming with a very academically oriented student from Thailand who always stood up when he studied, and it was a learning experience for both of them.
"Lots of times this was the first time they've lived and worked with kids of such multicultural backgrounds," Mr. Mooney said.
Dr. James Byer, headmaster of the Hun School of Princeton, which takes 6 to 12 postgraduate students each year, noted that the schools also gained by the presence of the postgraduates.
"We expect them to be leaders," Dr. Byer said. "They add a degree of leadership that enhances the school environment."
For Michael Chiusano of Medford, who attended Shawnee, a large regional public high school, his year at Lawrenceville meant admission to Princeton University in 1999, where he is playing football.
"I always wanted to go to Princeton, and I got rejected and I wasn't happy about that," Michael said. "I was young and would have been 17 starting college. It was the greatest year of my life so far, and it prepared me for Princeton."
While the year helps some students get into Ivy League schools, they should not assume that they are buying an automatic ticket to admission. Harvard University, for instance, gets applications from 2 to 20 candidates a year who are completing a postgraduate term.
"A good year is a help and better is always better," said Marlyn McGrath Lewis, director of admissions for Harvard College, but it is by no means a guarantee into a school where fewer than 11 percent of the applicants are accepted. "Every case is different, and there's no formula for this."
Still, Mrs. McGrath Lewis said she has never met a student who regretted taking the extra year, even if he did not get accepted by his first choice for college. "I've never heard people say it was a mistake," she said.
Daria Guelig, 16, who recently graduated from Wellsboro High School in a rural area of north-central Pennsylvania, was accepted by William and Mary College, but she has decided to spend next year at Lawrenceville.
"I thought I wouldn't really be prepared for college right away," Daria said. "I think I could handle college, but Lawrenceville will be a good way to really prepare me. When I went there, I just fell in love with it."
As for Brian Lyons from Hamilton High, he realizes that a lot of people do not understand why he is going to Lawrenceville this fall even though he was accepted by seven colleges, including the University of Pennsylvania, Johns Hopkins and Cornell. But the 6-feet-2-inch, 235-pound lineman said his dream was to play varsity football for Harvard, Princeton or Cornell. He hopes to add 20 pounds to his frame and show an excellent academic record.
"I'm young, so a year of maturing would be good," he said.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Audrey Choi, Robert Orr

 BODY:
Audrey Choi, the chief of staff to the President's Council of Economic Advisers in the White House, was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Cameron Orr, a deputy in Washington to Richard C. Holbrooke, the United States ambassador to the United Nations. The Rev. Ronald Meyer, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Cleveland Park Congregational Church in Washington.
Ms. Choi, 32, is keeping her name. In 1998 and 1999, she was a domestic policy adviser to Vice President Al Gore, and before that held posts at the Commerce Department and the Federal Communications Commission. She graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University and was a Fulbright scholar in 1988 and 1989 at Georg-August University in Gottingen, Germany, where she studied East and West German feminist literature. 
 The bride is a daughter of Sook Nyul Choi of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Nung Ho Choi. Her mother is a lecturer and an author of novels for young readers, including "Year of Impossible Goodbyes" (Houghton Mifflin, 1991), about a young girl growing up in Japanese-occupied Korea. The bride's father owned KMC Enterprises, an import and export company in New York.
Dr. Orr, 36, also directs the Washington office of the United States Mission to the United Nations. He is a magna cum laude graduate of the University of California at Los Angeles and received a master's degree in public affairs and a doctorate in international relations from Princeton. He is a son of Bonnie and Jack Orr of Santa Barbara, Calif. His mother retired as the chief librarian at Santa Barbara High School. His father, also retired, taught mathematics and was a student counselor at Dos Pueblos High School in Santa Barbara.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLATIRON -- BUZZ;
At a Dot-Com Mixer, Ideas And Money Seek Partners

BYLINE: By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
THE SETTING -- First Tuesday, a dot-com mixer held monthly in scores of cities around the globe, arrived last week in New York, which one organizer called "the dot-com center of the world." Despite the dripping rain, about 600 prescreened participants crammed into Ohm, a restaurant-cum-nightclub at 16 West 22nd Street, in the heart of Silicon Alley.
At a registration desk up front, a dozen helping hands issued laminated name badges with color-coded stickers: red for venture capitalists, green for entrepreneurs and yellow for everyone else, including service providers, lawyers and hangers-on. The basic idea is to allow people with ideas (green) to identify people with money (red). Farther inside, past endless trays of hors d'oeuvres, attendees lingered under a mirrored disco ball, swapping business cards, talking shop and hunting for untapped e-commerce fortunes. 
 THE BUZZ -- "New York is a big step for us," said Julie Meyer, 33, who founded First Tuesday with several friends two years ago in a London bar. "People are operating at a higher clock speed here."
Allison Britz, an associate with Easton Hunt Capital Partners, a $100 million investment fund, said, "It reminds me of a singles party."
Even so, not all of the matchmaking was easy. "I'm making more effort than I thought I had to," Ms. Britz said, proudly displaying her red sticker. "I thought I could stand here and people would come."
Michael A. Porges, a partner with Andersen Consulting, one of the evening's corporate hosts, was unapologetic about the stratified glad-handing. "This is the 21st century way of networking," he said, standing next to a television set tuned to CNBC. "It's part social, part business."
John Marchant, chief executive of Business360.com, was equally upfront. "I'm talking to people so I can get money," he said. "We're looking for first-round investment."
Much of the conversation centered on "ultrahigh net worth individuals" or "angels," financial backers with more than $1 million to offer.
But there was also the usual rivalry of the new economy. "Everything is off the record," said Elie Poltorak, an entrepreneur with a cigar hanging from his lip. "I don't want my competitors to learn about my idea."
First Tuesday organizers said their events, held on the first Tuesday of each month, have garnered more than $100 million in seed capital throughout Europe and South America.
As the three-hour marathon ended, it was unclear whether any big deals had been struck. But Douglas Grieco, owner of a startup branding company, Take, left hopeful.
"I finally made a good connection," he said, heading back to the office with a fresh stack of business cards. DENNY LEE

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1450 words

HEADLINE: NOTICED;
Dressing Up Mini-Me

BYLINE: By RUTH LA FERLA 

 BODY:
ANNABELLA CACIOPPO is a creature of fashion. She wears bonnets and rustling silk onesies, spoons her Pablum from a vintage silver porringer and exudes the soapy fragrance of Bulgari Petite Maman. She is trundled down Madison Avenue in a Silver Cross, the Rolls-Royce of English perambulators.
Her mother, Jennifer Cacioppo, a freelance publicist for Ralph Lauren, can't do enough for her 7-month-old. "I bring her to the swings each day in her dressy outfits," she acknowledged cheerfully. "It's a thing of pride. You wash your car, you polish up your baby." 
 Six-month-old Tate Dubilier, another high-maintenance baby, lets his mother, Minnie Dubilier, buff and shine him like a pair of Prada boots. A former accessories editor at Vogue, Ms. Dubilier, who is married to an investment banker and lives in Greenwich, Conn., says she spends about $2,000 a season decking her son out in rompers and smocks and other traditional togs. "My husband complains, 'You dress him like a girl in all these little bubble outfits,' " she reported unconcernedly. "But my theory is, I'm going to dress him how I want to dress him until he has an opinion."
Like other new mothers in styleland -- a breed that includes Aerin Lauder Zinterhoffer of the Estee Lauder cosmetics empire; Cindy Crawford; Cynthia Rowley, the fashion designer; and Kate Betts, Harper's Bazaar's editor in chief -- Ms. Dubilier might be expected to turn her infant into a doll-size fashion statement.
What is surprising is that many of her contemporaries from all walks of life have lately followed suit. Women, enamored of fashion but without access to personal stylists or inflated wardrobe budgets, insist just the same on dressing their newborns like modern infantas or, likelier still, Lilliputian versions of themselves.
In the last year or two, the lust for chic luxurious infant wear has spawned a boom in designer bibs and booties, toys and toiletries, home furnishings and, in particular, fashions.
In the late 1980's, when Gay Empson went to work as the fashion editor of Child magazine, "infants wore pink and blue, and there it ended," she recalled, adding, "Now, there is such an explosion of everything."
What began with a trickle of posh merchandise from shops like Bon Point and Jacadi on Madison Avenue, has become a deluge, flooding upscale stores like Bergdorf Goodman and Saks Fifth Avenue and filtering into the mass market as well. In the last few months, upscale designers began offering layette, a wardrobe for first year babies. Now, new moms of means can stock up on DKNY cashmere cardigans ($60), Baby Dior jumpers ($165), Ralph Lauren velvet frocks ($110), Tommy Hilfiger khakis ($26), Jay Kos cashmere dresses ($395) and booties emblazoned with Gucci double-G's ($145).
More rarefied types can also choose from sumptuous knits designed by Stella Tennant, the patrician English model. Princess Marie Chantal of Greece says she plans to come out with a layette collection.
Or they can buy from the Gap. The chain, which pioneered the concept of adult fashions scaled to infant proportions and then added a luxury baby line in a handful of stores, now sells cashmere twin sets and receiving blankets in all of its Baby Gap outlets.
The appetite for high-style, high-end baby wares is partly the outgrowth of a vibrant economy. "People have more disposable income, and they want to represent their wealth in full," from the baby on up, said Evan Tawil of Tawil Associates, which manufactures Baby Dior, a licensee of Christian Dior in Paris.
Last year, consumers spent $7.9 billion on infant and toddler apparel, up from $7.1 billion the previous year, according to the NPD Group, which tracks spending in the apparel industry.
The increase reflects the tastes not just of affluent consumers, but of middle income mothers. Women at all income levels have become increasingly style-conscious, thanks to the influence of marketers and the fashion media, said Tracy Mitchell, the editor of Children's Business, an industry monthly.
"Naturally, they want their children to express that," she said. "Even at the discount level, there is a sense that merchants are catering to consumers' increasing fashion awareness. Everyone wants something special for their money."
Often that something is a scaled-down version of what the mother might wear. "If she looks good in capris, she will probably reason that her baby will look just as good in a small-scale version of the same thing," Ms. Empson said.
And buy accordingly, it seems. Baby capris, featured for summer at Target, sold out well in advance of the season. The store is currently stocking tiny denim jackets and drawstring mini skirts, and chambray jumpsuits for boys.
Macy's, which recently expanded its infant and layette department to accommodate an infusion of sportswear by Nautica, Guess, Polo and Tommy Hilfiger, also sells racer-back swimsuits and terry cloth robes scaled to an infant's proportions.
E-commerce sites have pounced on the trend. Babystyle.com, a favorite site, recently weighed in with DKNY onesies in denim blue and thistle, and a snakeskin diaper bag, the latter a recommendation from Cindy Crawford, a Babystyle columnist. Online or off, some of the most-coveted goods carry a whiff of nostalgia. At Best & Company, a new incarnation for children of the classic store and which opened recently in Greenwich, Conn., Susie Hilfiger, a co-owner (she is married to Tommy Hilfiger), sells traditional English garden dresses by Anthea More Ede, alongside hand-knit booties, antique bibs and handpainted garden furniture by the socialite C. Z. Guest.
Saks, too, has tapped its heritage, reintroducing a baby staple of the 1950's and 60's, a white beribboned bassinet filled with an infant's first-year wardrobe. Priced from $150 to over $10,000 (for a basket including a $1,000 christening dress), some 1,000 of the baskets were sold within two weeks of their arrival on the sales floor.
White wicker baskets, seersucker bibs and sailor middies conjure a world so sugary and fey you expect Mary Poppins to come drifting into its midst. Which is fine with Lillian Wang von Stauffenberg, a publicist for Verdura, the purveyor of fine jewelry, who likes to dress her 9-month-old son, Sebastian, in traditional blazers and Gap pocket T's. Abigail Daley, a Greenwich homemaker, shares Ms. von Stauffenberg's penchant for the conservative baby styles of the postwar years, insisting that her three sons, who range in age from 2 weeks to 3 years, all wear tailored shorts.
"Babies are so fair and sweet -- they belong in old-fashioned clothes," she said.
Consumers' current love affair with nostalgic products and packaging extends to toiletries, as well. One of the most popular infant items at Sephora and at Zitomer Pharmacy, the upscale destination on Madison Avenue, is Bubbe's Special Cream for Special Tushies, sold in a gingham-patterned tube on whose label a Gerber baby look-alike grins.
Such items are a hit with moms who groom their offspring to compete with the British royal family or, better yet, with the celebrity tykes exhibited in the pages of In Style. "There's a heightened level of rivalry when it comes to dressing your baby," observed Jill Sorkin, the buyer of infant and toddler styles at Bergdorf Goodman. "It's who has got the best, who has got the newest, and it's coming not just from the grandparents, as you might expect, but from the parents themselves."
At the Monogram Shop in East Hampton, N.Y., where the Lauder family buys its infant wear, Hadley Smith, a part owner, has seen it all. "If your are tracking down the jacket Aerin Lauder Zinterhoffer's child is wearing," she said huffily, "you are obsessive and you have a problem."
Noting that she had seen more than her share of overstyled, overgroomed infants on Manhattan's streets, Nancy Tuckerman, a co-author of "The Amy Vanderbilt Complete Book of Etiquette" (Doubleday, 1999), chided: "It's really a sad commentary when people are dressing their children up to make themselves feel more important. It sounds like the parents are very insecure."
Or simply style-besotted. There might not be much sense in spending $400 for a cashmere dress likely to be soiled or outgrown after just one wearing. But since when did sense have anything to do with fashion? "You know that if you walk around Manhattan in your Manolo pumps, the heels will get stuck in a grate," Ms. Sorkin of Bergdorf Goodman said. "But you wear them anyway."
The same law applies, for many, to dressing your tot. So what if she drooled on her designer denims? "At least you know," Ms. Sorkin said, "that she looked good while she wore them."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 12; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: CAREER ARC;
At Midcareer, Unlikely Segues Into Dot-Commerce

BYLINE: By AMY ZUCKERMAN

 BODY:
IF you called Central Casting looking for some dot-com-founder types, they wouldn't send you these people: the head of a quasi-governmental agency, a college professor who founded a nonprofit group, an industrial quality maven -- all past 40 and
well established on traditional career paths.
Yet each of them has taken a sharp turn into territory that the popular imagination reserves for 20-something nerds in sneakers and pizza-stained shirts. 
 Or maybe it's not so sharp a turn. What Sergio Mazza, Mary Furlong and James Harrington have in common are a knack for synthesis and an open mind about packaging their knowledge and experience in new ways -- characteristics that may matter more as prerequisites for new-economy success than technical wizardry or tolerance of 100-hour workweeks. Each started a Web-based business that extends and amplifies what he or she had been doing before.
They also have in common an entrepreneurial itch, of course, and they share hopes of big profits online. But world-conquering riches do not seem to be the main point.
"I'm more of an entrepreneur at heart," said Mr. Mazza, 41. "I like to make things happen." His previous incarnation was as chief executive of one of the most nuts-and-bolts organizations in the old economy, the American National Standards Institute, which represents the United States in world forums that set technical standards for a wide array of products and processes.
Impatient with the glacial pace of the regulatory arena, he left the institute last winter to invest in and advise two Internet start-ups: Revbox.com, which offers consumers service contracts on big-ticket Internet purchases and helps keep track of warranties and arrange service, and WorldWideTesting.com, an industrial marketplace that matches business customers with testing and certification laboratories. Both ideas grew out of his time at the institute, which highlighted the importance of assuring product quality in a global marketplace.
"I've returned to the for-profit world because I wanted growth and opportunity," said Mr. Mazza, who was president of the computer supplies division at Memorex before joining the institute.
He said he did not choose Internet commerce for its own sake. "I'm interested in changing the way commerce takes place, particularly changing the speed, breadth and accuracy of information that is delivered," he said, adding that the Web is just "a convenient tool."
RAISING start-up capital was a struggle for Mr. Mazza, but he also found he had to wrestle with a bit of a generation gap. Being "born old," as he described himself, sometimes made it difficult for him to work with fresh-faced youngsters in the dot-com world "who don't have a clue about running a business." The challenge, he said, is to help the two start-ups make the most of his experience while "working on not being condescending."
For his own part, he often reminds himself, however swept up he may be in entrepreneurial fervor, to pass up "good business ideas that involve bad people."
Instead, Mr. Mazza said, he is content with his current partners and keeps his focus on nurturing the two fledgling companies "until I'm certain they're successful."
"Maybe at 51 I won't like it so much," he said, "but I'm happy where I am right now."
MRS. FURLONG, the professor, gravitated to the Web as a kind of global classroom -- "a place to be empowered, and to learn and create as we get older."
Throughout her career she has made a habit of spinning off her three decades of academic experience into new ventures. In the mid-1980's she took a leave as an education professor at the University of San Francisco, where she taught teachers how to cope with new technology, and started a nonprofit organization called SeniorNet to do the same thing for elderly people.
Four years ago, watching the evolution of the Internet and "realizing the boomer generation would be quite different" from the seniors she had been working with, she founded ThirdAge Media, whose Web site, www.thirdage.com, aspires to be an online community and shopping site for first-wave baby boomers like her.
Mrs. Furlong, 51, says her teaching experience is central to her business. "I've learned to take in the hearts, minds and souls of my customers and make a plan for them to grow, just as I did for my students," she explained. Still, she said, she had to swallow hard and summon her tenacity and courage to make the leap from the security of academia to the risks of a new company. "I had to let my hair down," she said. "I had to learn new skills and make changes. Most of all, I couldn't fail.
"My father was an entrepreneur, so I've always been interested in taking an idea and bringing it to an international level," she said. "I want the business to be successful, to get a return for our team and shareholders, but I also want to make a difference in the world."
NOW in his mid-60's, Mr. Harrington is further still from the prototypical dot-com demographic, and he occasionally feels the tug to go fishing with his many retired friends. But he finds that tackling new challenges and learning new skills keeps him young. "There's always something interesting that I want to do that I haven't done yet," he said. "There's a continuous need to accomplish."
He spent most of a long career in quality management at I.B.M., where he worked for 30 years. He had the makings of a Big Blue lifer: as a boy of 12, his first job was setting pins at the company bowling alley.
But two years as the volunteer chairman and president of a professional group, the American Society for Quality, showed him wider possibilities. He left I.B.M. and remade himself as a consultant on quality management and business processes. As a consulting principal at Ernst & Young, he developed software related to his work, and software took him to the Web.
"Technology is changing so fast, it's opening a whole new world of business," Mr. Harrington said. "The excitement of being tapped into this new world is invigorating." Today he is tapped into three technology companies: he is chief operating officer of Systemcorp, which makes business process software; chairman of TQnet, an online quality-services provider; and chairman of Performance Improvement Network, a global group of consultants and information-technology service providers. The only link among the three companies is Mr. Harrington and his drive and energy.
This latest career turn required "some reassessment of my priorities and beliefs," he said, "For years I found myself in the teacher's role, but in dot-coms there are no teachers; we are all learners."
He is not complaining. "Putting it on the line, win or lose -- that brings me to life," Mr. Harrington said. "I see guys struggling around Pebble Beach -- they get older every day. I get younger."
 
This article inaugurates Career Arc, an occasional feature examining the turning points in working life and strategies for navigating them. E-mail: careerarc@nytimes.com.
