PUB-DATE: June 11, 2000

SECTION: Section 1; Page 18; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1104 words

HEADLINE: Yeshivas of Traditional Orthodoxy Flourishing

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
Down a narrow lane near the western outskirts of this city, wood-framed country houses and arching trees impart a rural feel, giving no hint that nearby is a place where a special kind of intellectual intensity rules the day.
But past a park can be seen the functional beige buildings of Ner Israel Rabbinical College, where the study hall reverberates with the voices of scores of young Orthodox men, debating one-on-one, across tables stacked high with books of Jewish law and tradition. It is an activity that occupies students here morning, afternoon and evening, Sundays through Fridays, before the start of the Jewish sabbath. 
 "The goal is not how much ground you cover," explained Isaac Greenberg, 21, a pile of well-thumbed texts at his elbow, "but how you understand it and how you incorporate it in your life."
Such a scene would have been a staple of Eastern European Jewish life a century ago, when yeshivas -- traditional academies for the study of Judaism's authoritative texts -- flourished. But rather than reflecting the past, what is happening here is part of a growing trend within Orthodox Judaism's right wing, its most rigorously traditional sector.
The number of collegiate and graduate students pursuing religious studies in these all-male institutions "has probably almost doubled" since 1980, to about 18,000 nationwide, writes William B. Helmreich in a new edition of his book "The World of the Yeshiva" (Ktav Publishing House, 2000).
Mr. Helmreich, who teaches sociology at City College of New York and the City University Graduate Center, said in an interview that the growth is primarily because of a high birthrate among the strictly Orthodox, and greater economic prosperity that allows them to provide more financial support to these institutions.
The Orthodox account for about 7 percent of the nation's 5.5 million Jews, but within that area of Judaism, a shift has been occurring. As yeshiva enrollments have grown, so, too, has the religious influence of the right wing -- at the expense of Orthodoxy's once dominant modern wing, which holds that Jews can be fully observant and highly involved in wider American society.
While modern Orthodox young people have become doctors, lawyers and other white-collar professionals, sociologists like Mr. Helmreich say, the right wing has been turning out a high number of rabbis and religious-school teachers, who in turn help shape the religious lives of many in Orthodoxy's next generation.
At Ner Israel, many people see growth around them.
Yaakov Feinstein, 26, of New York City, a student of Talmudic law, said he has seen the college add a dormitory and faculty housing over the past dozen years.
"I think it's more than Ner Israel, I think the total community is growing," Mr. Feinstein said.
As for the college, he said, "We're really here to be God-fearing Jews."
Ner Israel was founded in Baltimore in 1933 by Rabbi Jacob I. Ruderman, a Lithuanian immigrant, who began with 15 students. Now, 800 boys and young men attend the high school, collegiate and graduate programs. The college's enrollment has grown by 50 percent since 1985.
Among yeshivas, Ner Israel is unusual in that it has always allowed students access to secular, professional education. The college is accredited by the state of Maryland and has agreements with public and private universities at which its students can major in law, business and other subjects.
The roster of recent alumni includes bankers, accountants and psychologists -- as well as rabbis and religious-school teachers, who college officials say make up 50 percent of graduates.
Ner Israel's mission statement makes clear its priority is religious studies. Students pursuing secular degrees are asked to limit their work to nights or summer. The college's purpose, the statement says, is to preserve "a rareified environment" for dedication to "intense Torah study."
At the heart of that study is chavrusa, students working in pairs, each young man selecting a partner based on intellectual and social compatibility. In the daily debate over religious texts lies educational growth, college officials say.
How long do they spend in this kind of study? "I'd say you've got to figure eight hours a day, at least on average," said Rabbi Ezra Neuberger, dean of the graduate school. "The more diligent would be a lot more."
Down the hill from the academic buildings is a residential area called Yeshiva Lane, where modestly dressed women with head coverings supervise flocks of children outside the six-bedroom town houses and three-bedroom apartments, built for faculty and graduate students.
The sight suggests a self-contained community, but the college has built ties to Orthodox Jews worldwide. Since the revolution in Iran two decades ago, it has taken in Iranian Jewish refugees. Nearly 50 study here now, said one of their rabbis, who asked not to be named out of concern for relatives in Iran.
But there are others from overseas, too. "There are a lot of South Americans here, a lot of Europeans, a lot of Australians," said Rafael Mael, 20, of Baltimore. "I've roomed with people from Chile and Panama."
A person who has helped foster ties to Latin American communities is Moshe Filler, 34, who came from Mexico City and enrolled in Ner Israel to study as a teacher some years ago. Now he runs programs that bring young Latin American Jews to study for the summer on campus, while maintaining the college's links with Jewish communities in Bolivia, Costa Rica, Peru and elsewhere.
"This has become like a center for all these communities," Mr. Filler said.
His job involves considerable travel. "Last week I was in Chile," he said. "Today, I go to Guatemala."
Tuition at Ner Israel is $9,000 a year, but only a minority of students pay full fare. The college considers its applicants first, then finds out if those it accepts can pay, said Rabbi Herman N. Neuberger, the president. "We feel we do make a contribution to the spiritual life of America through training of our young men," he said.
Many students have come here from Orthodox day schools. But some have taken a different route.
Among the latter is Gil Neuman, 31, who arrived in October after two years' study in Israel. Before that, he worked in Hollywood, producing and writing films.
But his life changed one Friday evening when he attended a Sabbath dinner at the home of a Ner Israel graduate, where, he said, he was deeply impressed with the religious lives of those he met.
"People had a sense of purpose and a sense of meaning that nobody has in today's world," Mr. Neuman said.

HEADLINE: City Unions Warn of Unrest If Talks on Contracts Stall

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Union leaders representing 300,000 New York City municipal workers say their members are growing increasingly angry about the lack of progress in labor negotiations that could be one of the last big tests of Rudolph W. Giuliani's mayoralty.
The contracts of half the city's work force have already expired, and the leaders say their unions may hold large demonstrations outside City Hall if the negotiations do not show significant progress soon. 
 The municipal unions have taken the position that Mr. Giuliani should be especially generous in this round of negotiations because the city has projected a $3.2 billion budget surplus and because city workers had accepted a two-year wage freeze in their previous contract.
"Clearly there is economic prosperity in the city," said Lee Saunders, the trustee running District Council 37, the umbrella union representing 125,000 municipal workers. "Our members sacrificed in the past when the city was experiencing financial difficulties. Our members made sacrifices in their wages and pension funds, and now that the city is in strong financial shape, we should be rewarded with increased wages and benefits."
In interviews, the leaders of the city's largest municipal unions said they saw one major obstacle to progress in the talks: Mr. Giuliani's demand that there be no across-the-board wage increase, but instead individualized merit increases in which some workers would receive no raise while others might receive up to 6 percent a year. Several union leaders denounced the mayor's proposal, saying it would leave many workers without raises and would create tensions between union members who receive merit raises and those who do not.
"It's not realistic to ask our members to accept a system of individualized merit pay," said Patrick Lynch, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. "Every police officer should get a merit pay increase because every police officer did work that helped bring about a substantial reduction in crime."
Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, also criticized the mayor's proposal, saying: "There's not one union in the City of New York that will accept a contract without a pay increase for all of its members. Ultimately, if the mayor stays on this course of individualized merit pay or nothing, then nobody's going to do a contract with him, and then it's clear to me that he's just not serious about bargaining."
But Deputy Mayor Robert M. Harding insisted that Mr. Giuliani was indeed serious about bargaining. "He's already shown his ability to negotiate with the unions," he said.
Mr. Harding said that in the last round of citywide bargaining, Mr. Giuliani and the city's unions successfully negotiated a five-year contract that included a no-layoff clause, a two-year wage freeze and a 12 percent increase over the last three years. He also noted that the city reached a pension agreement with the unions just two weeks ago.
That agreement, which would require state legislation to take effect, would reduce the percentage of annual salary that city workers contribute to their pensions each year by about 3 percent. In return, the unions approved a plan to let the city use $808 million from unexpectedly high investment profits from union pension funds. The one-time windfall would be used in the city's operating budget.
Some labor experts say that some of that money may be used to finance a labor contract (each 1 percent wage increase in the city's payroll costs about $160 million). Several experts said they expected that Mr. Giuliani would eventually make a fallback proposal that included a modest wage increase for all employees and individual merit increases on top of that. In the handful of negotiating sessions held so far, the unions have demanded a substantial wage increase without specifying a percentage.
James F. Hanley, the city's labor commissioner, said the recently negotiated pension agreement created a spirit of cooperation that could give some momentum to the collective bargaining. He added that the unions would feel some pressure to reach an agreement because their members would not see reductions in their pension contributions until an overall labor agreement was reached.
But he would not predict when an agreement might be reached.
"We're still in the early stages," Mr. Hanley said.
Some union leaders said Mr. Giuliani's decision not to run for the United States Senate would make it easier to reach an agreement, suggesting that Mr. Giuliani had taken his hard-line approach to bargaining as a campaign strategy to please upstate Republicans and conservative donors from outside New York.
Mr. Giuliani's aides said, however, that the mayor had adopted his merit pay proposal because he considered it the best way to make the city's work force more productive. Good workers, these aides said, would be rewarded while unproductive workers might be persuaded to shape up or leave the city's work force.
Norman Adler, a political consultant, said the mayor's withdrawal from the Senate race could make it harder to reach a labor agreement. He said that as a candidate, the mayor might have pushed for contracts to win the backing of several unions, most likely the firefighter and police unions, or to neutralize them.
"I don't think he wanted to have any union job actions to take place while he was a candidate," Mr. Adler said. "You want to keep the seas as smooth as possible while you're sailing toward Election Day. Now that he's not running, he can play this game any way he wants. There are no electoral consequences."
Ms. Weingarten, who is chairwoman of the Municipal Labor Coalition, which coordinates bargaining for all the city's unions, said the unions had a plan calling for them to step up pressure on the city if there was no agreement soon. Her union, which represents more than 80,000 teachers and guidance counselors, is planning to picket at city schools on June 21 and has started a $3 million advertising campaign about the need for higher teacher pay.
"They have a $3.2 billion surplus," she said. "They have money for labor negotiations this year. They should just do a contract. If not, the unions will continue to escalate their public campaign to win a good contract."
Mr. Harding gave City Hall's response to such a pressure campaign. "That's a threat," he said. "We don't respond to threats."
Mr. Harding took sharp issue with statements that much of the surplus should be devoted to large wage increases. "If you took the city's surpluses and you spent it on any one thing," he said, "you would have such large deficits in future years that you wouldn't be able to keep the budgetary commitments that we made this year."
Carroll Haynes, president of Teamsters Local 237, which represents 20,000 Housing Authority workers and other city employees, insisted that municipal workers should benefit from the surplus after having endured a wage freeze, pension givebacks and layoffs to help restore the city's financial health.
"Our motto right now is, 'We shared in the pain over a five-year period, now we wish to share in the gains of a $3 billion surplus,' " Mr. Haynes said.
One of Local 237's contracts with the city expired on Dec. 31 and the other on March 31. District Council 37's contract expired March 31. The contract of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association expires July 31, while the teachers' contract expires Oct. 31.
State law bars teachers and other government employees from striking.

HEADLINE: Countdown to the Parade, With Pride and Profit

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Each spring for the last 20 years, Nestor Rantas has traveled to the Bronx from Juana Diaz, P.R., to sell hats, T-shirts, key chains and anything else bearing the colors or name of his native land.
So it was no surprise that early yesterday, the day before the annual Puerto Rican Day Parade in Manhattan, Mr. Rantas, 44, was standing near Southern Boulevard with a bundle of flags in his hands. 
 He was a small dot in a sea of red, white and blue flags on East Tremont Avenue. Men carrying their own collections of flags and hats came by and asked what he still had in stock. Some were looking for flags to place on their cars or to drape around themselves during the parade; others were sellers trying to stock up.
Each year in the weeks before the parade, hundreds, perhaps thousands of vendors and hawkers take to the streets of the Bronx to sell the symbols that unite proud Puerto Ricans, many of whom travel across the country for the event.
And the East Tremont neighborhood, where Mr. Rantas also owns the Borinquen Records store, is at the center of that industry.
At first, Mr. Rantas said, he sold the apparel "for the people of Puerto Rico." But his next comment, which came after the driver of a flatbed truck stopped to pick up a flag and hoist it, suggested a motive somewhat less altruistic.
Mr. Rantas said he made tens of thousands of dollars each spring selling the items on the street and in his nearby store. But he does think that the economic returns show another type of pride.
"For Puerto Rico, everything," he said. "It is also good for the community because so many people are buying flags and selling them on the streets, and that helps the community."
Among New York City's many annual parades, the Puerto Rican Day Parade is particularly merchandise-rich. In the weeks before the event, flags begin popping up in windows all over heavily Puerto Rican sections of East Tremont and Mott Haven in the Bronx, East Williamsburg in Brooklyn and the Lower East Side and East Village in Manhattan.
People also drape flags on the hoods of their cars or use them as shawls, hang trinkets in their cars and wear T-shirts emblazoned with phrases like "I love you Puerto Rico."
The vendors are the economic engine of the annual rite.
There are no official city estimates on the revenue generated by the hundreds of thousands of people drawn into New York City by the parade, or "el desfile," as it is more commonly known in the East Bronx. But businesspeople in the neighborhood said the economic windfall was essential.
Ramy Khalif, 28, the owner of Mak 99 Cents store at East Tremont and Marmion Avenues, said he purchased 40,000 Puerto Rican flags about three weeks ago to sell -- at $1 to $8 -- before the parade. There were only 2,000 flags left yesterday morning. He had already run out of towels and caps.
The merchandise cost Mr. Khalif about $70,000 and he expects to make more than $100,000. He said yesterday that he expected to sell out in several hours. "I don't think there will be anything left," he said.
Mr. Khalif, who was an employee in the store before buying it five years ago, added that the parade-related sales "help bring people into the store."
At Mr. Rantas's music store, the rows of CD's and tapes that usually fill the store had been replaced by flags, T-shirts, clocks, coat racks, towels and key chains. There were even belts, plates and umbrellas.
Mr. Rantas would not say how much he expected to make from the parade, except that it would be in the tens of thousands of dollars.
But to many, he said, the merchandise sales are simply a symptom of pride. For Juan Nass, who is not Puerto Rican, it is less about pride and more about money. "Tomorrow is going to be slow and back to normal, but in the week before the parade we make lots of money," he said.

HEADLINE: Test Scores Are Up. From This We Can Conclude that the schools are doing:

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
In this era of standardized student testing, it has become an all-too-familiar ritual in New York City and across the country: the leader of the school system calls a news conference and holds a wedding or a funeral, crowing if scores are up, grieving and accepting blame if they are down.
Historically, most New York City chancellors have been able to do a bit of both. Test results can be relied on to rise in some years and fall in others. For parents and many teachers, the constant ratcheting up and down of scores -- testing experts call it the sawtooth effect -- is confusing and exhausting, if not dispiriting. 
 So it was a reality test last week when Harold O. Levy, New York's new chancellor, greeted two successive waves of good news on testing -- a nine-point rise on a statewide test and a five-point rise on a citywide test -- by urging caution. Mr. Levy half-joked that he would post bar charts in the lobby of 110 Livingston Street in Brooklyn, headquarters of the Board of Education, where, like a corporation reporting to stockholders, the school system would be forced to expose its long-term gains and losses.
In the war of perception against reality, almost nothing can be harder to gauge than the meaning of test scores. It seems only common sense that a system of 78,000 teachers and 1.1 million schoolchildren -- or, as Mr. Levy likes to point out, one out of 43 schoolchildren in America -- is too big an ocean liner to turn around in just a year. Is the curriculum new and wonderful? Did the quality of teachers improve? There is no systemic evidence of either. Yet parents and teachers are encouraged to judge their children and schools the way investors watch the Dow industrials.
"There's a quantifiable aspect to testing that is so seductive," said Gary Lincoff, the father of a fifth grader in Manhattan. "If a kid does well and scores high, you can dismiss the tests as meaningless, because you're happy. But if your kid gets a low score, you suspect he isn't getting it and blame yourself, your child, or go the other way and blame the system.
"Success in America is like a quiz show. It's how to be a millionaire, and there's usually a number in there."
But the more sophisticated view, experts say, is that it is almost impossible to attribute real meaning to a one-year gain in scores.
The New York City reading test seems a particularly clear case in point. The city and the state are now in their second year of a new reading test, and experts say it is almost axiomatic that scores go up in the second year of a test.
Last spring, in the first year of the new state test, 32.8 percent of New York City's fourth graders and 56.8 percent of the fourth graders in the rest of the state met state standards for reading and writing. This year's results showed that 41.7 percent of fourth graders in New York City met the standards, a gain of nine percentage points, as did 68.2 percent in the rest of the state.
Then, last week, the results of the city's separate reading test for grades three, five, six and seven came out, offering some corroboration of the rise in performance. On the test, 40.8 percent of students met the standards, up from 35.7 percent last year. Every district and almost every school in the city improved. But despite the overall improvement, schools at the bottom stayed at the bottom and schools at the top remained there.
Pessimists point out that the scores still mean that 6 out of 10 students in New York City, mostly poor black and Hispanic students, are not meeting city and state standards for reading and writing.
"Some schools, what I call the dead zone schools, just seem stuck at the bottom," said Raymond J. Domanico, an education consultant to the Metro Industrial Areas Foundation, a coalition of New York civic and church groups. "They were dysfunctional, they continue to be dysfunctional, and they won't reap the benefits of any of these systemic efforts until we get more highly qualified teachers and principals."
The Board of Education, in its press release, ascribed the rise in scores to a variety of causes: more diagnostic reading tests, expanded prekindergarten, reduced class size and after-school reading classes. But as David Liben, principal of the Family Academy in Harlem, pointed out, "you have to look at this like Sherlock Holmes."
Many steps, including reducing class size and expanding prekindergarten, are new and have affected only a small fraction of the city's very youngest students. They seem only remotely connected, if at all, to sixth and seventh grade, where scores rose the most.
While children who failed the test last year and were held back in the same grade showed large gains in test scores this year, experts say such results are the norm the year after schools stop promoting failing students. Those students, said Lorrie A. Shepard, a professor of education at the University of Colorado at Boulder, are reviewing the same material and taking roughly the same test, so their performance can be expected to go up. The more critical question, she said, is whether their gains will be maintained in future years.
Mr. Levy defended testing as a crude, if necessary, check on the system, yet sided with the skeptics in suggesting that a one-year gain revealed little about the condition of the schools.
"It's very hard to identify causality with any certainty," he said. Once other exams also show positive trends, "the more comfort one can have that we're moving in the right direction," he said. "But in judging whether the system is performing, someone in my position needs to be properly skeptical about test scores and constantly questioning what are the alternative explanations, so that you don't put on rose-colored glasses."
A further complication is the completely different way of scoring reading tests. Percentile scores, based on a national norm, were replaced with performance scores, based on an absolute standard for what children should know. The performance standards were developed by a committee of teachers and test company officials. They rank students within four levels, from lowest to highest, and by what is called a scale score, much like an SAT score, from 427 to 810. The state also uses performance standards.
Many experts say performance standards are a better measure of what students know than percentile scores, but they caution that the standards are also somewhat arbitrary, and subject to the caprices, judgment and manipulation of the officials who establish the cutoff points. "There's no precise science for deciding what meets standards and what doesn't," Dr. Shepard said.
The New York City results are also puzzling because they show striking variations from grade to grade, with scores stable in third grade, rising 12.4 points on the performance scale in sixth grade and dropping 4.1 points in fifth grade.
Given the fluctuations, Sylvia Wertheimer, whose daughter Laura is a fifth grader, said she found it hard to put too much emphasis on the five-point gain. "It doesn't make me feel better about the school system," she said. "It makes me concerned that there's too much emphasis on tests."
Opponents of standardized testing use such fluctuations to argue that tests are meaningless and should be abolished.
But others, echoing Mr. Levy, warn that test results matter most in the long term. From the 1960's to the 90's, performance on standardized tests declined in New York City as schoolchildren became poorer and dropout rates went up. Though the dropout rates and test scores have both shown a slight improvement in recent years, as the economy has improved, it is too early, experts say, to conclude that the change reflects real progress in the school system.
Mr. Levy said that rather than focusing on test results, he wanted to focus on hiring, encouraging and retaining good teachers, principals and superintendents.
Some experts suggested that the increased emphasis in the last two years on tests -- and on using them as a standard for promotion and graduation -- was enough to raise test scores in the beginning.
"One common denominator is that we are now involved in high-stakes testing," said Joseph Viteritti, a research professor at New York University. "And that's a motivator."
Diane Ravitch, the education historian, said studies showed that children who benefit most from testing were those just below the middle, "who understand that with a little bit more effort they can reach the goal." That is why, she said, the outcry against more testing and higher standards "never comes from poor districts, it comes from superadvantaged districts, like Scarsdale, which say, 'We don't want this, we're too good for this.' Those kids will do well, no matter what."
Jennette Williams, whose daughter Shauntay is in the eighth grade at Intermediate School 311 in the East New York section of Brooklyn, said tests had given her daughter a sense of mastery and pride. "All children should know how far they are in life," Ms. Williams said, "so they know where to go to move on."

HEADLINE: Putin Seeks Allies in Quest To Fight U.S. Missile Plan

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 10

 BODY:
President Vladimir V. Putin had barely said farewell to President Clinton this week before the Russian leader and top aides fanned out across Europe to campaign against American plans for a national missile defense.
On whirlwind trips to Brussels and Rome, the Russians sought to persuade the Europeans that a blend of diplomacy, vigilance and Russian technology is a better way to cope with the emerging missile threat. 
 Then the Kremlin announced that Mr. Putin would be undertaking a diplomatic mission to North Korea, the very "rogue nation" Washington has cited to justify its plan.
Given Russia's economic weakness, the new Russian president is not looking for a confrontation with the United States. But neither is he very pliable.
Indeed, it seems as if Mr. Putin, the former K.G.B. agent who spent the waning days of the cold war in East Germany, is trying to split the Europeans from the Americans. It is a classic Kremlin tactic, wielded with a heavy hand in Soviet times.
Today, Mr. Putin is more gentle, insisting only that Russia is a fellow European power and as such more concerned with preserving the framework of arms control than what many Europeans see as the go-it-alone Americans.
"There is a public relations war over missile defense, and all's fair in P.R. wars," a Clinton administration official said of the new Russian stand. "Some of it has been sophisticated. Some has been crude. But we have really seen an activist Russian foreign policy."
The Clinton administration had been accustomed to dealing with Boris N. Yeltsin, a sickly president who nonetheless had a rapport with leaders like Mr. Clinton and Helmut Kohl, the former German Chancellor. But while Mr. Putin's relations with Western leaders are more correct than close, he has engaged in a surprising burst of diplomacy.
Since his election two months ago, Mr. Putin has visited Britain, Italy, Belarus, Ukraine, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan. Over the next six weeks, he is headed to Spain, Germany, Moldova, Tajikistan, China, North Korea and Japan, where he plans to attend the summit meeting of the major industrialized nations, and possibly to South Korea. Visits to the United States, India and Brunei, the site of an Asian summit meeting, are also planned for the rest of the year -- but so far not to France, which has been fiercely critical of Russia's war in Chechnya.
A principal goal of the globe-trotting Russian leader is to lure Western investment, an important element of his plan to strengthen his country's economy and restore Russia as a world power. He is also looking for relief from his nation's mammoth debts, which is a major purpose of his coming German trip.
Countering the administration's missile defense plan and its insistence that the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty be amended to accommodate it, however, is clearly a top priority.
The Russians understand that the first phase of the American plan would have little effect on their nuclear forces. But they fear that it would lay the basis for still grander plans, which would give the United States a strategic advantage. Having failed to persuade Washington to abandon its push to build an antimissile system, the Kremlin is doing the next best thing: It is working on America's allies.
The Europeans, for example, not only fear that the American plan to place 100 interceptors in Alaska and to build a battle-management radar system would undermine the framework of arms control accords and ignite an arms race. They are also not entirely convinced that there is a new missile threat, and they are keenly aware that the administration's missile defense plan is not intended to protect them.
The Russian diplomacy is intended to exploit all of those fears. At a meeting on Friday at NATO headquarters, Marshal Igor D. Sergeyev, the Russian defense minister, presented a Russian alternative, which he dubbed a plan for "European, nonstrategic defense."
The not-so-subtle message is that Russia, unlike the United States, has a plan that not only protects the European Continent from an evolving missile threat, but would be consistent with the ABM treaty, which is widely seen as the bulwark of arms control as pursued to date.
"Obviously, Russian policy is trying to use the European skepticism for its own purposes," said Karl Kaiser, a German foreign policy analyst.
Russia is also calculating that the Europeans view their Russian neighbor as more of a potential partner than the Americans. By casting himself as a philosophical ally, Mr. Putin is also trying to win friends and secure funds from Europe.
"Instead of just saying no and saying that we do not see a threat, Putin is proposing a way to address it," said Aleksei Arbatov, a defense expert and member of the Russian Parliament. "I think it is a very smart policy."
At the NATO meetings on Friday, Marshal Sergeyev presented a seven-step plan so vague in outline that it appeared more of a debating agenda than a blueprint.
Under his proposal, NATO nations and Russia would first evaluate the missile threat and develop a joint European and Russian defense that would use theater antimissile systems. Those are systems that are designed to intercept shorter-range missiles, not long-range ballistic missiles, and as such are allowed under the ABM treaty.
The Russians have suggested nonetheless that those systems might have some use against the emerging missile threat. Marshal Sergeyev did not say, however, whether the theater defense would be used to blow up third world missiles on their way up or to intercept warheads on their way down. Nor did he provide any detailed account of how the defense system would work.
"At this stage we know very little about what, if anything, the Russians have in mind at a detailed technical level," Walter B. Slocombe, the United States under secretary of defense, said after the NATO session. Defense Secretary William S. Cohen and his aides will have a chance to investigate further at meetings in Moscow early next week.
While the Europeans harbor doubts about the American missile defense scheme, they are unlikely to rally around the Russian plan. Western European nations are reluctant to spend their limited military funds on missile defense, regardless of whether the technology originates in the United States or Russia.
Mr. Putin, however, is not counting only on the Europeans. He is also likely to encourage opposition to the American missile defense plan during his visit to Beijing. The Chinese are already strongly opposed to Washington's plan, and Mr. Putin is expected to encourage them to remain firm.
Mr. Putin is also expected to use his visit to North Korea, the first ever by a Russian president, to cast doubt on the rationale for the American missile defense plan. He will probably use the trip to portray North Korea as a rational government that is emerging from its isolation and to try to debunk the American notion that North Korea is an irrational "rogue state" that is likely to hurl a missile at the West at any moment.
After the flurry of Russian moves this week, Mr. Putin called Mr. Clinton on Friday to express his appreciation for a workmanlike summit meeting and to state his commitment to deeper arms cuts. American officials said Mr. Putin's tone was polite but doubted it heralded a breakthrough on the missile issue.
"Yeltsin might say no at first but it would eventually mean yes," a Clinton administration official said. "Putin says yes when he means no. He says I agree with you and then elaborates. And after you examine his elaboration you discover there is almost no agreement there."

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN SYRIA;
Syria's Leader Assad Dies, Clouding Mideast Prospects

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, June 10

 BODY:
President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, a standard-bearer of Arab nationalism and anti-Zionist fervor who ruled his country with an iron hand for three decades, died today at 69 in Damascus.
Although Mr. Assad had long been in ill health, his death from a heart attack casts a quick cloud of uncertainty over the dynamics of peace and conflict in the Middle East. Obituary, Page 51. 
 Syria itself, however, moved swiftly to give at least the appearance of stability. After the announcement of the death, Parliament began to pave the way for Mr. Assad's son Bashar, a 34-year-old ophthalmologist and army colonel, to take over.
While an autocrat who brooked no dissent, Mr. Assad transformed Syria from a backwater nation into a semideveloped one and, more important, a regional power broker. Over the years, he earned begrudging acceptance from world leaders who criticized his outmoded Soviet-style leadership but came to appreciate his courtly tenacity and deep-seated convictions.
"We had our differences, but I always respected him," President Clinton said today as he issued condolences from Northfield, Minn.
Mr. Assad leaves big shoes to fill at the helm of a nation of 17 million whose isolation is reflected in the fact that it remains largely unconnected to the Internet.
After the death of his oldest son in a car accident in 1994, Mr. Assad had turned to grooming his next oldest, Bashar, and a crucial formal step in the transition of power was to have taken place next Saturday during a rare political convention of Syria's ruling Baath Party.
But Bashar Assad still has a potential family feud to quash with his uncle, Rifaat Assad, who always aspired to succeed his almost ascetic older brother. And beyond that, it is unclear whether the ruling Alawite ethnic minority led by the Assads will be able to retain its lock on Syrian politics under another member of the family.
Bashar Assad, according to his father's authorized biographer, the English journalist Patrick Seale, "would not deviate from his father's legacy." But even if he formally assumes power in the near future, it will take him considerable time to emerge from the shadow of his father and assert himself as leader.
This opens up the possibility of a tense and destabilizing transition in Syria at a crucial time in the relationship between Syria and Lebanon and between Syria and Israel. Israel's recent troop withdrawal from southern Lebanon after 22 years scrambled the power lines in the Israeli-Lebanese-Syrian triangle.
Although Mr. Assad took a resolutely hard line toward Israel, many Western diplomats believed that he was the linchpin to any breakthrough between Israel and its northern neighbors. Many believed that only Mr. Assad was strong enough to deliver a change in five decades of hostile habits.
Still, beneath anxiety about what lies in the immediate future, some Israeli and Western leaders expressed hope tonight that Mr. Assad's death could stimulate a new political and economic opening of Syria that could improve the chances for peace.
"For 30 years, Assad was Syria, and Syria was Assad," said the Israeli Justice Minister, Yossi Beilin. "With his death, this is undoubtedly a different Syria. My hope is that whoever will replace him will understand that Syria's only chance for serious economic growth will come by way of peace with Israel."
Palestinian leaders said they hoped that Palestinians and Syrians could reconcile after a long-strained relationship between Mr. Assad and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, which had put them at odds instead of side by side in their separate struggles with Israel.
Mr. Assad had survived several assassination attempts and at least one previous heart attack and had suffered from a variety of debilitating illnesses for years. But despite his gaunt appearance and his infrequent travels abroad, many in Syria had wondered if talk of his imminent demise was not exaggerated.
Syrian television made an official announcement only after the news had circulated first internationally. It showed members of the Syrian Parliament standing for a moment of silence, many of them crying and holding their heads in their hands.
"This is a day of sadness and sorrow in every home, school, farm, factory and quarry," the announcer on state-run television said. "Sadness is in the heart of every man, woman and child because the legacy of his accomplishments is a sun that will shine not just on this generation but on the many to come."
In Israel, state television interrupted regular programming to run live broadcasts from Parliament -- a highly unusual sight here -- that included recitations from the Koran in memory of Mr. Assad.
When Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel first took office last sumer, he assiduously courted Mr. Assad, issuing flattering public messages about his strength as a leader. Mr. Barak and many Western experts believed that Mr. Assad wanted to return to peace talks with Israel in order to regain the Golan Heights in his lifetime and to ease the burden on his presumed successor, his son.
Mr. Assad was Syria's defense minister when Syria lost the Golan in the 1967 Middle East war.
But after the ice between Israel and Syria was broken last winter, the short-lived peace effort between the two nations, with the United States as intermediary, screeched to a halt.
In Geneva in March, Mr. Clinton made a final, failed attempt to revive the talks at a meeting with Mr. Assad. The meeting ended with American pronouncements that its diplomatic focus would shift to the Israeli-Palestinian track.
But after Israel withdrew its troops last month from Lebanon, where Syria is the power broker, officials here and in Syria voiced tentative questions about renewing the peace effort. Mr. Barak, however, said publicly this week that he was wondering if Mr. Assad would ever be fully behind it.
Israel expressed condolences tonight to the Syrian nation, but it also voiced concern over how a transition period would affect the calm that has reigned on its northern border since the troop withdrawal.
"Israel views with importance the keeping of quiet on its borders with Syria and Lebanon and expects that Syria will continue to do so, too," said a statement issued by Mr. Barak's office tonight.
Syria possesses a largely Russian-equipped military machine that is believed to be far less potent today than when Mr. Assad, a career military man, assumed power in 1970. But with mid-range and long-range missiles, and with 30,000 troops stationed in Lebanon, it remains a force to be reckoned with in the region.
Syria installed the current civilian leadership of Lebanon. But after the recent Israeli troop withdrawal and with eagerness to reconcile their nation, the Lebanese leaders as well as the Hezbollah guerrilla movement backed by Syria and Iran started to test just how much autonomy Damascus would permit. This transition period could strengthen their move in that direction.
Mr. Assad, known as the Lion of Damascus because his family name means lion in Arabic, was one of the last surviving members of a generation of Arab rulers after the deaths of King Hassan of Morocco and King Hussein of Jordan.
Mr. Assad had surprised Middle East observers by attending King Hussein's funeral, a visit that marked a warming in what had been an icy relationship with Jordan. Since then, the late King Hussein's son, King Abdullah, has been a frequent visitor to Damascus and has cultivated a personal relationship with his fellow Western-educated scion, Bashar Assad.
In much of the Arab world, Mr. Assad was seen as a purist who remained until his death one of the last few believers in Arab nationalism. He disdained those, like Egypt, Jordan and lastly the Palestinian Authority, that negotiated individual peace treaties with Israel.
Mr. Assad believed that Israel wielded too much power in the region, and that the peace treaties reflected the imbalance of power.
The Arab League praised him tonight as "one who devoted his life to serving the Arab and Islamic nations and fighting for the recovery of their land and for Arab right." And in Gaza City, Mr. Arafat called for a three-day period of mourning and said the Palestinian people "would stand with their Syrian brothers and believe in their ability to survive this critical moment."
In Syria, Mr. Assad will be remembered quietly for some other traits as well -- like intolerance and the fear he inspired. A momentous marker of this was a massacre in Hama in 1982, when Mr. Assad succeeded in squelching an Islamic insurgency by having thousands killed.
Still, the country immediately fell into deep mourning today. Black banners were unfurled from apartment house balconies in Damascus, and noise in the streets stilled. Preparation got under way tonight for his funeral, scheduled for Tuesday.
Lebanese television reported tonight that Prime Minister Emile Lahoud of Lebanon had been talking to Mr. Assad on the telephone earlier today when the line suddenly went dead. "His last words were, 'Our destiny is to build a better future for our countries,' " Mr. Lahoud said of Mr. Assad. "And then there was a silence, and I knew something had happened."

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
A Spot for LaRouche? No Way, Party Says

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
Like Rodney Dangerfield, Lyndon LaRouche says he don't get no respect.
Or delegates to the Democratic National Convention. 
 Mr. LaRouche is running for president. Again. He says he is a Democrat, perhaps the only one who can save the nation, and maybe the world, from an economic and social implosion.
But the Democratic Party says he is a convicted felon (mail fraud involving fund-raising) with political beliefs that are "explicitly racist and anti-Semitic."
Nevertheless, Mr. LaRouche continues to campaign as a Democrat and, in states where election officials permit his name on the ballot, he draws some votes, sometimes thousands of votes. In last month's Democratic primary in Arkansas, for example, he got more than 53,000 votes, or 22 percent of the total cast. The other candidate on the ticket, Vice President Al Gore, got 194,000 votes.
So does Mr. LaRouche get to go to the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles with 22 percent of Arkansas's 48 convention delegates? Or with delegates from any other state?
No way, says the Democratic National Committee. If he shows up, committee officials say, he will be barred from the convention and, they add, courts have ruled several times that such exclusion is legal.
Mr. LaRouche denies he is a racist or an anti-Semite. As for his fraud conviction, he says he went to prison and paid his debt to society. His big vote in Arkansas, he argues, proved his viability as a candidate. "In Arkansas," he says, "reality struck."
As Senator Tim Hutchinson, the chairman of the Bush campaign in Arkansas, sees it, the reality is that 53,000 Democrats "couldn't stomach Al Gore" so they voted for a candidate "not famous for being somebody you can support."

HEADLINE: Green Calls for More Trains To Ease Subway Crowding

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
New York City's public advocate, Mark Green, responding to a call by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for improved safety procedures on subway platforms, said yesterday that the best safety measure would be more frequent service. More trains, he said, would prevent overcrowding in subway stations.
At a news conference, Mr. Green released a study of the frequency of service during the morning rush hour, which found that trains on more than half the city's subway lines arrived at intervals of more than six minutes. He said more trains should be put into service, to shorten the time between trains to no more than four minutes, comparable to subway systems in Tokyo, London, Paris and other foreign capitals. 
 "When subway platforms are so overcrowded that riders are at risk of falling onto the tracks," Mr. Green said, "it's time for increased and more reliable service."
The comments by Mr. Green, a frequent adversary of Mr. Giuliani who has announced his intention to run for mayor in 2001, came five days after Mr. Giuliani said he had ordered the police to study ways to reduce the risk of accidents in which people fall onto the tracks and of incidents in which people are deliberately pushed.
Police records show that there have been nine platform pushing incidents this year, the same number as for all of 1999. The statistics for accidental pushings have not yet been compiled.
But increased service can be brought about only by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its subsidiary that runs the subway system, New York City Transit.
Tom Kelly, a spokesman for the M.T.A., said yesterday that the agency would review Mr. Green's suggestions.
Mr. Green released copies of a letter yesterday that he sent on May 19 to Lawrence G. Reuter, president of New York City Transit, more than two weeks before the mayor announced his police study. The letter recommended a fresh investment in new subway trains, saying that service had fallen far short of keeping pace with increased ridership over the last three years, an increase due largely to the city's robust economy and surging tourism.
Mr. Green said yesterday that Mr. Reuter had not responded. Mr. Kelly, the M.T.A. spokesman, declined to comment on the letter.
At his news conference, Mr. Green ranked subway lines on the basis of their rush-hour frequency. He said the study found the least frequent service on the B, C and M lines, with trains arriving at intervals of more than 8 minutes, and on the G line, where trains arrived at 10-minute intervals.
The transit agency's biggest hurdle in relieving overcrowding, he said, was on the Lexington Avenue line, where riders have complained for decades about crowding despite short waits between trains.
The M.T.A. says no more trains can be squeezed into the rush-hour schedule on that line. Mr. Green said the only solution on that line was to build a Second Avenue subway.

HEADLINE: 2 States Promote Plan To Clean Up Sound

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
WITH millions and possibly billions of dollars in financing in the balance, a plan to create a reserve for Long Island Sound is being advanced in Connecticut and New York, which are bound together by the 110-mile-long estuary.
The reserve would protect shoreline and underwater lands, restore habitats and increase public access to the Sound, which is severely limited for the 25 million people who live or work nearby. Though the Sound lies in the most densely populated region of the country, it has attracted less federal support than other estuaries, like Chesapeake Bay. 
 Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, and others said the designation would improve the chances of federal financing by providing a conduit through which money could flow to the states, municipalities and groups involved in carrying out reserve programs.
"The Congressional climate seems positive for an increase in conservation funding," Senator Lieberman said. "Creating a reserve system might help the Long Island Sound region receive some of that money."
Potential federal funds include a share of $900 million in fees from offshore oil drilling. In addition, a bill passed in the House in May would provide $80 million annually for four years to clean up the Sound; the Senate version would provide $10 million a year for five years.
Three groups that support the reserve concept -- the National Audubon Society of New York, the Regional Plan Association in Manhattan and Save the Sound in Stamford and Glen Cove, have called hearings to gather opinion and build a consensus about what a reserve should include.
Comments at the 10 hearings, four of which took place in Connecticut earlier this month, will be sent to public officials, and Mr. Lieberman said they would be crucial in framing a bill he has tentatively agreed to introduce to set up the reserve.
The reserve would begin a second phase in efforts begun by the two states and the federal government in 1985 to reverse a decline of water quality in the Sound.
A 1994 agreement between the states and the federal Environmental Protection Agency cited low levels of dissolved oxygen, a condition known as hypoxia, as the leading threat. It set goals for a reduction in nitrogen, which is generated by sewage-treatment plants and causes the overgrowth of algae that consume oxygen, causing hypoxia and killing marine life.
The nitrogen-reduction programs, paid for principally by state and local governments, have had some success in limiting the spread of hypoxia. But an assessment by the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection last August estimated that an area more than five times the size of Manhattan was still hypoxic, mostly in the western Sound.
New York City, whose four sewage plants account for nearly 40 percent of the treated sewage discharged into the Sound, is being sued by the state and by a private group, the Soundkeeper, for exceeding agreed nitrogen levels.
Most of the $200 million earmarked for the Sound under New York State's Clean Air and Clean Water Bond Act, and the more than $200 million budgeted by Connecticut for the Sound, is intended to lower nitrogen levels by upgrading treatment plants.
To date, federal involvement has been limited to annual allocations to the Long Island Sound Office, which administers the 1994 plan. Mark Tedesco, the director, said the program had received about $18.5 million in federal money since 1985. He estimated that fulfilling the 1994 agreement would cost $2 billion over 15 years.
Mr. Tedesco said that while hypoxia had been contained, there was no decisive evidence that it had declined as a result of sewage-plant upgrades, even though they had reduced nitrogen discharges by 25 percent since 1994. "I'm hesitant to say we have significantly reduced the problem," he said.
But he added that there could be a lag before a cut in nitrogen resulted in higher levels of dissolved oxygen.
Mr. Tedesco said an earlier estimate that nitrogen reduction alone could cost $8 billion in sewage-plant upgrades had been reduced to $1 billion because of better technology and evidence that bacteria used in treatment was more effective in cold weather than projected.
Proponents of the reserve said it would move beyond upgrades of treatment plants to address acquisition of shoreline properties, measures to restore wetlands and related programs.
To involve greater numbers of people, increasing access would also be a high priority. In Connecticut and Long Island, almost all municipalities restrict beaches and boat-launching areas to residents.
"We're spending billions of dollars cleaning up the Sound, and most of the people living around it can't get there," said Robert D. Yaro, the executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a private planning group. "It's probably the least accessible piece of coastline in the United States."
Mr. Yaro said shoreline acquisitions could also limit development, a kind of "insurance policy for water quality."
Save the Sound, which represents environmental and civic groups in the Long Island Sound Watershed Alliance, has identified 450 sites, private and public, that could be preserved or restored. William P. Shadel, a habitat ecologist for the group, said the group's goal was to preserve 2,000 acres of shoreline and strengthen protection along 1,000 miles of riverfront in Connecticut by 2007.
John Atkin, president of Save the Sound, agreed that land acquisition would "potentially have a very high price tag," but he and others said the cost of degradation from overdevelopment would be more costly.
The Long Island Sound Office has estimated the annual contribution that the Sound makes to the regional economy at more than $5 billion, with boating and recreation in the lead, despite limits on access.
David Sutherland, director of government relations for the Connecticut chapter of the Nature Conservancy, said development pressures would make land acquisitions challenging. But though "the prices may seem high," he added, "in the end it will be a bargain."
Mr. Atkin, of Save the Sound, said a reserve could also set aside surface and underwater areas for research into restoring marine habitats and understanding how contaminants affect marine life.
Proponents of the reserve cited the extensive lobster die-off last fall as a dramatic example of the need to learn more. Researchers said the lobsters might have been attacked by a parasite, but uncertainty remained.
Some lobster and fishing groups fear that pesticides used in mosquito spraying were washed into the Sound and killed the lobsters.
William N. Smith, the executive director of Fish Unlimited of Shelter Island, said dumping in the Sound of material dredged from Mamaroneck Harbor could also have played a part. Mr. Smith said the dredged material contained pesticide residues and other contaminants.
There are four dumping sites in the Sound. The E.P.A. and the Army Corps of Engineers are conducting an environmental study to assess the suitability of the sites.
Mr. Smith, whose group favors a ban on dumping, said he planned to raise the issue at a hearing that Save the Sound has scheduled in Southold on June 29.
David J. Miller, the executive director of the National Audubon Society of New York, said similar hearings in 1990 helped define issues addressed in the 1994 management plan. "We want to turn the corner and get the people behind this new initiative," he said. "Now let's look at the natural coast and how to connect people to that natural coast."
Mr. Miller said the recent creation of the 153-acre Nissequogue River State Park in Kings Park on Long Island and $25 million pledged by Gov. George E. Pataki for public access to the Sound had advanced these efforts.
 
To Have a Say
Four hearings on the future of the Sound are planned on the Island this month.

HEADLINE: 2 States Promote Plan To Clean Up Sound

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
WITH millions and possibly billions of dollars in financing in the balance, a plan to create a reserve for Long Island Sound is being advanced in Connecticut and New York, which are bound together by the 110-mile-long estuary.
The reserve would protect shoreline and underwater lands, restore habitats and increase public access to the Sound, which is severely limited for the 25 million people who live or work nearby. Though the Sound lies in the most densely populated region of the country, it has attracted less federal support than other estuaries, like Chesapeake Bay. 
 Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, and others said the designation would improve the chances of federal financing by providing a conduit through which money could flow to the states, municipalities and groups involved in carrying out reserve programs.
"The Congressional climate seems positive for an increase in conservation funding," Senator Lieberman said. "Creating a reserve system might help the Long Island Sound region receive some of that money."
Potential federal funds include a share of $900 million generated annually in fees from offshore oil drilling. In addition, a bill passed in the House in May would provide $80 million annually for four years to clean up the Sound; the Senate version would provide $10 million annually for five years. But additional allocations could accompany federal legislation creating the reserve, backers said.
Three groups that support the reserve concept -- the National Audubon Society of New York, the Regional Plan Association in Manhattan and Save the Sound in Stamford and Glen Cove, have convened hearings to gather opinion and build a consensus about what a reserve plan should include.
Comments at the 10 hearings, four of which took place in Connecticut earlier this month, will be sent to public officials, including Mr. Lieberman, who said they would be crucial in framing a bill he has tentatively agreed to introduce establishing the reserve.
The reserve would begin a second phase in efforts begun by the two states and the federal government in 1985 to reverse a decline of water quality in the Sound. A 1994 agreement between the states and the federal Environmental Protection Agency cited low levels of dissolved oxygen, a condition known as hypoxia, as the leading threat. It set goals for a reduction in nitrogen, which is generated by sewage-treatment plants and causes the overgrowth of algae that consume oxygen, causing hypoxia and killing marine life.
The nitrogen-reduction programs, paid for principally by state and local governments, have had some success in limiting the spread of hypoxia. But an assessment by the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection last August estimated that an area more than five times the size of Manhattan was still hypoxic. Most effected areas are in the western parts of the Sound.
New York City, whose four sewage plants account for nearly 40 percent of the treated sewage discharged into the Sound, is being sued by the state and by a private group, the Soundkeeper, for exceeding agreed nitrogen levels. Most of the $200 million earmarked for the Sound under New York State's Clean Air and Clean Water Bond Act, and the more than $200 million budgeted by Connecticut for the Sound, is intended to lower nitrogen levels by upgrading treatment plants.
To date, federal involvement has been limited to annual allocations to the Long Island Sound Office, which administers the 1994 plan.
Mark Tedesco, the director, said the program had received about $18.5 million in federal money since 1985. He estimated that carrying out the 1994 agreement in full would cost $2 billion over 15 years.
Mr. Tedesco said that while hypoxia had been contained, there was no decisive evidence that it had declined as a result of sewage-plant upgrades, even though they had reduced nitrogen discharges by 25 percent since 1994. "I'm hesitant to say we have significantly reduced the problem," he said. But he added that there could be a lag before a cut in nitrogen resulted in higher levels of dissolved oxygen.
Mr. Tedesco said an earlier estimate that nitrogen reduction alone could cost $8 billion in sewage-plant upgrades had been reduced to $1 billion because of better technology and evidence that bacteria used in treatment was more effective in cold weather than projected.
Proponents of the reserve said it would move beyond upgrades of treatment plants to address acquisition of shoreline properties, measures to restore wetlands and related programs.
To involve more people, particularly residents of the Bronx and areas of Connecticut and Long Island with limited public access, increasing access would also be a high priority. In Connecticut and Long Island, almost all municipalities restrict beaches and boat-launching areas to residents. Much of the coast is privately owned.
"We're spending billions of dollars cleaning up the sound, and most of the people living around it can't get there," said Robert D. Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a private planning group. "It's probably the least accessible piece of coastline in the United States." Mr. Yaro also said shoreline acquisitions could also limit development, a kind of "insurance policy for water quality."
Save the Sound, which represents environmental and civic groups in the Long Island Sound Watershed Alliance, has identified 450 sites, private and public, that could be preserved or restored. William P. Shadel, a habitat ecologist for the group, said the group's goal was to preserve 2,000 acres of shoreline and strengthen protection along 1,000 miles of riverfront in Connecticut by 2007. Three Connecticut rivers, the Housatonic, the Thames and the Connecticut, and a number of smaller rivers and creeks drain to the sound on the Connecticut side.
John Atkin, president of Save the Sound, agreed that land acquisition would "potentially have a very high price tag," but he and others said the cost of degradation from overdevelopment would be more costly.
The Long Island Sound Office has estimated the annual contribution that the Sound makes to the regional economy at more than $5 billion, with boating and recreation in the lead, despite limits on access.
David Sutherland, director of government relations for the Connecticut chapter of the Nature Conservancy, said development pressures would make land acquisitions challenging. But though "the prices may seem high," he added, "in the end it will be a bargain." The group buys and preserves environmentally important land and assists in land acquisitions by governments.
Mr. Atkin, of Save the Sound, said a reserve could also set aside surface and underwater areas for research into restoring marine habitats and understanding how contaminants affect marine life.
Proponents of the reserve cited the extensive lobster die-off last fall as a dramatic example of the need to learn more. Researchers said the lobsters may have been attacked by a parasite, but uncertainty remains.
Some lobster and fishing groups fear that pesticides used in mosquito spraying for West Nile encephalitis were washed into the Sound and killed the pesticide-sensitive lobsters.
William N. Smith, the executive director of Fish Unlimited of Shelter Island, said dumping in the sound of material dredged from Mamaroneck Harbor could also have played a part. Mr. Smith said the dredged material contained pesticide residues and other contaminants.
There are four dumping sites in the Sound. The E.P.A. and the Army Corps of Engineers are conducting an environmental study to assess the suitability of the four areas and other locations for future dumping.
Mr. Smith, whose group favors a ban on dumping, said he planned to raise the issue at a hearing that Save the Sound has scheduled in Southold on June 29. The group has members on Long Island and in Connecticut.
Within the past two weeks, Connecticut hearings were held in Essex, New Haven, Norwalk and Greenwich.
David J. Miller, the executive director of the National Audubon Society of New York, said similar hearings in 1990 helped define issues addressed in the 1994 management plan. "We want to turn the corner and get the people behind this new initiative," he said. "Now let's look at the natural coast and how to connect people to that natural coast."
Mr. Miller said the recent creation of the 153-acre Nissequogue River State Park in Kings Park on Long Island and $25 million pledged by Governor George E. Pataki for public access to the Sound had advanced these efforts.

HEADLINE: State Referendums Seeking to Overhaul Health Care System

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 10

 BODY:
They were gently spoken and kind-eyed in their white coats, but make no mistake: the handful of doctors and nurses gathering signatures outside the Massachusetts Statehouse see themselves as part of a popular health care insurgency, and some medical powers are taking them seriously enough to spend millions of dollars trying to stop them.
With one final petition drive this weekend, a coalition of doctors, nurses, senior citizens' groups, labor unions and others is expected to collect the last several thousand signatures needed to place before Massachusetts voters what experts call the most sweeping health care referendum on any state's ballot this fall. 
 Seeking to tap into widespread discontent with inaction by Congress and the Statehouse, the referendum would require the Legislature to find a way to provide health insurance coverage for all by mid-2002 in a state where more than 600,000 people lack it. It would also introduce a patients' bill of rights that would guarantee patients the freedom to choose their doctors, and guarantee doctors the freedom to choose the right treatment for their patients. And it would put a temporary ban on the conversion of nonprofit hospitals to for-profit.
Similar white-coat rebellions are in the works elsewhere: campaigners in Washington State, too, are close to getting a measure calling for universal health care onto the state ballot for this fall, which would make this the first campaign season in which more than one state had a universal care initiative on the ballot, experts say.
In a handful of other states -- Arizona, Arkansas, Oklahoma and Montana -- campaigns backing narrower health care proposals, like requiring tobacco settlement money to go toward health, are using ballot initiatives as well.
"What is happening is an enormous backlash by the public," said Dr. Bernard Lown, a Nobel prize laureate and a leader of the Massachusetts initiative drive.
A push to overhaul the health care system, he said, "has to come from below, from the state level; you're closer to the people, you're closer to their pain, and they're more readily mobilized."
He and other campaigners say they believe a convergence of several factors is at work in their favor. They point to the swelling numbers of uninsured people, the trouble that many patients have paying for their prescription drugs, the spiraling costs of medical care and the widespread complaints from doctors and nurses that new constraints are keeping them from offering the best care to their patients.
The opposition appears readily mobilized as well.
Here in Massachusetts, the Coalition for Health Care, which is running the ballot campaign, is already opposed by the Committee for Affordable Health Care Choices, which unites business associations, managed care organizations and other insurers.
"We're just getting into campaign readiness," said Richard C. Lord, its spokesman and president of the state's biggest business association. "But it's probably going to take millions of dollars, because if you want to get your message across to the voters, you need to advertise, and that's very expensive."
His group's message, he said, will include the points that the initiative could destroy the networks that are the very basis of managed care, and could throw the health care system into chaos by the beginning of next year.
The committee also argues that the initiative is overly vague in that it calls for universal health care but does not specify how it is to be paid for. Several commissions in recent years have been stymied by the question of who would pay that bill, Mr. Lord noted.
The initiative's backers counter that the vagueness was intentional, because it allowed the formation of a coalition that included those who favor a Canadian-style single-payer system, those who favor a Hawaii-style requirement that employers provide health insurance, and others.
"People have been specifying the funding mechanisms forever, and they've been losing," said John O'Connor, the campaign's co-chairman and a veteran campaigner for environmental causes. "We want to keep the majority of voters together on the concept that everybody has to be covered by a date certain," July 1, 2002.
Judging by polls and the signature-gathering outside the Statehouse on Friday, support is indeed broad for the general idea of universal coverage.
A few passers-by withheld judgment, but several signed with alacrity. "I'm definitely for universal health care," said Shuang Wang, a 21-year-old intern at the Statehouse, "though I don't know where the money is going to come from." Another signer, Tom McCarron, a lobbyist on transportation issues, said, "I just think it's vitally important that people be covered for health care. The cost of it is just out of control."
Proposals for universal coverage have been made repeatedly in recent years around the country, since well before the Clinton administration tried to overhaul the country's health care system in the early 1990's.
In liberal Massachusetts, a universal health care proposal was even enacted into law in the late 1980's, though the Statehouse went from Democrat to Republican and the economy from flush to hard up, and the measure was repealed before it took effect.
Usually, measures calling for universal health care and other sweeping changes have tended to go down to defeat, said Diane Lardie, national coordinator of Uhcan, the Universal Health Care Action Network, a national group based in Cleveland. They have come up in more than 20 states beginning in Ohio in 1989, Ms. Lardie said, but usually either failed to make it onto the ballot or died in a legislative committee or on the floor of one house or another.
"One of the difficulties with something like a health care issue is that health care is so complex that people are scared," she said, "and they're willing to say, 'Don't do anything,' as opposed to 'Change it for the better' because they're afraid it won't be for the better."
The Massachusetts and Washington State initiatives are important bellwethers to gauge whether public opinion has indeed shifted, Ms. Lardie said. Maryland, too, is "ahead of the pack," she said. There, a political push for universal health care is under way, though it involves no referendum this year.
Oregon, as well, is a spot to watch. Campaigners there had planned a referendum on a health care overhaul this season, they said, but postponed it, in part because action is under way on the legislative front. Also, Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon, a doctor, called for universal health care insurance for all Oregonians earlier this year, saying he hoped to work out a proposal for the 2001 Legislature.
In Massachusetts, other political avenues are being pursued. State Senator Richard T. Moore, the Senate chairman of the Legislature's joint committee on health care, said he was confident that legislators would pass their own patients' bill of rights within the next month or so, one that would include the possibility of external review for patients denied care by their managed care providers. In addition, he said, a commission appointed by the governor to examine health care financing, quality and safety is to begin meeting next week.
He is concerned, Senator Moore said, that the ballot initiative "really goes too far."
Dr. Harris A. Berman, the chief executive of Tufts Health Plan here, also opposes the initiative, arguing that it can be expected to raise the price of health care significantly by taking away H.M.O.s' ability to control costs. To him, the very existence of the initiative, which tries to "use oversimplification to solve a very complex problem," is counterproductive.
"In a health care system hurting as badly as Massachusetts'," Dr. Berman said, "with every hospital and just about every health plan losing money and home health care operations going out of business, to spend millions of dollars that should be used on health care on this fight is just a travesty."
But campaigners say they will soldier on, regardless of criticism and possible legislative action, convinced that universal health care would save money by improving access to preventive care and thus avoiding expensive emergency room visits. And, they said, it is also the morally correct path.
John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist, has lent his name to the campaign and said he was supporting the initiative because he joined "with all sensible people in not wanting to see anyone die because they can't afford the requisite medical treatment."
He said he had grave doubts about whether health care "can be a business enterprise, where one saves money by cutting back care."
