SECTION: Section 2; Page 4; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2521 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Shhh. There's a New Musical. It's Hush-Hush.

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
THE safety of distance is one reason that would-be Broadway musicals -- the holy grail of theater -- sometimes try out 3,000 miles from their ultimate goal. Southern California is the ideal hideaway. As one New York commercial producer put it: "Farther is better. You feel that you have more privacy. The farther away a show is, the fewer people tend to get on planes and see it and gossip about how bad it is."
These days, this area seems to be making a concerted pitch to be taken seriously as a generator of new musicals. The strip from Los Angeles to San Diego is percolating with an unusual number of musical shows, but though some preliminary reviews are in, the larger jury is still out about how well these musicals might do on Broadway, once their problems are solved. The difficulties of creating a Broadway musical hit are notorious and, with a few notable exceptions, most of those involved in the quest here do not have a track record in the field. 
 Fifteen years ago, "Big River" was a hit on Broadway and its director, Des McAnuff, who had nursed it at the La Jolla Playhouse, would subsequently repeat the trick with "The Who's Tommy" and the revival of "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying" starring Matthew Broderick.
But the casualties have been almost as well known and include "Elmer Gantry" (1991) at La Jolla; "Time and Again" (1995) at the Old Globe Theater in San Diego; "Buddy . . . the Buddy Holly Story" (1997) at the San Diego Repertory Company; "Harmony" (1997), composed by Barry Manilow, at La Jolla, and "What the World Needs Now" (1998), with the music of Burt Bacharach and Hal David, at the Old Globe.
This time around, the most eagerly anticipated mainstream show here is probably "The Full Monty" at the Old Globe, a musical stage version of the highly successful 1997 movie. The six unemployed steel mill workers who decide to become male strippers are Americans in Buffalo now, not British laborers in Sheffield, England. Yet with the exception of a handful of new characters, as well as songs and dances, the show has been designed by its American creators to adhere to the poignantly funny path of those desperate men who find friendship and strength by taking off their clothes to earn money.
"When I got the call two years ago and was asked, 'What do you think about the idea of "The Full Monty" as a musical?' I thought, 'Oh, man, what a great idea,' " said Jack O'Brien, the artistic director of the Old Globe, who is staging the show. The book is by the playwright Terrence McNally, who also wrote the books for the musicals "Ragtime" and "Kiss of the Spider Woman"; the music and lyrics are by David Yazbek, a relative unknown.
"The Full Monty" officially opened here on June 1 and critics have called it highly commercial but flawed. "The show's an energetic, if forgettable, crowd-pleaser," said Variety, with "a strong shot at an extended Broadway run and life beyond that." While "The Full Monty" is widely expected to go to Broadway in the fall, the other shows are more offbeat and commercially risky. But depending on local reaction and that of commercial producers, they could wind up in New York someday.
The productions include "Celebration of the Lizard," a futuristic rock musical built around the songs of the Doors, which opened on May 28 at the San Diego Rep. The Los Angeles Times called the show a "silly, derivative and rather sweet nostalgia trip," while The San Diego Union-Tribune found it "a flat, retro show."
The third musical that recently opened, "The Education of Randy Newman" on June 2 at South Coast Repertory in Costa Mesa, was more favorably received. In this show, conceived by Mr. Newman, Michael Roth and Jerry Patch, the composer-performer chronicles his life, from his boyhood in New Orleans -- where he never quite fit in -- to his career, marriage, divorce and remarriage in Los Angeles. The Hollywood Reporter found it "a deft musical catalog that is touching, hilarious, satirical and always unmistakably Newman." And Variety called it an "intelligently staged, powerfully sung revue-that's-almost-more."
A new show based on the 1967 movie musical "Thoroughly Modern Millie," and using the same title, is to open this fall at the La Jolla Playhouse. With a book by Richard Morris, the author of "The Unsinkable Molly Brown," and Dick Scanlon, based on Mr. Morris's original screenplay, it will have additional music by Jeanine Tesori, the composer of the Off Broadway musical "Violet." The director is Michael Mayer, who recently did the revival of the musical "You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown" on Broadway.
Next spring in Los Angeles, the nonprofit Center Theater Group will present a full-scale revival of Rodgers and Hammerstein's "Flower Drum Song" at the Ahmanson Theater, with a revised book by David Henry Hwang, the author of "M. Butterfly" and the recent "Golden Child," both on Broadway. It will be directed and choreographed by Robert Longbottom, who directed the Broadway musicals "Side Show" and the revised "Scarlet Pimpernel."
The number of shows in various states of progress is a sign not only of the built-in audiences here for musical theater but also of the continued blurring of the line between nonprofit regional houses and commercial Broadway interests. A national three-day conference on the current and future relationship between nonprofit and commercial theater in America begins on Friday at Harvard University. Critics of commercial producers who use nonprofit stages to develop work bound for Broadway argue that commercial pressures for wide audience appeal can stifle experimentation.
Mr. O'Brien, who has been the artistic director at the Old Globe for 19 years, is optimistic. "San Diego was a perfect place to start this project," he said about "The Full Monty." "We're far enough from New York to work in a protected environment."
Certainly San Diego has been used for years as a tryout town for New York. And the Old Globe itself has nourished such Broadway-bound shows as the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical "Into the Woods," the revival of "Damn Yankees" with Bebe Neuwirth, and Neil Simon's "Rumors" and "Jake's Women."
T HE FULL MONTY" will remain at the 600-seat Old Globe, nestled in Balboa Park, until July 9. It is expected to open in the fall on Broadway at a Jujamcyn theater at a cost of nearly $7 million, financed by Fox Searchlight, the division of 20th Century Fox that released the movie. The San Diego production cost about $2.2 million, 75 percent of that provided by the Old Globe, the rest by Fox Searchlight.
"Audiences at a lot of these theaters are excited about being part of the birthing process of new plays and musicals -- they know their reaction can alter a piece," said Neel Keller, associate artistic director at La Jolla, where "Thoroughly Modern Millie" is to open in October.
Mr. Keller, who was trained on New York and Chicago stages, said that local audiences seemed committed to eclectic theater. "Sure, they enjoy their day at the beach -- who doesn't?" he said. "But the sun goes down and people love that outlet of the theater."
Seated in his office at the Old Globe, Mr. O'Brien put it more bluntly: "Twenty or 25 years ago this was a Navy town. It was a bastion of conservatism and military correctness, and it was quite sleepy. But it's not sleepy any longer. To be candid, a large number of the people now in Southern California have come from other areas and brought their own tastes, sophistication and expectations with them. We've seen an influx of technology companies like Qualcomm and Gateway. It's far more sophisticated, far more discerning. And people really enjoy theater."
TOM HALL, the producing director of the Old Globe, said the commercial enhancement money that nonprofit theaters can receive for a Broadway-bound production allows them to stage musicals they ordinarily could not afford. At the same time, the local theater has a chance to share in the profits if a show reaches Broadway and does well.
A few miles from "The Full Monty" is the San Diego Rep's "Celebration of the Lizard." This fable, set in a post-apocalyptic Los Angeles, is based on the music and lyrics of the rock 'n' roll icons Jim Morrison and the Doors. (The 33 songs include, of course, "Light My Fire.") The show, costing $750,000, the most expensive so far at the 24-year-old theater, has aroused interest among New York producers. But the price of a move to Broadway would probably be three times as much as opening the show in San Diego.
"We have high hopes it will have an afterlife," said Sam Woodhouse, the theater's artistic director, who is staging the production.
The show was conceived and adapted by Joel Lipman, 42, a television producer who said that his head has been spinning since he heard "Light My Fire" on a transistor radio one summer night when he was 10. A meeting in 1989 with Ray Manzarek, one of the Doors, led Mr. Lipman to return to the poetry and writings of Jim Morrison, who died in 1971. Mr. Lipman helped create the musical from a Morrison poem, "Celebration of the Lizard," recorded in the late 1960's.
What appealed to Mr. Lipman -- and what may give the show a life despite the reviews -- is the consistent appeal of the music of the Doors to audiences who weren't even born when the group flourished. "There has been a steady increase in sales of their music for the last 30 years," Mr. Lipman said. "Many musicians popular today -- from R.E.M. to U2 to Jon Bon Jovi -- cite the influence of the Doors. One of our hopes is that younger audiences will find a new excitement in the theater with this musical."
At South Coast Rep, Mr. Newman has used the classic autobiography "The Education of Henry Adams" as a model for his show, which is directed and choreographed by Myron Johnson. The composer's songs, presented by seven male and female singers, are intended to depict his personal voyage. "It's a compilation of about 40 songs," Mr. Newman said. "It's a sort of fantasy based on my life."
He added with a laugh that the public revelations of his personal life hardly bothered him. "I would use anything I had for a song, I would make an entertainment of my life even if it were enormously lurid," he said. "If I had anything to confess and get a song out of it, I'd do it. I can't keep my mouth shut."
Mr. Newman's production of "Faust" (he wrote the book, music and lyrics) at La Jolla in 1995 moved to the Goodman Theater in Chicago but never reached Broadway. The composer spoke happily about his theatrical experiences at La Jolla and now at South Coast Rep. "The people are so well-trained," he said. "They're terrific actors, they sing harmony, they sight-read better than I can. And they get paid practically nothing. It's ridiculous."
It was to La Jolla that the commercial Broadway producer Rocco Landesman and the set designer Heidi Ettinger, who was then his wife, brought "Big River" after originally working on it at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass. They would also become involved with "Into the Woods" at the Old Globe. "It was the first time that musicals were put into development through regional theaters," Mr. Landesman said recently from his office at Jujamcyn Theaters in New York, where he is the president. "You had transfers before, but this was commercial producers coming to the theater and saying, 'We'd like to develop a musical with you.' "
"In terms of being able to see your whole production in front of an audience, it's a lot cheaper," he continued. "And something which is so critical: you have the luxury of time. You can close the show and then work on it. But if you're in Boston, you have a week and then you have to be in New York. Time is the biggest luxury in developing a musical and a regional theater gives you that."
Mr. Landesman was also one of the commercial producers on the musical "Time and Again," based on the novel by Jack Finney, with Mr. O'Brien at the Old Globe. Despite the show's failure, Mr. Landesman said, "I think there's a good chance that that show has a viable future." His long-running revue "Smokey Joe's Cafe," which recently closed on Broadway, played at the Doolittle Theater in Los Angeles (part of the Center Theater Group) on its way to New York.
Interest in a musical stage version of "The Full Monty" began almost as soon as the film was released, according to Lindsay Law, the former president of Fox Searchlight, who said he had fielded calls from theatrical producers in Europe and the United States. "I told Fox, 'It's a valuable project, you don't want someone to make a bad musical that would tarnish the name,' " recalled Mr. Law, who is now a producer of the show.
He took the idea to Mr. O'Brien and Mr. Hall at the Old Globe -- two longtime friends. They decided to seek out Mr. McNally. "When I called Terrence," Mr. O'Brien remembered, "and told him about this project, he said, 'I would have killed you if you hadn't asked me to do it.' "
The team's major task was finding a composer. Mr. O'Brien and Mr. Law said they wanted songs that would, in the words of Mr. Law, "not be the same ones you hear on the Broadway stage -- we wanted to bring a different sound to Broadway than what you traditionally hear."
THEY offered the job to Adam Guettel, the composer of the Off Broadway musical "Floyd Collins." Mr. Guettel was intrigued but committed to several other projects. He suggested a composer-lyricist friend, Mr. Yazbek, 38, who was once a writer on the CBS show "Late Night With David Letterman." Mr. Yazbek, who lives in Manhattan, has recorded two albums of his own songs, scored television shows and written songs and scripts for children's television.
The producing team listened to CD's of his songs, and asked him to try out by writing several more for "The Full Monty." Mr. Yazbek said he wrote three songs, two of which are still in the show.
Mr. O'Brien said, "The music was energetic and edgy, male, witty and literate."
Patrick Wilson, 26, who recently appeared in the "Encores!" concert version of the musical "Tenderloin" in New York, has the main role created by Robert Carlyle in the movie. A 1995 graduate of Carnegie Mellon, Mr. Wilson also performed in "Bright Lights Big City," the Paul Scott Goodman musical Off Broadway.
Seated outside the Old Globe on a recent morning, awaiting the start of rehearsals, Mr. Wilson, in baggy pants and a sweatshirt, said he grew up singing in St. Petersburg, Fla., where his mother is a choir director and voice teacher and his father and brother are local television anchors. Sipping a soft drink, he said with a grin that he and the other performers were uneasy about the show's finale in which, like the film, the men remove all their clothes.
"It's lit so you can't really see too much," Mr. Wilson said. "I keep talking myself into it, saying, 'It's going to be fine, it's totally tasteful.' But you know as well as I do that someone in the audience is going to have a camera. And the next thing that happens is it's going to be on the Internet. And that weirds me out."

HEADLINE: 2 Counties: The Profligate and the Prudent

BYLINE: By AL BAKER 

 BODY:
TWO old men chatting on a street outside the Larchmont Post Office could occupy the same turf in Garden City. The sweet aroma of cafe con leche drifting out of a Mexican restaurant in Port Chester could be coming through the entrance of a Salvadoran eatery in Hempstead. A diner in Hastings-on-Hudson could be a diner in Oyster Bay, the same hungry eaters with their sport utility vehicles nosed to the curbs outside.
The weekend tag sales that proliferate each spring could be in Levittown or Tarrytown, Roslyn or Rye, any of the scores of bedroom communities that make up Nassau and Westchester Counties. 
 To casual observers, the two counties are nearly indistinguishable. Westchester is larger in land area, Nassau larger in population. Westchester was recently ranked the seventh wealthiest county in America; Nassau placed 17th. They share Long Island Sound and a state government. Both have fabulous mansions and pockets of poverty, Lyme ticks and West Nile mosquitoes and a border with New York City.
Yet one glaring difference sets them apart. While Westchester's government is the picture of economic health, awash in a sea of surplus and with a credit rating that is among the best in the country, Nassau is in a budget crisis that will probably require every New York State taxpayer's help, and with a deficit that has pushed its bond rating nearly to junk status.
How such similar counties evolved financially -- "like night and day" in the words of an aide to the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall -- is a tale of philosophically opposite methods of budgeting and taxing set against wildly varying political landscapes.
In Nassau, one-party politics prompted Republican leaders into disastrous financial decisions. For years, county officials forged a steady record of underestimating costs and overestimating revenues. They held the line on property taxes but paid employees handsomely, while selling off county property or borrowing mountains of cash to keep government chugging along.
But their luck ran out last year as the deficit reached $300 million. An apathetic electorate was energized, humbling a legendary G.O.P. machine and creating a Democratic legislative majority for the first time in nearly a century. At the heart of the election was the budget mess.
In Westchester, more conservative budgeting grew out of years of competition between Democratic and Republican elected officials, who held one another in check. Westchester voters saw their legislative branch overhauled 26 years ahead of Nassau's, a move that gave lawmakers more responsibility and provided needed checks and balances in government, officials on both sides agree.
Westchester leaders never got into Nassau's habit of using one-time revenues, like money from the sale of a hospital, for example, to pay continuing costs. They did little borrowing. And, unpopular as it was, they increased property taxes a bit each year to cover spending increases.
"The problems in Nassau have been a reflection of politics and history," said Bruce Nyman, a former Democratic member of the Nassau County Legislature, which replaced the old Board of Supervisors in 1996. "One-party government controlled a part-time legislature that was able to rubber-stamp the executive branch of government. When you put the politics and history together, it was a recipe for disaster."
A comparison of the counties found the following:
*In Nassau, each resident's share of the county's debt is $2,065. That is more than twice as much as any other county in New York and more than six times the state average. By contrast, Westchester's debt is $627 per resident.
*Nassau spends $520 million -- nearly a quarter of its $2.2 billion budget -- on a police department whose rank-and-file officers are paid $90,000 a year. Officers eat up half the county payroll but comprise just 29 percent of the work force. Westchester has a much smaller police force, representing a mere 1.8 percent of the county's $1.17 billion budget. The average officer is paid $63,500 a year.
*When Nassau sold its hospital last year for $82 million, it used the windfall to help plug the deficit. When Westchester transferred its hospital to a public benefit corporation in 1997, it did it for $1, not seeking to make money off the deal. Similarly, Nassau used $170 million in tobacco settlement money to pay for ongoing costs and to help balance its books. Westchester used $63.4 million of its tobacco money to erase hospital debts through 2005.
*The biggest share of Nassau's debt -- $100 million a year -- goes to repay homeowners and merchants who successfully challenge their property tax assessments. Westchester paid $9 million in such refunds last year. And unlike Nassau, which borrows to pay, Westchester pays with money budgeted for that purpose.
*In Nassau, property taxes are collected by towns and cities, which first take their share and forward the remainder to the county. If there is a shortfall, it's the county's responsibility to collect. In Westchester, the towns and cities collect the money and pay the county first.
Taken together, the effect of such procedural differences is staggering, experts say. Today, Westchester has the highest credit rating given by Standard & Poor's, while Nassau's rating is hovering just above junk status, with a downgrade threatened for month's end.
"I would say that if Nassau had used Westchester as an example of how to run a county over the past 10 years, Nassau's taxpayers would be in much better shape today," Comptroller McCall said.
But the tale of the two counties is also a story of residents whose lives are playing out differently. While Westchester's roughly 900,000 residents are gliding along on one of the nation's longest economic expansions, there's a recession mentality among Nassau's 1.3 million people, who are nagged by a daily sense of fiscal chaos, by the prospect of tax increases and layoffs of county police officers and by cutbacks in services that are punctuated by protest marches through the county seat in Garden City.
Still, both counties have hordes of retail stores filled with shoppers with ready cash. Both have high per-capita income and low unemployment.
"The fact that Westchester didn't have Nassau's problems doesn't mean it's more affluent than Nassau," said Anthony A. Cupaiuolo, a professor of public administration at Pace University in White Plains. "It was just managed better than Nassau and didn't get involved in all the political games."
In Nassau, the problem comes down to one simple truth: there is not enough money flowing in to cover the amount streaming out, as County Comptroller Frederick E. Parola, a Republican, has been saying since June 1996.
In Westchester, because the math adds up, deficits are unheard of and the cost of governing is balanced, said Kathleen M. Carrano, Westchester's budget director, who grew up in Nassau County and once worked as the controller in Glen Cove.
Nassau's fiscal tailspin started long before its deficit hit $300 million last summer. The county executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, a Republican, took office in 1987. While he oversaw spending increases for things like keeping the county parks pristine and ensuring that salaries for county employees outpaced inflation, he held the line on property taxes. Feeling no pain, the voters for years rewarded him at the polls.
In Westchester, tax increases came in frequent small steps. It was enough so that County Executive Andrew J. Spano, a Democrat, could cut taxes by 3 percent this year.
"I think the reluctance to raise property taxes incrementally is a major cause of where Nassau stands fiscally today," said Dr. Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, Long Island's largest business group.
One beneficiary of Nassau's lavish spending has been the county police department, where costs have shot up 64 percent in the past decade, and where lucrative provisions in a series of police contracts -- one negotiated, in 1992, and the most recent one decided by an arbitrator -- have seen payouts for retiring officers reach the six-figure mark, with the average supervisor taking home $207,000 upon retirement last year.
Westchester's spending on its police force is much lower, just $19.6 million.
The Westchester Department of Public Safety was created by voter referendum in the early 1980's, and it merged a former Sheriff's Department with what used to be called the office of Parkway Police. Today, there are 273 positions budgeted for the department, including 222 uniformed officers. That compares with 4,100 positions, including 3,100 officers, in Nassau.
To Todd A. Whitestone, managing director of public finance ratings at Standard & Poor's, it is not the cost of such things as police services that is alarming in Nassau as much as it is Nassau's inability to pay.
Peter J. Schmitt, the Republican minority leader of the County Legislature, said Nassau must rethink what it can afford.
"Nassau has always had the Cadillac of programs, and everyone else has had Chevys and Fords, and we have to get to that," he said.
Now, he added, politicians in Nassau need the political will to cut costs.
Of course, cutting jobs or salaries in Nassau has always been politically unpalatable because appointed commissioners, deputy commissioners, secretaries and others have been the lifeblood of a strong Republican machine.
Democrats in Nassau, hampered by internal squabbling for more than a decade, were often left on the sidelines by an electorate that "tolerated wasteful spending and governmental mismanagement," said Neal Lewis, executive director of the Long Island Neighborhood Network, an advocacy group.
Dr. Cupaiuolo, of Pace, said: "In Westchester, for quite a few years, both parties held active roles. Both parties have been healthier, and that is healthier when you have two parties that are competitive. The impression I get is that Nassau is just riddled with patronage, and outrageously so, and the political culture was, 'Let's keep bringing people on, giving them good salaries and this way we can stay in office as long as we want.' It certainly exists in Westchester, but I don't believe to that extent."
Nassau's problems are aggravated by its debt.
In addition to loans for roads and buildings, Nassau borrows just to keep government going. To cover operating costs, Nassau's projected cash flow borrowing this year is $485 million, compared with $75 million for that purpose last year in Westchester, municipal analysts said. Westchester has scheduled no short-term borrowing in 2000.
"That is a big difference with Westchester's triple A and Nassau's triple B," Diane P. Brosen, director at Standard & Poor's, said of the credit ratings. "One big warning sign of fiscal problems is an escalation of debt and cash-flow borrowing."
Overall, Westchester has been closer to the mark in estimating cash flow, for items like sales tax receipts, and its expenses, for things like employee overtime. Only once in recent history, in 1998, has Westchester overestimated its sales tax revenue, Ms. Carrano said.
Nassau, on the other hand, has consistently underestimated overtime costs and, at least since 1995, it has overestimated sales tax receipts. Last year, receipts were $9 million short, and the year before they were $33 million short, according to Standard & Poor's.
When shortfalls or apparent overruns do occur, Nassau is slow to pick up on them and make budget adjustments at midyear or at quarterly marks in the fiscal year, Ms. Brosen said. "They just wait and say, 'Whoop, you know, there is a big gap here,' " she said. But in Westchester, there is "ongoing budget monitoring, both expenditures and revenues," said Robin Prunty, the Standard & Poors analyst who monitors Westchester.
Michael P. Jacobson, a former budget official in New York City who helped the Nassau Legislature prepare a fiscal plan last fall, said he was left feeling that Nassau's financial management system was completely nonexistent. A key problem, he said, was that Nassau's budget office was understaffed, though adding people was a "heavy lift politically, if you are in financial straits."
He continued: "There was not a centralized, powerful budget office that was able to know immediately, on a real-time basis, early on, what problems were coming down the pike, what to do about them, how to avert problems; there was absolutely no multiyear budgeting. My sense is Westchester probably has a better management system. They keep closer track."
Stopping the kind of actions that lead to budget problems in Nassau will take political will, most financial experts agree. It is an ingredient many say was missing in Nassau for years, especially considering that budgets must be passed a few days before Election Day, making tax increases that much more difficult, politically.
Arthur J. Kremer, a former Democratic state assemblyman who is now a lawyer at Rivkin Radler & Kremer, one of Long Island's largest law firms, said that in Nassau "the government was sound asleep and failed to follow any of the warning signs" of a fiscal wreck coming down the road.
But unlike New York City in 1975, or Troy, which nearly went bankrupt in 1994, or Orange County, Calif., which lost $2 billion in a risky investment scheme, Nassau threatens to crumble in the midst of a soaring national economy. To Edward Glaeser, professor of economics at Harvard University, the case for a state government bailout of Nassau is hard to make, even though the first steps are in place with a plan by Gov. George E. Pataki to combine $100 million in grants to Nassau with a fiscal control board that would monitor Nassau's efforts to get its act together, and impose its own plan if it cannot.
"This is not a city like Detroit that is mired in poverty; it is a healthy place that, if it were run with any sense of fiscal responsibility, should be very healthy," Mr. Glaeser said of Nassau. But, he said, the comparison to Westchester is even more startling, given the two counties' many similarities. "In one area, fiscal responsibility reigns, and in the other place they are playing games."
 
The Difference a Legislature Makes
IF you ask Arthur J. Kremer the No. 1 reason why "the structure crumbled" in Nassau County, the former state assemblyman will tell you it is because Nassau did not have a legislature until four years ago.
In Westchester County, those who know the system said, the creation of such a body in 1970 is a big reason why government is now in good financial shape.
"No doubt, the closer you get to one person one vote, the more effective you can govern," said Stephen P. Tenore, a Republican lawmaker for 11 years in Westchester and the former chairman of the county's Board of Legislators.
Under Nassau's old Board of Supervisors system, one representative each came from the cities of Long Beach and Glen Cove and from the towns of Oyster Bay and North Hempstead. Two more came from the more populous town of Hempstead.
"The board was made up of town supervisors who really didn't care much about county government except to make sure they got their share of the pie," said Mr. Kremer, a Democrat, who said that even when the new 19-member Legislature took over in 1996, it "needed two to three years to find out what was going on, and they were in no position to find out the depth of the problems until recently."
Westchester abandoned its Board of Supervisors for a legislature 26 years earlier than Nassau because its board wasn't working well. The legislature "never let the budget go out of shape" over the years, said Herman D. Geist, a Republican and the legislature's first chairman.
While a strong legislative body in Westchester kept a check on the executive branch, Nassau suffered "from a lack of a strong county government in terms of planning, environmental protection, industrial development," said Bruce Nyman, a former Democratic member of Nassau's Board of Supervisors and Legislature.
David Liebschutz, an adjunct professor at Rockefeller College of SUNY Albany, said that even now politics has kept an inexperienced legislature in Nassau from forming a consensus with the executive branch on how to pull the county out of its mess. The alternative may yet be a fiscal oversight board to shoulder the tough decisions -- and share in any potential political blame. AL BAKER
 On Thursday, after the article had gone to press, Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature agreed to spend $105 million to bail out Nassau County and impose state oversight of county spending. Nassau will have to agree to make deep budget cuts in return for the state aid.

SECTION: Section 3;Page 1;Column 1;Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Charities' Investing: Left Hand, Meet Right

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON

 BODY:
THE Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation -- the largest anywhere, with an endowment of $22 billion -- spends tens of millions of dollars each year aimed, in its own words, at "helping to improve people's lives through health and learning." In addition to making a sweeping effort to vaccinate the world's children, it has backed charities like Cancer Lifeline, which provides support to people with cancer and their families, and the American Cancer Society.
But according to its most recent tax return, the Gates Foundation also owned bonds in Philip Morris, the tobacco company -- raising the issue of whether the foundation's behavior as an investor sometimes runs counter to its charitable mission. 
 "If you believe tobacco kills, and you are concerned about health, it would seem absurd to hold tobacco stocks in your portfolio," said Stephen Viederman, a longtime foundation executive who has waged a tireless battle to persuade more of these charities to rethink their investments in light of their social aims.
Yet at a time when many foundations are benefiting from a huge run-up in stocks -- and as socially responsible investing has proven to be a successful bull-market strategy -- few foundations have been quick to adopt Mr. Viederman's approach.
To be sure, a smattering of foundations are active as shareholders. But many more view their sole responsibility as maximizing returns so that they can give away more money.
Mr. Viederman and a handful of others, however, contend that foundations are also obligated to consider, as he puts it, "the social and environmental consequences of their investments."
The $90 million endowment that Mr. Viederman led until recently, the Jessie Smith Noyes Foundation, based in Manhattan, screens its portfolio for investments that might conflict with its goal of protecting the environment. It declines, for example, to invest in companies like Dow Chemical and Monsanto.
"You would think that foundations have a clear mission in social policy issues and would look at the portfolio as another tool they could use, but by and large they don't," said Scott Fenn, the executive director of the Investor Responsibility Research Center, a Washington group that advises large shareholders on corporate governance and social issues.
A spokesman for the Gates Foundation declined to comment about its thinking on socially responsible investing.
While most efforts to use investments to further social goals are associated with liberal causes, the concept is not tied to a specific ideology. A foundation that disapproved of abortion, for example, might refuse to own stocks of health care companies whose hospitals performed abortions.
But conservative foundations also tend to neglect their missions when investing their endowments, according to Leslie Lenkowsky, a professor at the Indiana University Center on Philanthropy and former president of the conservative Hudson Institute.
"The trustees of conservative foundations tend to be interested in maximizing the returns of their assets," he said -- and are not likely to favor shareholder activism as a tool for change.
AT most foundations, in fact, there has been a historical separation between who decides which causes to support and who decides how to invest the endowment. The second group, more comfortable with finance than advocacy, has focused exclusively on investment returns, resisting the idea of investing with other goals in mind.
Advocates of socially responsible investing argue that foundations are ignoring their influence as shareholders.
"If you have a large endowment, the power of that money to create change is probably more than the power of your grant-making," said Jill Ratner, president of the Rose Foundation for Communities and the Environment, based in Oakland, Calif. The foundation, with about $1 million in assets, has taken an activist stance as a shareholder in Maxxam Inc., the Houston natural resources company; critics say Maxxam has logged old-growth forests and has a poor relationship with labor.
Because their endowments typically dwarf the grants that these charities make, Ms. Ratner said foundations should think more about the corpus, or principal, of their portfolio than the investment income they give away. "What you have at a lot of foundations are people trying to use their earnings to basically bet against their corpus," she said. "It's weighted the wrong way."
Earlier this year, the Rose Foundation joined with the United Steelworkers of America to push for the election of independent directors to Maxxam's board, asserting that if the company were better governed, its record on environmental and labor issues would improve. Charles Hurwitz, the company's chief executive, has voting control, and the proposal was defeated in May.
About $1 of every $8 under professional management -- some $2 trillion over all -- was involved in socially responsible investing last year, according to the Social Investment Forum, a Washington group that surveys the landscape every two years. That sum, the bulk of it invested under social screens, has roughly doubled from 1997.
The concept has grown in popularity among individual investors. Well-known investment managers like the Vanguard Group and TIAA-CREF recently began offering mutual funds with holdings screened for social considerations.
In the past, many people worried that issue-minded investing damaged investment performance. But there is a growing consensus that other influences -- like the sectors and companies in a portfolio -- may have greater impact on returns.
Moreover, some money managers who screen holdings for financial considerations, like those who run the Domini Social Equity fund, can now boast a performance history that closely matches the overall market. Over the last five years, Domini has returned 25.2 percent a year, on average, versus 24.6 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Like the S& P, the fund is weighted toward the technology stocks that have led the market the last few years.
Still, foundations, especially larger ones, have not been in the forefront of the social investing movement.
When it last surveyed its membership in 1997, the Council on Foundations found that slightly less than 15 percent screened for any social or ethical consideration. Small foundations, those with assets of less than $10 million, were almost twice as likely to do so as large ones, those with assets of $100 million or more, according to the survey.
While many foundations were active in dissuading companies from doing business in South Africa in the 1970's and 80's, subsequent causes do not appear to have captured their interest. Even the movement among large investors like state pension funds to divest their portfolios of tobacco stocks has not won many foundations' favor, although a few-high profile ones -- like the nearly $9 billion Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and the $3 billion Charles Stewart Mott Foundation -- have rid their endowments of those stocks.
By contrast, some of the largest foundations, like the Gates fund and the $13 billion Ford Foundation, invested in these stocks, according to the latest tax returns. So did relatively big foundations whose primary aim is to improve the health of Americans, like the $525 million Commonwealth Fund in New York.
"We feel our energies are better spent on our grant-making," explained Michael C. Vachon, Commonwealth's director of communications. Commonwealth has supported programs intended to improve health care for minorities and to increase health insurance coverage and access to care for working Americans. The impact of divesting its portfolio of tobacco stocks would be "minimal," Mr. Vachon said.
UNLIKE other large investors -- including colleges and state pension funds -- foundations have been all but immune to public pressure, despite having amassed nearly $400 billion in assets, according to 1998 figures, the most recent available. Organizations that receive their grants do not want to endanger future aid; staff members tend not to have the power to force the issue. And to date, many activists seem unaware of the divergence between foundations' grant-making and their investments.
The foundation world has been truly left alone," said Matthew Myers, president of the National Center for Tobacco-free Kids, in Washington.
Foundations have also chosen not to model themselves after pension funds as shareholder activists, only rarely proposing shareholder resolutions urging a company to improve its business practices.
In the mid-1990's, the Noyes Foundation and the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility established the Foundation Partnership on Corporate Responsibility to involve more endowments in shareholder activism. Only a dozen or so foundations, however, were sponsors or co-sponsors of shareholder resolutions within the last year.
"We have not gotten behind the force of the portfolio," acknowledged William S. White, president of the Charles Stewart Mott Foundation in Flint, Mich. While Mott, which invests its endowment without the aid of outside managers, pays attention to proxy matters, it does not view its $3 billion in assets as a way to accomplish change at companies that prove themselves to be poor corporate citizens.
"We feel the market has a way of getting at some of these issues," Mr. White said.
Some foundations are leery of devoting much in the way of staff or time to shareholder issues, and activism rarely rises to the level of debate. "Most foundations still put a Chinese wall between their investment arms and their grant-making arms," said Doug Cogan, the deputy director of the social issues service of the Investor Responsibility Research Center.
Many social activists argue that selling a holding should be a last resort, preferring to use their shareholdings within the system to effect change. Indeed, some foundations that have undertaken shareholder activism say they have had an impact.
In the mid-1990's, for example, the Noyes Foundation started working closely with one of its grantees, the SouthWest Organizing Project, a community group in Albuquerque, to put pressure on the Intel Corporation to weigh environmental and employment concerns about plans to expand its chip-making operations in New Mexico.
Noyes, which owned 100 shares of Intel stock, filed two shareholder proposals that it says led to discussions between Intel and community activists about the impact of the company's actions. Intel eventually changed its environmental, health and safety policy to commit to more dialogue with communities housing its facilities, and Noyes withdrew its second shareholder proposal.
Activists say the presence of a foundation in such discussions can make a difference by convincing executives that there is a broader group of institutions concerned about their behavior. "The acoustics change with a company," said Timothy Smith, the director of the Interfaith Center.
BUT most foundations, beyond choosing not to sponsor shareholder resolutions, have remained largely silent on many of the proposals put forward by other investors, from measures pressing Home Depot to stop using old-growth wood to resolutions urging Sara Lee to avoid genetically modified food.
Even Ford, Rockefeller and Carnegie, the three foundations that helped create the Investor Research Responsibility Center in 1972, say little publicly about their current roles as shareholders. People who follow shareholder campaigns say all three foundations appear to take their voting responsibilities seriously, but not one was willing to talk in detail about how it votes its proxies.
"The key question to be raised is how best to engage corporate leadership," said Alexander W. Wilde, a spokesman for the Ford Foundation. While Ford will write privately to companies from time to time, he said, in addition to voting on shareholder issues, it prefers to work with companies on charitable programs rather than engage them through its ownership of their shares.
Some big foundations, like the Commonwealth Fund, do not even vote their shares, leaving the task to their investment managers. Others, like the $13 billion David and Lucile Packard Foundation, invest much of their money in pooled index funds, which means that they cannot vote their shares.
"I think that is a tremendous lost opportunity," said Robert Massey, executive director of the Coalition for Environmentally Responsible Economies, which works with investors to improve corporations' environmental records.
While many foundation officials say they believe that their fiduciary duty lies in trying to maximize returns, some advocates of social investing go so far as to argue that these endowments have a legal obligation to consider their mission when making investment decisions.
"It is not a question you can disregard," said William McKeown, a New York lawyer who specializes in nonprofit law. "Fiduciaries have a responsibility to carry out the purpose of the organization."

HEADLINE: Raising the Rent, and Raising the Roof

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
IT is surely one of the most thankless tasks in public service. And on Thursday morning, when the gavel pounds for the start of this year's all-day hearing on proposed rent increases for New York City's 1 million rent-stabilized apartments, members of the city's Rent Guidelines Board may well have shudders from hearings past lurking in the recesses of their minds:
Thoughts of marbles arching at them from the back of the auditorium. Of rainstorms of epithets. Of circling like covered wagons on stage to conduct business while a phalanx of police officers holds the placard-shaking crowd at bay. 
 And of all nine board members, those most wondering why on earth they are doing this may well be the five public representatives seated center stage -- landlord members to the right of them, tenants to the left.
This year, the board has issued a preliminary recommendation that rents on apartments covered by the rent stabilization regulations be raised by 4 percent for one-year leases and 6 percent for two-year leases -- a significant jump from the 2 and 4 percent increases ordered in most recent years.
Recalling unruly meetings of years past, Vincent Castellano, one of the two landlord members -- who readily affirms that he serves on the board to protect his own interests and those of the city's 25,000 other landlords -- wondered: "Can you think of any agency of government where the meetings are as bizarre? It's a zoo."
As for the public members' motivation, he said, "They're masochists."
David Pagan, one of the two tenant representatives, is the administrator of Los Sures, a housing and community development organization in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. "I come in from the neighborhoods where I deal with a lot of tenants, that's why I'm here," Mr. Pagan said. "The public members, I don't know. I can't figure what's there for a public member."
"There's not much recognition; it's not a power position," Mr. Pagan said. "They really must love to be helpful. At the same time, how long can you be helpful if you are being hit over the head?"
There is also not much pay; the members receive the same $100-a-day fee that was set back in 1969 when the Rent Guidelines Board was created -- a point of particular annoyance to them. "We get $100 per session, about 10 times a year," Mr. Pagan said. "So it's an extra thousand dollars, for which we have to reveal our financial history" -- in a 35-page form.
To be sure, meetings of the board have been somewhat calmer in recent years. "Far more decorous than prior years," said Mr. Castellano, the landlord representative, "almost bordering on the civil -- almost, not quite."
In part, the relative decorum "has to do with the economy," Mr. Castellano said. "It's hard to get worked up about a 2 or 4 percent increase when you've got a job. If you're unemployed, it's a different story. It's not the hot-button issue it was in the early 90's." Yet, when the board convenes in the Great Hall of Cooper Union, 7 East Seventh Street, at 10 a.m. Thursday, the button may be pushed, a bit.
For five of the last six years -- not counting tumultuous 1996 when they were 5 and 7 percent -- the rent increases have been 2 percent and 4 percent. And, in the view of tenant advocates, with inflation largely in check, the current proposal for 4 and 6 percent increases seems unjustified.
The landlords argue, however, that they have been hit with significant increases in fuel costs and real estate taxes, and deserve compensation even greater than the preliminary recommendation.
The board's final vote will not be taken during the public hearing, but is scheduled for 5 p.m. on June 22, also in the Great Hall at Cooper Union. The final guidelines will affect those leases with starting dates between on Oct. 1, 2000 and Sept. 30, 2001.
Piqued last month by media accounts that a proposed change in the way the board's staff provides economic reports could lead to whopping increases of 8.5 and 12 percent (in fact, the change was not adopted by the board), public interest in the current proposal has been stirred. And with it, renewed railing on opposing sides of the landlord-tenant divide that (a) the rent board is in the pocket of a city administration beholden to the real estate lobby or (b) that tenant advocates are simply flexing their numbers to politicize the process, invoking protection of the poor on behalf of lots of people who can afford to pay more.
Central to the board's deliberations is a debate over whether one year's rent guidelines should be based solely on economic factors from the immediately preceding year or should compensate for previous inflationary fluctuations. Also at issue is what role a potentially one-time spike in a particular element of the calculations -- fuel costs, in this instance -- should play.
All of which sets the stage for 12 hours of vigorous contention on Thursday, with landlord and tenant advocates from the audience taking turns in last-word attempts to test the limits of their allotted three-minute speaking times -- punctuated by vociferous support or derision from opposing factions in the crowd.
Edward A. Weinstein, for one, will brook little of the disorder of the not-too-distant past. Mr. Weinstein, one of the five public members of the board, is a retired senior partner at the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche and sits on the boards of six not-for-profit organizations, including the Cooper-Hewitt Museum. At the request of a friend in the city administration (whom he would not name), Mr. Weinstein agreed to serve on the rent board three years ago.
"Given my background, I'm not quite used to what I've had to endure from the people who attend the meetings," Mr. Weinstein said. "It's a question of unruliness, and the feeling that they have the absolute right to just yell out."
"I don't mind if they applaud or boo or hiss, although it's childish," Mr. Weinstein said, "but they disrupt people who are speaking and scream out their unhappy remarks. It just offends me."
Vivid in his recollection is a woman who confronted him at the intermission of a meeting during his first year on the board. "She started screaming at me that I had never heard of Patrick Henry or the Boston Tea Party," Mr. Weinstein said, "meaning I had no right to stifle their right to dissent. I just walked away."
The low moment for Edward S. Hochman came in 1994, the year Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed him to serve as chairman and a public member of the board. That year, the board voted increases of 2 and 4 percent and, after a four-year hiatus, reinstituted what it calls the low-rent supplement -- an extra charge for apartments with rents below a certain level. Tenants call it the "poor tax."
IN 1989, the supplement was $5 for stabilized apartments renting for $325 or less. For the next four years, no supplement was charged. But in 1994 it was restored at $15 for apartments renting for $400 or less (This year, the board has proposed a supplement of $15 for rents up to $500).
"After the final meeting in '94, when it died down," Mr. Hochman said, "I walked to the subway -- the good old City Hall stop for the 4, 5 and 6 trains -- and a couple of people in the crowd followed me and threatened to throw me on the tracks. I remember thinking that's not such a bad idea, an alternative to suicide."
During the final meeting in 1996, the one year in the last six in which the increases exceeded 2 and 4 percent, rising to 5 and 7 percent, "I got hit with marbles, gum and tacks," Mr. Hochman, who is a corporate lawyer, said.
That '96 meeting was probably the stormiest in the board's 31-year history. Kenneth Rosenfeld, director of legal services for the Northern Manhattan Improvement Corporation, a tenant rights group, was then one of the two tenant representatives on the rent board. He left the board last year.
Fully the tenant advocate, Mr. Rosenfeld recalled: "In that year, there was a temporary increase in fuel costs. And, despite the staff statistics in what is called the Core Price Index, the board ignored its own data and passed what, under those circumstances, were startling and onerous guidelines" -- the 5 and 7 percent increases.
"The place was full of people screaming," Mr. Rosenfeld said. "Landlords were yelling, too. We voted on the apartments and the crowd went nuts. In order to continue the meeting, because there were other votes to be taken, we ended up sitting in a circle on the stage at 1 Police Plaza, trying to conduct the rest of the business."
IF the 5 and 7 percent increases of 1996 were outrageous, in Mr. Rosenfeld's tenant-protective eyes, the 2 and 4 percent guidelines of 1994, '95, '97, '98 and '99 were less egregious only to a degree.
"Two and 4 percent may sound reasonable," he said, "but, if you recall, in almost all those years inflation was significantly lower than in the past, and, in the most recent years, almost nonexistent."
Mr. Pagan, one of the two current tenant representatives, agreed. "We're talking about zero and maybe 1 percent inflation, and the fact is that they went to 2 and 4," he said.
"This year," Mr. Pagan continued, "oil is the factor that has skewed landlord costs more than anything else, and everybody understands that oil is one of those commodities for which the price will come down at some time."
Pointing to the issue of whether the board should allow a one-time spike in a particular economic factor to govern the guidelines, Mr. Pagan said: "What happens is that we are building in a higher percentage rent increase, and when the oil price comes down and inflation comes down to a normal level, because the oil was pushing it, we will not get a reduction on rent."
"So we're just putting costs on top of costs," he said.
Referring to an annual study produced by the board's staff called the Price Index of Operating Costs -- or "the PIOC," in board terminology -- Mr. Weinstein said Mr. Pagan was contending "that if we take a look at the PIOC in relation to the increases voted upon by the board, in general the board lags behind in those years when the PIOC shows abnormal inflation, and the board leads the PIOC in years of moderate or low inflation."
"So he's saying that the board tends to act as a moderating force when it comes to prices," Mr. Weinstein continued.
"But I look at a year within itself, as well as within a framework of history, and try to achieve a balance," Mr. Weinstein said. "So his interpretation is that of the tenant representatives, and I don't agree with it. I think what we did was appropriate, based upon the statistics that we saw."
"Whatever we do, this board is not going to be popular," he said. "Either the tenants or the landlords are not going to be happy, and probably both."
The statistics, compiled by the board's full-time staff of six, provide only guidance to the members in their deliberations, rather than setting a hard-and-fast conclusion.
Rent stabilization was instituted in 1969 to counter the effects of Rockefeller-era vacancy decontrol laws that allowed a landlord to go to free-market rents when a rent-controlled apartment became vacant. There were widespread instances of landlords forcing out long-time tenants.
Under stabilization, the owner of a vacated rent-controlled apartment could set an initial free-market rent, after which the rent would be subject to the increases allowed by the board. There are currently about 70,000 rent-controlled apartments in the city, down from more than 1 million at the time stabilization was enacted.
The rent board's staff prepares at least five reports each year assessing the affordability and profitability of stabilized housing. Probably the most significant are the Price Index of Operating Costs and the Income and Affordability Study.
Like the federal Consumer Price Index, the PIOC surveys a basket of goods -- among them taxes, labor, fuel and contractor costs -- that estimate the cost of running a rent-stabilized apartment. It then offers a projection of the coming year's expenses for the landlord.
The Income and Affordability Study focuses on tenants, surveying such factors as their salaries, Social Security, public benefits, rent-to-income ratios, eviction rates and homelessness. It provides a balance to the data on landlord costs.
Mr. Rosenfeld, who in his years on the board frequently clashed with Mr. Hochman, the chairman, believes the board's political balance has changed in recent years. "Having been appointed by Mayor Dinkins in '93, the last year of his term, I spent most of my time on the board under the Giuliani administration," he said. "I saw an extreme shift in the attitudes of both the city administration and the Giuliani appointees -- from balancing out the inequities in the rent-regulated universe toward satisfying the landlord and real estate lobbies." Of the nine current members, seven -- including the chairman and three other public representatives -- were appointed by Mayor Giuliani. Members serve two-, three- or four-year terms, except for the chairman, who serves at the pleasure of the mayor.
Bart D. Carmody, one of the new public members, sees no shift in the board's attitude. "Simply put, when the vote was 2 and 4 percent, the tenants were making statements about the public members being pro-landlord," said Mr. Carmody, who is a certified public accountant. "This year, when the rates, in my view, could have been higher, the landlord advocates are crying that we are pro-tenant. So, my point is: one year yes, one year no."
Mr. Castellano, the landlord representative appointed by Mayor Giuliani, thinks "it's funny how some of the tenant advocates portray the behind-the-scenes politics."
"When I hear from them that the mayor has such control over the board," he continued, "the fact is that virtually everybody on the board is doing the mayor a favor by being there, and if he had to replace them it would be difficult, at best. There is not a long line of people who want to take this kind of abuse."
THERE is no cohesive bloc of public members, Mr. Castellano said. "My role and the role of any of the advocate members is to persuade at least two public members to agree with us and, hopefully, get the chair's vote," he said. "That makes a bare majority."
Mr. Hochman, the chairman, asked rhetorically: "Does the administration have an interest in what the Rent Guidelines Board does? I not only presume so, I would hope so. Do I, as the only member of the board who, by law, can be fired at any time, the one designated as the administration's representative, talk to the administration?
"When all the reports come in, I tell the administration that this was the board's factual findings and this is the general range where I anticipate that the preliminary guidelines may be," Mr. Hochman continued. "I have never talked to the mayor on this. Usually I send my report to a deputy mayor. I'll say, 'This is a general range; do you guys have a problem with that?' The answer has always been no."
Mr. Carmody said, "I would think the mayor has to look more to the voters than any industry" -- a point not entirely lost on Mr. Rosenfeld.
"In appointing the board and approving, to the extent that a mayor does, the final result," Mr. Rosenfeld said, "a mayor is balancing out how much influence the real estate lobby has and the dollars it provides to political campaigns with the potential votes of 1 million regulated apartments."
Mr. Hochman pointed out that those 1 million apartments house, perhaps, 2 million voters. "I've always said that if either side ever thanks us, we've probably done a poor job," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 9, 2000, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on June 11 about the New York City Rent Guidelines Board misstated the background to the state legislature's 1969 passage of the Rent Stabilization Law. The law was enacted in response to sharp increases in rents of apartments not subject to the Rent Control regulations, which covered buildings built before 1947. The law was not a response to harassment by landlords seeking to vacate rent-controlled apartments.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 16; Column 3; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1134 words

HEADLINE: Let's Make a Deal

BYLINE: By James B. Stewart; James B. Stewart is the author of "Den of Thieves" and, most recently, "Blind Eye."

 BODY:

 THE WHITE SHARKS
 OF WALL STREET
 Thomas Mellon Evans and
 the Original Corporate Raiders.
 By Diana B. Henriques.
 Illustrated. 368 pp. New York:
 A Lisa Drew Book/Scribner. $27.50. 
 There are surely few phenomena more remarkable in American business than the periodic ability of cash-poor but swashbuckling newcomers, using little or none of their own money, to seize control of some of the country's most valuable corporations. In its most recent, frenzied incarnation, dot-com entrepreneurs have exchanged stock in companies with few tangible assets and even fewer profits for control of established, profitable companies. Fifteen years ago, the currency was junk bonds rather than inflated stock. And before that, it was bank loans using a target's assets as collateral.
Wall Street greets each wave of takeovers as the dawning of a new era. But the proposition that nothing has fundamentally changed is convincingly set forth in "The White Sharks of Wall Street," an engaging and thorough history of early corporate takeovers by Diana B. Henriques, a financial reporter for The New York Times. Her central character is Thomas Mellon Evans, who surfaces in what seems like nearly every trendsetting corporate battle from 1945 until his retirement in 1984, and whose tactics remain essential to practitioners of corporate warfare. Junk bonds? Greenmail? Scorched earth? Evans had been there long before investment bankers coined a catchy vocabulary to describe the maneuvers of people like T. Boone Pickens, Carl Icahn and Saul Steinberg.
Though Evans seems to have escaped the widespread public resentment and envy the others generated, and Henriques's portrait is carefully nonjudgmental, it is difficult for a reader to work up much sympathy for him. He was ruthless, bad-tempered, usually indifferent to workers and communities. He repeatedly displayed what appears to be a criminal disregard for the antitrust laws (though he was never prosecuted). He divorced two wives (the second later committed suicide), and both times a replacement was conspicuously at hand long before any legal proceedings had begun. He betrayed two of his own sons in his quest for corporate dominance and wealth.
Orphaned at the age of 11 in Pittsburgh, later taken under the wing of his prominent but distant relatives the Mellons, Evans was poor but grew up in a milieu of inherited wealth and privilege to which he evidently aspired. In later life he mingled prominently in old-line society, and took up art collecting and horse breeding. True to his class and era, Evans was frustratingly taciturn throughout his life, betraying little emotion. It is hard to tell whether any of his achievements, wives or riches brought him much satisfaction.
Yet as a deal maker Evans displayed a natural audacity and genius. In 1935, 24 years old and lacking any money to speak of, he decided he wanted to gain control of Pittsburgh's struggling H. K. Porter Company, a manufacturer of steam locomotives. Inspired by a Fortune magazine account of Floyd Odlum, who became rich by using borrowed securities as collateral for loans to buy undervalued stock, Evans borrowed shares from a Mellon mentor, took out a loan and invested in Gulf Oil stock, then a Mellon enterprise. When Gulf's stock rose handsomely as the nation emerged from the Depression, Evans used his profits to buy Porter bonds, then selling for a small fraction of their face value. When Porter finally had to declare bankruptcy and was reorganized, Evans, as the largest creditor, traded his bonds for equity and became the largest shareholder. Porter, essentially acquired for junk bonds, would be Evans's vehicle for most of his life.
Like many who followed in his footsteps, Evans was not much of an operations man. He shrewdly hired experienced managers while he pursued his real interests, which were balance sheets and deals. He turned his attentions to the Mount Vernon Car Manufacturing Company, a rail car manufacturer that was the economic mainstay of tiny Mount Vernon, Ill. The company was on the block for $2.7 million, even though it had over $3 million in cash. Such was the nation's aversion to debt and its paucity of capital in 1944 that no one but Evans seemed attracted to such an obvious bargain. Nor would any commercial bank lend Evans the $2.7 million until he hit on the idea of selling Mount Vernon's rail car division and using the expected proceeds as collateral for the loan -- in other words, using as collateral something he did not yet own. Pittsburgh bankers balked at the unorthodox proposal. But Evans found financing in New York and completed the purchase. In 1946, showing scant interest in the town of Mount Vernon or the company's employees, he sold off the company's core assets. Mount Vernon proved to be another model that was widely copied: buy an undervalued, underperforming company using its own assets as collateral for borrowed money; ruthlessly slash operating costs and improve profitability; then break it up and sell the pieces at a profit -- the forerunner of the leveraged buyout perfected by Henry Kravis.
Though he was a wealthy man by the mid-1950's, Evans never lost his zeal for corporate battles, even as other players came on the stage (several of whose stories are told here in less satisfying detail), the stakes rose and the tactics became tougher. Henriques painstakingly recounts Evans's numerous forays: his discovery that even unsuccessful attacks can yield handsome profits; that price fixing boosts profit even if it is eventually detected; and, in a flurry of mid-70's takeover fights, that Establishment credentials are a poor defense to a well-mounted hostile bid. Throughout, Evans displayed the cool, even heartless detachment that brought opprobrium to more recent corporate raiders.
In the book's most dramatic narrative, Henriques recounts Evans's willingness to betray his son Sheldon, who was both a board member and executive vice president of the venerable Crane Company, the Chicago plumbing-fixture manufacturer Evans had conquered in a hostile 1960 maneuver. Without informing his son, Evans secretly negotiated in 1984 to sell the company at a price that seemed unfair to shareholders -- a deal that would have cost Sheldon his job. He rallied Crane's independent directors, who canceled the sale and accepted Thomas Evans's abrupt resignation -- a matter father and son never spoke of again.
Still, surely Evans would have admired his son's fortitude, and at Evans's funeral 13 years later, it was Sheldon who delivered the eulogy. "It is not always easy to be the son of a great man," he said. "And he was a great man. His business career was legendary, innovative and ahead of its time. . . . He loved the 'hurly-burly' of the marketplace."

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 19; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1420 words

HEADLINE: Job Training, Child Care Under One Roof

BYLINE: By EMILY BAZELON 

 BODY:
TO move from welfare to work, Tyree Dickey took a job at Southern New England Telephone and then one at St. Raphael's Hospital in New Haven, but left them both because she didn't have reliable day care for her 2-year-old son.
Then with her time on welfare running out, she found a way to get job training and look after her child at the same time. "Coming here was like 'Yes!' " Ms. Dickey said. "I was desperate." 
 Ms. Dickey, 28, is a member of the first class of All Our Kin, a small pilot program that instructs women about early childhood development while they take care of their own children. This month, the program expects to graduate four women, all of them once unemployed. Each will have spent nine months earning a Child Development Associate credential, a prerequisite to a job at a day care center or a pre-school program like Head Start.
By attending to the needs of parents and children, All Our Kin makes a connection missed by most welfare-to-work efforts, experts said.
"The state has been very industrious about getting mothers to work, but not about taking care of the children," said Edward Zigler, a psychology professor at Yale University and one of the founders of Head Start. "It's obvious that to have successful welfare reform, you have to have child care reform. All Our Kin, while small in numbers, is a very good model."
State officials also said the All Our Kin approach has potential, though they cautioned against assuming that child care training is the answer for larger-scale welfare-to-work programs.
"This kind of training is worthwhile for some people, but it's not a panacea for everyone on welfare," said Nancy Wiggett, director of Welfare to Work at the Connecticut Department of Labor. "Not everyone should be a child care worker. I think we need to be careful of that. But for some people, who have that natural talent or ability, this program is a first step in that career. Compared to just sending people to work as waitresses, it offers an opportunity to get a credential and for growth."
 To address the need for child care where it's sharpest, the founder of All Our Kin, Jessica Sager, located the program in an apartment at the Brookside housing project, home to about 200 families in New Haven's West Rock neighborhood. Boarded-up apartments line the streets. For years, the city's housing authority has been vacating the project because of its isolated location.
There is only one convenience store and one bus line within walking distance. And Brookside has no organized child care.
That means Brookside is like a lot of poor neighborhoods in the city. According to a recent study by researchers at Yale and the University of California at Berkeley, New Haven neighborhoods where welfare families live have less than half as many day care programs as comparable neighborhoods in California and Florida cities, for example.
New Haven's scarcity of local child care programs has been felt acutely since the 1996 advent of welfare reform, when the state's new work requirements and 21-month time limit for state benefits began pushing more mothers into the work force. The Yale-Berkeley study found that about three-fourths of welfare mothers in Connecticut leave their children with relatives rather than at day care centers or pre-schools, compared with about half in California and one-fourth in Florida.
Relatives can be lifesavers, but they often provide poor care. Children cared for by relatives watch television more and read less than children who go to day care, the researchers found. Connecticut does not regulate family settings, though it pays up to $315 a month for them. "There is no quality control," said Professor Zigler. "This is a huge disservice. We're spending tax dollars to buy negligent child care."
All Our Kin, on the other hand, has state approval to provide both child care and job training. And the program teaches the mothers how children learn. "We are not baby sitters. We are professionals," said Janna Wagner, the programs' early childhood development teacher.
The women in All Our Kin spend half the day taking classes and the other half putting theory into practice while tending the six children in the program, ages 11 months to four years. On a recent morning, Ms. Dickey and Maryann Williams, 24, monitored the play of four children (two others were out sick for the day) at All Our Kin's home base. In a room freshly painted yellow and decorated with children's drawings and collages, the children moved from reciting parts of books they had memorized to playing with a child-sized kitchen set. When two kids threatened to tangle over a toy, Ms. Williams deftly separated them.
"I was raised that you spank a child if you want them to know something is wrong, or you make them sit down," Ms. Dickey explained. "But 1- and 2-year-olds won't sit -- they don't understand! There are a lot of underage mothers in my family. What I'm learning, I can pass on to them."
Ms. Sager sketched a small-scale model of the program in a law school paper. She named the project after a book by the sociologist Carol Stack about the importance of family networks for poor urban African-Americans. To put the idea into practice, she needed a partner who was expert in working with young children and in poor communities. Ms. Wagner had taught third grade in the South Bronx and then earned a master's in education at Harvard. She was also a New Haven native eager to return.
Together, the pair looked for applicants who had the staying power to complete nine months of full-day training and the potential to be community leaders. "We're looking for women on public assistance who have been having children from an early age," Ms. Sager said. "They are the backbone of their families, and they've failed to enter the work force because the jobs they could get conflicted too much with their responsibilities."
To select the first group, they posted flyers and attended tenant meetings at Brookside and two neighboring projects, and recruited parents at the local elementary school. They asked for written applications, conducted interviews, and observed applicants playing with their children. The written samples measured literacy skills. At the interviews, Ms. Wagner tried to scare off the faint-hearted by stressing the program's workload and schedule. Eight women out of 25 original applicants completed the process. Six were selected for All Our Kin. One dropped out a few weeks into the program, another near the end, leaving the current four.
There has been some tension with other Brookside tenants who have wondered why so many resources have been devoted to only a handful of children. "Everybody is ready to bring their kids here," said Maria Coardes, 31. "People knock on the door, and it's hard to say no." In response, All Our Kin started a twice-a-week after-school program open to all Brookside children.
When their training is complete, the All Our Kin graduates will face a low-paying job market. Child care workers make starting wages of $6 or $7 an hour.
Ms. Sager said that rising demand for child care may mean the All Our Kin graduates will be able to get benefits like health insurance and access to more education. Eventually, she hopes that the program's graduates will go on to college (the All Our Kin credential counts for some credits), open their own day care programs, or work their way up to direct a larger center.
All Our Kin also plans to open another site for six trainees and six children in Quinnipiac Terrace, another New Haven housing project. The program's annual budget will increase from $87,000 this year to about $200,000 to staff the second site, most of it coming from private grants. Costs are relatively low because the New Haven Housing Authority gave All Our Kin its Brookside apartment rent-free and the state has allowed the women to continue receiving welfare benefits while they train. Most of the program's books, toys, and furniture have been donated.
As graduation approaches, the women are lining up work for next year. Ms. Coardes and Ms. Williams are choosing between job offers from area day care centers. Ms. Dickey has been hired to help staff All Our Kin's expansion. Ms. Young plans to open a home-based child care program in Brookside and has nearly completed the state's licensing process.
"I get phone calls every day from people asking me when I'm opening up," Ms. Young said. "If I had a place, I could fill it 24 hours a day."

HEADLINE: Ph.D.'s in Demand

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Higher Degrees of Occupation" (Workplace section, June 7):
While the recent rise in job openings in the humanities is heartening, it is premature to describe college teaching as "a hot career in a hot job market." A 1999 study shows that only half those seeking tenured positions in English had actually achieved them after 10 years. 
 Any country with 50 percent underemployment would declare a national crisis.
To remedy this chronic underemployment, the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation is helping create positions for humanities Ph.D.'s. As a result, new doctoral graduates are finding challenging opportunities inside and outside academia.
A robust academic market for Ph.D.'s in the humanities requires a robust market for these professionals throughout the economy.
 
ROBERT WEISBUCH
Princeton, N.J., June 7, 2000
 
The writer is president of the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation.
