HEADLINE: Market Economics;
Chicken Shows the Difficulty of Exporting Food to India

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, June 13

 BODY:
Americans love succulent chicken breasts dressed up in every conceivable way, while Indians relish a savory tandoori drumstick brandished easily in one hand or a spicy chicken curry enriched by the marrow of the leg bone.
For Perdue Farms, America's No. 3 chicken producer, this divergence in culinary tastes seemed a heaven-sent opportunity. While selling white meat at a premium to Americans, it could ship inexpensive, unwanted dark meat to India. 
 So as India prepared to lift its longstanding ban on chicken imports next year in a deal worked out with American trade negotiators, Perdue began developing a strategy to sell leg portions in this potentially huge new market, home to as many as 150 million middle-class customers.
But India does not have a reputation as one of the world's most protected economies for nothing. There is still a deep ambivalence here about foreign investment and trade, and India has taken a decidedly cautious approach to globalization. Over the last decade, it has let in ever more foreign goods and lowered barriers to trade, cutting average tariffs from 128 percent to 40 percent. Still, India has some of the world's highest tariffs.
Sure enough, as the domestic chicken industry considered the fearsome prospect of cheap imported dark meat, its lobbyists began to protest. The government hastily agreed last month to raise the tariff on chicken legs from 35 percent to 100 percent -- a year before the import limitations were to be removed.
"Without the tariff, we would be in a big soup," said Anuradha Desai, chairwoman of the Venkateshwara Hatcheries, based in Pune in west-central India, and the National Egg Coordination Committee.
The higher tariff, if it sticks, would be a big setback for Perdue, for this is a market to make an agribusiness giant salivate. The average Indian eats only 2 pounds of chicken a year, compared with more than 90 pounds for an American. Lower prices could increase consumption exponentially. A 100 percent tariff would sharply curtail Perdue's ability to compete on price in India.
Chicken is one of more than 1,400 goods that India is taking off its restricted list this year and next and allowing to be freely imported, after tariffs are paid.
Among those products is a cornucopia fit for a king's table. Cooks will no longer have to scrounge on the black market for foie gras and caviar, chardonnay and cordials. And the rich will be able to serve these treats by the light of foreign-dipped candles on imported yachts.
But more threatening to Indian industrialists, farmers and fishermen is the free importation of more plebeian items: coffee and tea, cardamom and betel nut, chewing tobacco and motor scooters, textiles and garments, mackerel and, of course, chicken legs.
And deep in the 10-page list of goods to be freely imported is one that would almost surely horrify India's independence leader, Gandhi, if he were alive. It is item No. 248, cotton that is "unbleached, plain weave." Gandhi made homespun cotton a symbol of India's economic independence from foreign domination, exhorting villagers to spin their own cloth rather than buy it from Britain, India's colonial ruler.
India began taking steps to open its economy several years ago. In 1997, India told the World Trade Organization that it planned to phase out its list of restricted goods over nine years, which was whittled to six years at the insistence of powerful trading partners. But the United States challenged that pace and won in 1999. India subsequently agreed to lift the restrictions by next April.
In actual purchasing power, India is now the world's fourth-largest economy, according to the World Bank. Its volume of exports and imports has grown substantially, but its share of global trade remains at just 0.6 percent, the same as it was more than 20 years ago.
Many Indians, from hard-line Hindu nationalists to Nehruvian socialists, believe India must shield its small producers, even at the expense of higher prices for consumers and lower-quality goods.
M. S. Swaminathan, a geneticist who played a pivotal role in the Green Revolution -- the development and use of high-yield strains of wheat and rice -- argues that free trade is unfair when mass-produced goods compete against goods made by the masses, particularly in a traditional agrarian society like India. Bankrupt farmers will not be able to buy food at any price. "There is no level playing field," he said.
But many economists, including those at the World Bank, argue that India should quicken its integration with the global economy as the best path toward lower prices, economic growth and millions of new jobs. Countries in East and Southeast Asia that have moved quickly have had greater success in reducing poverty, they say.
Even some in India's chicken industry say that it is in the industry's long-term interest to become more globally competitive -- and perhaps, one day, become an exporter itself.
Kiran Khatri, whose farm is near Delhi, said he sometimes thinks to himself: "If they can dump drumsticks here, why can't we dump breasts in the American market? For that we'll have to raise our quality. There are lots of diseases."
The chicken industries of northern India and the United States seem to come from different centuries.
In Perdue's highly mechanized plants, when a chicken is placed on a conveyor belt, a worker grabs it and hangs it upside down by the legs -- and it will probably never again be touched by human hands. It will emerge at the other end plucked, chopped and boned; packed in a plastic-foam, shrink-wrapped tray; and stamped with the retail price.
A single Perdue plant can process a quarter of a million chickens a day. The company, which had revenue of $2.5 billion last year, also produces the chicken feed, hatches the chicks and raises them.
In contrast, the northern Indian chicken industry is fragmented among hatcheries, chicken farmers, middlemen and traders, while in southern India a number of integrated corporate chicken producers have appeared.
Estimates of the number of chicken farmers in India, which has a population of a billion, range from 30,000 to 100,000, while a million to a million and a half people depend on the industry.
A slaughterhouse in New Delhi is often a Dickensian place. In all likelihood, it is a small neighborhood shop where men do the killing and gutting after a housewife -- or a middle-class family's cook -- has selected the bird that will adorn the table that evening.
New Delhi's INA Market, which is not air-conditioned, caters to expatriates and middle-class Indians. The air inside was heavy with the smell of blood and damp feathers in the 110-degree heat of a recent afternoon. Plump gray rats scurried across floors smeared with blood and guts.
At the improbably named Fish Corner, one of a dozen chicken shops, a man sat cross-legged slicing off heads against a large fixed blade. A few feet away, men in loincloths and flip-flops squatted precariously on the thin edge of large vats of water, tearing off feathers and dunking birds into the murky liquid.
The chickens were then cut into pieces and set out in unrefrigerated, open-air cases. Workers stood by to shoo away swarms of flies.
Shoppers in this market all said they liked their chicken killed fresh. They want it newly killed because they believe it to be fresher, healthier, tastier and less likely to give you gas -- views that could make frozen chicken a hard sell in India.
Annamma Jacob, who buys imported Tang, Quaker Oats and Kikkoman soy sauce at the market, said she liked picking out a live bird herself, preferably a small, tender one. "I don't like chicken in the United States," said Mrs. Jacob, who owns a garment business and travels to New York occasionally. "It has no taste."
But the chicken preferences of Indians are not the only obstacle to frozen chicken. Some industry experts doubt that it can be profitably distributed until refrigeration is more widely available and power failures less common. There are no big American-style supermarkets in New Delhi, a city of 14 million, or in most of India, for that matter.
But Keith Sunderlal, an economist here who is a consultant to Perdue, said he was confident that Indians would buy frozen chicken for the same reasons people in America, China and Indonesia do. "Consumers have all kinds of taste demands," he said, "but what talks is convenience and the pocketbook."
And he said he believed Perdue could move large quantities of its chicken legs in New Delhi at perhaps a third to half of what local retailers charge through more than 100 meat shops, equipped with refrigerators, that have opened in recent years.
At least that is what he thought until India raised the tariff. Now he is not so sure. And Perdue's vice president for international operations, Peggy Vining, said in an interview, "Anytime you have a tariff that high, it makes exporting more difficult."
Perdue still hopes that American officials can persuade India to lower the tariff, but United States diplomats here say they doubt India will do so in the face of a vigorous domestic lobby.
Without the jolt of much lower prices for frozen chicken, it is hard to see Indians switching from the fresh-killed chicken they find so tasty. Every now and then, Rajana Ramachandran, a housewife, said she picks up Tang or imported cheese at the market, but she said it would never occur to her to buy frozen chicken.
Americans like their mild bell peppers and their mass-produced chicken, but Indians will stick with fiery hot chilies and fresh chicken.
"We don't like bland," Mrs. Ramachandran said.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 16, 2000, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about chicken exports to India misstated the prices at which Perdue Farms estimated that it could sell chicken legs there. Assuming a 35 percent tariff, the company said, it could charge one-third to one-half less than local merchants, not a third to a half of local prices.

HEADLINE: GAME THEORY;
A Teenager With a (Very) Big Problem

BYLINE: By CHARLES HEROLD 

 BODY:
APRIL RYAN is an 18-year-old art student living in the 23rd century. She has an art project due, the sleazy guy across the hall keeps pestering her for a date, and she holds the fate of two worlds in her hands. That's a lot of responsibility for a teenager, but April has yet one more feat to accomplish: she must get the attention of American game players without a missile launcher.
April is the protagonist of The Longest Journey, an adventure game from Funcom of Norway. It has been translated into six languages and has received some of the most enthusiastic reviews of any adventure game ever produced. But you can't yet buy it in any store in the United States, where the adventure game has been declared dead. (DreamCatcher Interactive, a small, Toronto-based publisher, plans to announce this week that it will distribute the game in North America.) Adventure games have continued to be popular in Europe, leaving Americans to their main diet of flashy, immersive violence. 
 The Longest Journey has more than a smart protagonist with a tall order to fill. It is easily one of the best adventure games ever made, with beautiful graphics, a compelling story and interesting puzzles.
You first meet April in her nightmare of a strange, supernatural world. It is the prettiest nightmare you are ever likely to see. The Longest Journey is an ostentatiously gorgeous game, the most stunning since Riven, with landscapes and animated sequences that will make you gasp.
As in many fantasy stories, April discovers that she has a destiny. She doesn't want a destiny. She wants to get A's in art school and find a boyfriend, but the fate of two worlds and billions of people depends on her. April must somehow save the mystical Balance that keeps our earth, the world of science, in harmony with Arcadia, an alternate, magical earth.
To that end, April goes everywhere from the bottom of the sea to outer space and talks to everyone from an ancient dragon to an unemployed actor. In breadth, depth and length, The Longest Journey qualifies as an epic adventure, at times seeming more like a novel than a computer game.
The game environment is a fully realized universe. Arcadia is beautiful and enchanted, with a range of strange beings, many of whom would love to trade unpredictable magic for good old-fashioned science. Three hundred years into the future, our own world is surprisingly familiar, except for things like hovercars, holographic candles and corporate-sponsored police who arrest you and then try to sell you products.
Story and character development have been given at least as much attention as the game's puzzles. The dialogue is terrific. Some of it is as funny as anything in the classic Lucas Arts adventure games, like Curse of Monkey Island and Grim Fandago. Characters like the cybergeek Flipper Burns or a prickly ship's captain will have you laughing out loud, although if you're offended by foul language, Flipper might make you cringe more than laugh.
At other times the writing is thoughtful and original, as exemplified by conversations with Abnaxus, who belongs to a race that experiences the past, present and future as concurrent. When April asks him how he knows her name, he says: "Have we not met then? I was sorry for confusing you. I will be Abnaxus."
While its puzzles lack the inspired ingenuity of a game like Day of the Tentacle, The Longest Journey is challenging without being unfairly difficult. Puzzles are logical, there are no dead ends, and even though April notes at one point that "life should carry a big ol' caution sticker -- it's certain to kill you sooner or later," you can't die in this game. Some games seem designed to frustrate you as much as possible, but The Longest Journey wants you to win.
While the tradition in adventure games is for puzzles to become more difficult as you proceed, the final puzzles in The Longest Journey are surprisingly easy. That's good because the story is so involving that it would be painful to be stuck for days on a puzzle so near the conclusion. Instead of hard puzzles, The Longest Journey's payoff is an emotional one, a satisfying and uplifting finale.
The Longest Journey also raises the question, Can the adventure game genre be revived? In popular entertainment, one of the rules is that nothing ever dies -- some things just hibernate. (In 1976 the common wisdom was that no one wanted to watch science fiction movies, and in 1977 "Star Wars" came out.) If given the opportunity, The Longest Journey stands a better chance than any game in years of reawakening the adventure game in America. It also has the potential to pull in women without putting off men.
The opportunity to play as a woman -- that is, a woman who is not simply a large-breasted male fantasy -- is rare. April Ryan, a heroine to Lara Croft's mannequin, could win the hearts and minds of disenfranchised female players.
She is strong, clever and resourceful. And for the men, April is both prettier and more personable than Lara Croft. She makes a far better sex symbol than a girl with outsize breasts whose conversation rarely goes beyond "aha." She may also be the best adventure computer game hero ever, one who creates the kind of emotional bond with the player that you expect from a good film or novel.
Funcom has hired a model who looks like April to travel the German talk show circuit and is working on an MTV-style video of April covering the Depeche Mode song "The Balance." With that determined media blitz, April Ryan is already doing more than fulfilling prophecies and saving two worlds. She is actually making the journey to a software store near you.
 
The Longest Journey, published by Funcom; CD-ROM for Windows 95 and 98; about $35 at www
.softwarefirst.com; soon to be distributed in North America by DreamCatcher Interactive.

HEADLINE: Where the TV Room Meets the Road

BYLINE: By ROY FURCHGOTT 

 BODY:
THE Maurer family -- Mike, Susan and their children, Ellen and Chad -- love their vacation condominium in Bellaire, Mich., four hours north of their suburban Detroit home. What they don't love is getting there.
"The kids hate the ride," Mr. Maurer said. "They fight because they hate being in the car for four hours. They fight over territory, or what's on the radio. They just fight over anything." Officiating the battles left the parents frazzled as well. 
 But all that changed early this year when the couple bought a Ford Windstar minivan with the newest option: a console with color television, VCR and Nintendo nestled between the front seats, facing the back-seat passengers.
"We saw it, drove it, liked it, and the kids loved it right off the bat," Mr. Maurer said.
Now the family's northern jaunts are placid. "This has been the best thing that has ever happened," Mr. Maurer said. "The kids are occupied, we can talk, and it's a much calmer ride."
In fact, Mr. Maurer is so impressed with the effect on family travel that he is considering spending $1,000 or more to install a similar system in his other car, a Ford Club Wagon, for times when he chauffeurs Ellen, who is 11, and Chad, 8.
Entertainment centers, once strictly for the home, have hit the road, turning the minivan or sport utility vehicle into a family den on wheels. Since October 1999, when the television-VCR combination became a factory option, studies have shown it to be a high-demand accessory, said Frank Forkin, a partner in the automotive marketing and research firm J. D. Power & Associates in Detroit.
"All of the minivans and family-type S.U.V.'s either already have them as an option or have them on the drawing board," he said. And aftermarket installers can put them into almost anything on four wheels.
The price of the entertainment systems usually tops $1,800, but now that they are an option offered at the dealership, buyers can rationalize the purchase more easily by rolling the cost in with the car financing.
Chevrolet expected sales of a special-edition Warner Brothers Venture van, which features a television along with the company's logo and an image of Bugs Bunny, to account for about 10 percent of Venture's sales for the 2000 model year. It is actually accounting for about 20 percent of sales, a percentage that is expected to increase, said Pete Langenhorst, brand manager for the Venture. "The growth potential is enormous," he said.
Some resourceful consumers are finding simple and cheap ways to put a television and a VCR in the car. But others are paying top dollar for fancy multizone systems, each equipped with a separate L.C.D. flat screen (the kind in laptop computers) that can be mounted in the roof or can flip up from a console, or screens that are mounted on the back of the front-seat headrests. Those more expensive systems, which give the car's interior the look of a business-class cabin on a jumbo jet, can let the children play Nintendo or PlayStation video games while Mom listens to a CD and Dad tunes in a radio talk show. To avoid multimedia cacophony, all the passengers can wear earphones, but it is illegal for the driver to wear them. And some systems have controls in the front seat so parents can shut things off in a disciplinary crisis.
But the prospect of such a crisis, among other things, leads some critics to question whether it might distract the driver to have people watching a favorite movie or playing Pokemon in the back seat, or whether a television could be a dangerous thing to have aboard in a car accident. Others debate whether it is wise to augment children's already heavy television consumption.
Entertainment technology has been making the transition from the living room to the car since the 1920's and has been criticized as dangerous at each step along the way.
In the 20's, do-it yourselfers installed tube radios in their cars, said Michael Lamm, who writes about automotive history. People could not listen to the radio as they drove because the firing of the spark plugs interfered with reception.
"You drove to a high place where you would get good reception," Mr. Lamm said, "you would take your girlfriend, and you would park and turn on the radio and it was a very romantic thing to do."
Earl Muntz, a legendary Los Angeles car salesman known as Madman Muntz, installed radios in the 30's that could play as the car drove, and states like Massachusetts considered prohibiting radios in cars as a dangerous distraction. (Now, car televisions could fall under broad restrictions found in some states against things that could distract a driver. But as long as they are not in the front seat, they are generally in safe legal territory.)
Chrysler somewhat unsuccessfully offered a car phonograph in the 50's. "If you hit a big bump, you'd know it," Mr. Lamm said. Although the reel-to-reel tape players never made it to the car as a standard option, eight-track tape players did in the late 1960's. "Eight-tracks didn't last very long because they were so big and bulky," Mr. Lamm said. "When the little cassettes came in, they did it in."
Car televisions are nothing new, of course. They were as common as shag carpet in conversion vans, popular in the 1970's. George Barris, known to some as King of the Kalifornia Kustomizers for his artistic car modifications, said he installed the first television in a car, in the dashboard of the 1953 Golden Sahara, a bubble-topped vehicle used in the Jerry Lewis movie "Cinderfella." The Golden Sahara television was a home unit, Mr. Barris recalled. "It was a Zenith, and we had the old Zenith remote control," he said. "We also used the remote control to open the doors." He had to put a transformer in the car because the television functioned on 110-volt house current.
Mr. Barris said televisions remained a popular option in the cars he modified. "When the 12-volt unit became accessible in the 50's, it became easier to put in," he said. "Now they are in all your S.U.V.'s, limousines -- we can do them any way you want now and hang them anywhere."
Some enterprising people simply adapt for car use small combination TV-VCR's that are designed for homes or camping and can be had for $200 to $300 apiece. Experts warn against that approach.
"The problem is it is not permanently mounted," said Carl Mathews, director of merchandise at the Crutchfield Corporation, a mail-order electronics retailer based in Charlottesville, Va., "and a TV can be a pretty dangerous projectile in an accident."
While some do-it-yourselfers suggest that a television can be secured by strapping it down or putting it in a milk crate that is lashed to the seats, Mr. Mathews suggested the $599 Video Traveler, a monitor and VCR in a bag that straps between the front seats.
"It can be taken out and plugged into a wall socket and played in a hotel room," he said. It also has the advantage of a color L.C.D. screen, which is less dangerous in an accident than the glass vacuum tube used in many portable televisions.
Virtually all of the entertainment units designed specifically for cars use L.C.D. screens. There are also floor-mounted entertainment units designed for the amateur installer; they are a step up from those that strap temporarily in place. A much bigger step up is the ceiling-mounted, flip-down television monitor, which is not recommended for amateur installers. The wiring has to run inside one of the car's roof support posts and in the ceiling cover.
The ceiling-mounted televisions have some advantages. Although they may partly block the rear-view mirror, they will not keep a parent from reaching into the back seat, as some floor-mounted units can. And they may also be better for passengers who suffer from motion sickness.
"What they are finding out is, kids are more likely to get sick looking down or level because when they look up they see the horizon in the peripheral vision," Mr. Langenhorst said.
Dr. Charles M. Oman, a scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who has studied motion sickness for 25 years, agreed that seeing the horizon might help. When someone watches television or tries to read a newspaper in a car, he said, "the motion you are experiencing does not match the brain's expectations -- you aren't creating the motion, and you don't have confirming visual cues."
But no matter where the screen is mounted, some people are simply prone to motion sickness. Susceptibility decreases as children mature so preteenagers are most likely to become ill. "The one thing users of TV can do is sort of pace themselves, and if they feel queasy, look away," Dr. Oman said.
Most mobile televisions use a VCR as the entertainment source, and many offer jacks for video game consoles. Manufacturers say more mobile DVD players are on the horizon, and they talk about a convergence of Internet, navigation and entertainment material, all accessible on the screen.
As for watching television stations, some systems offer a tuner, although the signal is not very good in a moving vehicle. "It's not going to be the quality TV you enjoy at home with cable," Mr. Mathews said.
That's just as well, say some child-rearing experts, like Dr. Dorothy G. Singer of the Yale University Family Television Research Center. Although some bemoan the idea that television has invaded another treasured family ritual, Dr. Singer is not concerned that watching television or videos on trips will dangerously increase the time spent in front of the tube. But she does recommend that parents take along videotapes that are instructive and stimulating and that can be discussed as part of the ride.
"I don't think if you are going on a four-hour or five-hour trip that you should have the TV on the whole time," she said. "I think that is feeding into the 'TV is the baby sitter' attitude that we fall into."
Dr. Singer recommends that parents use television as a reward if the children play well together first. And that periods of watching television be broken up with periods of talking or listening to books on tape.
"We put a book in and it really teases your imagination," she said. "It's like old-time radio. Anything that stimulates the imagination is good, but when you watch TV, the images are provided for you."
Parents who want to heed her advice are in luck. Many entertainment systems, some using wireless headphones, can broadcast different programming to each person in the car. That works out well for Davis and Nancy Weaver and their teenage boys, Matthew and Mark.
"The boys have trouble agreeing on the same entertainment," Mr. Weaver. Davis and Nancy Weaver have a similar problem: Ms. Weaver likes the occasional Faith Hill CD, while Mr. Weaver likes to listen to sports on the radio. With a 30-hour drive from their home in Landenberg, Pa., to the Florida Keys ahead of them this summer, they found a solution in a top-of-the-line van with a multizone entertainment system that lets Mr. Weaver listen to the radio while his wife listens to music on a headset and the boys, also using headsets, watch a movie.
"It's quiet in the car now," Mr. Weaver said. "It's great. It's nice to take a long trip." And now that his oldest son can drive, Mr. Weaver will be able to spend some time watching the scenery and listening to his favorite music on a headset without torturing the family.
"I'm a John Denver-type person," he said. "My kids can't stand John Denver."

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 2; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1400 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Out West, Giving the Musical Some Pop

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: COSTA MESA, Calif., June 10

 BODY:
The Broadway musical, ever in search of the shows that will expand its traditional audience into hipper or younger (or both) sectors of the populace, pushed forward this past season with "Contact," "James Joyce's 'The Dead' " and "The Wild Party," all of which offered innovation in form or tone. Now in Southern California, three nascent works are trying to lure new (and old) theatergoers by energizing the traditional form with the force of pop culture in general and rock 'n' roll in particular. They vary in their achievement, but they all project at least one welcome idea: the world of pop is stageable, a tap-worthy vein of material.
All three of the productions are in the midst of world-premiere runs. At the South Coast Repertory Theater here in Costa Mesa, "The Education of Randy Newman" is a kind of stage biography of the popular singer, with a narrative built on the bittersweet and wryly acid songs that have characterized his career. An hour to the south in San Diego, the San Diego Repertory Theater is presenting "Celebration of the Lizard," a post-apocalyptic tale based on the writings of the rock icon Jim Morrison and featuring 33 songs originally recorded by his band, the Doors. Meanwhile, also in San Diego, the Old Globe Theater is putting on "The Full Monty," an adaptation of the hit British film comedy of 1997 about a half-dozen laid-off mill workers who resort to stripping to earn a quick and necessary buck. 
 A hot ticket, "The Full Monty," directed by Jack O'Brien with a broader humor than in Peter Cattaneo's film, is the most accomplished of the three. It is headed for Broadway in the fall -- not surprising considering that Mr. O'Brien, the artistic director of the Old Globe, and the book writer, Terrence McNally, both have Broadway pedigrees. Fox Searchlight, the division of 20th Century Fox that released the film and that will finance the $7 million Broadway production, has also helped the Old Globe set the show on its infant feet. To judge from a recent performance, it is a crowd-pleaser, with audience members leaping up during the final striptease and hooting for the characters to show it all.
It's a little early in the game for serious carping -- John Arnone's lighthearted sets are zippy and functional but could make use of some of that Broadway money, and at three hours the show is overlong, leaning on Mr. McNally's dialogue-heavy book, which seems likely to be streamlined -- but a few observations won't hurt.
The music and lyrics are by David Yazbek, a stage newcomer with a rock background. His wordplay is sophisticated, his sensibility brusquely unsentimental and occasionally risky. (A Motown-flavored rock song called "Big Black Man" pokes fun at an egregious racial stereotype by indulging it.)
Mr. Yazbek writes in a variety of pop modes, from a jazzy big-band overture to a country-ish lament sung by a father to the son he feels he is failing. There is at least one knockout song: "Scrap," a jangly and jarring lament sung by a chorus of the bitterly unemployed. And Mr. Yazbek knows the traditions of his medium enough that he has written a handful of numbers that would be at home nowhere but in musical theater, including a sweet and funny duet by two husbands romantically serenading the obsessions that rule their lives. One sings to his spendthrift wife, the other to his fat belly ("You grumble/And I stumble/Toward the Muenster cheese.")
Among the surprises for those who fondly remember the movie are augmented roles for three of the characters' wives and the invention of another female character, a crusty old piano player who comes out of retirement to accompany the boys in their striptease. But the most significant change is the relocation of the story from Sheffield, England, to Buffalo -- ostensibly so the show would feel more familiar to American audiences -- and with it a change in attitude.
The characters in the film, out of work and desperate, remained fundamentally gentle; they wore their uncertain plight rather meekly. In the musical they are brasher and angrier and, in the case of the male lead, played by Patrick Wilson, capable of blunt aggression; he walks an interesting line between lovable and loutish.
The show is full of penis jokes, casual obscenity, pelvic thrusting, even gay baiting, but it is able to codify its attitude in a sunny enough manner, particularly in the rousing dance number that ends the first act, choreographed by Jerry Mitchell on a basketball theme. The song is called "Michael Jordan's Ball," and it lionizes Mr. Jordan -- Mr. America indeed! -- for his ability to seize a game and make it his own.
Neither of the other two shows has as assured a future, but "The Education of Randy Newman" might well enjoy an extended life, particularly with its pretension checked and maybe presented in a more intimate setting than on the South Coast Rep main stage. Using an ambitious literary model, "The Education of Henry Adams," for its spirit if not its actual form, the show purports to tell the songwriter's life story in the context of his historical times by knitting 40 or so of his songs into a loose narrative.
As conceived by Mr. Newman, Jerry Patch and Michael Roth, staged by Myron Johnson and performed by a seven-piece band and a strong cast of seven actor-singers upon whom the physical demands are considerable, the show works better than you might think -- at least for a while. Most of the opening act concerns Mr. Newman's upbringing in New Orleans, and the songs -- including the mocking satire, "Rednecks," and the tongue-in-cheek paean to Huey Long, "Kingfish" -- provide the kind of specificity of time and place that good storytelling requires. Perhaps the best number is "Four Eyes," about the social travails of a young boy with glasses, and Mr. Johnson has staged it here as a nightmarish first day of school. Over all, Mr. Newman's upbringing feels satisfyingly singular.
In the second act, however, the action moves to Los Angeles, where the path of Mr. Newman's adulthood seems pretty familiar, if not downright generic: heartbreak and divorce, obsession with money, profligate behavior, redemption in love as a sense of mortality sets in. The songs, many familiar, are perfectly fine, but they end up dividing easily into two categories, sweet and sarcastic, and a little of each goes a long way. A bit of a saccharine sheen begins to accrue by the end of the show's 2 hours 40 minutes.
If one of the themes is that Los Angeles inflates one's sense of oneself, well, here's a case in point. Mr. Newman's life story, modest and wry, might be better served with less aggrandizement -- fewer songs, simpler orchestrations (the music was most informative and touching when played by Mr. Roth on solo piano), a smaller house.
Alas, no such solution is likely to perpetuate "Celebration of the Lizard," which takes seriously not only the music of Jim Morrison, with the lascivious thrum that made him a rock star, but also the anti-establishment defiance that made him a hippie icon.
The book, by Joel Lipman, is drawn from Morrison's own self-righteous writings, telling a futuristic story about a Mad Max-type hero on the run from the fascist authorities who encounters a tribe of hostile renegades in the desert. It is often laughably ponderous, a condition underscored by the reverent spirit of Sam Woodhouse's direction and the lead performance by Jeff Meek, a handsome guy who sings well enough to be the Morrison stand-in the part requires but who has none of Morrison's insolent charisma.
The interesting thing is that the music is as alive and enthralling as it ever was, and the chief pleasure of this production is in the moments it is well adapted for the stage. Mr. Woodhouse, the artistic director of the San Diego Rep, has found apt context for three of the Doors' most famous songs. "The End" serves as a haunting dirge. "People Are Strange" accompanies Mr. Meek's first encounter with the spookily costumed desert tribe (the one laugh-inducing scene in the show). And, of course, there's "Light My Fire," which is employed as a first-act finale, beginning as a love duet enacted by two separate couples and ending with the entire ensemble communing around a glowing campfire.
In those scenes, we get a glimpse of the Doors as theater folk. Maybe they're not Lerner and Loewe, but who would've thought?

HEADLINE: The Library As the Latest Web Venture

BYLINE: By LISA GUERNSEY 

 BODY:
WHEN Carrie Larkworthy, a student at Harvard University, is faced with a research project, getting a book out of the library is the last thing on her mind. Instead she sits in her dormitory room and logs onto the Web, starting with Harvard's online system for searching and retrieving journal articles. "I hate the library, so I try to avoid it," Ms. Larkworthy said. "It's such a big facility that you have to search through."
If Ms. Larkworthy's experience is anything like that of other students, and many librarians acknowledge that it is, the use of books for research is becoming an archaic concept. If scholarly books are not on the Web, they are invisible to anyone using the Internet as a substitute for in-depth investigation. 
 But new efforts are afoot to change that. Several companies are racing to put the full texts of hundreds of thousands of copyrighted books, old and new, on the Web. NetLibrary started the contest, with technology that lets people view books online for short periods of time, the digital equivalent of borrowing them from the library.
Now two other companies, Ebrary.com and Questia Media, are taking on the same challenge but using a new strategy. They want to give people the opportunity to search through reams of pages at no charge, then will charge people a few cents a page for using that information. (Questia users will be asked to pay for viewing, copying and printing the online pages. Ebrary.com users will be able to view pages free but will pay for copying and printing.)
These electronic library projects are not attempts to compete with the budding electronic book industry, which offers books for downloading to handheld devices and is focused on popular fiction, like Stephen King's recent Web-only novella, "Riding the Bullet," and on other newly published trade books. The library projects have very little to do with the debate over the promise or pitfalls of gadgets that let people read novels electronically from the comfort of their beds.
In fact, the new effort to build an electronic library is not about reading at all. It is about the power of electronic searching. With digital scanning, texts of works that may be decades old can be mined for those few morsels of insight that may enhance a research paper or help prove an argument. It could be a way, some publishers say, to move books into the Web's fold and make them more visible to students like Ms. Larkworthy.
"In an ideal world, a person would find a book in the card catalog, pull it off the shelf and use it," said Kate Douglas Torrey, director of the University of North Carolina Press. "But that is just not the world we live in today." The University of North Carolina Press is among more than 80 publishers working with Questia to turn many of their titles into searchable documents available on the Web.
Laziness is not always the excuse for avoiding the traditional library. Even people who do go hunting in the stacks are sometimes thwarted. The books they want might be checked out or misplaced, lost forever among call numbers that have no relation to the sticker on their spines. Or the books might be at other libraries and available only to those researchers who are willing to wait weeks for interlibrary loans.
Such situations can be avoided on the Internet, proponents of digital libraries say. "This will take some of the tedium out of research," Ms. Torrey said, "and make it easy to use an extensive collection of scholarly work."
Of course, people have been hailing the promise of digitized libraries for years, and the reality has not yet measured up. When netLibrary opened in March 1999, for example, it was promoted in press releases as a company that would "revolutionize the library system" by enabling people to tap into a searchable and comprehensible database of reference and scholarly books.
Until this month, netLibrary offered two types of access: holders of library cards from participating libraries could use the service at no charge, and others could subscribe to the service for $29.95 a year. The subscription option is no longer being offered to new users.
Now netLibrary is primarily a service for public, academic and corporate libraries that want to buy electronic titles and make them available to their patrons. Rob Kaufman, netLibrary's president and chief executive, said the shift away from a consumer service was partly an attempt to appease librarians and publishers. Some librarians said the service was competing with them. Publishers did not like the subscription model for another reason: they said it gave people too much access to electronic texts at too low a price.
Even those who gain access to netLibrary may find the experience less than satisfying. There are just not yet enough books in the site's collection to make serious searching worthwhile. The site now has about 18,000 copyrighted books and 4,000 public-domain works, numbers that are tiny compared with the hundreds of thousands of volumes in most research libraries and the millions of volumes in major ones.
Will companies like Questia Media and Ebrary.com do any better? Ebrary.com already has more than 130,000 volumes in its demonstration database and says that it may include as many as 600,000 by the time it opens in the fall. Questia, backed by $45 million in venture capital, plans to offer access to 50,000 volumes when it opens next spring and is working toward a goal of 250,000 books in three years.
These numbers are possible, the founders say, because they have appealed to publishers' pocketbooks. When a book is sold to an actual library, the publisher makes a one-time profit. That book might be retrieved and read by hundreds of people, but the publisher never sees another dime. In the models used by Questia and Ebrary.com, however, that book could continue to make the publisher money as more people see it.
Anyone going to Questia's site, for example, will be able to search the entire database of books at no cost, but only subscribers will be able to see the books' pages by clicking on the search results. (Questia has not yet set its subscription price, but Troy Williams, the company's chief executive, said that it would be "affordable for the average college student.")
Ebrary.com has adopted what Christopher Warnock, the chief executive, calls "the photocopier model." Searching will be free, he said, and so will the act of simply reading whatever pages are retrieved from a search. But when a person tries to copy the text of those pages by using copy and paste commands, a dialogue box will appear on the screen. In a recent demonstration, the box said: "This will cost you $0.25. Would you like to continue?"
The same kind of message pops up when a user tries to print the page. If the user decides to pay for copying or printing, the software will automatically generate a citation for the work and place it below the copied or printed text.
Most people will have no problem paying a few cents for what they want, Mr. Warnock said, since they already scrounge up quarters to use photocopy machines. At the site, a user will be able to sign up for a debit account of, say, $10 and will then need to type in a user name and password during each session in which the user prints or copies pages.
These payments, the founders say, can add up to big money when millions of people are spending a few cents at a time. And many publishers are willing to license their copyrighted material in exchange for some of that cash. "It holds the promise of being profitable," said Tim Cooper, vice president for strategic operations at Harcourt Trade Publishers, one of the companies that has signed a letter of intent with Questia.
It is not just those micropayments that interest publishers, said Larry Weissman, director of new business development for Random House, which, he added, has struck no deals with either Questia or Ebrary.com. But the ideas are appealing, Mr. Weissman said, partly because they may introduce readers to new works. "The hope is that they would want to continue that reading experience by buying a book," he said.
If the sites succeed, they will be mixing the qualities of libraries and bookstores. Most people think of the bookstore as a place to buy and the library as a place to borrow or browse at no charge. But on the Internet, where full texts can be searched in seconds and information can be retrieved with a few clicks, convenience is part of the package as well. These companies, including netLibrary, are betting that people will pay for it.
Librarians are intrigued by the concept, said Kenneth L. Frazier, the president of the Association of Research Libraries. And they are eager to see how quickly texts can be digitized when put into the hands of companies, which may find more efficient ways to scan books on a huge scale.
But Mr. Frazier, who is director of the general library system at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, also wonders what that will mean to traditional research libraries, which have always been motivated by public interest, not private profits. Making sure that low-income people have access to expansive new online libraries is one area of concern. Another concerns the selections made by digital libraries. Will databases include only the most popular books, Mr. Frazier asked, "or the stuff that gets the highest return economically?"
At Ebrary.com, books are included for technical reasons. They must already exist on publishers' computers in a format called PDF (for portable document file), which was developed by Adobe Systems and is commonly read online using the Adobe Acrobat Reader. Many publishers, Mr. Warnock said, have been using this format since the early 1990's during the design of their hard-copy books.
Questia is taking a more academic approach. It has hired Dr. Carol Hughes, a research librarian who recently worked at the University of Iowa, to lead a team of librarians in selecting core titles that have been known to be useful to college students. A few of the books that will be included on Questia are "The Industrial Revolution," a 1956 book by Arnold Toynbee, and a 1982 edition of Dante's "Divine Comedy."
Dr. Hughes said she suspected that Questia might drive more students to the actual library instead of away from it. After using the Web to find books that meet their needs, she said, they may want to check them out to read them more closely. "I think it is going to greatly enhance libraries," she said.
Being able to search online books will help students see their value, Dr. Hughes said, particularly when they can easily get access to books that have become classics in particular subject areas.
A nonprofit project called JStor is often offered as proof that digitizing old texts can breathe life into them. For the past five years, JStor has been creating digital copies of scores of scholarly journals, some of which have issues more than 100 years old. University libraries around the world pay for access to JStor and provide it to their students free. A recent study by JStor showed that students used the online service almost 20 times as much as they dug into the stacks for the paper versions.
Just a few years ago, said Mr. Frazier, of the University of Wisconsin, librarians and publishers scoffed at the idea that a full-scale project like JStor could be adopted for books any time soon. Many people said it would take centuries before the equivalent of a library's bookshelves would ever make it onto the Web.
But now that Mr. Frazier has seen and heard about new efforts, he said, "I'm not so sure about that anymore." "I think this might happen much more quickly than we might have imagined a few years ago," he added. No longer, he said, will books suffer from what he called that "fatal disadvantage": the fact that they are available only in print.
 
Site-Seeing: Literature Texts
 
Although commercial companies are getting into the act, several education Web sites have been offering access to electronic texts for years. The sites are ideal for finding classic texts that are not restricted by copyright, like works of Shakespeare or Robert Frost. Most of them are plain text versions of books and are not integrated into Web-based databases, which means that they do not allow keyword searching across multiple volumes. Here are some of the sites that give people access to texts of literature and reference works:
 
ALEX CATALOG OF ELECTRONIC TEXTS: sunsite.berkeley.edu/alex
Includes about 700 books that are in the public domain, which typically means that they have been written by authors who died decades, if not hundreds of years, ago. Titles are drawn from American and British literature and Western philosophy.
 
BARTLEBY.COM: www.bartleby.com Features a searchable database of about 100 books, most of which are multivolume reference books or classics of literature and poetry. Although the site is now commercial, it started as a university project and access remains free. The company is starting to include copyrighted books as well, like The Columbia Encyclopedia, Sixth Edition.
 
ELECTRONIC TEXT CENTER: etext.lib.virginia.edu/uvaonline.html Offers about 5,000 public-domain texts, including English literature, manuscripts and newspapers from 1500 to the present. Also includes texts in more than a dozen other languages.
 
PROJECT GUTENBERG: promo.net/pg One of the first electronic text projects on the Internet, this has about 2,500 public-domain titles.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section F; Page 10; Column 1; House & Home/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1252 words

HEADLINE: Will Chairs Fly on the Web, or Just Fold?

BYLINE: By JULIE V. IOVINE 

 BODY:
A YEAR ago, the idea of selling furniture on the Internet seemed a stroke of genius. What could be cooler than clicking up a couch? Over a dozen Web sites sprang into action, all promising to take the schlep out of shopping and the fear out of fabric selection. After all, the furnishings industry was huge, with more than $190 billion in sales in 1999, by the estimate of the Bureau of Economic Analysis. Moreover, there weren't a lot of household names dominating the marketplace. The gold rush was on.
New companies like Furniture.com, GoodHome.com and Living.com popped into view and were quickly valued at hundreds of millions of dollars. "It was the hottest thing since sliced bread," said Seema Williams, a senior analyst at Forrester Research, a new-technology research concern in Cambridge, Mass. Starting early last year, an estimated half-billion dollars was invested in home-furnishings Web sites in a little more than 12 months, said Lester Craft, editor in chief of e-Commerce Business, a two-month-old trade magazine. 
 The pressure on established brands to start selling their furniture online was relentless. "It was considered blasphemy not to have a Web site up and running," said Shelly Hale, a senior research analyst in home furnishings and a managing director at Banc of America Securities. "The world was going to come to an end if you didn't sell online."
Then the gold rush turned into a soap opera, as Web entrepreneurs discovered what a tangled web the home furnishings industry can be. Trying to satisfy customers with products they hadn't seen in person was only the beginning. There was also shipping and warehousing, and the need for private labels. (Most large manufacturers didn't want to provide their brands, especially not on someone else's Web site.) There's a big difference, it seems, between ordering a $15 book from Amazon and ordering a $1,500 sofa.
Still, attracting customers wasn't difficult, especially those searching for good prices on small items, like designer sheets with 200-plus thread counts, or on known entities like the Aeron office chair. Then it turned out that what people wanted more than low prices was painfree shopping. But they weren't getting it.
A woman in California ordered a pair of bookcases from HomePoint.com in Greenville, S.C. They arrived damaged. She sent them back, taking advantage of the company's free return policy. Another set went out, and arrived damaged again.
"It was a real challenge to get that order out," said William Herlong, interim president and acting chief executive of HomePoint, who related the story. "I know we sent it back two times, maybe even three. You know, I'm not sure if she was ever satisfied. And I know she wasn't the only one."
Last month, HomePoint closed its online consumer retail operation; its founding chairman, president and chief executive resigned.
Other online companies are making adjustments, both subtle and wrenching. On June 2, Fortune.com, the Fortune magazine Web site, reported drastic reappraisals of the potential value of various furniture Web sites. By Fortune.com's estimates, Furniture.com, the mother lode of home furnishings on the Web, which sells over 20,000 products online, slid to a $20 million valuation in May, from $255 million in January; Living.com dropped to $140 million, from $600 million in December. Recently, Living.com also laid off 13 percent of its work force, even as it announced an exclusive deal to become the home furnishings Web site of choice on Amazon.com.
Now that the Web sites are faltering, the causes seem all too obvious. "Personally, I kept thinking the furniture industry is the last place I'd look" to sell directly to consumers, Ms. Hale said. "What a hard way to make money. I kept shaking my head." Web sites are simply not touchy-feely: customers still want to bounce on the mattress, caress the nub and otherwise feel the product.
Online consumers are often faced with images murky enough to be featured on "The X Files." Just try to decide whether you like the grain of a cherry sleigh bed, or whether a gingham sheet is actually checked. Hit the zoom-in button and you are still looking at murk -- but close up.
"You can't tell the difference in quality between something that's $3,000 and something that's $10,000," said Bill Sibbick of Stanley Furniture in Stanleytown, Va. "That's our biggest concern."
Stanley, a leading manufacturer, agreed to put its furniture on Living .com but pulled it off less than two weeks later after complaints from retailers who felt they were being betrayed. They said that they had to invest in floor samples and advertising, then watch while customers stopped by, kicked the tires and went and ordered the items on the Web.
Returns have also been a problem. Many sites initially offered free shipping both ways. In April, Furniture.com replaced free shipping with a $95 "no matter the amount of purchase" policy. That "works psychologically," said Carl Prindle, Furniture.com's senior vice president for product development. The company, he said, is happy with a 10 percent return rate; 5 percent is the average for the industry; Ethan Allen enjoys less than 2 percent.
Living.com is phasing out free shipping in favor of "heavily subsidized rates" said Shaun Holliday, the chief operating officer. So is GoodHome.com, which will end free shipping on July 15. "We had it to build our image," said Doug Mack, a founder and the chief executive.
As it dawns on companies that the question is not "Who is going to be the Amazon.com for the furniture business?" but rather "Who is going to survive?" the focus has also shifted from Sell! Sell! Sell! to an approach that could better be described as service . . . service . . . service. For some, the goal now is to escort site visitors through a bewildering array of choices into the waiting arms of retailers and manufacturers -- the people who physically possess the furniture.
"Everyone's tired of bloodying their foreheads against the walls of existing distribution channels and against such meager rewards," said Brian Carroll, the e-commerce editor at Furniture Today. He noted that Web sales of furniture don't even approach 1 percent of all furniture sales.
Technology may have gotten the Web sites into their predicament, but it is also being promoted as a way out: new systems will offer rotating 3-D views, virtual reupholstery and on-screen room makeovers. "There are a lot of cool tools in development so that the Web sites will be able to do things no brick and mortar store will be able to do anytime soon," said Ms. Williams of Forrester Research. By the end of the year, Furniture.com hopes that people will be able to send in pictures of a room so they can try placing different products in it. This month, GoodHome.com will introduce "floor planning," allowing site visitors to build an electronic version of their rooms, then drag in furnishings to see how they fit.
Analysts still expect e-commerce to grow, if perhaps more slowly than initially anticipated. By 2004, they say, 5 percent of all furniture sales will be made online. Steven Wagner, the editor in chief of Poshandsticks, an e-commerce Web site that has already postponed its introduction twice this year, said: "Everyone is diving in without a parachute. We've tried to learn from others' mistakes."
The site's grand plan: making sure shoppers love the furniture when they see it online, and love it even more when they get it at home.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

AFRICA
 
ETHIOPIA: YES TO PEACE -- Ethiopia accepted a peace plan to end a two-year border war with Eritrea, paving the way for a cease-fire and the deployment of a United Nations force to keep the rival armies apart. Prime Minister Meles Zenawi said a proposal drawn up by the Organization of African Unity had been approved by his cabinet. The plan calls for setting up a 15-mile buffer zone in Eritrea along the disputed border, to be policed by a peacekeeping force. Eritrea has already accepted the plan. (Reuters)
 
NIGERIA: NEW SHARIAH STATE -- Shariah will go into effect next week in Kano, the third of Nigeria's 36 states to adopt the Islamic penal and social code. Hundreds were killed this year in clashes between Muslims and Christians in the state of Kaduna, which was considering introducing Shariah. The movement toward Shariah is considered by many to be politically inspired, intended to weaken the government of President Olusegun Obasanjo, a Christian. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT) 

MIDDLE EAST
 
ISRAEL: PLEA ON LESBIAN RULING -- The government has asked the High Court of Justice to expand its panel of judges and review its recent landmark ruling that allowed a lesbian who adopted her partner's son in California to be officially listed as his second mother. The couple, Nicole and Ruti Berner-Kadish, urged the court to reject the request, and said they had been subjected to homophobic harassment since the ruling was made public. Deborah Sontag (NYT)
 
ISRAEL: RED CROSS COMPROMISE -- Israel and its relief agency, the Magen David Adom, proposed a compromise in Geneva in the controversy over whether it can become a Red Cross movement member while still using the red Shield of David emblem instead of the Red Cross or Red Crescent to identify its workers. Israel said it wanted to continue to use the shield for its work inside the country, but put it inside a new, neutral emblem outside its borders. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
ARGENTINA: THOUSANDS STRIKE -- Thousands of government workers went on a one-day strike to protest austerity policies that are cutting their salaries by between 12 and 15 percent. The action came less than a week after a general strike paralyzed the country for a day in protest at the 14 percent jobless rate.
 Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
MEXICO: JOURNALIST QUIZZED -- One of Mexico's best-known journalists, Sergio Sarmiento, was called in as a witness in a high-profile murder case by the Mexico City district attorney, raising a storm of protest from the press. Mr. Sarmiento said he cited his professional confidentiality rights and refused to reveal how he obtained an interview last year with former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. He said prosecutors seemed to be looking for a connection between a visit by Mr. Salinas and the killing of the comedian Francisco Stanley. Julia Preston (NYT)
 
PACIFIC
 
SOLOMON ISLANDS: PREMIER QUITS -- Prime Minister Bartholomew Ulufa'alu resigned, saying he did so under duress but that the resignation would pave the way for peace between warring factions. Tensions have been growing for 18 months since indigenous Guadalcanal residents, called Isatabus, began forcing out migrants from the nearby island of Malaita. (AP)
 
EUROPE
 
NORTHERN IRELAND: TROOP PULLOUT -- With paramilitary cease-fires holding and security improving, Britain's military presence fell to 13,500, its lowest level in three decades as the last 100 paratroopers scheduled for withdrawal flew to the mainland. Troop levels reached 30,000 in 1972. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
FRANCE: ALGERIAN'S PLEA -- On the first day of a four-day visit, President Abdelaziz Bouteflika of Algeria urged closer ties between the two nations. In a speech to the National Assembly he condemned the colonial past but called his state visit, the first by an Algerian leader since 1982, a reunion of friends. Suzanne Daley (NYT)
 
FRANCE: McDONALD'S SECOND THOUGHTS -- After more than 800 shopkeepers in the Marais, the Paris district known for its synagogues and Jewish shops, signed a petition to keep a McDonald's restaurant out of the neighborhood, the company announced it was abandoning plans to open a restaurant there. The shopkeepers said a fast-food outlet would ruin their neighborhood. McDonald's said it dropped the project because of technical difficulties. Suzanne Daley (NYT)
 
RUSSIA: JEWISH SPLIT -- The Jewish minority appeared split after a new group declared a leader of the Hasidic Chabad Lubavitch movement, Rabbi Berl Lazar, the nation's chief rabbi. That title has been claimed since the early 1980's by Adolf Shayevich, an Orthodox rabbi. Each sect called the other's leader an imposter. Some linked the dispute to the arrest of the media baron Vladimir A. Gusinsky, who heads the group that supports Rabbi Shayevich. Rabbi Lazar, above, appears to have the Kremlin's support. Michael Wines (NYT)
 
ASIA
 
SRI LANKA: SUICIDE BLAST -- A suicide bomber in Colombo tried to blow up a bus carrying wounded airmen, but the attack was impeded by a passing cyclist, the police said. Two civilians died in the blast, for which the police blamed Tamil Tiger rebels. Barry Bearak (NYT)
 
INDIA: PAKISTAN REJECTED -- A spokesman termed a recent overture by Pakistan for nuclear restraint as "essentially propagandist," and said India would discuss arms control only after Pakistan "stops cross-border terrorism." Pakistan's foreign minister, Abdul Sattar, is in Washington this week for talks on security issues. Barry Bearak (NYT)

HEADLINE: Booming Atlanta Saps Water as Drought Wilts Georgia

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 11

 BODY:
Just after dawn they emerge onto their pillowy meadows of fescue and bluegrass, some with hoses and some with mighty irrigation systems, each squeezing out every last legal drop of water before the 10 a.m. cutoff arrives with its water police, tattling neighbors and dark civic guilt.
On every block in the region the desperation of these homeowners is almost palpable, as they will their lawns to soak it up and beat the drought that is parching Georgia and most of the Gulf Coast. But the most thoughtful of them admit that it is hopeless and that Atlanta, with its famous forested canopy and brilliant shrubs, has finally gardened itself into a corner. 
 "Hey, I admit it, I'm addicted to water," said Caroline Gordon, a suburban Alpharetta resident who was pushing a shopping cart laden with peonies and impatiens at a branch of Pike's, a large local nursery chain. "Chances are, every one of these plants is going to die once they cut the water off. But I just don't want to live in a big brown field. That's not what I moved here for."
There have been droughts before in Georgia, mostly affecting the peanut and cotton farmers in the southern part of the state. Those farmers are struggling dreadfully again this summer. But something different is happening this year: a combination of uncontrollable forces that has state officials darkly warning about major changes on the horizon in lifestyle and economy.
For one thing, the drought is worse this year than in most past summers; some parts of Georgia have received less rain in the last 25 months than at any time in recorded weather history. Dr. David E. Stooksbury, the state climatologist, says the regional climate is changing in a profound way, moving from many years of stability with predictable rainfall to a far more variable climate that will veer between years of plenty and years of scarcity.
The Gulf Coast of Florida is experiencing the driest spring in a century, and the federal government's National Drought Monitor lists the crescent from Tampa to New Orleans as experiencing extreme drought. There has been a similar lack of rain in West Texas and northwest Missouri, and drought conditions exist in many other parts of the West and Midwest as well.
But the situation in Atlanta is an example of what can happen when growth and a shortage of rainfall collide. At the same time the natural spigot has been closed here, the Atlanta region has continued to grow without respite, adding nearly 100,000 people a year who fully intend to take showers, drink iced tea and swim. Most of the growth is in suburban areas, where the lawns are bigger, greener and thirstier, when they are not interrupted by backyard pools. And native and newcomer alike expect their lives to be air-conditioned, which in the summer requires huge releases from reservoirs to generate hydroelectric power.
The unstoppable flow of new customers would have taxed municipal water systems even without the drought, but with it the situation has become dire. The streams that fill the region's man-made reservoirs are flowing at less than half their usual rate, and the lakes would have dipped to dangerous levels if the Army Corps of Engineers had not agreed to cut back on power generation. But with the advent of summer, the electricity will have to be produced, the demand for water will increase and the lakes are expected to reach record lows. That makes water managers very nervous.
"Very soon, we're going to have to start drawing down those lakes," said Nowlton Johnson, the water resources chief at the state Environmental Protection Division. "But there's a limit to how much we can deplete our entire water storage. Something has to give."
That something is outdoor use. Water consumption nearly doubles here during the summer, and most of that increase feeds the sod, trees and gardens that have become the region's pride and bane. Last week, the state banned all outdoor watering for the 15-county Atlanta region from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. On Monday the state tightened the restrictions to limit outdoor watering to every other day. Violators face fines and the ultimate threat of a water shut-off; neighbors are being encouraged to report water criminals. But most officials expect a round-the-clock ban if these brilliant cloudless days continue, and then the great botanical brownout will begin.
"Please don't let it happen," said Walt Chastain, production director at the Gibbs Landscape Company, one of the region's many high-end lawn designers. "Most of our clients have invested well over $50,000 in their landscaping. You know what happens if they ban all watering? They're toast, man. Toast."
The loss of a lushly terraced oasis may seem a small price to pay in the face of a regional emergency, particularly considering what farmers farther south are experiencing. Tommy Irvin, who has been state agriculture commissioner since 1969, said this year's drought appears to be the worst in his tenure.
"Farmers had to start irrigating earlier this year than I've ever seen them do," said Mr. Irvin, whose office has been besieged with pleas for assistance. "The water tables are going down, and the ponds aren't filling. We had farmers planting peanuts in dry dust just to meet the federal government's June 1 deadline. And you know they're just not going to germinate."
But the potential water cutoff is no less threatening to those who work in metropolitan Atlanta's billion-dollar green industry. The Metropolitan Atlanta Landscape and Turf Association counts 530 landscape, maintenance and nursery companies in its membership, and Jean Ray, the group's executive director, estimated that the jobs of more than 3,000 people -- many of them Hispanic immigrants -- would be at risk if outdoor watering was cut off.
"The farmers tell me their cattle are eating brown grass, so why can't we play golf on brown grass?" Ms. Ray said. "And that sounds reasonable, until you think about the economic impact on our industry. It would be huge, a lot of layoffs."
The current restrictions are the most serious since the drought of 1986, when 26 cities and counties imposed total watering bans, lawns went brown, trees toppled and landscapers went hungry. But the region has grown by more than a million people in those 14 years, and this year's drought appears to be worse than that in 1986.The state has never imposed a total watering ban but is seriously considering doing so in the northern region if it does not rain soon.
At the rate the region is growing, demand for water will increase by 50 percent by 2020, according to the Atlanta Regional Commission, a planning body, which predicts that the demand will never be met without a 10 percent cutback in water use by customers. State officials and horticulturalists are warning homeowners that they will have to begin mastering the principles of xeriscaping -- a kind of low-water landscaping -- if they want to preserve enough water for outdoor growth.
"People don't realize their lawns can look just as nice at one-third the size," said Walter Reeves, a University of Georgia horticulturalist whose television and radio gardening programs are immensely popular here. "They can have islands of flowers instead of a whole row, and there are many species of plants that require less water than the ones people use now."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Price Data From May Fuels Rise In Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices rose sharply yesterday after a government report on consumer prices for May showed no acceleration in inflation.
The report bolstered investor sentiment that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates again when its policy makers meet on June 27 and 28. 
 The price of the 30-year bond gained 17/32 , to 104 26/32 while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.91 percent from 5.94 percent on Tuesday. The 10-year note rose 16/32 , to 103 12/32 ; its yield dropped to 6.03 percent from 6.11 percent.
Prices of government securities turned higher after the Labor Department said the Consumer Price Index rose a less-than-expected 0.1 percent in May, suggesting that the six interest rate increases over the last year are having the desired effect in slowing rapid growth.
Even with the good news, the market rally fluctuated, leaving some market participants believing that they have already seen the best of the data showing benign inflation. Elsewhere, traders said an overnight purchase of longer-maturity Treasuries on the open market by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York lifted prices at the longer end of the yield curve.
"The debate over whether the recent softness in economic data presages a definitive slowdown in the pace of business activity or is merely a pause in the economy's momentum continues to command center stage among market participants," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management. "Nevertheless, the economy has built up a lot of steam and is not likely to come to a sudden, screeching halt."
"In the face of still-buoyant economic growth and tight labor markets," he added, the Federal Open Market Committee "will continue to regard inflation as being the major risk to economic well-being, and thus further Fed tightenings seem probable as the year progresses, although the F.O.M.C. is expected to remain on hold and defer any action at its meeting on June 28."
At first glance, inflation as measured by the C.P.I. appeared benign in May, but looks can be deceiving, Mr. Fine said. A timing quirk in the method for calculating the index produced a sharp drop in gasoline prices and did not include much of the increase in airline fares. He thinks the June C.P.I. could paint a drastically different picture.
After a weaker-than-expected retail sales report earlier this week, Richard DeKaser, chief economist for the National City Corporation in Cleveland, said the financial markets should be careful not to overinterpret that news as evidence of newly emerged weakness. That would be as inaccurate as exaggerating the strength apparent earlier this year.
"The outlook for Fed policy is unchanged," he said, "with no move expected in two weeks."
