HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Of conservatism and distinctiveness in the religious marketplace.

BYLINE: By Virginia Postrel; This column appears here every Thursday. Virginia Postrel is the editor at large of Reason magazine and the author of "The Future and Its Enemies: The Growing Conflict Over Creativity, Enterprise and Progress." Four economic analysts -- Ms. Postrel, Jeff Madrick, Alan B. Krueger and Hal R. Varian -- rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
THE Southern Baptist Convention voted yesterday to amend its official statement of faith to declare that the Bible bars women from serving as pastors. Although each Baptist congregation is autonomous and the convention cannot stop a local church from ordaining or hiring a woman as pastor, the pronouncement is generally considered an important symbol of the denomination's increasing conservatism.
Critics also see the move as bad marketing. In a Gallup survey in May, 71 percent of Americans who expressed religious preferences said they favored "having women as pastors, ministers, priests or rabbis in your own faith or denomination." As a result, the Gallup organization said that in approving the new statement, the Southern Baptists would be "out of step with the significant majority" of religious Americans. 
 To Laurence Iannaccone, however, the vote is part of a rational strategy and is not necessarily a sign of greater conservatism. Professor Iannaccone, of Santa Clara University in California, has pioneered the application of economic theory to religion. His research examines how individuals make rational choices among religious alternatives and how religions compete in what is, thanks to the First Amendment, the nation's freest marketplace.
Among the questions he has explored are why strict churches -- those that in some way limit members' activities outside the church -- are strong, and how conservative churches adapt when social norms become more liberal. Both questions are relevant to the issues faced by the Southern Baptists, a moderately strict denomination that is the nation's largest Protestant group.
Strictness can manifest itself in dietary restrictions, distinctive clothing, geographical separation or prohibitions on activities like dancing or drinking. It can also entail such requirements as sending one's children to the church school, observing unique holidays or attending Wednesday night services in addition to Sunday services.
Joining a strict group may sound irrational when there are less costly alternatives. "Why become a Mormon or a Seventh-day Adventist" -- let alone join a so-called cult -- "when the Methodists and Presbyterians wait with open arms?" Professor Iannaccone wrote in "Why Strict Churches Are Strong," a 1994 article in the American Journal of Sociology.
His answer is that high costs screen out "free riders," deadbeat members who would otherwise enjoy a church's benefits without contributing energy, time and money. If everyone in the group has to pay a visible price, free riders will not bother to join and a committed core will not end up doing all the work. The group may attract fewer members at first, but it will be stronger over time. Distinctiveness also gives people a reason for affiliation and a sense of camaraderie. Why join a religious group if it is identical to the rest of society?
But a church cannot survive if the cost of membership is too great, especially if it wants to draw members from social groups that have other opportunities. By raising the costs of the old rules, social change poses a significant challenge to conservative religious groups. It is harder for members to find a happy compromise between the church's ideals and social norms, because the two are now far apart. Views or practices that were once close to the mainstream become deviant -- and costly.
"Contrary to most folks' assumptions, a successful conservative church must constantly adapt to social change," Professor Iannaccone said. Churches that do not evolve lose members, especially among the young, and they attract fewer converts. "The trick," he emphasizes, "is not to adapt so quickly or completely that all sense of distinctiveness is lost." A successful church will maintain what he calls an "optimal gap" between its norms and society's. Nowhere is this clearer than in the changing role of women.
In a 1990 article, Professor Iannaccone and his wife, Carrie A. Miles, a social psychologist, examined the Mormon Church's reaction to the women's movement. They combined a careful analysis of church literature from the 1950's to the mid-1980's with statistics on temple rituals performed by younger and newer members and those performed by older ones. The ritual statistics measure the degree of religious commitment for the two demographic groups.
Their analysis disclosed the church's balancing act: tough rhetoric in the short term and gradual accommodation over the long run. This strategy looks like the optimal way to keep older members without alienating younger Mormons or new converts.
Throughout the period, the church upheld the ideal of a family headed by a husband with a full-time homemaker wife and many children. Indeed, during the 1960's and 70's, church literature was much more likely to pound home the point than in the 1950's, when general social norms were not much different from Mormon views. But over time, the church began to allow exceptions to the idea that wives should not work: for widows or women whose husbands were disabled, for women who prayed about their careers and had God's and their husbands' permission to work and, eventually, for women whose children were grown.
By the 1980's, family was still primary, but the ideal of women's work had changed. "They were acknowledging that women should have careers before they have children and after their children are grown, and that they should do things that will keep their skills alive while they're home with their children," Dr. Miles said. "And Mormon women are working at the same rate as anybody else."
For Southern Baptists, the story is much the same. Far from being kept at home, Baptist women run many of the denomination's operations, and they have career aspirations similar to non-Baptists. Drawing the line at pastorships, Professor Iannaccone argues, is a low-cost way to preserve the church's distinctiveness while quietly accommodating broader social changes.
"The average woman doesn't want to be a priest or a pastor," he said. "The average woman wants a career, and the church has allowed it. Twenty or 30 years ago, people seriously talked about men being the authorities in the household. Now they talk about 'servant leadership,' and when you get underneath all that language, it's almost devoid of content. They don't say that men should always make the big decisions in the household."
In a dynamic marketplace, even the most conservative faiths have to adapt to what people want. But that does not mean giving up their distinctiveness.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Nasdaq TurnsLower Again, But Blue Chips Edge Ahead

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday as the Nasdaq market fell 1.39 percent, the seventh consecutive session in which the technology-dominated gauge has reversed direction from the one before, while blue chips gained.
The Dow Jones industrial average posted its second consecutive moderate gain after three declines as some investors appeared to seek safety among household names, embracing a range of companies from Microsoft to Alcoa. 
 A Labor Department report showing minimal consumer inflation last month and a Federal Reserve survey of regional economies that found signs of slackening economic growth did little yesterday to change the prevailing belief that the Federal Reserve would probably forgo raising interest rates again when it meets in two weeks but might have to do so later.
"The rate increases that they began a year ago have begun to bite," said Mary Jane Matts, director of research for National City Private Investment Advisors in Cleveland. "But we don't think they're done" raising rates, she added, because inflation pressures are likely to persist.
To Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment officer for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the market's chief worry has shifted to a focus on a possible side effect of the Fed's rate medicine: stunted growth of corporate profits.
"There is a sea change," Mr. Galvin said.
The Nasdaq composite shed 53.65 points yesterday, to 3,797.41, leaving it 1 percent ahead of its level on June 6, when the protracted up-down pattern began. The loss so far this year is 6.68 percent.
As for the Dow industrials, where 20 issues gained and 9 fell, the average climbed 66.11 points, or 0.62 percent, to 10,687.95. That narrowed its loss for the year to 7.04 percent.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index scarcely budged, edging up 1.1 points, to 1,470.54. Although winners outnumbered losers by 263 to 217, the index was weighed down by losses in Intel, off 5 1/16, to 126 7/16; Lucent, down 2 1/8, to 56 5/8; WorldCom dropping 2 7/8, to 401 3/16; Qualcomm, falling 10 7/8, to 70 1/2; and Oracle down 21 1/16, to 79. Cisco Systems managed a gain of 3/16, to 65 3/16.
"I thought we'd be doing better today," Donald G. Berdine, chief investment officer for PNC Advisors in Pittsburgh, said yesterday, pointing to subdued inflation data and an economic slowing that he said he did not think would wind up in a so-called hard-landing. He projects that profits of the S.& P. 500 companies will rise 8.3 percent next year.
Seagram, which confirmed it was in negotiations to be acquired and jumped 7 1/8, to 60 1/8, was one of the day's standout gainers. Schering-Plough, which a Morgan Stanley Dean Witter analyst raised to a "strong buy," climbed 3 1/8, to 48 1/2, to pace a generally strong drug sector.
Brokerage firm stocks also surged, with Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers each gaining more than 4 points, and Merrill Lynch more than 3.
Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange was 929.8 million shares, slightly less than on Tuesday, as 1,687 stocks rose and 1,253 fell.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Inflation Rate Flat in May, But Up Over Last 12 Months
The national inflation rate, which has been inching up this year, leveled off in May, the Labor Department reported.
The Consumer Price Index, the best known measure of American inflation, rose 0.1 percent in May. Measured over 12 months, however, the inflation rate through May was half a percentage point higher than it was last fall. Excluding energy and food prices, the index was up 0.2 percent in May. Page C14. 

Even in Deal, Seagram Trails S.& P.
Since Edgar Bronfman Jr. took control of Seagram nearly six years ago and sought to recast the liquor and beverage giant as a liquor, media and entertainment empire, he has added some value, but Seagram's performance has lagged the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Even if Seagram receives $77 a share in a deal with Vivendi of France, its performance would still trail the S.& P. 500. Market Place. C14.
 
Bear Stearns Net Profit Falls 40%
Bear Stearns said that its second-quarter profit fell 40 percent because of a slump in the bond market and a one-time $96 million charge stemming from a federal court judgment. Excluding the charge, profits rose 8 percent and beat Wall Street expectations. Shares of Bear Stearns rose $1.375, to $42.25. C27.
 
Nasdaq Declines in Mixed Trading
Stock prices were mixed as the Nasdaq composite index fell 53.65 points, or 1.4 percent, to 3,797.41. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 66.11 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,687.95, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.1 points, to 1,470.54. C12.
 
New York Life in Racketeering Suit
Top executives of the New York Life Insurance Company were accused in a racketeering lawsuit of enriching themselves by charging tens of millions of dollars in excess fees to the retirement plans that the insurer maintains for its workers and agents. Company officials denied the accusations and said they would prevail in court. C8.
 
Justice Files Brief to Appeals Court
The Justice Department filed a brief with a federal appeals court intended to persuade the judges not to begin work on the Microsoft case until the Supreme Court decides whether to take the case or not. C2.
 
Frankel Fights Extradition to U.S.
Martin R. Frankel, the businessman accused of looting more than $200 million from insurance companies he acquired, made a concerted effort at a Hamburg courtroom, where he faces German charges of using false passports and evading customs duties on about $5 million worth of diamonds, to avoid extradition to the United States. C4.
 
Bass Is Exiting Brewing Business
Bass of Britain agreed to sell its 223-year-old brewing business to Interbrew of Belgium for $2.1 billion. C4.
 
House Passes E-Commerce Bill
The House overwhelmingly passed an electronic signature and record-keeping bill that would give new technologies like fingerprint scans the legal weight of ink-and-paper signatures, making it easier for both companies and consumers to do business online. C10.
 
Pondering a Southern Baptist Vote
A professor who pioneered the application of economic theory to religion thinks the Southern Baptist Convention's vote to bar women from serving as pastors is part of a rational strategy to maintain distinctiveness and is not necessarily a sign of greater conservatism. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING

 BODY:

THE DEMOCRATS
 
GORE PROSPERS IN NEW YORK -- Vice President Al Gore is giving a double meaning to his current "prosperity tour," collecting a cool million in New York last night. After opening his "progress and prosperity tour" in New York on Tuesday, Mr. Gore headed for Scranton, Pa., then swooped back into Manhattan last night for two dinners on the Upper East Side for the Democratic National Committee before resuming his tour today in Cincinnati. Unlike Pennsylvania and Ohio, however, New York is perceived as squarely in Mr. Gore's corner and is a reliable source of campaign cash. The vice president stopped first at the Park Avenue home of Alan J. Patricof, a financier, where 40 people paid $12,500 each for a total take of $500,000. At the next stop, the 90th Street home of Mitchell Blutt, a doctor and venture capitalist, 50 people paid $10,000 each, also yielding $500,000. At Mr. Patricof's apartment, Mr. Gore praised his listeners, many of whom had supported President Clinton's presidential campaign in 1992 and had been contributing to the Democratic Party ever since. The vice president thanked them for "being a constant source of good common-sense advice on how to pursue progressive values in a way that would ensure economic strength, build the economy and lift up the people who most need the benefits of good policy." Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT) 

NEW ROLE FOR GORE AIDE -- One of Vice President Al Gore's top consultants, Tad Devine, is shifting into a more central role in Nashville, where he will be spending several days a week. Mr. Devine, 45, a partner with Bob Shrum, Mr. Gore's media adviser, has periodically been deployed to Nashville from Washington as a trouble-shooter at crucial moments, such as early this year in the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary, and last fall when Mr. Gore was angling for the endorsement of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Mr. Devine has a reputation for being a fierce campaigner, but he is also perceived as a mediator among some of the factions that have developed within the Gore campaign. Meanwhile, Tony Coelho, the Gore campaign chairman, was admitted Monday night to a hospital in Washington, where doctors found he had an inflamed colon. He was expected to be released soon. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)
 
THE HOUSE
 
SOUTHERN PRIMARY RESULTS -- The lineups for Congressional races across the South were set in primaries on Tuesday. In Virginia's Seventh Congressional District, anchored in the Richmond suburbs, Eric L. Cantor of Henrico, a member of the Virginia House of Delegates, defeated State Senator Stephen H. Martin of Chesterfield for the Republican nomination by only 197 votes, out of 41,539 cast. Mr. Cantor will face Warren Stewart, a Democrat who is school superintendent of Goochland County in a race to fill the seat of Representative Thomas J. Bliley, a Republican who is retiring after 20 years. In other primaries on Tuesday, Henry Brown, a South Carolina state representative, defeated H. B. Limehouse, a former state transportation chairman, for the Republican nomination for the seat now held by Representative Mark Sanford, a Republican who is retiring to keep his campaign pledge to serve only three terms. Mr. Brown will oppose Andy Brack, the Democrat who is a former journalist and spokesman for Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina. In a heavily Republican district where South Carolina Democrats declined to nominate a candidate, Jim DeMint, a freshman representative, assured his House re-election by defeating Frank Raddish in the Republican primary. In Arkansas, State Senator Mike Ross defeated Dewayne Graham, a former television reporter, for the Democratic nomination and will face Representative Jay Dickey, a Republican seeking his fourth term. Francis X. Clines (NYT)
 
THE ISSUES
 
DEBATING FOR CHARITY -- The billionaire financier Theodore J. Forstmann announced yesterday that he would donate a total of $1 million to children's charities if Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas agreed to participate in a 90-minute televised debate on education. Mr. Forstmann, a critic of public education who co-founded the Children's Scholarship Fund, which sends children from poor families to private schools, said he sent invitation letters to each candidate on June 13, but had yet to hear from either one. "If we are to see the day in which every single child in America has equal opportunity in education," Mr. Forstmann said at a news conference at the New York Press Club, "then we must face up to the failure of our current model of education to provide it." Mr. Gore told reporters today that he would accept Mr. Forstmann's proposal, although he seemed a bit insulted that money was attached to it. "Nobody has to give money to get me to debate," he said in response to a question from reporters as he campaigned today in Scranton, Pa. Ray Sullivan, a spokesman for Mr. Bush, said, "The governor looks forward to debating on education this fall since education is his top domestic priority, but as to this specific invitation, we have not had an opportunity to review it yet." Edward Wong (NYT)
 
THE SOUTH
 
GAY PROSECUTOR DEFEATED -- The only openly gay Republican officeholder in the South lost that designation on Tuesday. David Schwacke, the solicitor, or chief prosecutor, in Charleston, S.C., was narrowly defeated in a Republican primary by Ralph Hoisington, a lawyer whose campaign slogan was "For our families." Mr. Hoisington won by only 265 votes out of 29,421 cast, a margin so small that it will automatically trigger a recount. Mr. Schwacke was seeking re-election for the first time since making his homosexuality public three years ago. He did so after local Republican officials asked the state police to investigate accusations that Mr. Schwacke had downloaded pornography on his office computer. He was cleared of any wrongdoing. Mr. Hoisington outspent Mr. Schwacke by nearly 4 to 1 and ran television advertisements vowing to get tough on child molesters. Kevin Sack (NYT)

The California Nurses Association, a 31,000-member union based in Oakland, praised Mr. Nader for what it called his commitment to universal health care, patients' rights and expanded federal health insurance. HEADLINE: Abolish the Estate Tax

BYLINE: By Nydia M. Velazquez; Nydia M. Velazquez, a Democrat, is a member of the House of Representatives from Brooklyn.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As the senior Democrat on the House Small Business Committee, I meet regularly with small-business owners who speak enthusiastically about their struggles and rewards. Many glow with pride as they place a hand on the shoulder of a son or daughter who they hope will one day inherit the family business.
Unfortunately, the reality for family-owned small businesses is that one-third will be forced to sell or partially liquidate themselves to pay estate taxes on the owner's death. (Many small businesses' earnings are taxed as personal income.) To try to avoid that fate, small businesses spend millions of dollars each year on estate planning. The estate tax rate is even higher for those owners who elect to pass their businesses on to a grandchild because of a penalty for generation skipping. 
 Recently, the House of Representatives passed legislation to eliminate the estate tax, a plan that will be used as the basis for solving this problem. The measure does not just benefit the rich, as some have argued. More than half of those who paid death taxes in 1996 had estates valued at less than $1 million, with most valued below $5 million. These are not the Rockefellers and Carnegies; they're the families next door. The legislation establishes a threshold to ensure that small businesses will benefit. For these businesses the issue is one of simple fairness. Small business represents 99 percent of all American employers and provides jobs for more than half of all nonfarm workers. These entrepreneurs generate 80 percent of the jobs, nearly half of them in the high-tech sector. They produce the majority of new products, and obtain more patents and make more discoveries than large companies. They are responsible for most of the basic skills training for our work force.
Small-business owners also have a new face, which is increasingly minority and female. At last count, there were two million minority-owned businesses and more than nine million businesses owned by women. And the numbers are growing.
Yet many first-generation business people know that the odds are against giving their children a chance to carry on the family trade. Some 70 percent of family businesses don't survive into the second generation, and almost 90 percent don't make it to the third. The estate tax is one impediment to future success.
As a child, I saw what members of my family had to do to keep a small business afloat. So I share the anxiety expressed in the letter of a New York man who is a third-generation owner of a manufacturing business. He estimated that in the last five years he had spent more than $300,000 in legal and consultant fees, life insurance and other planning expenses to protect his children from having to sell the business to pay estate taxes when he dies. Despite the careful planning, he worries he may have overlooked something. He is also concerned about his 150 employees, who would lose their jobs and benefits, should his children not be able to pay the estate taxes.
His story is one of many. A survey of 365 businesses in New York State found that one-third anticipate having to sell or partially liquidate their businesses to meet their federal estate taxes. They could better spend their time and money on capital investment, job creation and employee benefits. Small businesses face enough hurdles without bearing the added burden of archaic laws that essentially tax them on their profits and then tax them again when the owner dies.
Parents work hard to leave their family business to the children. Those children should not be forced to sell that business to pay taxes once they inherit it. Protecting family businesses and fueling our new economy is what reforming the estate tax is all about. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Abortion Politics Surface at Gore Event

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: SCRANTON, Pa., June 14

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore brought his "prosperity and progress tour" to northeastern Pennsylvania today, promoting his plan to protect Medicare and saying he would provide additional money for health care providers that serve Medicare patients.
But in the process, Mr. Gore also became ensnared in abortion politics as he was forced at the last minute to move his event from a Roman Catholic hospital to a nondenominational health care center after church officials registered concern about Mr. Gore's support for abortion rights. 
 Pennsylvania is a crucial battleground between Mr. Gore and his Republican rival, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. It is also home to one of the largest concentrations of elderly people in the country, and Mr. Gore addressed his message today to them.
With the pending retirement of the baby boom, the number of Americans on Medicare is expected to double to 80 million from 40 million by 2035. Mr. Gore has proposed removing Medicare from the normal budget process so that the money collected from the payroll tax for it is dedicated to the health care program, and is not raided by Congress.
And he wants to offer a prescription drug benefit under which those on Medicare would receive half of the cost of their drugs, up to $5,000 annually. He said today that for no extra premium, he would provide a catastrophic prescription drug benefit that would cover all drug costs for recipients after they paid $4,000 out of their own pockets. He said that plan would begin in 2002.
Mr. Gore also spoke of his commitment to increasing money for biomedical research. And in his zeal to spread a positive, can-do message, he told his audience here at the Allied Services health care center about a conversation he had earlier today with a woman outside a pharmacy.
Mr. Gore said that the woman, in her late 20's or early 30's, told him that her 32-year-old husband had died last month of Lou Gehrig's disease. "She said, 'I'd like to say something to you. I want you to do everything you can to help our country find a cure for that disease,' " Mr. Gore said.
"Well, there's good news," Mr. Gore went on. "Within weeks, an event will take place that is comparable in importance to the landing of the first person on the moon." He was referring to the completion of the first phase of the human genome project, which is expected to aid in the treatment of various diseases.
He said he would double the amount of money devoted to cancer research, adding, "I'll make it a priority to treat and conquer diseases like Alzheimer's and diabetes, Lou Gehrig's disease, mental illness and H.I.V./AIDS."
Mr. Gore also said that too many health care providers had been hurt by excessive budget cuts under the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 and that he would provide extra money for nursing homes, hospitals, home-health agencies and teaching hospitals.
He said that he would offer details on how to pay for all of these programs once the new budget surplus numbers were released, perhaps within a couple of weeks. The surplus outside of Social Security, already estimated at between $750 billion and $2 trillion, is expected to grow by a trillion more dollars.
Mr. Gore's staff had scheduled today's health care forum at Mercy Hospital, run by nuns, in Scranton.
But at the last minute the local bishop, James C. Timlin, a hospital board member who had been notified by the Scranton chapter of Pennsylvanians for Human Life, said he did not want Mr. Gore, a supporter of abortion rights, using the hospital as a political platform.
As a result, the Gore campaign switched the event to Allied Services.
Still, anti-abortion protesters held a candlelight vigil outside Mr. Gore's hotel on Tuesday night and demonstrated today at his speech.
August Perrotti, 49, a state food inspector who identified himself as a Democrat, was one of those holding signs. Like many voters in this Democratic stronghold in Northeastern Pennsylvania, Mr. Perrotti opposes abortion rights and said he would vote for Mr. Bush because of Mr. Gore's stance. He said he was disappointed that Mr. Gore had abandoned his earlier anti-abortion views and was pleased that "our bishop stood up for us on this issue."
Meanwhile, Republicans today challenged the whole premise of Mr. Gore's "prosperity and progress tour," mocking Mr. Gore by calling it the "I invented prosperity tour."
Gov. Tom Ridge, the Pennsylvania Republican who is under consideration as Mr. Bush's vice-presidential running mate, said in a statement released by the Bush campaign, "As he travels along on his 'I invented prosperity tour,' I ask him to remember that the credit for our healthy economy belongs to the hard-working men and women of Pennsylvania, not Pennsylvania Avenue."
"The vice president can lay no claim on their personal prosperity or professional success," Mr. Ridge added.

HEADLINE: THE KOREAN BREAKTHROUGH: WASHINGTON;
U.S. Says It Will Soon Drop Its Sanctions on North Korea

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Clinton administration officials, trying to build on the progress of the Korean summit meeting, said tonight that they would announce within a week the lifting of a broad set of economic sanctions that have been in place against North Korea since it invaded the South 50 years ago this month.
The end of these sanctions would allow North Korea, which is economically desperate, to export raw materials and goods to the United States and would open air and shipping routes between the two countries. American companies would be allowed to invest in agriculture, mining, roads, ports, travel and tourism in the North, though it is likely that far more Japanese and South Korean companies would try to do so. 
 The Clinton administration's decision to end sanctions -- a carrot that President Clinton dangled in front of the North last fall as part of a strategy formulated by former Secretary of Defense William J. Perry -- has limits. Prohibitions on the sale of high technology and "dual-use goods" -- those that could be used for both civilian and military purposes -- will remain in place as long as North Korea is still classified a terrorist state by the State Department, officials said. The United States is also required by law to oppose financing to terrorist countries from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
But administration officials said today that they hoped the North might, in coming months, make concessions that would get it off the terrorist list.
Today, Mr. Clinton cautiously referred to the agreement on the Korean peninsula as "just the first step," but added, "It's clearly a move in the right direction, and everyone else in the world should be encouraged."
Perhaps as striking as the imminent lifting of the sanctions is the administration's sudden change of tone about the North's mysterious leader, Kim Jong Il. Until recently, Mr. Kim was usually described by American officials as paranoid, a recluse, a kidnapper and a patron of European prostitutes. But this evening, one senior administration official went to some lengths to praise Mr. Kim and compare him to his South Korean counterpart, Kim Dae Jung.
"We knew that Kim Dae Jung was courageous and a visionary," the official said. "Kim Jong Il clearly has some of those qualities, and is displaying some vision himself."
That new approach to the North marks a big risk for the Clinton administration, especially if the accords reached today dissolve in bickering over the details.
There is reason to worry about that: some of the concessions announced today, such as cultural exchanges and visits across the demilitarized zone by Koreans who have not seen family members for half a century, were the centerpieces of a 1991 agreement between the two nations that was never put into action.
But the agreement today, officials noted, bears the imprimatur of both nation's leaders. And Kim Jong Il, they said, made a public about-face, inviting North Koreans to line the streets as he welcomed a South Korean leader that the North has regularly characterized as an evil lackey of the Americans.
If the change in the North's attitude proves real, however, it creates a whole new set of questions for the United States. Would the United States be willing, over time, to withdraw some of the 37,000 American troops based in South Korea? Is it ready to resume diplomatic relations with the North, as it did five years ago with Vietnam?
And how could the United States justify spending $60 billion on a missile defense system predicated partly on the threat of a nuclear attack from North Korea, if it believed the North was changing course?
While the administration has gone to extraordinary lengths in the past two years to coax the North out of its shell, it is unready and unable to answer those questions.
"The sticking point is the North's nuclear weapons and their missiles," said Donald Gregg, the former Central Intelligence Agency station chief and then American ambassador to Seoul. "As soon as we raise those, they are going to raise the question of why we still have troops on the Korean peninsula. And no one is ready to deal with that."
He added, "Kim Dae Jung very wisely went to Pyongyang with an agenda that deals with those issues that are within the control of South Korea and North Korea." Diplomats familiar with Kim Dae Jung's talking points say he went determined to raise the security issues, but only in an oblique way. South Korean officials say that Kim Dae Jung planned to tell Kim Jong Il that those issues needed to be resolved, but not to press specific ideas.
"That may be the subject of the return visit to Seoul," one senior South Korean official said.
North Korea watchers here -- from intelligence officials to State Department diplomats -- say that even if a new era of cooperation is dawning, there is little reason to believe that the agreement reached today heralds any imminent unification of the Korean peninsula.
Neither side really wants that any time soon. The North's leaders have long been focused on survival -- keeping their regime together at any cost. Kim Jong Il appears to have concluded that his best chances of survival lie in milking South Korea and Japan for the aid and trade he needs to achieve that goal.
And South Korea, for all its talk about the ultimate goal of reunifying the nation, knows that true reunification would cost a fortune. The billions spent propping up the country could endanger the South's recovery from the Asian economic crisis that threatened to ruin it two years ago. And it would dramatically change the country's social dynamics.
"Unification is a national goal," one senior South Korean diplomat said earlier this year, "and it should stay that way for a good while."

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton Steps Up Jabs Against Lazio

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Signaling a new, aggressive approach to her Senate campaign, Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday accused her opponent, Representative Rick A. Lazio, of voting in Congress "against the interests of women, children and families."
She invoked his positions on gun control, abortion and education financing to assert that Mr. Lazio is not the moderate figure he claims to be -- a claim that even Mrs. Clinton's aides acknowledge is gaining some currency with voters. 
 The first lady assailed Mr. Lazio repeatedly during a 30-minute address to female supporters in Manhattan. She variously portrayed Mr. Lazio as a captive to the gun lobby, a Republican partisan and a supporter of abortion rights only when it came to "rich women" who did not need government assistance to pay for the procedure.
"On issue after issue, my opponent has been a follower, not a leader," Mrs. Clinton declared at a fund-raising breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria. "He voted to shut down the government. He voted for a trillion-dollar budget that would have slashed so many services that we need here in New York. He would squander the surplus and, I believe, endanger the economy. And yet he says he agrees with me on issues."
"Time and time again, my opponent has voted against the interests of New York's women, children and families," she said.
Mrs. Clinton's speech yesterday morning underscored a shift in strategy over the last several days by a candidate who has, with the loss of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as an opponent, seemed unsure how to proceed in an unexpectedly tight race with his replacement, a little-known Republican representative from Suffolk County. In taking on Mr. Lazio so directly -- the speech sounded like the kind of attack candidates save for the final weeks of a campaign -- Mrs. Clinton was trying to shape New Yorkers' perception of her new opponent before he can.
A New York Times/CBS News Poll released on Monday found the candidates in a dead heat, even though most New Yorkers polled said they did not know enough about Mr. Lazio to venture an opinion on his fitness for office.
"Maybe his folks think that if he remains a blank slate, he wins; but no one remains a blank slate," one of Mrs. Clinton's advisers said, adding that it was "time to run the fingernails across the blank slate."
This aggressive stance was notable for a first lady who has been, with a few exceptions, decorous in most of her campaign appearances, to the continuing frustration of Democrats who worry that her campaign is overly placid.
But for Mrs. Clinton, who is disliked by many voters, the strategy risks alienating potential supporters. She already was viewed unfavorably by 31 percent of respondents in the Times/CBS poll, taken from June 4 to June 10, an uncomfortably high number that may explain why Mr. Lazio is doing so well.
And by noon yesterday, Mr. Lazio moved to encourage this sentiment about Mrs. Clinton, releasing a statement asserting that the first lady was engaging in "mudslinging" and distorting what he described as his "mainstream record."
"I was deeply disappointed today to see Mrs. Clinton launch a campaign that seems to be made up of little more than attacks designed to fool New Yorkers about my record," Mr. Lazio said. "While I understand the first lady's frustration with her campaign's inability to connect with New Yorkers, I believe she would better serve herself by addressing the issues rather than throwing mud.
"I am sad to say that all too often it appears that the first casualty in a Clinton campaign is the truth," he declared.
Mrs. Clinton is seeking to do what is known in politics as "defining" an opponent, though in practice, several politicians noted yesterday, the word "destroying" might be more apt. In this case, Mrs. Clinton's advisers have cited polls that suggest that voters, if they have a view of Mr. Lazio at all, consider him moderate rather than conservative; in the Times/CBS poll, 34 percent of respondents described him as moderate, and 28 percent called him conservative. (The poll of 1,384 voters across New York was taken from June 4 to June 10 and had a sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.)
Mr. Lazio is viewed in Congress as having an ideologically nuanced record; he is conservative on some issues and moderate on others. Mrs. Clinton pointed to votes Mr. Lazio had cast to try to place him on the conservative side of the spectrum.
For example, she noted that he had joined Republicans in voting against legislation to provide funding to allow public schools to hire 100,000 more teachers. Instead, Mr. Lazio supported Republican legislation that would have given school districts more flexibility in deciding how to spend federal money for education.
She also noted that Mr. Lazio had opposed legislation to give patients the right to sue health maintenance organizations, and a Democratic bill to provide Medicare coverage for prescription drugs. And she assailed him again for opposing proposals to require the registration of new handguns and the licensing of gun owners.
"Apparently, he is more willing to go along with the Republican leadership and the N.R.A. than the children and families of New York," she said, referring to the National Rifle Association.
Most of all, with an eye to her female audience, Mrs. Clinton stressed Mr. Lazio's views on abortion. She noted that the next Senate is likely to vote on nominees to the Supreme Court, and asserted that Mr. Lazio could not be counted on to oppose justices who would support curbing abortions.
Mr. Lazio says he supports keeping abortion legal but, unlike Mrs. Clinton, opposes public financing of abortion and supports a ban on the procedure that abortion foes refer to as "partial birth abortion."
"I know that my opponent calls himself pro-choice, but if you look at his record, he's apparently pro-choice for rich women," Mrs. Clinton said.

HEADLINE: Report Shows Inflation Level in May but Rising Long-Term

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The national inflation rate, which has been inching up this year, leveled off in May, the Labor Department reported yesterday. But rising gasoline prices promised a fresh increase in inflation for June.
The Consumer Price Index, the best-known measure of American inflation, rose an unremarkable 0.1 percent in May. What is striking about this latest report, however, is not what happened in May, but the long-term trend that is finally emerging. Measured over 12 months, the inflation rate through May was half a percentage point higher than it was last fall. 
 "There is no longer any doubt that inflation has accelerated," said Joel Popkin, president of Joel Popkin & Company, an economic consulting firm. Like many other economists, he attributed the acceleration mainly to months of strong consumer demand that have permitted many companies to gradually raise prices.
Only recently has consumer demand appeared to ease a bit, the principal evidence being a decline in retail sales in April and May. The Federal Reserve, in a separate report yesterday, took note of the incipient easing. Its periodic survey of economic conditions, called the beige book, found that "solid economic performance continued in April and May," but with "signs of some slowing from the rapid pace earlier in the year." The Fed also found "indications of worsening price inflation" in some parts of the country.
Rising prices are often attributed to increasing labor costs. Labor shortages give workers the leverage to obtain higher wages, this argument goes, and then companies raise prices to cover the higher costs of labor. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, has raised this concern recently. But other economists argue that labor costs, while rising, have played no role so far in the gradually accelerating inflation rate. Most companies, they argue, would first cut back profits to pay for labor, and profits have not yet fallen.
"Inflation today is not the conventional story," said Dean Baker, an economist at the Center for Economic and Policy Research. "It is clearly not wage growth that is pushing up prices."
With May included, the overall Consumer Price Index rose 3.1 percent over 12 months, and 2.4 percent when energy and food were left out. In each case, the rate was half a percentage point higher than the annual rate late last year. Because energy and food prices fluctuate rapidly, many economists prefer the so-called core rate, which eliminates these items.
Food prices jumped by 0.5 percent in May, the biggest increase since October 1998. But fluctuating gasoline prices -- they were found to have fallen in May -- more than offset the food price increase. As a result, the overall Consumer Price Index rose only 0.1 percent, while the core rate was up 0.2 percent.
Timing played a big role in this idiosyncratic result. With OPEC's production cutbacks apparently ending, gasoline prices had fallen in April and then, on May 1, they began to rise again. But when the Bureau of Labor Statistics surveyed prices in early May, gasoline had not yet returned to its early April level.
It has since gone much higher, reaching $1.66 a gallon on average this week, according to the Energy Department. Other things being equal, gasoline prices at $1.66 could add three-tenths of a percentage point to the overall Consumer Price Index in June, said Patrick Jackman, a senior economist at the bureau.
Housing and medical care have made steady contributions to the gradually accelerating core inflation rate, and they did so again in May. Housing was up 0.2 percent, mostly because of higher rent and an equivalent increase in the monthly cost of owning a home. Many hotels raised their daily rates, and that helped to push up housing costs.
Those costs have now risen 2.9 percent over the 12 months that ended in May, while medical costs have gone up 4 percent in the corresponding period, including a 0.3 percent increase in May. Ever more costly prescription drugs and rising hospital rates have played big roles in the rising medical costs.
Airline fares were up 0.8 percent in June, starting in mid-month when Continental Airlines raised fares and the other airlines followed. The airlines cite higher fuel costs as a reason for the increases, but other than airline fares, very little of the increased cost of petroleum has been passed through to other products and services -- to trucking rates, for example, and to plastics made from petroleum-based petrochemicals.
"It is tough to see the secondary effect yet," Mr. Jackman said.
Among other items, apparel prices fell 0.2 percent in May. They often decline, driven down by huge quantities of imported clothing. Tobacco prices, which often fluctuate, fell in May. They rise and fall as tobacco companies discount cigarette prices one month and remove the discounts the next. Auto prices, which have remained fairly steady, rose in May, driven up mainly by higher prices for used vehicles.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Evidence of a Slowdown
 (By Reuters), WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The booming United States economy showed signs of cooling during April and May but there also were indications in several regions of increased price inflation, the Federal Reserve said today.
The central bank's latest summary of coast-to-coast conditions, known as the beige book, reported "solid economic growth" but with glimmers of slowing in areas like borrowing and home building.
"All but Minneapolis said scattered signs of cooling are in evidence or the pace of growth is slowing," the Fed said.
"Indications of worsening price inflation, while not widespread, are reported by several districts," it added.
The beige book's findings will be used by members of the Fed's policymaking Federal Open Market Committee when they meet June 27 and 28 to consider interest rate strategy.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
As a salelooms, questions on leadership and strategy at the Seagram Company.

BYLINE: By Geraldine Fabrikant 

 BODY:
DURING one of the greatest bull markets in history, how has Edgar Bronfman Jr. done for the shareholders of the Seagram Company since he took control nearly six years ago and sought to recast his liquor and beverage giant as a liquor, media and entertainment empire?
With the Bronfman family negotiating to sell Seagram in an all-stock deal to Vivendi S.A., the French conglomerate that wants to expand its holdings in the entertainment business, the answer is that Mr. Bronfman has added some value, but Seagram's performance has lagged the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. 
 Indeed, even if Seagram receives $77 a share, the highest rumored price yesterday, its stock would have appreciated 166.6 percent since May 1994, compared with more than 200 percent for the S.& P. 500. Its shares rose $7.125 yesterday, to $60.125.
The appreciation in the stock since 1994 could grow depending on what price is paid, of course, but the deal still faces hurdles, including the fact that Vivendi does not yet trade in the United States.
And if Mr. Bronfman had not undertaken a transformation of Seagram and had simply retained its holdings, it is not entirely clear that the per-share value of the company would have been much different from what it is today, according to analyses by a media analyst and an industry executive, both of whom insisted on anonymity.
Nevertheless, the stock has improved. So why a sale? The company has said that it feels it cannot compete in a world of far larger media companies. Still, Mr. Bronfman's performance has been criticized over the years, and while the Bronfman family certainly supports him publicly, at least one family member, his uncle, Charles Bronfman, has sold about 10 percent of his holdings to make investments elsewhere.
A sale will allow Edgar Bronfman Jr., who is expected to become vice chairman of the combined company, to follow the trend of media mergers. It will also produce profits for the Bronfman family, which has run Seagram for three generations and will be the largest single shareholder of the merged company, receiving 5 of the expected 18 board seats. Any gains, however, will be influenced by Vivendi's stock. Its price has risen sharply over the last year, but its future performance is uncertain.
One person close to the negotiations said yesterday that Mr. Bronfman had been having some misgivings about reporting to Jean-Marie Messier, the chairman of Vivendi. Nevertheless, the deal still has a decent chance of closing, he said. Still, the muted response of Seagram's stock raised questions about shareholders' confidence in a merger.
Precise terms have not been announced. Seagram's board is expected to meet informally on Saturday in New York and then formally on Wednesday at its regularly scheduled meeting, though the deal may not be announced for two weeks or more, one person close to the discussions said. The deal could be worth as much as $33.5 billion, a second person close to the transaction said. And Seagram shareholders will be protected with a minimum guarantee said to be at least 90 percent of the agreed-on per-share price if either Vivendi's stock drops or exchange rates move unfavorably.
Vivendi is a diversified conglomerate that has been scrambling under Mr. Messier to expand from mundane industries like water utilities to pay television and advertising.
Seagram was an attractive target because of Mr. Bronfman's razzle-dazzle acquisition tear. He started with a $2 billion investment in Time Warner and went on to buy 80 percent of MCA, the parent company of the Universal film and television studios; several record companies, including Polygram; and the 50 percent of USA Network and the Sci-Fi Channel it did not already own.
And Seagram did more than buy assets. When Mr. Bronfman could not find suitable managers for his television and cable operations, he sold 50 percent of the cable channels to USA Networks Inc., along with a half-interest in its own television production business, betting that USA's chairman, Barry Diller, could run them better.
Despite the glamour connected with buying film, music and theme park businesses, Seagram's performance has been erratic. When Mr. Bronfman took over, Seagram consisted of a liquor company and a 25 percent stake in DuPont.
Had the company simply held on to its DuPont holdings, rather than selling nearly all of them in 1995, they would be worth roughly $24 billion, according to both an analyst and an industry expert.
The 328 million shares of DuPont the company then owned are now worth $14.7 billion. And the liquor business, these experts said, would be worth about $7 billion.
He pointed out that Seagram would have added roughly $1.5 billion in cash from DuPont dividends and the estimated $3 billion to $4 billion in capital it used to invest in the entertainment business. That would have brought the value of Seagram to about $27 billion, compared with its current value of $26 billion. Although the company has issued new stock since Mr. Bronfman took over, there were originally 350 million shares outstanding. Per share, the company would have been worth about $77 a share. Vivendi would spend an additional $6.6 billion because Seagram now has 436 million shares outstanding.
A Seagram spokesman argued that such comparisons were not valid because the company's stake in DuPont was illiquid, thus making it difficult for the company to realize its value, regardless of the stock price. And he noted that Seagram had increased its "enterprise value" -- in this case the combined value of its stock market capitalization, based on the offer price, and debt -- from $15 billion in 1995 to $41 billion.
In the view of Bruce Greenwald, a professor of finance and economics at Columbia University: "If something is illiquid, the right strategy is to sell it off slowly over time because the market is relatively thin compared to the size of the holdings. Had Seagram sold DuPont over four years, it would have realized substantially more as the price rose over $80 a share."
As to the enterprise value argument, he noted that "adding the debt ignores that much of the value is simply money Seagram borrowed and put into the business."
"If this argument were valid, businessmen could borrow huge amounts of money, put it into their business, raising enterprise value, regardless of performance."
The larger question will be how savvy was Mr. Bronfman's decision to enter the film and music business. Though Universal Pictures has recently benefited from hits like "Erin Brockovich," its film business has suffered, reporting a $206 million operating loss in the 1999 fiscal year.
Seagram has been aggressively building its music business, paying $10.4 billion for Polygram last year. And though Mr. Bronfman is a big fan of the music industry, the sale of music assets may be well timed.
Vivendi is paying a premium to buy heavily into the music industry at a time when its future is uncertain because of the online transmission of songs through services like Napster, which raises copyright questions.
"Until some of the potential becomes clearer, it remains vulnerable," said Michael Nathanson, a music industry analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Vivendi Chief Bets on His Ability to Create Media Empire

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, June 14

 BODY:
With his boyish good looks and knack for relentless deal-making, Jean-Marie Messier has dazzled investors by transforming France's biggest water utility into a media conglomerate.
As chairman of Vivendi S.A., Mr. Messier now controls Europe's biggest pay-television company, France's second-largest mobile telephone operator and a major publishing house. 
 But when Mr. Messier confirmed today that he was in talks to acquire the Seagram Company, including the Universal movie studio, investors were far from enthusiastic.
Shares of Vivendi plunged 10 percent, to 103.5 euros, or $99, in Paris today while shares of Canal Plus S.A., the pay-television company that Vivendi controls, dropped nearly 3 percent by midafternoon. That reaction reflected fears that Mr. Messier is about to take on a huge new burden and get little in return except for the glamour of becoming a Hollywood player.
"Clearly, the deal risks being very expensive for Vivendi, and that is the risk that the market is reacting to," said Andrew Shepherd-Barron, an analyst in London at the Dutch bank ABN Amro. "To pay for it, they are going to have to do something very clever."
But there are other problems as well. For all of Mr. Messier's nimbleness and vision about new media, Vivendi is one of Europe's most complicated and messy companies.
In some ways, Vivendi is the kind of European company that infuriates American investors. Though Mr. Messier is a passionate advocate of shareholder value, Vivendi is a maze of old- and new-economy businesses, many controlled through partial holdings and partnerships.
More than half of Vivendi's roughly $40 billion in revenue still comes from water distribution, waste management and construction. Its expanding portfolio of high-technology and media companies remains a mish-mash that provided only about one-quarter of Vivendi's $2.28 billion in operating profit last year.
As a wireless operator, Vivendi remains largely limited to France, while companies like Vodafone AirTouch are rolling out pan-European networks. Canal Plus, though profitable in France, is losing money over all in order to finance expansion in other European countries. To be sure, the 43-year-old Mr. Messier has achieved remarkable results. A former investment banker who became chairman in 1996, he has engineered huge acquisitions in both the old and new sides of the business. Last year, Vivendi acquired US Filter, one of the biggest water-treatment companies in the United States, for $6.2 billion. It also acquired the industrial waste business of Waste Management Inc.
Mr. Messier has been on a relentless buying binge in media and telecommunications. Like other brash European business executives, Mr. Messier has financed part of his expansion with the cash thrown off by the old-line businesses. Vivendi was a founding investor in Cegetel, a consortium that included Vodafone and British Telecommunications, which in turn created France's second wireless telephone network as well as a small but growing fixed-line competitor to France Telecom.
Much like Chris Gent of Vodafone or Roberto Colaninno of Olivetti, Mr. Messier has increasingly used Vivendi's own stock or bonds convertible into Vivendi stock as his acquisition currency. In 1997, he used Vivendi convertible bonds to acquire Havas, a large publishing and advertising company. Last year, he used Vivendi stock to acquire a 15 percent stake in Canal Plus from Richemont S.A., raising Vivendi's existing stake to 49 percent. Also last year, Vivendi acquired Pathe, which owned many media properties.
In his quest to become a global media player, Mr. Messier seems bent on making Vivendi a distributor of media and entertainment rather than an operator of telecommunication networks. But Vivendi remains an off-again-on-again player in Europe's torrid market for wireless telephone services. By siding with Vodafone Airtouch in its hostile takeover of Mannesmann A.G., Mr. Messier cut a deal with Vodafone to acquire its stakes in Cegetel and SFR, the French wireless carrier. That gave Vivendi control of SFR. Mr. Messier and Vodafone now plan a multimedia portal that would provide customers access to wireless services, television entertainment and the Internet. In negotiations to acquire the Universal movie studio as well as Polygram record label through Seagram, Mr. Messier appears to be betting that his control over rights to music and movies will greatly strengthen his hand as a distributor in Europe.
"It will give them access to English-language content that they would not otherwise have," said one French analyst. It might also have a curious effect on French cultural policies, which are still geared to preserving French culture by limiting the influx of Hollywood movies.
Mr. Messier is also busy shoring up his balance sheet. He raised nearly $8 billion last year in stock and convertible bond offerings. In July, Vivendi hopes to raise as much as $4 billion more through a public offering of Vivendi Environment, which contains the water treatment, waste management and construction businesses. Vivendi will still own about 60 percent of Vivendi Environment, but company executives say the partial spinoff will make the company much easier to understand. Vivendi Environment will assume about $14 billion of the company's overall debt.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 426 words

HEADLINE: Korean Reconciliation

 BODY:
This week's first encounter between the leaders of North and South Korea did not end tensions in one of the most volatile corners of the world, but it did begin to overcome the enmity of a half-century. The Clinton administration rightly seeks to reinforce the gains by lifting many sanctions against Pyongyang. The North-South meetings unfolded in a surprisingly cordial atmosphere, and yesterday's joint declaration, though vaguely worded, contained just about all that could be realistically hoped for from this initial meeting. President Kim Dae Jung returns to South Korea with his stature enhanced. North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, shed some of his reputation for reclusiveness and mystery.
The agreement addresses the long-term issues of reconciliation and eventual reunification, and the more immediate matters of economic and cultural exchanges and reunions of families divided since the Korean War. South Korea also promised to consider handing over prisoners who have served out their sentences for spying for the North. Encouragingly, both leaders pledged to follow up this week's sessions with a reciprocal visit by Kim Jong Il to Seoul, at "the earliest appropriate moment." 
 South and North Korea have agreed on reconciliation plans twice before, in 1972 and 1991. Each time, the two countries soon fell back into hostility and confrontation. This week's understandings, which incorporate elements of those earlier efforts, could produce more tangible results. Unlike the previous agreements, these have been endorsed by the top political leaders of both countries and are accompanied by a series of practical first steps.
If these steps are carried out on schedule, it may be possible to address more difficult political and military issues. Some earlier indicators will be whether the family visits are accomplished this summer, how plans for Kim Jong Il's visit to Seoul proceed, and whether arrangements can be worked out for a joint Korean team in the World Cup soccer competition in 2002.
The two Korean leaders played down security issues, with no public mention of North Korea's demand for the withdrawal of the 37,000 American troops stationed in South Korea or of North Korea's suspended nuclear weapons and long-range missile programs. It is reasonable to put off such issues until greater trust has been established. But the border between the two Koreas remains the world's most militarized frontier. Reconciliation cannot advance very far without steps to address the North Korean threats that have made it so.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: THE KOREAN BREAKTHROUGH: THE OVERVIEW;
KOREAS REACH ACCORD SEEKING RECONCILIATION AFTER 50 YEARS

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, June 15

 BODY:
With surprising speed and warmth, the presidents of North and South Korea reached a broad agreement on Wednesday to work for peace and unity on their bitterly divided peninsula, the biggest step by either side to ease tensions in 50 years.
The agreement, which came after more than three hours of talks in the North Korea capital, Pyongyang, on the second day of their first summit meeting, was signed and toasted by President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea and President Kim Jong Il of the North, who were shown on South Korean television clinking champagne glasses, shaking hands vigorously and smiling broadly. 
 The agreement, while deliberately vague, had clearly left both men buoyant. If carried through, the accord would reduce the precarious isolation of the North and address many basic points that have long been seen as keys to ending the cold war on the heavily fortified peninsula, where the United States still maintains 37,000 troops.
The general points agreed on included the need for reconciliation and unification; the establishment of peace; the commencement in August of exchange visits by members of divided families; and more cultural exchanges. Text, Page A14.
In addition, it was agreed that Kim Jong Il would visit Seoul "at the earliest appropriate moment." The two sides also discussed the creation of offices in each other's capitals, and establishing a hot line between their leaders.
"At this very hour, the attention of the 70 million Korean people is drawn to Pyongyang, and the eyes of the entire world are riveted to this place," the South Korean president said in a banquet prior to the signing. "For the first time, the Korean people can see a bright future as a dawn of hope for reconciliation, cooperation and unification is breaking."
While the agreement provides no road map for the future and did not address pressing security issues, it left many people here hopeful that a decisive turn was shaping up in relations between two governments that have vilified each other for decades.
In addition, the emergence of the reclusive North Korean leader in the role of a jovial statesman was certain to challenge the image of North Korea as a "rogue state" so dangerous that Washington is proposing to spend billions of dollars on an antimissile system to defend against it.
"It is important to remember the symbolic importance of this meeting," said a diplomat. "Hopefully, things will continue to proceed from here, but this has already been an unexpected success."
If the agreements lacked the kind of fine detail that is often carefully worked out in important negotiations like these, they may have more than compensated for that by the strongly personal imprimatur placed on them by leaders whose repeated performances before the cameras left no doubts about their enthusiasm.
"In societies as hierarchical as Korea, that counts for a lot," said Leon V. Sigal, a North Korea expert at Columbia University. "In the North, having Kim Jong Il sign his name to a communique like this makes it the equivalent of dogma."
Perhaps the brightest moment of the day came at the toast shared by the two leaders at the signing ceremony, which took place at 11:20 p.m. on Wednesday and was broadcast in South Korea an hour later.
While the 75-year-old South Korean president paused between draughts as he tried to empty his glass, the younger Kim Jong Il, who has been characterized in the South as a heavy drinker, tilted his head back and finished his champagne in one go.
One of the meeting's most significant achievements was to help fill in a sketchy portrait of the 58-year-old Kim Jong Il, who has been caricatured outside his country as a crackpot and a playboy.
He was frequently on view again on Wednesday, for the second consecutive day, as he was shown talking with his southern counterpart in a relaxed and self-confident manner. He himself joked about his reputation as a recluse.
"Westerners seem to have been very anxious about why I live like a hermit," he said in an informal chat with Kim Dae Jung, moments before the two leaders went into a two-hour and 20-minute meeting. "And now, with your visit, they've got the answer."
Seeking to dispel this image, the North Korean leader said he had traveled overseas many times, naming two countries he had visited, China and Indonesia, but said that he had done so secretly.
Kim Dae Jung, who had smiled politely throughout this impromptu banter, set off laughter among the aides in the room from both sides when, referring to the reports about the North Korean leader, he replied, "You seem to know everything."
South Koreans, who paused from work throughout the day to watch the events on television, and were riveted to the their screens for the dramatic late night conclusion, expressed surprise about the warm and apparently relaxed atmosphere surrounding the talks, which began with the unexpected greeting of Kim Dae Jung by the northern president upon his arrival at the airport.
Many people said they were impressed by how normal and personable the mysterious northern leader was, after years of denigrating propaganda in the south.
"This will change the relationship between the two countries," said Park Han Sung, a clerk at an eyeglass shop in downtown Seoul.
"Maybe nothing dramatic will happen right away," he added, "but most people would agree that a surprising amount of progress and understanding has been achieved already."
In his reply to the South Korean leader's banquet toast, the second-ranking figure in North Korea, Kim Young Nam, said: "History gives us opportunities only once. Reunification is not for the future but for the present."
Western journalists, who were not invited to the North for the summit meeting, covered it via a special television link in Seoul and were told to expect a streamlined, four-point agreement. But the final text appeared to have hastily added other items, like language about a search for reconciliation and respect for each country's political system, both of which appeared to be included to appease the prickly North.
For Pyongyang, there was also little doubt that mention of increased exchanges in fact meant a boost in aid and investment from the South that northern leaders hope will prop up their failing economy. Famine in the North has claimed the lives of as many as two million people, according to the estimates of aid workers and outside experts.
The southern delegation rushed to leave little doubt of its willingness to help, on Wednesday offering to speed delivery of 200,000 tons of fertilizer, and also reportedly offering to provide $450 million in economic assistance.
For the South Korean leader, progress on reunion was a vital gauge of the success of the meeting. Seven million of his compatriots have relatives in the North.
"Many of the family members are passing away due to their advanced age," Mr. Kim said in a speech intended to give a clear sense of urgency to their agenda. "We have to attend to their life-long wishes."
While both sides clearly have direct interests in reconciliation and reaching a peace agreement to finally end the state of war that formally persists between them, those interests are also keenly shared by the United States, China, Japan and other countries.
Japan has only recently renewed diplomatic contacts with North Korea, after a breech caused by Pyongyang's test-firing of a ballistic missile over Japan in 1998.
Washington has long been engaged in painstaking negotiations with North Korea seeking an end to the country's missile program, as well as a commitment not to develop or deploy nuclear weapons. For American defense planners, the divided peninsula remains one the most dangerous spots on the planet and the North's weapons programs have been seen as so potentially threatening that Washington is considering spending billions of dollars on a missile defense system to counter them.
How events of this summit meeting will shape those perceptions remains to be seen, but the North Korean leader has cleverly succeeded in changing an image that has alternated from flake to a modern-day Dr. Strangelove.
By showing himself far more publicly than ever before in meetings with the country's historic arch-enemy, whose peace initiatives he accepted with little of the North's usual intractability, he may have powerfully affected the dynamics surrounding American proposals to build an expensive antimissile shield.
North Korea's missile program has been the leading justification in Washington for the unproven shield. But Pyongyang has already suspended testing of missiles for over a year at Washington's request, and Mr. Kim's detente with the South, if upheld, with further chip away at the regime's image as being dangerous and unpredictable.
Despite the good feeling of the last two days, leaders in Seoul and elsewhere are likely to remain wary of the North's promises.
"I think it's very important that they've met, it's very important that they've signed this agreement," Joe Lockhart, the White House spokesman, said in Washington. "But I think it's also very important that a process comes out of this summit that allows them to implement the important work they have agreed to in the last two days."
The South Korean president took a moment out to bluntly advise his North Korean counterpart, "It is important to improve your relations with the United States and Japan."
Over the last 20 years, the North and the South have held innumerable rounds of lower-level talks on issues like the reunion of families, and twice before such agreements have later come apart.
Most recently, in 1991, talks led to an agreement promoting peace and eventual reunification, but it was never put into practice, partly because of a dispute over the North's suspected development of nuclear weapons. And in the 1970's, Red Cross officials of both sides began talks that lasted 14 years on the reunification of families, bearing only meager results.
President Kim Dae Jung, who is expected to fly home later today around a border that separates over a million men under arms, often spoke with passion to his host in their second day of meetings.
In one statement he told his younger counterpart that, in the age of the Internet, competition between nations now rests on brain power and economic strength, and no longer so much on the weapons of old.
"To survive the fierce international competition, the North and South must be one," he said. "I would like to quote an old proverb: 'United, strength and mind wins over heaven.' When all Korean people join forces, there is nothing we cannot achieve."
