SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 3; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1764 words

HEADLINE: Theater for Fun or Profit;
Producers' Two Camps Remain Uneasy Allies

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
At a gathering of commercial theater producers and nonprofit theater executives at Princeton University in June 1974, Julian Beck of the experimental Living Theater emphatically called for the death of Broadway: "The alternative theater is a theater which has always been opposed to the Broadway theater. We want to destroy it. It is now being destroyed. It is in fact dying, and that is good."
Things have calmed down considerably in the last 26 years. Back then most nonprofit theaters were merely burgeoning artistic outposts; now many are formidable producing operations. Although the two worlds used to regard each other with suspicion and even disdain -- some of which still lingers -- commercial and nonprofit producers have increasingly become partners. The commercial side looks to the nonprofit for new material and chances to test costly projects; the nonprofit looks to the commercial to shoulder some expenses of ambitious productions and to help give shows longer lives on larger stages. 
 "You cannot afford the luxury any longer of thinking of two distinct isolated worlds of theater," said Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization, New York's most powerful theater owner. "Economics have been the driving force between profit and nonprofit, or taxpaying and nontaxpaying, as I call it."
But although the two spheres have been collaborating more and more, disputes still rankle. Some Broadway producers, for example, resent New York's large nonprofits for reaping the benefits of producing shows on Broadway without the risk that comes with raising money from people who expect a return. The nonprofit Lincoln Center Theater, for example, has been criticized for being eligible for coveted Tony Awards -- like this year's best-musical prize for "Contact" -- without having the burden of repaying investors. Some nonprofit executives resent commercial producers for taking their work while cutting them out of the process and sometimes out of the financial rewards.
As a result questions remain: When projects are jointly developed, who has artistic control? Are nonprofits becoming too much like their commercial counterparts and abandoning a commitment to daring work? Has the commercial theater become overly dependent on the nonprofits for ideas it should be developing itself? (All of the American dramas nominated this year in the Tony Awards' best new play category originated in the nonprofit world, along with all three American productions competing for best revival of a play and two of the four best-musical nominees. And since 1976, with the exception of Neil Simon's "Lost in Yonkers" in 1991, every Pulitzer Prize winner for best play has been developed in a nonprofit theater.)
To tackle some of these sensitive issues, the two camps are coming together again, this time at Harvard University for a weekendlong conference that begins tomorrow. The conference, called Act Two, the Second American Congress of Theater, was organized by the League of American Theaters and Producers, which represents commercial producers, and the Theater Communications Group, which has 360 nonprofit members.
Among the country's estimated 1,100 nonprofits, most have annual budgets under $500,000. In New York they range from the Roundabout Theater Company, which has a budget of about $20 million and produces plays like the current "Uncle Vanya," to the Collapsible Giraffe, with a budget of about $25,000, which combines video and theater in new productions like its recent "Three Virgins," performed in a Times Square strip club. Conference participants will include a range of theater professionals -- artistic directors of regional theaters, Broadway producers, a few playwrights and actors -- as well as government officials.
Even though most of the conference will be closed to the press and the public to encourage candid discussion, there is some question about how frank participants will be about their real concerns. In an effort to spur some frank discussion, the Broadway producer Rocco Landesman -- writing in the June 4 Arts & Leisure section of The New York Times -- accused nonprofit theaters of modeling themselves after "the commercial arena, which is, in the end, not dedicated to the art so much as to the audience." In particular, Mr. Landesman, president of Jujamcyn Theaters, which owns several Broadway houses, criticized the Roundabout's artistic director, Todd Haimes, for playing it safe with audience-pleasing work and for selling the name of his new theater to a corporation; it will now be the American Airlines Theater.
"It would, I suppose, be hyperbolic to say that Todd Haimes has had a more pernicious influence on English-speaking theater than anyone since Oliver Cromwell (and it wouldn't be nice, either, since Mr. Haimes is a personable and honorable man)," Mr. Landesman wrote, "but it can be reasonably argued that the forces of the marketplace through the years have been just as effective a censor as government edicts."
In an interview, Mr. Haimes called Mr. Landesman's assertions "absolutely ridiculous," as did several other nonprofit executives. While some nonprofit theaters with large groups of loyal subscribers have to worry about pleasing big audiences, Mr. Haimes said, most of them continue to concern themselves primarily with producing a body of work they can be proud of, not looking for the next commercial score.
"Ultimately they just don't want any more competition," Mr. Haimes said of producers like Mr. Landesman. "They should spend more energy focusing on doing plays."
As for agreeing to name the renovated Selwyn Theater on West 42nd Street in Manhattan for an airline sponsor, Mr. Haimes, whose company is known for producing revivals and musicals that appeal to a broad subscriber base, said: "I have absolutely no reservations about it. If they want to put their name on our theater and give us money and give us artistic control, I think it's a wonderful thing."
Roche Schulfer, the executive director of the Goodman Theater in Chicago, which originated the current New York production of "A Moon for the Misbegotten" and helped move it to Broadway, said he bristled when Broadway producers like Mr. Landesman accused nonprofits of selling out.
"Yes, we did 'A Moon for the Misbegotten,' " Mr. Schulfer said, speaking of the revered O'Neill play that has become one of the season's hits. "But there are 10 other things we did this year. I don't know how familiar he is with any of them."
"We work together with commercial producers when something is in line with our artistic priorities," he added. "We do business when our goals intersect."
Still, Mr. Schoenfeld of the Shubert Organization said the lines between the two camps had been blurred, often beyond recognition. "The larger nonprofit institutions are really replications of Broadway," he said. "Some are just booking houses for Broadway shows."
Aside from debating the role of the nonprofits, theater professionals say they hope the conference will address several other issues. With commercial producing now so costly, for example -- Broadway plays can run $1 million to $2 million, musicals as much as $12 million -- the traditional out-of-town tryout has become too expensive in most cases. Workshops, on the other hand -- rough versions of shows performed before invited guests -- are not considered a realistic gauge of a show's prospects because they lack critics and a paying audience.
As a result producers have started to use regional theaters as places to mount what are essentially workshop versions of their productions. These days "almost no commercial plays start on Broadway or even off Broadway," said Thomas Viertel, a Broadway producer. "They were developed someplace else. Economically it's safer to do it that way. Till you get something up in front of an audience, there's no way to know what works and what doesn't."
Too much of this, some warn, is not a good thing. "You don't want to be perceived as a laboratory for every commercial producer that comes along," said John Breglio, an entertainment lawyer and president of the Theater Development Fund, which runs the TKTS discount-ticket booths and several theater support programs.
Increasingly nonprofits do not want simply to hand over their productions to commercial producers. As their shows move to the commercial realm, some nonprofits will settle for a financial percentage; others want to move with the show as co-producers. The role of the nonprofit was dramatically redefined by Joseph Papp, who moved the Public Theater's "Chorus Line" to Broadway on his own in 1975, holding onto 100 percent of the production.
Now the relationships between commercial and nonprofit producers take many different forms. This season Claudia Shear's "Dirty Blonde" started at the nonprofit Vineyard Theater on Martha's Vineyard in Massachusetts in a production financed by the Shuberts. Then it was produced at the nonprofit New York Theater Workshop with backing from the Shuberts, who finally moved it to Broadway with several other commercial producers, all of whom shared the cost equally.
The nonprofit Manhattan Theater Club plans to move "The Tale of the Allergist's Wife," which received strong notices earlier this season, to Broadway in the fall with commercial producing partners.
In the case of the Joseph Papp Public Theater's version of "The Wild Party," commercial producers shared the cost of producing that new musical, although the Public retained creative control. This became a source of tension when the commercial producers wanted to close the struggling show, but the Public decided to keep it open until the Tony Awards. It was shut out of the awards and closed on Sunday at a loss of $5.5 million.
Mr. Breglio, the lawyer, said it was important for commercial producers who back a nonprofit's production to respect the originating theater's decision-making. "If a nonprofit is going to put its resources at risk, it has to maintain control," he said. "It's, financially speaking, too dangerous to permit outside commercial forces to dictate how the money is to be spent."
Theater professionals say they hope the conference also deals with the question of how to develop talent and commission new work to maintain the flow of productions. With theater so economically forbidding, that challenge has become particularly daunting.
"The question of how we nurture the talent that we ultimately all depend on is an area none of us is paying much systemic attention to," Mr. Viertel said.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1198 words

HEADLINE: The Road to Reviving a Reputation;
Cendant Chief Tries to Recover From a Deal Gone Very Bad

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
Ever since the Cendant Corporation announced in April 1998 the "accounting irregularities" that would decimate its stock, Henry R. Silverman has been on a crusade to restore his reputation.
As the deal maker who built HFS Inc., a huge franchiser of brands like Century 21, Ramada, Days Inns and Avis, Mr. Silverman was responsible for the merger with CUC International that created Cendant. So with the announcement, just months after he became chief executive of the combined company, it was not only a tremendous blow to Cendant's stock that suffered a tremendous blow. So did Mr. Silverman's standing as a pillar of the business world. 
 Over the last two years, Mr. Silverman has taken a personal, as well as professional, interest in clearing his name. After embarking on a strenuous internal investigation, Mr. Silverman has cooperated extensively with regulators and been pointed in his contention that blame for this fraud lies elsewhere.
"His reputation is very precious to him, and he wanted to clean it," said Frederick Kobrick, a Boston money manager who has invested in Cendant.
This effort has pitted Mr. Silverman's credibility against that of Walter A. Forbes, the man who once headed CUC International. Mr. Forbes, who was originally positioned to run the combined company with Mr. Silverman but who resigned from Cendant in July 1998, has previously denied any knowledge of the accounting irregularities. Yesterday, his lawyer would not comment.
Yesterday's events, in which three former senior managers pleaded guilty to criminal charges of fraud and the Securities and Exchange Commission brought charges against seven former managers, goes a long way in providing a measure of vindication for Mr. Silverman. The regulators contended that senior managers at CUC were responsible for falsifying earnings over more than a decade in a fraud that artificially lifted earnings by more than $500 million in its last three years.
The announcement "does definitely restore a large degree of Henry's excellent reputation as a builder of companies and shareholder value," said James Citrin,, an executive recruiter with SpencerStuart. "It also justifies the aggressive stance that he took in dealing with it."
But analysts agree that Mr. Silverman's quest to restore his credibility and rebuild Cendant is not over. The accounting fraud that resulted from the merger with CUC "will be the epitaph to Silverman's career," said Patrick McGurn, director of corporate programs for Institutional Shareholder Services, a company based in Rockville, Md., that advises large investors on proxy issues.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Silverman was quick to dismiss any suggestion that he might have -- or should have -- known about the fraud when the 1997 merger took place. "I'm down $800 million," he said. "I don't think the height of personal financial masochism could reach that level."
"This is very painful," he added, "personally, professionally and financially."
The outline presented by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the fraud seems to dispel any notion that Mr. Silverman or other HFS managers were involved. "It enhances credibility," said Michael Millman, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. "It makes him a more sympathetic actor in this sordid play."
Investors may be more likely to buy shares in the company now that the taint from the current management team has been removed, he said.
Some Cendant investors may benefit from the company's pending $2.85 billion settlement of a shareholder class-action suit. Last December, Cendant also received a vote of confidence from John C. Malone and Liberty Media, which invested $400 million.
The S.E.C. painted a dark portrait of a concerted effort by CUC senior managers -- including the former chief financial officer, who said he was acting at the direction of his superiors -- to falsify earnings.
"For more than 12 years, until its exposure in 1998, certain members of CUC's senior and middle management devised and operated a systemic, systematic scheme to inflate operating income at CUC. The scheme was driven by senior management's determination that CUC would always meet earnings expectations of Wall Street analysts and fueled by a disregard for any obligation that the earnings reported needed to be 'real,' " the regulators said.
By contrast, the regulators praised Cendant's management for its response to the discovery of accounting problems at CUC: "Cendant management promptly reported the discovery of the fraud and its attendant accounting irregularities to the commission staff; conducted a thorough internal investigation and compiled an extensive report," the regulators said, adding that they also "cooperated with staff in its investigation of this matter."
What is still subject to debate is whether Mr. Silverman should have known that CUC, the subject of lengthy accounting travails, might be a problematic purchase. "For an executive who has built fame and fortune as a savvy deal maker," Mr. McGurn, the proxy adviser, said, "to be snookered by fraudsters does beg the question of how good the due diligence was."
Still, argued Mr. Kobrick, the money manager, any such deliberate fraud would be practically impossible to detect. Regulators also acknowledged that if one co-conspirator had not come forward the extent of the fraud might not have been discovered for a long time.
But Mr. Silverman's efforts to vindicate himself are clearly not over. Cendant is trying to force Mr. Forbes to return his $47 million severance package, the subject of legal proceedings. Earlier this month, Mr. Forbes paid back $2.3 million in travel and entertainment expenses, which Cendant had disputed. "We intend to pursue that to a conclusion," a Cendant spokesman said.
Mr. Silverman would not address the issue of whether he feels personally betrayed by Mr. Forbes. "I think the court will be the instrument of retribution," he said.
The company has also brought suit against Ernst & Young, which Mr. Silverman has publicly argued neglected its responsibilities to uncover the fraud in its long history of auditing CUC. Ernst & Young is also suing Cendant, arguing that its management misled them.
All of this leaves Mr. Silverman with the continued task of rebuilding Cendant. The stock, which has been hurt in recent months by concerns about the economy and a slowing housing market, closed yesterday at $12.4375, still a far cry from its high of $41.69 just before the disclosure.
Mr. Silverman has put Cendant through a wringer, shedding $4.5 billion of businesses not related to its central operations. "It's clearly been a distraction for him and the company," said Greg Zappin, an analyst at Standard & Poor's. "It's caused them to radically change the business plans. The company's been in a holding pattern ever since."
Mr. Kobrick, for one, said he thought yesterday's events provided a kind of coda to the story of the last two years. "He's going to be the most focused guy in the world," he said.
As for his own view, Mr. Silverman acknowledged the need to move on. "We need closure," he said. "This is the beginning of the end of closure."

SECTION: Section E; PT1; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 935 words

HEADLINE: No Fluff, No Gimmickry In These Searing Stories

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
In discussions of popular culture nowadays, few words are more crassly degraded than reality, as in the ''reality programming'' that is a hot new television trend. The misapplication of the word to categorize gimmicky televised pseudo-events is all the more distressing when such sensationalist fluff is compared with the best documentary and fiction films to be seen each year at the Human Rights Watch Film Festival. This reality is the genuine article.
 The vital annual series, which opened on Wednesday at the Walter Reade Theater with Randa Chahal Sabbag's documentary about Lebanon, ''A Civilized People,'' is probably the best New York showcase for films exploring political, social and economic issues that cannot be neatly summarized in 15-minute segments. And in a gossip- and celebrity-saturated media climate that increasingly ignores the world beyond our borders, the festival offers intimate, often painful glimpses into other cultures that no other information source could provide. 
 Human rights issues, of course, concern the United States as well as the rest of the world. One of the most powerful films to be shown in the festival, Laurie Collyer's documentary ''Nuyorican Dream'' (next Friday at 6:15 p.m. and June 26 at 8:30 p.m.), is set mostly within the city limits of New York. Seven years in the making, this astoundingly intimate film is a close-up, at-home portrait of a troubled Puerto Rican family in the Bronx. Their troubles are viewed through the compassionate and loving eyes of Robert Torres, the only family member to have graduated from college.
 Mr. Torres, a 30-year-old New York City schoolteacher, is the eldest son of Marta Gutierrez, a courageous mother to whom falls the almost impossible task of holding together three generations of her family with few resources. Throughout the movie, Mr. Torres offers pointed observations about how a legacy of colonialism, an inadequate inner-city educational system and ingrained prejudice that keeps Puerto Ricans out of fast-track classes and diminishes their already low self-esteem combine to perpetuate a cycle of poverty, drugs and hopelessness.
 In addition to the mother and son, we meet two of Mr. Torres's sisters, who are battling drug addiction, and a younger brother who is in prison. What gives the film an extra edge is that Mr. Torres, who is gay, is clearly alienated from his loved ones by his middle-class status. The dual perspective he offers, of someone who belongs to the family yet sees beyond its insular world, lends the film a wrenching authenticity. As much knowledge and wisdom as Mr. Torres has gained, he is essentially powerless against the social forces that have oppressed his family and thousands like them. ''Nuyorican Dream'' strikes an even deeper emotional chord than ''An American Love Story,'' the much-publicized multipart documentary about an interracial marriage that was shown last year on PBS.
 A perfect example of an international story that could be done justice only by a documentary film is Kevin McKiernan's video movie ''Good Kurds, Bad Kurds: No Friends but the Mountains'' (June 24 at 1 p.m., June 28 at 6 p.m. and June 29 at 1 p.m.). The film is, among many other things, a concise history of a people Mr. McKiernan calls ''the Native Americans of Asia Minor.''
 The ''good Kurds'' in the eyes of the United States are those who live in Iraq and are persecuted by Saddam Hussein. The ''bad'' are those fighting a guerrilla war against the government in Turkey (an American ally), where they make up 20 percent of the population. The movie delves deep into the history and politics of Kurdistan region while analyzing the seemingly contradictory policy of the United States and criticizing Turkey for human rights violations.
 Also notable on the international front are Marco Bechlis's ''Garage Olimpo'' (next Friday at 9:15 p.m., June 25 at 8:45 p.m. and June 26 at 3:15 p.m.) a not-for-the-squeamish film from Argentina about an opponent of the military dictatorship who is tortured in a garage in the heart of Buenos Aires, and ''Pathos'' (tomorrow at 6:30 p.m., Sunday at 8:15 p.m. and Monday at 3:45 p.m.), a drama by the Indian director Jayaraaj about aging parents whose grown children sell the family plantation out from under them and blithely ship them off to an old-age home. The touching Lebanese video documentary ''Children of Shatila,'' directed by Mai Masri, looks at the impoverished lives of two Palestinian children, 11 and 13, growing up in a refugee camp in Lebanon (June 26 at 6 p.m., June 28 at 8:45 p.m. and June 29 at 3:30 p.m.).
 A high point of the festival is a rare showing (tonight at 9:15 and tomorrow night at 9) of Martin Ritt's black-and-white drama ''Edge of the City,'' a movie so atmospherically gritty it has dirt under its fingernails. Released in 1957, three years after ''On the Waterfront'' (an obvious prototype), ''Edge of the City'' is a portrait of an interracial friendship and social prejudice on the job. John Cassavetes plays Axel, a drifter with a guilty secret, and Sidney Poitier is his best friend, Tommy, a cocky, free-spirited fellow porter at the West Side Terminal. Jack Warden is their corrupt, bullying boss. As Tommy, Mr. Poitier is nothing less than incandescent, effusing a volatile mixture of devil-may-care humor and infectious joie de vivre.
 The Human Rights Watch Film Festival continues through June 29 at the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center. Admission: $9; members, $5; senior citizens, $4.50 at weekday matinees. Information and screening times: (212) 875-5600 or www.filmlinc.com.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 893 words

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology;
A Hybrid With Brains and Brawn

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
HYBRID-POWER vehicles, the engineers point out, can come in all shapes and sizes. The first two on the market are the two-passenger Honda Insight and the five-passenger Toyota Prius.
They are notable for using electric motors to achieve remarkable gasoline fuel economy. And they look like hybrids: eggy, sleek and futuristic. 
 But DaimlerChrysler is demonstrating another tack entirely.
Call it the red-meat hybrid, an S.U.V. as brawny as a pure gasoline version, in exactly the same body, with the same tough-looking wheels and grille, and four-wheel drive. But this Dodge Durango is modified to get 30 percent of its horsepower through an electric motor instead of from the gasoline engine. As with the Japanese entries, the result is better fuel economy. The improvement is just three miles per gallon, but on a big sport utility like the Durango, that is a full 20 percent.
DaimlerChrysler showed the truck here recently at the conclusion of the American Tour de Sol, an annual electric-car race.
An early fan was Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, who is chairman of the Energy Committee. "Feels like a normal car," he said.
In contrast to the Insight, a two-seater that gets about 70 miles per gallon but owes part of that to its sleek form and aluminum frame, or the Prius, which has a slightly boxy appearance, the hybrid Durango prototype is indistinguishable from the gasoline version -- unless you spot the "state of charge" meter on the dashboard, or crawl under the front to see the 70-horsepower electric motor, mounted sideways, that drives the front wheels.
"This is the soccer mom car," Senator Murkowski said.
It is also, by far, the simplest of the three. The Insight has an electric motor sandwiched into the drivetrain between the gasoline engine and the manual transmission. The Prius has a planetary gear, a specially developed device that means that at any given moment, the electric motor can be working alone, or assisting the gasoline engine, or draining energy from the gasoline engine to recharge the battery.
The Durango is far simpler; an ordinary V-6 gasoline engine in the front drives ordinary wheels in the back, and the electric motor under the front of the car turns the front wheels; the only connection between the two drivetrains is the pavement. When the driver pushes the brake pedal, the electric motor switches into a generator, robbing the car of momentum and converting that into current to recharge the batteries.
If the batteries are depleted as the car cruises, the motor in front will start letting the wheels drag a little and recharge the batteries, using the pavement to transfer energy from the gasoline system to the electric one.
"This is a leap in technology that can get you an instant improvement," said William Craven, a project-management specialist who works on the Durango and the Epic, the company's all-electric minivan.

 His competitor, David W. Hermance, an executive engineer at Toyota, whose car and its unusual gearing system is perhaps more of a leap, put it differently.
In a telephone interview, he said: "There are three attributes you're trading off -- emissions, fuel economy and acceleration, or performance. You decide what it is you want your vehicle to do in those three attributes, and then you size your internal-combustion engine and your motor so as to get the combination you're interested in."
To get acceleration, Mr. Hermance said, use a larger gasoline engine; to get better fuel economy and pollution control, favor the electric side.
The Toyota relies on the electric motor alone when it is moving slowly, and the Honda makes heavy use of the electric motor every time the driver shifts to a higher gear; both shut off the gasoline engine entirely when the car is waiting at a stop sign or red light.
Both of them were designed as hybrids, from the ground up. And both, but especially the Honda, gain performance by shedding weight. Their performance is good but nothing special.
In contrast, the Durango weighs the same in the hybrid version, and performs about the same -- that is to say, like a hard-charging bull. It has a slightly lower towing rating than the all-gasoline version of the Durango. The Prius and Insight, on the other hand, are unlikely candidates to tow anything.
Chrysler said that teaming the 3.9 liter V-6 with a Siemens 3-phase AC induction motor gave "V-8 performance with better than V-6 fuel economy."
 In the parlance of this emerging technology, the Durango is a "mild hybrid," and the Insight and Prius are "heavy hybrids."
There are other differences. The Prius and Insight have no direct cost comparisons, since they are not new versions of an all-gasoline car, but both appear to sell at a modest premium above what a conventional gasoline car that size would cost.
American manufacturers suggest that Toyota and Honda are actually taking considerable losses on each of the cars sold, something that DaimlerChrysler does not seem willing to do.
DaimlerChrysler says each hybrid Durango would cost $3,000 extra to make; it is lobbying for special tax credits.
The Japanese entries are on the road now. The population of hybrid Durangos is one lonely preproduction prototype. If the Chrysler division decided now to produce it, the hybrid would go on sale in about three years.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 31; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1427 words

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Finding Endless Conflict Hidden in a Peaceable Kingdom

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

DATELINE: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., June 12

 BODY:
Some artists zero in on a single image and can't or won't let go. It's as if everything they really need to say is sayable there. The American painter Edward Hicks (1780-1849) was one. The Peaceable Kingdom was his theme.
All 62 surviving versions of his subject share a basic image: a kind of petting-zoo cluster of animals around a child in a parklike woodland. The tableau, often taken for an uncomplicated emblem of the Eden that America once was, has made Hicks a folk classic and also an artist that one can overlook. We know what he's about. 
 But are Hicks's kingdom paintings really identical? And are they unruffled idylls of innocence and peace? An exhibition titled "The Kingdoms of Edward Hicks" at the New York State Historical Association in Cooperstown, N.Y., which includes 20 such paintings, says no to both questions and reclaims his icon work for the difficult, prickly thing it is.
Organized by Carolyn J. Weekley for the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Folk Art Center of Colonial Williamsburg and slightly edited here (a painting referred to in a wall text isn't on view), the show is built around the quietly intense drama of Hicks's life.
He was born in rural eastern Pennsylvania. His grandfather, a wealthy Tory, had been stripped of his property in the Revolution. His mother died when he was an infant, and his father, unable to support the children, boarded them out. From the age of 3, Hicks lived with a Quaker family named Twining. He loved them and idolized one Twining daughter, Mary, calling her his closest friend. This time was as near to a state of earthly grace as he ever got.
At 13, he was apprenticed to a local coach-making firm and showed a flair for ornamental painting: heraldic devices, fancy lettering and so on. He also fell into a pattern of drinking and carousing that spun out of control by his own account. Then he found or rediscovered religion. Around 1800 he began to attend meetings of the Religious Society of Friends and never stopped.
Hicks was as impractical as he was devout. In 1811 he both became an unsalaried Quaker minister and opened a carriage-and-sign painting shop. Because the ministry required frequent travel from home (he was married with children by this time), the business had to fend for itself.
There were other conflicts. The painting Hicks specialized in was censured by Quakers. His expertly decorated signs and objects, of which there are examples in the show, were viewed as vain, luxurious, un-Friendly things. He tried to restrict himself to a no-frills style, then sold the business to become a farmer, with calamitous economic results.
His problems were compounded by his high-strung, fractious personality. He was given to bursts of fury and fits of sobbing, and he was damagingly candid in his opinions, particularly on matters related to the religious community.
And finally, he lived at a turbulent time, when the Society of Friends had a devastating internal rift. On one side was the orthodox faction, largely urban and prosperous and promoting a rational religious hierarchy and reformist causes like abolition.
On the other side was a conservative, primarily rural faction, with which Hicks was fiercely aligned. It advocated an older version of the religion based on individual revelation. This group, called Hicksite, gathered around the charismatic minister Elias Hicks, the artist's older cousin.
What followed was a bitter doctrinal and psychic war that radically shaped Hicks's art. After his farming misadventure, he resumed his career as an artisan but also began to do easel paintings on the Peaceable Kingdom theme, at first perhaps as a way to give what he self-rebukingly called his "excessive fondness for painting" an acceptable moral dimension.
His earliest known version of the subject, crudely executed, was adapted from a Bible print illustrating a passage from Isaiah about a millennial vision in which natural enemies are reconciled: "The wolf shall also dwell with the lamb, and the leopard shall lie down with the kid; and the calf and the young lion and the fatling together; and a little child shall lead them."
Hicks continued doing other work -- shop signs, landscapes, historical scenes -- on commission. But the kingdoms were special. He painted them repeatedly and obsessively, for himself, or as gifts. They become more complex in style, combining the vivacity of popular art with surprising academic finesse, and they grew more pointed in content.
The first series, starting in the early 1820's, incorporated a secondary background vignette of the 17th-century Quaker William Penn arranging a treaty of peace with American Indians. These paintings, fitted with hand-lettered frames carrying the Isaiah quotation, already addressed growing dissension within the membership.
After the great schism of 1827, the images become more volatile. In an overtly propagandistic group, Penn's treaty is replaced by a ghostly troop of historic Quaker elders, Penn among them, greeting Elias Hicks. And in the next decade, when the paintings become both deeply expressive and wildly uneven in quality, the foreground changes.
Additional children and animals crowd in. The carnivorous beasts -- lions, leopards, wolves -- grow in size. Where once they had cast their eyes docilely to the ground, they now stare out, alert, aggressive, challenging, even rabidly agitated.
Hicks meant the beasts to typify human traits in line with his view of contemporary Quaker politics: the lion symbolized power gained through wealth, the leopard a suave, threatening worldliness. Occasionally animals are in conflict. But even when they aren't, the assemblies have a jumbled, restive feeling. The ground beneath them is eroding; a fissure in the earth separates them from Penn's treaty behind.
Then, around 1840, the mood shifts again. The artist was in his 60's. He saw that the ideological battle he had anguished over would remain unresolved. The exhibition catalog points out that the animals start to look aged and weary, and it's true. In one painting, the lion's face bears a startling resemblance to that of Hicks in a portrait by his nephew, Thomas, where he poses with an unfinished kingdom on his easel.
He produced these images to the end of his life; he was preparing one for his daughter when he died. But he also turned to other subjects. From 1846 comes "James Cornell's Prize Bull." A modest-size commissioned portrait of a heroic farm animal, it clearly demonstrates Hicks's highly developed naturalistic style.
That he seldom chose to use it may be significant. His plainer, colloquial approach was closer to a Quaker aesthetic. And maybe he thought it was more appropriate for depicting what he felt most in sympathy with, a world that wasn't quite this world and that operated by its own pictorial laws.
He combined both modes in late landscapes that departed from the allegorical kingdom image while sustaining its programmatic ideal. Two examples in the show are nostalgic memory paintings of the Twining farm of his childhood, in which Hicks includes himself as an apple-cheeked toddler. Another is a commissioned picture of a farm owned by the son of Mary Twining, his childhood friend.
Titled "A May Morning View of the Farm and Stock of David Leedom" (1849), the scene falls into two horizontal bands. The bottom one is the farm. Its animals, masterfully rendered, stand in an enclosed yard. Piero della Francesca would have approved of the pristine geometry of the buildings.
At the paddock fence stand small figures who gesture conversationally among themselves. An inscription at the lower edge of the painting, scratched into the painted grass, identifies them as David Leedom, his wife and family, and Mary Twining and her husband, who were dead by that time.
A blossoming apple orchard stretches behind the farm. And behind that hills fade into mist: they seem to have been done with a dabbed sponge, a technique familiar from pottery decoration. Above everything, and taking up half the painting, is one of the prettiest skies in American art: soft pink, unostentatious gold, summery blue. It's the perfect cap to one man's peaceable kingdom come at last, part heaven, part earth, where plain beauty reigns, and reason and revelation meet.
 
"The Kingdoms of Edward Hicks" is at the New York State Historical Association/Fenimore Art Museum, Lake Road, Route 80, Cooperstown, N.Y., (607) 547-1400, through Sept. 4. It travels to the M. H. de Young Museum in San Francisco from Sept. 24-Jan. 7.
